notes.text: Dobbins is extremely talented, there's no doubting that. However, if you think he's a breakout candidate to finish as a top-five running back, you're betting against the odds. Among the running backs who finished top-10 last year, just two of them finished there while seeing fewer than 39 targets. Those two running backs were Derrick Henry and Nick Chubb, who averaged 5.4 and 5.6 yards per carry, numbers no one can actually project to hit. They also scored 17 and 12 touchdowns on the ground, propping their numbers up. Dobbins saw just 24 targets last year, a number that's unlikely to move much considering he's in the same offense with the same quarterback, only with more weapons around him. If Dobbins can rush for over 5.0 yards per carry (he did last year) and score double-digit rushing touchdowns (again, hard to project), he's going to finish as a top-10 running back, but not top-five due to the lack of work in the passing game. He's best-suited as your RB2 who has RB1 in his range of outcomes.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: J.K. Dobbins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Dobbins was a fantasy force in the second half last year if you had the patience to wade through Mark Ingram szn. From Weeks 11 to 17, Dobbins was the RB8 averaging 16.7 fantasy points per game. His nine TDs are the most ever by a rookie RB with fewer than 140 carries. That is a ridiculously high TD rate and causes you to question: did he show double-digit TD ability or is there regression coming? From the eye test, the dude looks like belongs on the field finishing top-10 in PFF’s Elusive Rating. However, the backfield split may continue to be a thorn in the side of those rostering Dobbins.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Nine percent of Dobbins’ rush attempts were 15+ Yards, the highest in the NFL. The TD rate might come down but the explosive runs were always part of his profile coming into the league. Think of Dobbins like rookie Nick Chubb, a ridiculously efficient runner on a team committed to running the ball. That could be a top-10 dynasty RB for the next couple of years.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Jaylen Waddle, DeVante Parker, Will Fuller V, Albert Wilson, Preston Williams

notes.text: Reunited and it feels so good? Maybe. Waddle will be playing with his college quarterback, Tua Tagovailoa. That certainly helps project him for a quick start to his career, as does the absence of Will Fuller in Week 1 as he serves the remainder of his suspension. Tagovailoa talked about his pass catchers not gaining separation last year, but that shouldn't be an issue with Waddle. Even when Fuller joins the lineup, it might not be a bad thing for Waddle, as he should slide into the slot where he'll be matched up with nickel cornerbacks and safeties. Waddle might be someone who produces quicker than most rookies due to his familiarity with his quarterback.

Waddle suffered an ankle fracture-dislocation during his final season at Alabama in October of 2020. This injury forced him to miss the rest of the regular season, the SEC championship and the first game of the College Football Playoff. Remarkably, Waddle was able to suit up for the National Championship game but was nowhere close to 100%. Now 7+ months out from surgery, look for Waddle to regain full explosiveness and ability to cut as the summer progresses with him entering Week 1 at or close to full strength.

Waddle was the 6th overall pick in the NFL Draft. He reunites with his college QB, but DeVante Parker, Mike Gesicki, and now Will Fuller are on this roster, and it’s very likely Waddle is 4th in the pecking order in his rookie season in terms of target share. He’ll have some splash plays, but it doesn’t look like he’s a guy you can trust in his rookie season despite his insane athleticism and speed.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jaylen Waddle
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Waddle was the 6th overall pick in the NFL Draft. He reunites with his college QB, but DeVante Parker, Mike Gesicki, and now Will Fuller are on this roster, and it’s very likely Waddle is 4th in the pecking order in his rookie season in terms of target share. He’ll have some splash plays, but it doesn’t look like he’s a guy you can trust in his rookie season despite his insane athleticism and speed.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Waddle projects as a high upside dynasty option given his NFL Draft capital, but he dealt with a significant injury in college, and we never got to see just how good he can be. Assuming Will Fuller is gone next year, Waddle could see an uptick in dynasty value while playing with his college QB.

notes.text: This is funny because I was always the guy saying that Parker was undervalued, and he was, but we've reached the point where I'm abandoning that ship. Last year, he played in eight games with Tua Tagovailoa, and in those games, he averaged 7.1 targets, 3.6 receptions, 43.1 yards, and 0.25 touchdowns. That's... not great. And now you add Will Fuller and Jaylen Waddle to the offense? Parker is the "big body" wide receiver of the bunch, but he's never been a touchdown scorer, finishing with more than four touchdowns just once in his six-year career. His ADP is way too high.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: DeVante Parker
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Parker didn’t have much competition for targets last year in Miami, especially after Preston Williams went down with injury but now the Dolphins have 1st round talent, Jaylen Waddle, and the prolific Will Fuller on the roster. Parker’s fantasy success will rely heavily on whether or not Tua can take a step forward in his second season, as this offense doesn’t look like it’ll be the one that can support three fantasy viable wide receivers. Remember, Parker’s breakout 2019 season and best fantasy games last year came with Fitzmagic under center.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The WR depth chart looks crowded right now given that Will Fuller is in town, but the Flying V is only on a one-year deal, and if he moves on, Parker and Waddle could be this team’s WR core for the next couple of seasons. He’s 28 and under contract with Miami until 2023. If Tua turns out to be the real deal, Parker could provide sneaky WR3/Flex value for 2+ seasons.

notes.text: Not only will Fuller finish up his suspension and miss Week 1 this year, but he'll also be returning to the field with a new quarterback, and let's just say that life without Deshaun Watson hasn't been kind to him. In 20 games with non-Watson quarterbacks, Fuller has averaged 6.0 targets, 3.1 receptions, 38.7 yards, and 0.10 touchdowns, which is a far cry from his 6.5 targets, 4.5 receptions, 70.6 yards, and 0.67 touchdowns per game with Watson under center. Can Tua Tagovailoa take a step forward in his career in 2021? Sure, but he's not going to be Watson, and there are suddenly tons of options for him to throw to, which means Fuller is going to have to fight for his target share. There's more risk than you'd like with Fuller, who's also had his fair share of injuries throughout his career. Getting him as a WR4 would be ideal, as you aren't relying on him for production week-in and week-out.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: William Fuller V
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Flying V's landing spot in Miami has Fuller enthusiasts up in arms after he pieced together a great first half of the 2020 season. Normally missing time due to injury, it was a PED suspension that caused him to miss the final five games of 2020 and the first game of the 2021 season coming up. Nevertheless, he’s always worth rostering despite the risk. The fact is when he’s on the field, he’s a difference maker for fantasy as he led the league in yards per target in 2020.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Will Fuller is playing on a one-year deal in Miami in 2021 but he’ll look to prove the doubters wrong and stay healthy for a full season...without PEDs. Given that he’s in a contract year, the long term outlook for Fuller is uncertain, but if he puts together a strong 2021, he’ll get paid in the offseason to likely serve as a team’s WR2.

notes.text: Williams has shown his talent when he has been on the field, but health - or a lack thereof - has limited him to just 16 games in his two-year career. He underwent surgery on his foot in November and even if he returns to full health, he's likely going to be in merely a depth role with Will Fuller, Jaylen Waddle, and DeVante Parker in front of him. There's little reason to consider him in pretty much any fantasy format this year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Preston Williams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Preston Williams missed the second half the 2020 season. Now he's low on the depth chart with DeVante Parker, Jaylen Waddle, and Will Fuller in Miami.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: It's hard to see a path to fantasy relevance for Williams in Miami. He's a restricted free agent in 2022.

notes.text: Bowden's rookie season was bizarre. He was drafted by the Raiders in the third round only to get shipped to Miami before the season began. Although the Dolphins were in need of playmakers, Bowden did little in his 10 games, with just nine carries and 28 receptions. He's a versatile player and can make things happen when the ball in his hands, but with the Dolphins adding Will Fuller and drafting Jaylen Waddle, and Myles Gaskin and Salvon Ahmed in the backfield, there's almost no chance for Bowden to have fantasy value this year absent multiple injuries ahead of him.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Lynn Bowden Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Raiders drafted Bowden with the 80th overall pick in the 2020 NFL Draft then traded him to Miami before he ever played a snap in silver and black. Bowden profiles as a player who is likely to help his NFL team more than your fantasy team. He doesn’t belong on fantasy rosters right now.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Bowden was jack of all trades player in college, drafted as a RB then traded to another team where he was converted to a full time WR. Now he’s playing behind Jaylen Waddle, DeVante Parker, and Will Fuller. Sigh.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Denzel Mims, Corey Davis, Jamison Crowder, Elijah Moore

notes.text: Yes, Mims was drafted in the second round last year. However, that doesn't matter much anymore. The Jets brought in a new coaching staff, and with that, they brought in a multitude of pass catchers. First, it was Corey Davis, who's built nearly identical to Mims (both 6-foot-3, just two pounds apart). Next, it was Keelan Cole, who's been underutilized throughout his career. Lastly, they drafted Elijah Moore, who's a utility blade in the offense. Oh, and they still haven't released Jamison Crowder. He's going to have a tough time seeing the field on a consistent basis.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Denzel Mims
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Jets offense in 2020 was...not good. Could Mims take a step forward in year two with Zach Wilson at QB? To do so, he’ll have to compete with Corey Davis, Jamison Crowder and Elijah Moore for targets, but Mims should be a near every down perimeter WR for this team. He’s among the late round, low risk WRs you can throw onto your bench and see what happens.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: A 4.38 40-yard dash and 96th percentile speed score helped Mims gain some steam last offseason in rookie drafts, but he didn’t do much in his rookie season. Could Mims be the next player to take a step forward after escaping from Adam Gase? A new scheme and high upside passer at the QB position could help. If you believed in Mims last year, his price via trade is much cheaper.

notes.text: We got somewhat of a breakout season from Davis last year, as he finished with 65 receptions for 984 yards and five touchdowns despite missing two games and playing second fiddle to A.J. Brown. He signed with the Jets in free agency and figures to be their go-to receiver, though there are suddenly tons of mouths to feed in New York. The Jets also added Keelan Cole in free agency, drafted Elijah Moore in the second round, and managed to restructure Jamison Crowder's contract to keep him in town. On top of all that, they have a rookie quarterback under center, which presents another obstacle. Davis is likely to be the leader in targets, but he may not have enough consistency to be a weekly WR3. Ideally, you draft him as a WR4 to play in spots.

The Jets new WR suffered a shoulder injury during OTAs in late May, but by all accounts, the injury is minor. It sounds like Davis landed on the top of his shoulder, which is typically consistent with one of two injuries: a sprained AC joint and/or a bruised rotator cuff. Regardless, these injuries won’t affect Davis moving forward. He’ll be ready for Week 1.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Corey Davis
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After being left for dead by fantasy managers, Corey Davis put together a really nice 2020 season playing alongside A.J. Brown in Tennessee. Now, he lands in New York with the Jets. While he could see an uptick in target volume, he’ll be relying on a rookie QB Zach Wilson. It's rare to find a team's WR1 sitting in the double-digit rounds so take the value in hopes he can be a top-36 guy in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Davis signed a 3-year deal with the Jets, but his 2023 contract carries zero guaranteed money. In other words, if things don’t work out over the next two seasons, Davis could be on the move once again.

notes.text: It's a shame the Jets re-worked Crowder's contract to keep him with the team because I'm not really sure where he fits in. The Jets are head over heels in love with Elijah Moore, who projects as someone who'll play quite a few slot snaps. They also went out and snagged Corey Davis in free agency, so he'll be their top receiver. You mustn't forget that Adam Gase is no longer the head coach, and Sam Darnold is no longer the quarterback. Removing those two is bad for Crowder's production, as both loved the slot very much. The Jets suddenly have a crowded depth chart at wide receiver, meaning Crowder might not even play a full-time role.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jamison Crowder
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Always underrated for fantasy, Jamison Crowder was a great value in the 11th-13th rounds of fantasy drafts last year. But, he’s one player who could actually be worse without Adam Gase, who’s always targeted his slot WR. There was concern with new regime in place and Elijah Moore on the roster, the Jets could actually cut Crowder before the start of the season. However, his contract has been renegotiated and he'll remain with the Jets in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: We don’t know if Crowder will get the volume in New York with a new scheme. Look for Crowder to be playing football in a new uniform next season as he’s an unrestricted free agent after 2021. At 28 years old, he could still have an impact on the right team and useable in certain weeks for fantasy.

notes.text: While scouting Moore this offseason, I came away saying, "that guy is a natural football player." The game seemed to come easy to him, which is the same thing I said about Tee Higgins. They're different players, but some are just born to play this game. So, to hear about Moore tearing up the offseason workouts, it didn't surprise me. What did surprise me was them re-working Jamison Crowder's contract to keep him with the team. His presence is going to be an issue for Moore's ceiling in his rookie year. The hope for Moore is that they'll use him in a Curtis Samuel-type role where they manufacture touches for him to give fantasy managers weekly usability. He's certainly someone to keep an eye on.

Elijah Moore somehow slipped to the 2nd round to the Jets and finds his way in a situation ripe with opportunity. His 40-yard time (4.33) was the main headline but his broad jump (121 in) and short-area burst was also on display at his pro day. He profiles as a slot WR (5'9, 184 lbs) but also didn't shy away from contested-catch situations at Ole Miss. His route running has been praised to the point where it shouldn't be shocking if he leads the team in receptions in Year One. The big question mark is rookie QB Zach Wilson.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Elijah Moore
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Elijah Moore somehow slipped to the 2nd round to the Jets and finds his way in a situation ripe with opportunity. His 40-yard time (4.33) was the main headline but his broad jump (121 in) and short-area burst was also on display at his pro day. He profiles as a slot WR (5'9, 184 lbs) but also didn't shy away from contested-catch situations at Ole Miss. His route running has been praised to the point where it shouldn't be shocking if he leads the team in receptions in Year One. The big question mark is rookie QB Zach Wilson.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Largely selected in the early 2nd round of dynasty rookie drafts, look for Moore to hold his value for at least one season regardless of his on-field performance. Moore fits exactly what the new Jets’ staff wants from their receivers - run after the catch ability.

notes.text: Blankenship had a fine rookie season with the Colts, and not just because he spawned a whole bunch of fantastic Halloween costumes with his signature look. He ranked fourth in the NFL in field-goal attempts wit 37 and converted 86.5% of his tries. Along with his 43 extra-point conversation, Blankenship ended the year as the sixth-best kicker in fantasy. Kicking in a dome and for an offense that should again be able to move the ball well but perhaps not score touchdowns at will, Blankenship should be a fine fantasy option once again.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Antonio Gandy-Golden, Terry McLaurin, Kelvin Harmon, Dyami Brown, Adam Humphries, Curtis Samuel

notes.text: Despite playing with a mixture of Dwayne Haskins, Alex Smith, Kyle Allen, and Taylor Heinicke the last two years, McLaurin has managed to produce 2,037 yards and 11 touchdowns. While that's not enough to get into the WR1 conversation, maybe the addition of Ryan Fitzpatrick is. We've watched Fitzpatrick support many fantasy wide receivers throughout his years, and he's been willing to target them relentlessly. It's part of the reason we loved DeVante Parker when Fitzpatrick was under center in Miami. There are suddenly a lot of mouths to feed in Washington, but McLaurin is the clear-cut No. 1 option who should be targeted 140-plus times in 2021 en route to what might be his first top-12 finish.

We get it. McLaurin broke out last year. That breakout also came with some of the worst QB play in the league. Now McLaurin gets the Bearded Wonder Ryan Fitzpatrick. Fitz loves to sling the ball down the field. He also loves to feed his No. 1 WR with an overflow of targets. Terry has legit top-10 upside this season.

Terry McLaurin quietly played through a high ankle sprain for the majority of the second half of the season. Over his final 4 games, McLaurin averaged just 39 yards per game while battling the injury, but earlier in the season, he averaged 87.5 yards per game when healthy. Look for McLaurin to return to form with a full offseason to recover.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Terry McLaurin
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It was a tale of two seasons for McLaurin last year. Through the first nine weeks, McLaurin was the WR11, but from Weeks 10-17, McLaurin fell off ranking as the WR44 over that time span. What happened? The Washington WR1 battled a high ankle sprain and was forced to catch passes from a combination of Dwayne Haskins, check-down king Alex Smith, and Kyle Allen. Yikes. McLaurin saw the 9th most targets at the WR position last year and if he sees a similar target share with Ryan Fitzpatrick at the helm, who historically elevates his WRs for fantasy, McLaurin has legitimate top-5 upside in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Scary Terry still doesn’t have a long-term QB and that’s pretty much the only knock on him at this point in his early career. Look for McLaurin to sign a long-term extension with Washington in the next 1-2 years. If the Football Team can get him a reliable passer, his dynasty value should keep him inside the top-15 at the position.

notes.text: Brown was a vertical threat at UNC going over 1,000 receiving yards along with 20 receiving TDs the last two years. With Terry McLaurin and Curtis Samuel locked in as the team’s top two WRs, he’ll be fighting for playing time alongside Adam Humphries, Cam Sims, and Antonio Gandy-Golden. Luckily, Ryan Fitzpatrick knows how to pepper his WRs with targets. Brown isn’t on the redraft radar for 2021.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dyami Brown
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Brown was a vertical threat at UNC going over 1,000 receiving yards along with 20 receiving TDs the last two years. With Terry McLaurin and Curtis Samuel locked in as the team’s top two WRs, he’ll be fighting for playing time alongside Adam Humphries, Cam Sims, and Antonio Gandy-Golden. Luckily, Ryan Fitzpatrick knows how to pepper his WRs with targets. Brown isn’t on the redraft radar for 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Brown should be drafted in the late 2nd round of rookie drafts but his ceiling looks capped on a team with two other dynamic playmakers at wide receivers.

notes.text: It was good to see Samuel finally have his breakout season in year four, though it's worth noting that his numbers have improved every year. The issue, however, is that he's being reunited with offensive coordinator Scott Turner, who couldn't get the most out of Samuel during the 2019 season. While Samuel saw a career-high 106 targets that year, he averaged a minuscule 5.9 yards per target while used in an incorrect role. Will that change? It's tough to say, but Terry McLaurin, J.D. McKissic, Antonio Gibson, and Logan Thomas are all competition for targets with his new team. Samuel should have plenty of manufactured touches, but don't automatically assume he's as valuable as he was in 2020.

Samuel missed all of Washington’s June mini-camp with a groin issue, and it appears he is still battling the same injury now in training camp after landing on the PUP list. Reports out of Washington indicate that the team is not concerned about their WR’s injury, but it is worth noting that this injury has been an issue dating back to OTAs in late May. Assuming this is a groin strain, his recovery timeline suggests this is a moderate strain. These injuries can be tricky, as they’re stressed with dynamic lateral movements, which are crucial for wide receivers coming in and out of their breaks. Washington may be conservative with Samuel in the preseason as an aggravation of this injury over the next few weeks could possibly lead to concerns regarding his Week 1 availability. This is an injury to monitor leading up to fantasy drafts.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Curtis Samuel
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Reunited with OC Scott Turner and head coach Ron Rivera, Samuel is very familiar with this system. Two years ago when he last played in Turner’s system in Carolina, Samuel ranked 9th in air yards and now he gets to play with a QB in Fitzmagic who loves to push the ball downfield. Despite starting training camp on the PUP list, Samuel has sneaky upside in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Samuel signed a 3-year deal this offseason to land in Washington, and now he’s got a coaching staff who knows how to use him. McLaurin and Samuel can form an exciting 1-2 punch for multiple seasons. Most managers view Samuel as a WR3/4 in dynasty, but we still haven’t seen his ceiling. Now is the time to buy before it’s too late.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: D.J. Chark Jr., Marvin Jones Jr.

notes.text: There are many trying to figure out the target share for Laviska Shenault, Marvin Jones, and Travis Etienne, but the one who's the clear-cut No. 1 option on this team is Chark. If Trevor Lawrence turns out to be the real deal, Chark can be the 2021 version of Tee Higgins when he was with Joe Burrow (was the No. 11 wide receiver in eight full games with Burrow). Chark already flashed WR1 potential in 2019 when he racked up 73 receptions for 1,008 yards and eight touchdowns with the combination of Gardner Minshew and Nick Foles, so why can't he be more with Lawrence? The coaching staff is a big question mark, but you don't draft Lawrence to run the ball 40 times per game. Chark comes with some risk but even more upside.

A new regime arrives in Jacksonville, along with Marvin Jones Jr.  While Chark has flashed talent, he's had only 4 games in the top 24 at the wide receiver position in his last 24 appearances.  Between Jones, Shenault, and Etienne, you may find Chark lower on the depth chart than you hoped or dreamed.  Stay away from him and try your best to forget the tantalizing breakout potential he once had.  It might be over when people least expect it.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: DJ Chark Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Chark's outlook has been on quite the roller coaster ride the last three years. He was non-existent as a rookie and abandoned before breaking out with Gardner Minshew in his 2nd year. Last year, he was a lauded pick across the industry before Chark and the rest of the team nosedived to a 1-15 finish. Enter Trevor Lawrence and an air of optimism for the downfield threat. The Jaguars did add veteran WR, Marvin Jones, and there is hype for second year WR, Laviska Shenault. There is no guarantee (despite the talent) that Chark emerges from the depths again.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Chark will be a free agent after this season so don't necessarily connect him with Lawrence and the Jaguars long-term.

notes.text: I'll be the first to admit it's possible we're all underestimating Jones this year. Sure, he's now 31 years old, but he's also coming off 1,757 yards and 18 touchdowns over the last two seasons, and that was while missing three full games. The Jaguars and their new coaching staff sought him out in free agency and paid him $7 million per year, so he's not likely going to be "just a mentor" to the young receivers. It is tough to see him being a consistent producer, however, as D.J. Chark, Laviska Shenault, and Travis Etienne are all going to be heavily targeted as well.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Marvin Jones Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Marvin Jones has out-performed his ADP three of the last four seasons, but there’s some uncertainty in Jacksonville this year. He goes from reliable gunslinger Matthew Stafford to unproven rookie Trevor Lawrence with a crowded WR room including D.J. Chark, Laviska Shenault and now possibly Travis Etienne. One thing working in Marv’s favor, however, is his connection with offensive coordinator, Darrell Bevell, who comes over from Detroit.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Now 31 and changing teams, Jones doesn’t hold much value in dynasty. If you’re rebuilding, look to move on from Marv after a splash week by trading him to a contender.

notes.text: It was going to be easy to name Shenault as a breakout candidate in 2021, as he was the clear-cut No. 2 option behind D.J. Chark on the Jaguars depth chart. Suddenly, the Jaguars have a new play-caller, a proven veteran receiver (Marvin Jones), and a first-round running back (Travis Etienne) they're calling a wide receiver. This has created some doubt in the role that Shenault will play under Urban Meyer. There's upside in selecting him as a bench receiver, though, as Trevor Lawrence should be a massive upgrade at quarterback, and it's not like Chark/Jones haven't dealt with injuries over the last couple years (Jones is also getting up there in age). Shenault is purely an upside pick that you stash on your bench until you find out just how he's being used.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Laviska Shenault Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Shenault is a Swiss-army knife weapon in the mold of Percy Harvin, a player Urban Meyer maximized in college. Don’t be surprised if Shenault ends 2021 as Trevor Lawrence’s favorite WR in Jacksonville. It may be a bit crowded there with D.J. Chark and newly signed veteran Marvin Jones. You can draft him as your WR4 knowing there is room to move up the ranks.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Viska had a productive rookie year and after gaining steam at the beginning of the offseason, his dynasty stock has cooled recently. D.J. Chark Jr. is a free agent in 2022 and Marvin Jones Jr. (as great as he is) turned 32 & the Jaguars have a potential out in his contract next year. Buy into a breakout coming. He’s a player worth trading for.

notes.text: We've legitimately seen Wentz perform as a top-five fantasy quarterback in Frank Reich's offense, so this one speaks for itself. The Colts offensive line might be better than the one the Eagles had in those days, though they'll need Eric Fisher healthy as soon as possible. Despite his bad 2020 season, Wentz has posted QB1-type numbers in 44.1 percent of the games in his career, which ranks as the 16th best quarterback over the last 15 years. *Update* Wentz has a foot issue that could require surgery, and the Colts are bracing for him to miss time at the start of the year. Stay tuned in for more updates.

Wentz injured his foot on July 26 and is set to miss up to 12 weeks following surgery to remove a piece of fractured bone from his foot. Given that this decision wasn't made until early August, it's very possible Wentz misses multiple regular season games. At this point, however, it's too early to determine how many exactly he'll miss. Because the surgery is to remove a piece of bone rather than repair an injured tissue, the progression of his rehab will primarily depend on rate of recovery and soreness levels. Look for Wentz's status to be updated as the regular season nears, but he is certainly a candidate to start the year on the PUP list. The latest report is that he is 'trending' towards playing in Week 1. We'll be monitoring this situation and updating as needed.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Carson Wentz
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: For all of the turmoil Wentz faced this season, he was the QB7 for the first seven weeks of the season and a viable every week start. But you know the rest of the story, as he crashed and burned into losing his job to Jalen Hurts before being traded to Indianapolis, and reunited with Frank Reich. The QB Guru will have to correct some of Wentz’s mistake-prone ways as he holds onto the ball for way too long, hence the reason he led the NFL in sacks despite not playing the final month of the season. The change of scenery should do wonders but he’s a bit of a mystery for 2021. UPDATE: Carson Wentz will undergo surgery to remove a piece of fractured bone from his foot. The latest report is that he's trending towards starting in Week 1. This is a situation we'll be monitoring.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Wentz’s dynasty value has cratered over the last two years. He’s still only 28 years old and playing indoors with a solid team can resurrect his stock. He’s a better QB2 in SuperFlex leagues than someone we’d trust going into 2021.

notes.text: Yes, Mims was drafted in the second round last year. However, that doesn't matter much anymore. The Jets brought in a new coaching staff, and with that, they brought in a multitude of pass catchers. First, it was Corey Davis, who's built nearly identical to Mims (both 6-foot-3, just two pounds apart). Next, it was Keelan Cole, who's been underutilized throughout his career. Lastly, they drafted Elijah Moore, who's a utility blade in the offense. Oh, and they still haven't released Jamison Crowder. He's going to have a tough time seeing the field on a consistent basis.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Denzel Mims
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Jets offense in 2020 was...not good. Could Mims take a step forward in year two with Zach Wilson at QB? To do so, he’ll have to compete with Corey Davis, Jamison Crowder and Elijah Moore for targets, but Mims should be a near every down perimeter WR for this team. He’s among the late round, low risk WRs you can throw onto your bench and see what happens.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: A 4.38 40-yard dash and 96th percentile speed score helped Mims gain some steam last offseason in rookie drafts, but he didn’t do much in his rookie season. Could Mims be the next player to take a step forward after escaping from Adam Gase? A new scheme and high upside passer at the QB position could help. If you believed in Mims last year, his price via trade is much cheaper.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Mecole Hardman, Cornell Powell, Tyreek Hill, Demarcus Robinson

notes.text: We've watched Hardman be one of the most efficient wide receivers in the league over the last two years, but it hasn't meant much to fantasy managers. For whatever reason, Andy Reid hasn't used Hardman in a full-time role, which meant he saw fewer than five targets in 11-of-16 games last year. Now that Sammy Watkins is gone, does his role grow, or does Reid continue to use him sparingly. If we hear that Hardman is being taken off special teams, it would be a massive boost to his stock. There's certainly upside with him, but we need Reid to have a change of heart for it to be recognized.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mecole Hardman
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Well, the Lizard King (Sammy Watkins) isn’t in Kansas City anymore, so the natural thought process might be to expect Mecole Hardman to see an uptick in usage. Nevertheless he's never gone over 100 receiving yards in the regular season and has only one top-12 performance in 32 career games. Hardman is not someone you can trust weekly and thus someone we don't recommend on your roster.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hardman is still just 23 years old and plays with the best QB in the NFL. As a result, he’ll have perceived dynasty value for the foreseeable future, but it’s possible the Chiefs view Mecole as Tyreek Hill’s direct backup and not the No. 2 option in the WR room, despite what dynasty managers want.

notes.text: Hill was more of a streaky wide receiver early in his career who relied on big plays to get him into WR1 territory, though that seemingly ended in 2020 where he saw 10-plus targets in seven different games. Those numbers combined with his efficiency equals big things, and there's no reason to think they go away; Travis Kelce is going to be 32 years old, Sammy Watkins is gone, and they brought in no big-name wide receivers who are guaranteed much of anything. He's worthy of a first-round pick in fantasy drafts.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyreek Hill
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Most people think of Tyreek Hill as this splashy up and down player and while he does have immense upside weekly, Hill was actually one of the most consistent wide receivers in the league in 2020. Hill finished outside of the top 36 receivers just three times all season. Since 2017, Tyreek Hill is tied with Davante Adams for the most multi-TD games at the WR position. With Patrick Mahomes throwing him passes, Hill has one of the safest floor/ceiling combos in all of fantasy football.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: As long as Tyreek Hill is playing with Patrick Mahomes as his QB and Andy Reid as his head coach, he’ll be a top five dynasty wide receiver. He’s only under contract with Kansas City through the 2022 season, but look for Cheetah to sign a long term deal soon.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: J.J. Arcega-Whiteside, Travis Fulgham, John Hightower, Jalen Reagor, Greg Ward

notes.text: Hey, remember that five-week stretch where Fulgham was the No. 1 fantasy football wide receiver? No, I'm not kidding. From Week 4 through Week 8, Fulgham scored 82.0 half PPR points while no other receiver scored more than 74.3 of them. Then, suddenly, the Eagles chose to not involve him in the offense anymore. It was odd, really. The Eagles now clearly have Devonta Smith and Jalen Reagor ahead of him on the depth chart, but if Jalen Hurts can take a step forward in his passing in 2021, we could see Fulgham have a few usable weeks in fantasy as the team's No. 3 receiver.

Was his disappointing rookie season a product of bad quarterback play? Bad offensive scheme? Or was it Reagor himself? It may have been a combination of all three things, though the other two have changed this offseason, as Nick Sirianni is now the head coach, and Jalen Hurts is now the quarterback. The downside is that the Eagles drafted Devonta Smith in the first round and he's immediately going to become the No. 1 target for Hurts, which puts Reagor into competition with Dallas Goedert as the No. 2 option in this offense. If Hurts pans out, Reagor could be a value later in drafts, though he may be a bit more boom/bust than you'd like due to his inconsistent targets.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jalen Reagor
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Reagor was dealt a bad hand last year and never really got things going thanks to multiple injuries and poor QB play, but he should be an every-down player for Philly in 2021, something he couldn’t say last year. However, Philadelphia did move up in the first round to take Heisman-winning WR DeVonta Smith. There may not be enough passing volume to support multiple productive fantasy WRs.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Reagor is being shuffled to the back of dynasty benches as we trade for him on the cheap in hopes that Jalen Hurts and the offense take a step forward and produce for fantasy. He’s the perfect player to sneak into a package deal.

notes.text: If you're looking for the clear-cut No. 1 wide receiver for his team who's not being drafted like it, Smith is your guy. The Eagles were severely lacking wide receiver talent last year, and it led to them trading up to take Smith to solidify their go-to receiver for Jalen Hurts. Smith was the most pro-ready receiver in the draft, though some are concerned with his lack of weight. Even though every college knew he was getting the ball, they couldn't stop him, and it's not like Alabama plays weak opponents. He dominated everyone he came across. As someone who should get a consistent six-plus targets per game, Smith should be a WR3, even in his rookie season.

Coming off his sensational Heisman winning season, Smith was drafted 10th overall to the Eagles. He could be limited by the passing volume and inaccuracies of QB Jalen Hurts, but Smith can establish himself immediately as the top pass catching option for the team. His route running and ability to get open are unmatched by any of his teammates.

The Eagles' rookie WR suffered a sprained MCL in his knee on July 31 and is set to miss 2-3 weeks. This reported recovery timeline is consistent with a grade II MCL injury, which will heal reliably without surgery. I expect Smith to be cleared for Week 1, but we may not see much of him in the preseason. One thing to be mindful of in this scenario is that Smith may require a few weeks to work on his conditioning towards the end of camp before the season starts.

The Eagles traded up to select the Heisman winning WR in the 1st Round this year. He has every opportunity to lead the Eagles in targets as a rookie. If Jalen Hurts can improve as a passer, Smith could easily be the most productive rookie WR in the 2021 class. He may compete with 2020 1st Round WR pick, Jalen Reagor, who is looking to bounce back after a bad rookie season, dealing with injury and a poor offense overall.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: DeVonta Smith
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Eagles traded up to select the Heisman winning WR in the 1st Round this year. He has every opportunity to lead the Eagles in targets as a rookie. If Jalen Hurts can improve as a passer, Smith could easily be the most productive rookie WR in the 2021 class. He may compete with 2020 1st Round WR pick, Jalen Reagor, who is looking to bounce back after a bad rookie season, dealing with injury and a poor offense overall.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Smith’s frame leaves a lot to be desired, but his college production profile is insane and now he’s got top-10 NFL Draft capital to support it. Whether Jalen Hurts can take a step forward in the passing game or not is a big factor in Smith’s success.

notes.text: Hurst is also a very good football player who's going to be on the field quite a bit, as Arthur Smith's offense used more 12 personnel (two tight ends) than any other team in the NFL last year. It's why Jonnu Smith was capped at 65 targets while Anthony Firkser saw 53 of his own. I'm not saying that'll be the split between these two, but Hurst is going to get more targets than some expect, limiting Kyle Pitts' true target ceiling.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Hayden Hurst
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Last year was his biggest opportunity to date as he ran the 4th most routes among TEs but ended 16th in receiving yards and only saw five deep targets. With Julio Jones out the door and superhuman Kyle Pitts in place, Hurst will mostly be utilized as a blocker but remain on the field in 2TE sets. It’s wild to remember the Ravens took him before Lamar Jackson as a first rounder in 2018. Hope you’re hungry because all you’re getting served this year is Hayden Bratwurst.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hurst will be 28 years old when the season starts which makes him a grandpa for a player entering his 4th year in the league. The Falcons didn’t pick up his 5th year option so he’s basically a sitting duck behind #4 overall pick Kyle Pitts. That crash you heard was your trade window slamming shut.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Robert Woods, Van Jefferson, Tutu Atwell

notes.text: It should be an interesting debate regarding Woods this year, because on the surface, it appears that he gets an upgrade to Matthew Stafford. While that's true, it can be argued that Jared Goff's skill-set was tailormade for Woods' skill-set. The 7.1 air yards per target Woods saw in 2020 was the 10th-lowest mark among wide receivers. Meanwhile, Stafford likes to push the ball down the field a bit more. Because of the questions (good or bad), Woods should ultimately be viewed as a mid-to-low-end WR2.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Robert Woods
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Has Robert Woods ever not been a value in fantasy football? At this point, we sort of know what Robert Woods is - a consistent and reliable high end WR2 in fantasy. In fact, he’s finished as a top 17 WR three years in a row, and while he’s usually not a ‘sexy’ pick, Bobby Trees has shown sneaky upside. Now he’s set to play with arguably the best QB of his career. Once again, Woods looks like a rock solid WR2 for your roster at an affordable ADP.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Woods is now 29 years old, but he just signed a big time extension last year, locking him up in Los Angeles likely for the remainder of his career through the year 2025. His fantasy value is likely to decline over time, but for the next 2-3 seasons, Woods should continue to provide WR2/3 value despite nearing the dreaded 30 year old mark. This alone makes him a great trade target for dynasty managers contending for a title.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Van Jefferson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After using a 2nd round pick on Van Jefferson in 2020, the Rams selected WR Tutu Atwell in the 2nd Round of this year’s draft. Of course Robert Woods and Cooper Kupp will dominate the targets, but the Rams also signed speedy veteran wideout DeSean Jackson. Jefferson will really have to step up to have any sort of fantasy impact.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Rams unexpectedly drafted a WR in Round 2 of this year’s draft (Tutu Atwell), although he may be used as more of a gadget player. Even though Josh Reynolds is gone, it’s still crowded in LA, and Jefferson will have to prove he belongs on dynasty rosters.

notes.text: His weight (155 lbs) is frightening to imagine someone running around on an NFL football field. Terrifying, actually. Sean McVay did spend the team’s first draft pick (2nd round, 57th overall) on Atwell and compared him to DeSean Jackson, who already is on this team. He consistently weighs in at one tutu if your league rewards points for that kinda thing.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tutu Atwell
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: His weight (155 lbs) is frightening to imagine someone running around on an NFL football field. Terrifying, actually. Sean McVay did spend the team’s first draft pick (2nd round, 57th overall) on Atwell and compared him to DeSean Jackson, who already is on this team. He consistently weighs in at one tutu if your league rewards points for that kinda thing.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Woods and Kupp clearly lead the way at WR. They also drafted Van Jefferson in the 2nd Round of the 2020 NFL Draft, and signed DeSean Jackson this offseason. While his production and speed is elite, he likely ends up as a gadget player.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: DeSean Jackson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We know the story with DeSean Jackson. If he’s healthy, he has big play ability, even at age 34. Look for splash plays with Stafford, but as we’ve seen, dependability isn’t DJax’s strong suit. He’s played a total of eight games over the last two years.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Jackson carries virtually no trade value at this stage of his career. If you’re rebuilding, wait for a splash DJax game and sell for whatever you can get.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: La'Mical Perine
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Perine is a favorite of Mike’s and should not be completely discredited from making some noise in this Jets backfield. While Tevin Coleman was brought in due to his familiarity with this system, 4th rounder Michael Carter is no sure thing. Perine isn’t exactly fast but his frame (5’11 216) says he can handle a bigger workload. He’s a name to consider in the later rounds.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Perine is a lottery ticket and likely a discounted RB in dynasty formats. He’s worth a look in a trades for the slim chance he becomes the lead fantasy back in New York.

notes.text: Don't sleep on Carter in redraft formats. The only player standing in his way of 15-plus touches is Tevin Coleman, who's played just 22-of-32 games the last two seasons. On top of that, he's never been efficient when asked to carry a heavy workload. Carter reminded me of Justin Forsett while scouting him. He does everything well, and though he's undersized, that shouldn't stop him from getting plenty of opportunity, especially in the passing game. The Jets are no longer an Adam Gase-led team. There's value to be had in this offense, and Carter is one of the best late-round values in fantasy football.

Carter played second-fiddle to Javonte Williams at UNC but he’s gained some steam recently given his receiving work in college. The Jets took him in the 4th round and he has a good opportunity to see 40 percent of the backfield touches in Year One. His main competition is La’Mical Perine and Tevin Coleman which is encouraging.

Talent and opportunity are lynchpins of fantasy football relevance. The Jets have improved their offensive line and Michael Carter comes into an intriguing backfield that has no true leader. Watch closely as Carter could earn the lion's share of the work right out of the gate in New York.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Michael Carter
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Carter played second-fiddle to Javonte Williams at UNC but he’s gained some steam recently given his receiving work in college. The Jets took him in the 4th round and he has a good opportunity to see 40 percent of the backfield touches in Year One. His main competition is La’Mical Perine and Tevin Coleman which is encouraging.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: When you factor in his height (5’7 7/8) and adjust for speed, he’s not an elite prospect. He’s a top-15 rookie pick in 2021 because opportunity sometimes is king. He also could be this year’s Ke’Shawn Vaughn.

notes.text: Let's just call it as it is: Coleman is essentially undrafted at this point in the offseason. He's not great, but he's going to be the starting running back for the Jets when the season begins. As time goes on, I fully expect Michael Carter to push him for that job (he's better than Coleman), but Coleman was brought to New York because he knows the offense. But still, a starting running back should be taken as a top-50 option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tevin Coleman
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Coleman and the Shanahan system seems to have a constant thing. From Atlanta to San Francisco to now with New York, Shanahan acolyte Mike LaFleur can certainly utilize him in zone running schemes. The oft-injured back is competing with Michael Carter and La’Mical Perine so he’s a dart throw at best for 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Coleman missed his window a couple of years ago to cash in for free agency and be a fantasy force. He’s 28 and on his last legs.

notes.text: With Trey Burton no longer on the roster, does Doyle have more appeal in fantasy? Well, yeah. The Colts targeted their tight ends 118 times last year, but dividing that three ways proved to be worthless for fantasy. Those targets should be divided between Doyle and Mo Alie-Cox in 2021, which makes him a bit more attractive, but Alie-Cox is the one with the true breakout potential, whereas Doyle will probably be the higher floor play.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jack Doyle
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Those tiny hands might come in handy in 2021. With Trey Burton gone, Doyle could turn into an every down TE, although Mo Alie-Cox might have something to say about that. In the Colts’ playoff loss to the Bills, Doyle was arguably the best Colts receiver on the field going 7/70/1. Carson Wentz has been known to favor a TE or two in his day so Doyle isn’t the worst TE to throw a dart at in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Doyle was a cut candidate this off-season but survived. He has two years left on his deal but his time as a relevant fantasy player is likely coming to a close soon. He’s been the beneficiary of opportunity more so than talent since coming into the league undrafted in 2013

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Dalvin Cook, Kene Nwangwu, Alexander Mattison

notes.text: Despite missing four games over the last two years, Cook has still managed to rack up 3,572 total yards and 30 touchdowns. He's still yet to play 16 games in his four-year career, but when he's on the field, he's a surefire RB1. In each of the final 12 games he played in 2020, he touched the ball a minimum of 17 times, including 24-plus touches in nine of them. The craziest part about his numbers, though, is the fact that he has 97 receptions for 880 yards over the last two years, but just one receiving touchdown, so there's room for even more of a ceiling.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dalvin Cook
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The only knock on Cook is his injury concerns but every single RB gets injured at some point. Of the top-20 RBs, only two(!) played all 16 games in 2020. Cook is a true dominator who gets the type of money touches that produces for fantasy. He had a league-leading 66 red-zone touches and the most goal-line carries in football. That’ll work! He also is an elite talent with the 2nd most evaded tackles and has been a top-5 RB in back-to-back seasons despite only playing 14 games. The change in offensive coordinator shouldn’t scare anyone as it’s all in the family with Klint Kubiak replacing Gary Kubiak. If you wanted to take him at 1.01, we wouldn’t file a complaint to the powers that be.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Cook is a top-3 dynasty RB and after signing a massive extension last year, he’s still under contract with the Vikings for four more years.

notes.text: When drafting a player like Mattison, it's not going to make you feel all warm and fuzzy inside. He's a handcuff, plain and simple. As long as Dalvin Cook is on the field, Mattison isn't going to get more than 10 touches in a game. However, if Cook were to miss time, Mattison is a potential league winner. If you have the space on your bench for someone like Mattison, he's much better than a bye-week-filler-type player.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Alexander Mattison
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Man… if Alexander Mattison ever got the opportunity, he’d… Ok we say this almost every year and when Dalvin Cook went out, he flopped against Atlanta but showed out in Week 17. He’s a volume-based backup that can be 70 percent of Cook when given the chance. However, he’s lucky to see five or six touches when Cook is in.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Mattison turns 23 and still has two years left on his deal in Minnesota. He’s a must for Dalvin Cook managers although he might never materialize for fantasy.

notes.text: It appeared the Bears were headed towards going to Kmet as their starting tight end over the tail end of 2020 and moving on from Jimmy Graham. However, they did have the chance to cut Graham this offseason and save $7 million against the cap, but they chose to release Kyle Fuller and Charles Leno instead. This highlights the fact that they still value Graham with his $10 million salary. With Graham still around, it's going to be tough for Kmet to become an every-week starter. Things can change quickly, but for now, Kmet is just a streaming option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Cole Kmet
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Jimmy Grandpa is toast and Kmet is the TE1 on this team. Kmet wasn’t a full-time player until Week 10 but from then on, he averaged over five targets per game. He’s going to get more red-zone looks and now he’s hitched to Justin Fields. Kmet can be a top-10 TE this year and he’s worth a shot as a late round flier. You can also cut him if Graham stays annoying.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Jimmy Graham was surprisingly kept this year despite the team having an out in his contract. Disregard the smokescreen. Kmet is an up-and-coming TE1 and if you can trade for him now, you’ll be ahead of the production.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Chad Beebe, Ihmir Smith-Marsette, Adam Thielen

notes.text: It seems the torch has been passed from Thielen to Justin Jefferson, though it's not as if Thielen will just fade into oblivion. It goes back to the Stefon Diggs days where he had to share that production. While Thielen did finish as the No. 8 wide receiver last year, it was thanks to his 14 touchdowns on just 74 receptions and 925 yards. No other receiver finished higher than No. 18 with fewer yards than Thielen. He's also going to be 31 years old at the start of the season and has a history of back issues, presenting a bit of risk, though he does have a ton of proven production with Kirk Cousins, which can't be ignored.

Adam Thielen was one of the best red-zone receivers in football last year, and all he gets for it is a place on this list.  We want to warn players about the otherworldly efficiency that Thielen had last season.  On just 13 red-zone targets, he ended up with 10 touchdowns.  These numbers are unlikely to repeat, and his volume has gone down in recent years.  He could surprise again, but banking on that level of touchdown efficiency is normally a bad bet.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Adam Thielen
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: “Ahhhhhhh--ahhhh--Hooked on a Thielen!” Or maybe not according to ADP... Adam Thielen looks like he’ll be a massive value in drafts with Justin Jefferson as the new hotness as fantasy managers look more excited to draft the younger Vikings WR. But let’s not forget - Thielen has finished as a top 10 WR three of the last four seasons, and he’s coming off a 14 TD season in 2020. The TD total should regress a bit, but he’s still locked in as Kirk Cousins’ favorite target in the red zone and should return WR2 value at a significant discount relative to 2020 ADP.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Adam Thielen has been a big fantasy contributor over the past few seasons, but his best football is probably behind him at this point. He’ll be 31 years old before the season starts, making him a player who should be rostered only by dynasty managers contending for a championship.

notes.text: I'm not sure many realize just how difficult it would be for Jefferson to repeat his 2020 season. Not only was he a rookie, which is amazing in it's own right, but to finish with 1,400 yards on just 125 targets is ridiculous. How did that happen? Well, he caught 70.4 percent of his targets... at 15.9 yards a pop. No other wide receiver in the history of the game has totaled 1,400 yards on 125 or less targets. Bottom line... he needs more targets if he's going to live up to expectations because that's unlikely to happen again. With the defense getting back on track with Danielle Hunter (and adding in free agency), do the Vikings trend back to their run-heavy ways? Adam Thielen is a year older, but the chemistry between him and Kirk Cousins is magical. The sky is the limit for Jefferson with his talent, but will the targets follow? Don't forget this is the same team that held Stefon Diggs to 112 or less targets in 4-of-5 seasons.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Justin Jefferson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Justin Jefferson had the best fantasy season by a rookie wide receiver...EVER, setting the all-time record for receiving yards at 1,400. “JJets,” as he’s known in the Twitter streets, thrived on efficiency last season, turning in seven 100-yard games while averaging 15.9 yards per reception, 9th best in the NFL. Jefferson’s 2.66 yards per route run was second best in the NFL last year behind only Davante Adams, further supporting the second-year WR is a big play monster. Entering year two, however, some regression may be coming after Minnesota spent big money on defense via free agency. Plus, this is a balanced offense that wants to feature the running game and Dalvin Cook. Even so, Jefferson has one of the highest ceilings of any WR in the league.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Justin Jefferson’s historic rookie season in 2020 sets him up to be a top notch dynasty WR for years to come. His youth plus production at such an early point in his career bodes well for long term success for the Vikings wide out. He’s right among the most valuable players to have on your dynasty roster.

notes.text: I really liked Moss coming out of college, but being injury prone was a label he needed to shake. Unfortunately, he suffered an injury early in the season and was never able to wrestle the starting gig away from Devin Singletary. He did finish with at least 12 carries in three of the last four games, which leaves room for hope, but he also saw just three targets in those four games combined, which makes him extremely touchdown-dependent. When Josh Allen is the primary goal-line back, that presents an issue. Without an injury to Singletary, it's tough to see Moss being anything more than a touchdown-dependent RB3/4 option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Zack Moss
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Moss suffered a toe injury and missed Weeks 3-5. It was hard to trust him in fantasy given the fact Josh Allen functions as this team's goal-line back. Devin Singletary and Moss basically cannibalized each other's fantasy production on the year. Apart from pass protection (which doesn't equate to fantasy points), he has no discernable, difference-making skill to make him an asset.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Before the NFL draft, Moss could be seen as the 1A in the timeshare in Buffalo and trading him away now is advisable. He is destined to be a backup and likely scouring dynasty waiver wires a couple of years from now.

notes.text: To this point in his career, do you know who Singletary's fantasy comparison is? Duke Johnson. Yeah, we all know how that story ended. Singletary has produced RB2 or better numbers just 35.7 percent of the time, which is extremely poor for a running back who's averaged 14.2 opportunities per game. The Bills don't run the ball a whole lot, and it's extremeley likely that Zack Moss is the better early-down back who will get more goal-line carries. Singletary is a very low upside pick late in drafts who's best served as a bye week flex-type player.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Devin Singletary
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Singletary is a between the 20s runner who does have some wiggle to his game. But for fantasy, he’s like buying a steak to-go from Applebees. It’s a bad idea and will ruin your appetite everytime you make the decision to go for it. Singletary is stuck in a timeshare with Zack Moss and the Bills’ goal-line is none other than QB Josh Allen. You're better off shooting your shot with another RB with higher upside than trying to ride with “Mr. Singlecarry”.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Heading into Year 3, Singletary just turned 23 so he still has a ton of tread left on his tires. Honestly, his dynasty outlook would look so much better if he was on another team.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Trey Sermon, Elijah Mitchell, Kyle Juszczyk, Raheem Mostert, JaMycal Hasty

notes.text: As of now, we have to assume it's Raheem Mostert as the starting running back, though Kyle Shanahan did trade up into the third round to get Sermon. This should tell you that Mostert is on a short leash, and to be fair, he hasn't been able to hold up to a workhorse workload. The 49ers have one of the softest schedules in the league among running backs, so if we start hearing whispers that Sermon will start right out of the gate, he should shoot up draft boards. For now, he should be viewed as one of the best bench stashes in fantasy football.

Any RB selected by the 49ers makes you perk up. He also is an interesting name to monitor knowing that the San Francisco backfield collective scored the 3rd most combined points in the league. He’s a solid RB3 with room to return massive value. For redraft, there’s upside if the opportunity is there or if Raheem Mostert misses time. Without the opportunity, he may be a bench clogger that you are afraid to drop.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Trey Sermon
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Any RB selected by the 49ers makes you perk up. He also is an interesting name to monitor knowing that the San Francisco backfield collective scored the 3rd most combined points in the league. He’s a solid RB3 with room to return massive value. For redraft, there’s upside if the opportunity is there or if Raheem Mostert misses time. Without the opportunity, he may be a bench clogger that you are afraid to drop.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Sermon looks like a borderline 1st round rookie pick with room to grow into an even bigger role in 2022 when Raheem Mostert becomes a free-agent. The range of outcomes is wide with San Francisco being a haven for RB fantasy points as well as a revolving door.

notes.text: There's no denying it... when Mostert is healthy and on the field, he's a beast. He's turned 282 career carries into 1,590 yards and 11 touchdowns. But that's the issue, he's never healthy. There's a reason he's 29 years old and has just 282 carries on his frame. Have the 49ers lost patience? They traded up to draft Trey Sermon in the third round, which could indicate they're ready to move on from Mostert, or it could be them ensuring they have a high-quality backup for if/when he gets injured. Mostert tallied at least 14 carries in 5-of-8 starts last year, which is more than enough to get into RB2 territory with his efficiency, but you can't draft him as such when injuries/Sermon are factored in. He's not someone you can confidently draft as a starter for your fantasy team because there's so much unknown. However, if he gets the job back, this is a pick that can make a difference in fantasy leagues. The 49ers have one of the easiest schedules in the league, so if they let Mostert get rolling, he's unlikely to slow down.

Raheem Mostert’s injury history is piling up quickly. He missed 2 weeks last year with a sprained MCL in his knee then suffered a high ankle sprain in Week 6. Upon returning later in the year, Mostert then re-aggravated his high ankle sprain in Week 15, and he missed the final 2 games. Mostert’s injury profile is concerning - he’s 29 years old and has missed 5+ games in every professional season except for one. The primary culprit? Recurring ankle and foot injuries. Research shows that 20-47% of ankle sprains are recurrent, indicating Mostert carries a higher injury risk entering 2021.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Raheem Mostert
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Mostert is an efficiency king with some of the best long speed of any RB in the game averaging over five yards per carry in his career. Unfortunately, he hasn’t exactly been the pinnacle of health. He also has only one 100-yard rushing game in the regular season over the last three seasons. Mostert and rookie Trey Sermon will be an ongoing conversation piece but consider Mostert the lead going into training camp. He’s risk/reward RB2.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s shockingly 29 years old so this joy ride for the former UDFA could be over soon. With one year left on his deal in San Francisco,

notes.text: So much for a potential breakout season for Wilson. He tore his meniscus while weightlifting in May, which required surgery that'll keep him on the shelf for 4-6 months, meaning he'll miss the start of the season (and maybe the whole thing). The 49ers drafted Trey Sermon in the third round, still have Raheem Mostert, and added Wayne Gallman in free agency, so they're not hurting at running back with Wilson out. He's undraftable.

Wilson is now slated to miss the start of the 2021 season after undergoing surgery to repair a torn meniscus in his knee. His reported timeline is 4-6 months, but these injuries usually take 6 months to fully heal. Look for Wilson, who missed time last year with a high ankle sprain, to miss all of September and part of October at a minimum.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jeff Wilson Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: My Name is Jeff! Whenever Wilson had opportunity due to other injuries in the backfield, he seized them. However, Wilson underwent meniscus surgery and will be sidelined until November.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s a dynasty legend helping teams the last two years with some monster TD games. It’s hard to bank on that success again with Trey Sermon now in the mix, especially with the offseason surgery.

notes.text: The marriage between the Raiders and Drake is an odd one, as Drake was somewhat of a Josh Jacobs doppleganger last year. They both finished between 3.9 and 4.0 yards per carry, both scored double-digit rushing touchdowns, and both were extremely limited in the passing game. The Raiders have continually given guys like DeAndre Washington, Jalen Richard, and Devontae Booker work alongside Jacobs over the last two years, so Drake is going to get mixed in quite heavily, and my guess would be that the passing game is where he gets most of it. You may not remember, but Drake was considered a solid third-down back early in his career with the Dolphins, and has two seasons with 50-plus catches on his NFL resume. It's tough to see him eating into Jacobs' carry totals a whole lot, especially after the way he looked with the Cardinals in 2020, but he should offer low-upside flex value due to his work in the passing game.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kenyan Drake
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Ouch. Josh Jacobs managers went on tilt after Kenyan Drake joined the Raiders on a two-year deal. Additionally, the Raiders have lost key pieces on the offensive line and could be in for a rough season. Drake is a worthy later round/Zero RB target if the team utilizes him in the passing game like they have spoken about this offseason.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Drake is on his last dynasty leg. Despite being only 27, he’s likely to bottom out in the next two years. If you can squeeze another year or two as a depth piece, you’re fortunate.

notes.text: I remember last year when Jacobs was going as a late first-round pick, though I wanted nothing to do with him at that price due to his lack of involvement in the passing game the previous season. Nothing changed except they added more pass catchers. He did get a slight bump in targets (45), though nothing you could rely upon every week. What's changed this offseason? The Raiders decided to pay Kenyan Drake a good chunk of money to come in and share the workload with Jacobs, forcing his fantasy stock to plummet. Drake was essentially the same running back as Jacobs last year, though we've seen him produce in the passing game before. Did the addition of Drake drop Jacobs' price too far, or is this a backfield to simply avoid if possible? I believe he's fallen enough to consider a value as a low-end RB2 who should see be in line for 250-plus touches. The expectations were out of control last year, but if you can get him in the fifth round this year, I'm buying.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Josh Jacobs
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Kenyan Drake signing is probably a mercy kill at this point for Jacobs managers. If you hadn’t been awake recently, his value is intertwined to the Raiders winning football games. Despite having the 3rd most carries and 2nd most touches inside the red zone, his splits are alarming when things go south for Las Vegas. In eight Raiders’ losses, he averaged just 51 rushing yards per game and 9.2 fantasy points. He more than doubled that (20.6) in wins. But with a revamped offensive line and minimal weapons, they look like the clear last-place team in the AFC West.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: You likely can’t get the value you want in return for the former 1.01 in rookie drafts just two years ago… But even 75 percent of that value is better than being left holding the bag as this Jon Gruden-led party begins to stall out soon. That being said, Jacobs is a talented running back, and still just 23 years old.

notes.text: We've watched Jamaal Williams get 226 carries and 80 targets in 28 games under Matt LaFleur, and he wasn't someone this regime drafted in the second round. That amounts to 10.9 touches per game, which is enough for most running backs to be considered a flex-type start. The issue with Dillon is that he's not likely going to be involved in the passing game, as Aaron Jones is a far superior receiver, and the Packers do throw quite a bit on the goal-line when Aaron Rodgers is under center. Dillon is essentially someone who's a touchdown-dependent flex option most weeks, but offers legitimate RB1 upside if Jones were to miss any time.

We saw only a small glimpse of A.J. Dillon last season, with a breakout week 16 performance. Jamaal Williams has left Green Bay, and Dillon will step into a complementary (and valuable) role for the Packers aside Aaron Jones. He stands out as a great sleeper candidate this year, after being the Packers 2nd round selection in 2020. Take a late round chance on him and see what his role looks like through the first few weeks of the year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: A.J. Dillon
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The thighs are real. And they’re spectacular! We saw what he could do last year when given the opportunity going for 124 rushing yards and two TDs against Tennessee in Week 16. For redraft, he’s an intriguing RB4 to draft in Round 7 or 8 knowing that there is massive upside if something were to happen to Aaron Jones.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: With Aaron Jones’ major free-agent deal, dynasty managers might be down on Dillon thinking they missed their window for a true early-down role. Jones’ four-year deal is more like a two-year deal and Dillon represents the perfect lottery ticket worth investing in on your bench.

notes.text: Based on the actual opportunity Chubb got in 2020, he should've finished as the RB24 in half PPR formats. Instead, Chubb scored 54.5 more fantasy points than the average running back would've and finished as the RB9 despite playing in just 12 games. The new offense proved to be very beneficial to the run game, though Kareem Hunt's presence does limit Chubb's true ceiling, which should be top-five, but unless he starts to get more targets, he'll remain in the mid-to-low-end RB1 range.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Nick Chubb
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It’s tough forming a compelling argument against Chubb because like Derrick Henry, he’s just an outlier. Chubb is an elite runner on a run-first team with the Browns, who had the league’s #1 rated offensive line in 2020. The main concerns are the lack of targets (fewer than two per game in 2020) and the presence of Kareem Hunt. We get it but have you ever seen this guy play football? Despite missing four games, he led NFL in Yards after Contact and had the highest Elusive Rating per PFF. He’s a locked-in end-of 1st round RB in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s just plain fun to watch play football and he’s also in a contract year although it’s expected that he’d stay with the Browns.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Dare Ogunbowale, Carlos Hyde, James Robinson

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Carlos Hyde
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: There’s debate over how much of a role he will have sitting behind James Robinson and rookie Travis Etienne. He’s an Urban Meyer guy from Ohio State who actually looked fine last year in Seattle.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hyde’s spot at the end of your dynasty bench is nice and warm.

notes.text: While Robinson was on the field last year, the Jaguars running backs combined for 332 touches. Robinson accounted for 289 of them, or 87.0 percent, a number that doesn't really exist in today's NFL. He averaged 4.46 yards per carry, 5.73 yards per target, and scored 10 total touchdowns, which is solid, though nothing special. Enter Urban Meyer, who said they wanted to add depth/competition at the running back position. After adding Carlos Hyde, you knew Robinson would lose some touches, but it wasn't that much of a concern. After drafting Travis Etienne in the first round, it's definitely a concern. Robinson would be lucky to earn a 50/40/10 split with Etienne and Hyde, with Robinson being the 40 of the group. If we knock Robinson's touches into the 10-12 per game territory, you're not going to be trusting him as anything more than a shaky flex option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: James Robinson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We just witnessed the greatest season ever for an undrafted rookie. Robinson was a usage monster with the most touches (289) ever by an undrafted rookie RB. Carlos Hyde will chip away at his early-down touches and Travis Etienne was a 1st Round pick this year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The window of trading Robinson promptly shut after the NFL Draft.

notes.text: If Urban Meyer wants to run a spread offense, you better get comfortable with Etienne as the running back to own in 2021. With as many holes as the Jaguars had on the roster, drafting a running back in the first round seemed like a poor choice. However, if he wants to justify his selection, Etienne will be involved early and often. Over the last eight years, there's been just one running back drafted in the first round who didn't net at least 197 touches. Just one of those running backs finished worse than RB28 on the season, and that was Melvin Gordon who failed to score a single touchdown. Etienne's current draft position is RB29 in half-PPR formats. I'll take him there all day at that price. I'm guessing he is a solid RB2 on fantasy teams this year.

Despite being selected in the first round of the NFL draft, Etienne’s stock sunk recently after reports of Urban Meyer wanting to use him exclusively as an X receiver. Fight through the coach speak and noise at this point of the offseason and realize Etienne is the most talented RB on the roster. He's likely not going to see 15+ touches from the start but as he showed in college, he might not need that type of volume to be effective. We still like him as a borderline RB2 but he’s going much later than that in drafts. While it might take a second to see the fantasy payoff, we know rookie RBs can come on strong in the second half and Etienne has the talent to break through in that Jaguar backfield.

The landing spot is far from ideal since he may be battling for touches with James Robinson and Carlos Hyde. Urban Meyer’s comments about making him an X receiver is also puzzling. However, draft capital is a strong indicator for fantasy production, which likely means Etienne will receive plenty of opportunities in this Jaguars offense. In addition, if Etienne is just as efficient in the NFL as he was in college (both as a rusher and a receiver), he might not need 15+ touches per game to return RB2 value even in Year One.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Travis Etienne Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The landing spot is far from ideal since he may be battling for touches with James Robinson and Carlos Hyde. Urban Meyer’s comments about making him an X receiver is also puzzling. However, draft capital is a strong indicator for fantasy production, which likely means Etienne will receive plenty of opportunities in this Jaguars offense. In addition, if Etienne is just as efficient in the NFL as he was in college (both as a rusher and a receiver), he might not need 15+ touches per game to return RB2 value even in Year One.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Trev & Trav connection in Jacksonville is set up for the next couple of years. Etienne can become an Alvin Kamara-lite if Urban Meyer doesn’t mess around too much.

notes.text: This time last year, I was much higher on Taylor than the consensus. I like Taylor, but did everyone forget about what happened the first 10 weeks of the season? Taylor was the RB19 and David Montgomery was the RB20. Taylor finished the year as the RB6 while Montgomery was the RB4. Many will talk about Montgomery's schedule as the reason for his production, hence why he's ranked at RB20 in ECR right now, but are they ignoring Taylor's schedule? He played against the Texans TWICE, Packers, Raiders, Jaguars, and the Steelers (who were decimated by injuries in that game). That's a large reason for his jump in production. I still like Taylor, just not nearly as much as the consensus.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jonathan Taylor
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: JTT! Yes, he was a 90’s heartthrob turned NFL RB and he certainly heated up in the second half. From Weeks 11-17, he was the RB3 winning many managers fantasy championships that believed in him despite starting slow. In the lull months of October and November, he averaged only 12 carries per game. This team looks like a playoff contender and should be in the mix with Tennessee to win the AFC South. However, Taylor was game-scripted out of far too many games in 2020 as the team seems to like Nyheim Hines a lot. Taylor averaged only 45 rush yards per game in Colts losses in 2020. He’s an RB1 albeit with an annoying set of teammates.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: JTT is a certifiable top-5 RB in dynasty. He’s going to be a stud for the next couple of years and when Marlon Mack or Nyheim Hines finally leave town, watch out.

notes.text: He finished as the RB20 in half PPR formats last year. Crazy, right?
