While that's firm RB2 territory, he finished as an RB2 or better in just 43.8 percent of his games, tied with Chase Edmonds. He clearly has a role in this offense, though it's a bit reliant on gamescript, as Jonathan Taylor is the clear early-down back, while Hines is the preferred back in passing situations. If they give Taylor more work in the passing game this year, it's coming at the expense of Hines, and knowing Taylor's ADP, drafters expect that increase for Taylor. Even going back to 2019, Hines was an RB3 or better just 43.8 percent of the time, which is more in line for how you should feel about him in 2021. He's just an emergency flex option.

The glory days of Nyheim Hines are likely over.  The departure of check-down king Philip Rivers, the growth and maturity of Jonathan Taylor, and the return of Marlon Mack all work against consistent fantasy production for Hines.  Look elsewhere for value at the RB position.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Nyheim Hines
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Hines was one of only two RBs in the top-20 along with Derrick Henry to play in all 16 games of 2020. Those two could not be more different in size and playing style but it goes to show you how sneaky Hines can be for fantasy. He had the third most targets, receptions, and receiving yards at the RB position. The Colts utilize him in the red-zone often so he still could have a place as a FLEX play in PPR leagues. Just expect more Jonathan Taylor this year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hines is only 24 years old and will be an unrestricted free agent in 2022. He likely will play his way into another contract as a third down specialist. He’s a perfect trade away candidate after finishing as a top-20 RB last year.

notes.text: There've been six times over the course of Higbee's career where he's tallied more than 67 yards. Five of those games came at the end of the 2019 season when Gerald Everett was either out of the lineup or very limited. Well, Everett has been signed by the Seahawks, and the next man up on the Rams depth chart to fill his spot is Bryce Hopkins, who's seen as many targets as I have in an NFL uniform (none). Eliminating Everett's targets and upgrading Higbee's quarterback is the recipe for success, and it shouldn't shock anyone to see Higbee finish as a top-10 tight end in 2021.

Hig-beast was one of the hot topics (no, not the clothing store) of the fantasy off-season last year after he ended 2019 on an absolute tear. His production leveled off and now it seems like he’s been thrown away by the wayside for 2021. With Gerald Everett on to Seattle, there is plenty of opportunity for Higbee, who seems like he'll be an every-down player. Going outside of the top-12 of TEs, Higbee is one of the few TEs we’ve seen with a ceiling to boast about this late in a draft. Take your shot on Higbee and a newfound connection with Matthew Stafford.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyler Higbee
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Higbeast is another player who was hyped coming into the 2020 season and the air got let out early. Apart from a 3-TD game in Week 2, he was a tease to fantasy managers. He now finds himself alone in Los Angeles with Everett out the door and an upgrade at QB with Matthew Stafford. He’s shown a ceiling before with five stellar games in a row to end the 2019 season. He’s one of the better late round TEs to target in 2021 with hopes he breaks through again.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: In a PPR or TE premium league, Higbee can take a step this year and if the dynasty manager has a bad taste in their mouth, why not put an offer for a player we've seen have a monster season?

notes.text: All you can ask for out of an NFL quarterback is improvement. Allen has done that every single year, and it's translated to fantasy football as well. His percentage of QB1-type games by year: 41.7 - 43.8 - 56.3. He tallied 26-plus fantasy points in eight games last year, which tied for the most in the league. Even better is that he had just one game that was labeled a bust, which lets you know he's a set-it-and-forget-it quarterback who can be played, regardless of opponent. When spending a high-round pick on a quarterback, that's what you need. Allen can start to be considered around the fourth round.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Josh Allen
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Allen’s transformation to one of the league’s most accurate passers in 2020 was nothing short of spectacular. The MVP runner-up was a fantasy force finishing as the QB1 on the back of 37 passing TDs and another eight on the ground, as essentially Buffalo’s goal-line back. He’s a top-5 QB paired up with an elite wideout (Stefon Diggs) in a passing game that led the league in pass rate and 3WR sets.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Last year was the time to trade for Allen. With a huge contract extension coming in the near future, he’s set up to smash and be a top-5 dynasty QB for years to come.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Duke Johnson Jr., Todd Gurley II, Le'Veon Bell, T.J. Yeldon, Chris Thompson, Frank Gore, Adrian Peterson

notes.text: There are many trying to figure out the target share for Laviska Shenault, Marvin Jones, and Travis Etienne, but the one who's the clear-cut No. 1 option on this team is Chark. If Trevor Lawrence turns out to be the real deal, Chark can be the 2021 version of Tee Higgins when he was with Joe Burrow (was the No. 11 wide receiver in eight full games with Burrow). Chark already flashed WR1 potential in 2019 when he racked up 73 receptions for 1,008 yards and eight touchdowns with the combination of Gardner Minshew and Nick Foles, so why can't he be more with Lawrence? The coaching staff is a big question mark, but you don't draft Lawrence to run the ball 40 times per game. Chark comes with some risk but even more upside.

A new regime arrives in Jacksonville, along with Marvin Jones Jr.  While Chark has flashed talent, he's had only 4 games in the top 24 at the wide receiver position in his last 24 appearances.  Between Jones, Shenault, and Etienne, you may find Chark lower on the depth chart than you hoped or dreamed.  Stay away from him and try your best to forget the tantalizing breakout potential he once had.  It might be over when people least expect it.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: DJ Chark Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Chark's outlook has been on quite the roller coaster ride the last three years. He was non-existent as a rookie and abandoned before breaking out with Gardner Minshew in his 2nd year. Last year, he was a lauded pick across the industry before Chark and the rest of the team nosedived to a 1-15 finish. Enter Trevor Lawrence and an air of optimism for the downfield threat. The Jaguars did add veteran WR, Marvin Jones, and there is hype for second year WR, Laviska Shenault. There is no guarantee (despite the talent) that Chark emerges from the depths again.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Chark will be a free agent after this season so don't necessarily connect him with Lawrence and the Jaguars long-term.

notes.text: I know Leonard Fournette had a strong finish to the season while Jones was hurt, but we mustn't forget that Jones averaged 5.14 yards per carry and nearly hit 1,000 rushing yards despite finishing with just 192 carries. There are just eight running backs in the post-merger era who've finished with as many yards as Jones did with 192 or less carries. He's not going to be heavily utilized in the passing game, which severely caps his upside, but Jones is the Bucs best ball carrier.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Ronald Jones II
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: RoJo! He ran for almost 1,000 yards and averaged 12.3 fantasy points per game last year. Heck, for the first 12 weeks of the season, Jones was the RB10! But you, like the rest of the world, feel like that is a faded memory after the Buccaneers installed “Playoff Lenny” to a Super Bowl title. Jones still can break a long one but now he’s a roll of the dice alongside Fournette and Giovani Bernard in this backfield. You can’t FLEX him as you likely won’t know which weeks to start him.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Jones is a free agent in 2022 and without Tom Brady and this offense, his value will likely plummet. He’s still only 23 so there’s some miles still left on the tires.

notes.text: It's easy to recall the good times Fournette had in the playoffs and use that as a reason to move him up draft boards, but don't let a couple games spoil what was a very mediocre season. He finished with more than 52 rushing yards just once all year, and that came in Week 2 against the Panthers. Fournette's primary source of fantasy points in 2020 was via the passing game, as he saw 47 targets in 13 games. Unfortunately, the Bucs added Gio Bernard, who's a much better receiver out of the backfield. Knowing that Bernard is the more reliable third-down option and that Ronald Jones is probably the better two-down option, that leaves Fournette in no man's land. He's not someone you're going to want to start every week.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Leonard Fournette
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Fat Len turned into Playoff Lenny and earned himself a new contract in 2021. What a wild ride for a player taken 4th overall, cut by his former team, signed with the Bucs right before the season, and played his way to the Super Bowl. Now he's back with the Bucs, splitting carries with Ronald Jones and Giovani Bernard. Fournette and Jones are back-to-back in our rankings and neither seem like dependable options in fantasy.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you somehow held onto Fournette through all of the turmoil, you were rewarded with at least another year attached to Tom Brady. But the clock is ticking so be willing to trade him if he gets hot early.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Cordarrelle Patterson, Calvin Ridley, Russell Gage

notes.text: Ridley finished as the No. 4 wide receiver with Julio Jones on the team, and that was while missing one full game. Just how much better can he be with Jones out of town? Some may worry about Ridley becoming "the guy" in the offense and seeing all the top cornerbacks, but we've already witnessed that in the games Jones missed. In the eight games Ridley has played without Jones, he's averaged 11.1 targets, 7.3 receptions, 107.0 yards, and 0.4 touchdowns, adding up to 20.1 PPR points per game. He should be a lock for 140-plus targets in 2021, making him a safe WR1.

Ridley has missed the Falcons mini camp due to lingering left foot discomfort, which required a minor “clean up procedure.” Ridley has a history of left foot and ankle injuries in the past, including a similar procedure done in his ankle in 2019 and just last year, he missed one game with a minor midfoot sprain from Week 8. These injuries can lead to lingering stiffness/discomfort in the foot, but following this procedure, which is done to remove scar tissue and/or tiny bone fragments, the outcomes are favorable with an expected recovery of 2-4 weeks. As of now, Ridley should be good to go for training camp, and assuming he’s full go early in camp, there’s no concerns about his 2021 season long outlook.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Calvin Ridley
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Calvin Ridley was labeled by many in the fantasy community as the breakout WR of 2020 and boy did he deliver. Ridley finished as fantasy’s WR4 on the back of 9 TD and 1,374 yards. Ridley led the league in air yards and number of 100-yard games, suggesting that he’s not only going to see a safe amount of volume, but he’s a high upside option as we know he’ll be targeted down the field and in the red zone. Now with Julio traded, the sky is the limit for Calvin Ridley in 2021. UPDATE: Ridley underwent a "clean up procedure" on his left foot. As of now, Ridley should be good to go for training camp, and assuming he’s full go early in camp, there’s no concerns about his 2021 season long outlook. See the full writeup in the UDK Injury Report.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Ridley took over as the Atlanta WR1 last season, thanks in part to Julio missing half the season. That said, what Ridley has done both with AND without Julio on the field in his first three seasons in the league is nothing short of fantastic. Ridley projects to lead the Falcons’ passing attack for the foreseeable future and should be in the WR1 conversation in dynasty for the next couple of years.

notes.text: In case you may have missed it, Dirk Koetter is no longer calling plays for the Falcons. The Falcons ran 3WR sets 61 percent of the time last year, which allowed Gage to get on the field more often. Arthur Smith's offense in Tennessee last year ran 3WR sets just 38 percent of the time, the second-lowest mark in football. That obviously presents a problem for Gage, as does the arrival of Kyle Pitts, who'll be utilized as a receiver at times. Some may wonder if the loss of Julio Jones opens things up for him. Yes, it will likely net him more targets, but targets on the perimeter haven't been the same for Gage, as he works best from the slot. The Falcons could very well start Tajae Sharpe over him in 2WR sets.

Russell Gage isn't flashy.  He certainly isn't Julio Jones.  What Russell Gage manages to be, however, is productive.  From the bye week on last season, he was on pace for a 140 target season, with 90 receptions and 7 touchdowns.  Now that Julio has flown the coop, Gage represents potential sleeper value on a team that loves to (and will have to) throw the football.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Russell Gage
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Russell Gage finished the 2020 season as the WR37, but it didn’t feel like it as he went radio silent from Weeks 3-9. He caught fire towards the end of the season, however, rattling off three top-16 finishes over the final month of the season. Now that Julio has been traded to the Titans, Gage could be a late round sleeper pick as the Falcons WR2.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Gage is in a contract year, making his dynasty value uncertain at this point. With Julio in Tennessee, Gage should have opportunity in 2021 as the likely WR2 for the Falcons behind Calvin Ridley.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Qadree Ollison, Mike Davis, D'Onta Foreman

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Qadree Ollison
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Ollison is a big, bruising back… the kind of runner HC Arthur Smith used in Tennessee. Ok so he’s not even a third of Derrick Henry but hey we’re grasping at straws in the Atlanta backfield.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Grab him off your dynasty waiver wire in hopes he maybe could potentially be something this year. That’s desperate.

notes.text: My guess is that analysts are worried about the Falcons adding a free agent running back because even my RB24 ranking feels a bit low for a back who should have no issue getting 15-plus touches per game. That would amount to 240-plus touches on the season. There have been 144 running backs who've hit that mark over the last 10 years and none have finished worse than RB28 (his current ECR). In fact, just 10 of those running backs (6.9 percent) have finished worse than RB20. If the Falcons don't add anyone of significance, I'll be moving him up even more.

The thighs might drive up his ADP even further but we still consider Davis a value heading into the summer. While he did not maintain high level production the entire time in relief of CMC last year, Davis was the RB6 from Week 3-14! He looks like the lead back in Atlanta and if new HC Arthur Smith’s zone running scheme takes off like it did in Tennessee, Davis could be in store for a solid season. His pass-catching ability also gives you some hope even if Atlanta remains inefficient on the ground.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mike Davis
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: CMC’s replacement held his own for a couple of weeks before hitting the wall. He signed with the Falcons, and looks to be the starter as of now, as the team failed to address the position in the draft. Consider Davis a volume-based RB2/3 that could have sneaky upside if the Falcons offense takes off under new HC Arthur Smith.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you held onto Davis, it looks like his improbable window of opportunity has opened again. Trading him now to a manager desperate for RB help might be wise because this joy ride could be over sooner than later.

notes.text: Everyone who scouted this year's class of running backs knew that Hawkins wouldn't be a workhorse running back anywhere, but he was a shifty back who might be a decent timeshare back in the right offense. Landing with Arthur Smith on the Falcons depth chart may have been his best shot at relevance, as the Falcons have almost no depth behind Mike Davis. I wouldn't expect more than 5-8 touches without injury, but he's a name worth monitoring if Davis were to miss time.

Sure, Montgomery finished as the RB4 last year. There were many factors that led to that, particularly the injury to Tarik Cohen, freeing up tons of targets in the passing game. Over the course of Montgomery's short career, he's played 19 games with Cohen and 12 games without him. In the games with Cohen, he averaged 2.32 targets per game. In the 12 games without him, that number rose to 4.92 targets per game. Well, Cohen is back, and the team signed Damien Williams, who's a better receiving back than Montgomery. On top of Cohen missing, the Bears had a ridiculously easy schedule down the stretch, playing against the Packers twice, Lions, Texans, Vikings, and Jaguars to close out the season. Did you know that Montgomery was the RB20 after 10 weeks (prior to starting that schedule)? He's a fine low-end RB2, but don't go about your day thinking you're getting a steal in the fourth round or anything.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: David Montgomery
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Montgomery was one of the most valuable players in fantasy over the final two months totalling eight TDs as the RB2 from Week 12 on against weak defenses. WIth Tarik Cohen sidelined for the season, Montgomery became a full 3-down back including the 2nd most routes run among RBs and the 6th most red zone touches at the position. Expectations must be tempered in 2021 with Cohen returning and Damien Williams added into the mix. Still, David Mopportunity is being a bit disrespected in drafts where he’s currently being taken. He’s a fine RB2.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Montgomery is more solid than spectacular although that hot streak towards the end of 2020 shows you a glimpse of what he can be. If someone wants to trade for him thinking that’s who he is, it might be put him on the trading block. He’s under contract for two more years in Chicago.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Damien Williams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After nearly winning a Super Bowl MVP in 2019 and opting out of the 2020 season, Damien Williams found himself on the outside looking in at the Kansas City backfield. Now he joins the Bears with David Montgomery and Tarik Cohen. He’s not draftable.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Remember when Damien Williams hype was through the roof? He’s always been a replacement level player outside of Kansas City.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Donovan Peoples-Jones, Anthony Schwartz, Odell Beckham Jr., Jarvis Landry

notes.text: Let's do an exercise... How many targets per game do you anticipate Beckham getting this year? I'm going with an extremely low number and say he averages 6.5 targets per game. That sounds more than reasonable, right? Beckham had 7.0 targets per game during the 2020 season before getting hurt and that includes a three-target game against the Steelers. The Browns were also throwing the ball a lot less early in the year as Baker Mayfield was still getting grasp on Kevin Stefanski's playbook. If Beckham gets 6.5 targets per game, that'd put him on pace for 104 targets, which again, is what I'd consider low. There were just 32 receivers in the NFL who hit that number last year, with 24 of them (75 percent) finishing as top-24 receivers and just two finishing worse than WR38. You mean to tell me with Beckham's talent, he can't produce top-24 numbers? There's health risks for sure, but there's also top-five wide receiver upside.

Odell Beckham Jr. has had some horrible injury luck since he entered the NFL. Dating back to 2014, his injury history includes a fractured fibula, a hamstring strain, a quad strain, sports hernia repair surgery and most recently a torn ACL. He’ll be 29 in November, which is important given that there is a statistically significant difference in the rate of soft tissue injuries in players that are age 26 and younger and we know from research studies that younger NFL players tend to have better performance outcomes following ACL surgery. Beckham will be ready for Week 1, but is he the same WR we saw five years ago? The injury history suggests possibly not.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Odell Beckham Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: OBJ’s 2020 season was cut short thanks to a torn ACL in his left knee, which happened in Week 7. Beckham’s injury history is piling up, and let’s be honest: Beckham hasn’t been good for fantasy while playing in Cleveland. He’s cleared 100 receiving yards just three total times since joining Cleveland in 2019. Beckham is still an extremely talented WR, but is he relying solely on name value at this point in his career?
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Beckham has really struggled to stay on the field throughout his NFL career, and now he’s coming off a torn ACL. To make matters worse, Beckham turns 29 in November and his current contract carries zero dead cap money after the 2021 season. Unless Beckham turns it around quickly, he could be a declining asset sitting on the end of dynasty rosters who never really lived up to the hype from earlier in his career.

notes.text: Here's a fun fact: Landry is one of just seven wide receivers who've finished as a top-24 fantasy wide receiver in five of the last six years. The others are Julio Jones, Mike Evans, DeAndre Hopkins, Davante Adams, Brandin Cooks, and Amari Cooper. However, the issue is that Landry isn't the "sexy" pick that everyone wants because he's never going to be the reason you win a championship. With Odell Beckham due back to the lineup, it's only going to cap his upside even more, and therefore supress his ADP. You need balance on your fantasy roster and Landry can provide stability that not many have. Just keep your weekly expectations in check.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jarvis Landry
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Jarvis Landry has always been a reliable fantasy WR, but in Kevin Stefanski’s run heavy scheme last year, Jarvis saw the lowest target count of his career and produced his worst fantasy finish since 2015. Odell Beckham is back, and this offense will look to remain run heavy, limiting Jarvis’ upside in 2021. He’ll likely settle into the top-40 range come season’s end.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Jarvis Landry has been extremely reliable throughout his entire career, but he’s a WR who’s thrived thanks to volume and targets. If the Browns remain run heavy for the foreseeable future, it’s possible Landry has already reached his ceiling in terms of fantasy performance. Cleveland can move on from him easily after the 2021 season.

notes.text: In eight full games with Justin Herbert under center last year, Ekeler saw 63 targets. Over a full 16-game season, that amounts to 126 targets. While I don't expect him to get there, he's one of just two running backs (Christian McCaffrey is the other) who I'm projecting for 100-plus targets in 2021. Targets are worth twice as much as carries, so even if Ekeler winds up getting just 12 carries per game, it's not the end of the world. In fact, he can still finish as a borderline RB1 if he were to hit just 200 carries on the season. The new coaching staff obviously brings on some potential volatility, but there's not much other talent on the roster at running back, so his role should be very safe.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Austin Ekeler
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Good friend of the show, Awesome Excellence was all set to dominate the fantasy rankings last year as the team’s clear-cut lead back with Melvin Gordon III finally gone. Instead, an early hamstring injury decimated any hopes for the pass-catching specialist to build off of his 2019 RB6 breakout. The Chargers improved their offense line and didn’t add any real competition in the backfield.The only thing holding Ekeler back is his lack of usage in the Red Zone as he had only two carries inside the 5-yard line. Ekeler is an awesome fantasy asset that has weekly top-10 upside, especially in PPR leagues.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Ekeler is under contract for three more years under a team-friendly deal. Still only 26, the only thing holding him back from being a top-10 back the next few years might be the lack of goal-line work. But the receptions are PPR gold...

notes.text: He had his chance and likely blew it. Kelley acted as the early-down back for the Chargers last year, but wound up averaging more than 4.0 yards per carry just four times all season, including seven games averaging 3.1 or less yards per carry. Neither Justin Jackson nor Austin Ekeler had issues running behind the line, as both of them tallied 4.6 yards per carry. The Chargers also have a new coaching staff and drafted Larry Rountree in the 2021 draft, which could make Kelley expendable, or pushed down the depth chart.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Joshua Kelley
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Kelley had the opportunity in 2020 and revealed what we all feared: he’s a boring plodder. The team showed a lack of trust bringing Kalen Ballage off the field and running him ahead of Kelley. He’ll compete with Justin Jackson and rookie Larry Rountree for a spot on the bench.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Apart from insurance for Austin Ekeler, he showed last year there ain’t much to him.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dan Arnold
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Postman delivered as a TE1 last year in Arizona… once in Week 13. He’s averaged a robust 13.8 yards per reception in his career but he’s been more hype than reliable. Not something you want from your mail carrier. He has a new home in Carolina and an excellent narrative at play: Darnold to D. Arnold. You can see the newspaper headlines and Tweets rolling in. For fantasy, he’s the 5th target at best in this crowded Panthers passing attack.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Postman is a nice bench player to have just for the sheer enjoyment of his nickname. He’s only 26 but through four years into the league, we know what he is.

notes.text: Despite losing Dak Prescott early in the year, Gallup managed to finish with 843 yards and five touchdowns despite being behind both Amari Cooper and CeeDee Lamb on the depth chart. That was good enough for a WR38 finish, though he's lasting much later than that in drafts. Now in a contract year, Gallup is likely showcasing himself for his future team.

There are a ton of mouths to feed in Dallas, and Michael Gallup seems to eat last.  With the return of Blake Jarwin and the ascension of Ceedee Lamb, Gallup's involvement will be hard to predict and even harder to rely on in fantasy football.  He'll have his games, but volume will go elsewhere in Dallas.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Michael Gallup
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Gallup was a hot name in the middle rounds of 2020 drafts, primarily because most in the industry were excited about the Cowboys passing attack. Through four weeks, the Dallas offense was cookin’, but without Dak on the field, the offensive production came to a screeching halt. Dak is back, but CeeDee Lamb will look to take a step forward in year two and Amari Cooper is still this team’s WR1. We only have a five-game sample of Cooper, Lamb and Gallup all on the field with Dak but in those games, Gallup saw just 5.6 targets per game. Expect spiked weeks from Gallup, but the consistency could be an issue.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Barring any major changes, Gallup figures to be the odd man out in the Dallas passing game after the 2021 season when he becomes an unrestricted free agent. CeeDee Lamb is still on his rookie deal, and Amari Cooper is under contract through 2024. With the team likely needing to upgrade their offensive line and their defense soon, it’s possible the Cowboys use their money to spend up elsewhere. That said, a change of scenery with more targets could be good for Gallup.

notes.text: He finished as the WR24 last year, his rookie season, while dealing with some poor quarterback play. While five games is a small sample size, Lamb was the WR12 with Dak Prescott under center. Now in his second year with a full offseason, Lamb might just finish as a top-10 option, especially if the Cowboys keep deploying him from the slot.

While it wasn’t a great season for the Cowboys, fantasy players got a taste of what Lamb could become. He had a solid rookie season and that was nearly all done without franchise QB Dak Prescott. Lamb has become the No. 2 option on a team that could easily see over 5,000 passing yards, and there’s an outside chance he even becomes Dak’s favorite.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: CeeDee Lamb
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Justin Jefferson overshadowed how good of a rookie year CeeDee Lamb had. He looked like he was on an historic pace with Dak through that 1st month. Through Weeks 1-5, he was on a 16 game pace of 93/1385/6. Lamb was a premier slot WR tallying the 2nd most slot snaps, slot receptions & slot yards in the NFL. Lamb is one of seven rookie WRs with 70+ receptions and 900+ receiving yards over the last decade. This rocket ship is about to take off so climb aboard because, by this time next year, Lamb could easily be drafted in the top-10 of the WR position.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Lamb enters year two in the league ready to take a massive step forward in value as he’s now locked up with Dak as his QB for the next three years at a minimum. Also working in Lamb’s favor is the fact that Michael Gallup is set to be a free agent after the 2021 season, opening up even more opportunity for Lamb moving forward. At just 22 years old with 1st round NFL Draft capital and a great QB, CeeDee Lamb has the makings of a perennial top-12 option at the position for the foreseeable future.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: N'Keal Harry, Nelson Agholor, Kendrick Bourne

notes.text: Through two full seasons, Harry has not lived up to expectations. He's only seen 81 targets over those first two years, but that's due to his lack of efficiency. Since coming into the league, his 5.11 yards per target ranks as the second-worst in the NFL during that time. After the Patriots spend a boatload of money in free agency, we can't even say that Harry is a top-three receiver on the depth chart.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: N'Keal Harry
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After being drafted with the final pick of the 1st Round in the 2019 NFL Draft, N’Keal Harry hasn’t been able to make any sort of impact. Bill Belichick identified the Patriots’ weaknesses and addressed the WR aggressively via free agency. It’s pretty bad when Nelson Agholor and Kendrick Bourne are considered upgrades at the position. Leave Harry on the waiver wire.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: A former 1st round NFL Draft pick, N’Keal Harry may flame out in the NFL. If you’ve got him, he’s a hold, and we certainly haven’t seen anything from him to suggest he’s a trade target.

notes.text: It's pretty remarkable what a change of scenery can do to a player, and no one better represents that than Agholor, who was left for dead after his stint in Philadelphia. He bounced back in a big way with the Raiders, averaging 10.9 yards per target, which ranked fifth among wide receivers who saw 60-plus targets. Unfortunately, he'll have to prove it again with another franchise. If Cam Newton is under center, we saw what that does to wide receivers in 2020, but knowing it's possible that Mac Jones starts gives us hope for Agholor with the Patriots. But as of now, it seems Newton will get the gig to start the season, meaning Agholor may not pay dividends right out of the gate.

Often maligned as an Eagle, Nelson Agholor got the last laugh last season in Las Vegas. The Raiders got a great season from Agholor, who put up four top 10 performances over the final 11 weeks. He parlayed the breakout performance into a new contract in New England, a team desperate for WR help. Agholor's upside only exists if Mac Jones and the passing game evolve and the volume increases. He'll be significantly down in drafts, so could be worth the late round flyer as New England's de facto #1.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Nelson Agholor
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Raiders were mocked by fantasy managers when they signed Nelson Agholor, but it’s time to give credit where credit is due - Nelson Agholor put together a solid 2020 season, finishing as a top-30 WR. Now, he lands in New England where the offense projects to run a ton of 2TE sets and utilize the run game to control the clock. More likely than not, Agholor won’t repeat his 2020 season given the constraints of the offense. However, he could be worth the late round flyer as New England's de facto #1.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Agholor’s career was revitalized in Las Vegas last year, helping him land a 2-year deal with New England. However, with Cam Newton likely to play the majority of the 2021 season in a run heavy scheme and Mac Jones unproven as a rookie, it’s still possible Agholor’s 2020 season is the best of his NFL career. It may be worth it to trade Agholor after he set career highs in receiving yards and TD last year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kendrick Bourne
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Patriots added WRs Nelson Agholor and Kendrick Bourne early in the free agency process. It may be another difficult year for all New England receivers.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Outside of a few weeks, Bourne hasn't been startable for fantasy in his first four seasons. However, Bourne was paid nicely on a 3-year deal and there is opportunity at WR in New England. Perhaps Mac Jones can eventually provide a much needed boost to the Patriots passing game.

notes.text: With Julian Edelman out of New England, we might see Meyers be the receiver to step into that role, though the lack of clarity with the quarterback situation is what will supress our optimism. In an expanded role with Edelman out last year, Meyers totaled 45-plus yards in 9-of-11 games, including two games with 110-plus yards. He didn't score a single touchdown, which is part of the reason he's not getting any love. What if I told you he finished with just one fewer catch and 19 fewer yards than Brandon Aiyuk last year? The concern is the addition of Nelson Agholor and Kendrick Bourne, who both signed lucrative deals. Meyers is worth a late-round pick in case he is the top receiver in New England.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jakobi Meyers
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Meyers had a few fantasy relevant weeks in 2020, but in large part due to volume. This offseason, the Patriots added Nelson Agholor and Kendrick Bourne in free agency. He could be the most targeted player on the team but after catching as many TDs as yo mama in 2020, he'll need more than just empty calorie receptions.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Meyers is a restricted free agent in 2022. Agholor and Bourne were both signed for three seasons. The Patriots need Mac Jones to provide a boost to the passing game.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Marquise Goodwin, Dazz Newsome, Damiere Byrd, Allen Robinson II

notes.text: Opportunity is everything, right? It's why despite Robinson's lackluster quarterback play, he's been able to finish as a top-12 receiver in back-to-back seasons. The upgrade to Andy Dalton was solid, but if the Bears play Justin Fields, it could be even better. Based on opportunity alone, Robinson should have finished as the WR4 in each of the last two seasons (that's based on how many targets he saw and where he saw them), so there's certainly room for improvement in his finish. Robinson has proven to be a WR1 with bad quarterback play in this same offense, making him one of the safer options as a low-end WR1/high-end WR2.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Allen Robinson II
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Allen Robinson has dominated in Chicago for multiple years now. Coming off 150+ target seasons in back-to-back years, there’s virtually no competition on the Bears roster to suggest that ARob can’t push for a 25+% target share yet again in 2021. Robinson has returned top-12 WR value in back-to-back seasons thanks to volume, but it is worth noting that his average depth of target has dropped every season since 2015. If the Bears’ QBs can push the ball down the field, A-Rob’s ceiling is massive with the target share he’ll see. Even if Andy Dalton starts the season over Justin Fields, he’s likely the best QB Robinson has played with.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: With ARob playing on the franchise tag in 2021, his long term outlook is difficult to project. However, at this point in his career, Robinson has proven to be QB-proof and excels when given the opportunity. If Justin Fields is the future in Chicago, you’d have to think the Bears attempt to bring Robinson back on a long term deal to secure a bonafide WR1 to support their young QB.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: DeAndre Hopkins, Rondale Moore, A.J. Green

notes.text: When drafting a wide receiver in the first couple rounds, you can't afford to miss on them. Is there anyone more reliable than Hopkins? He's now seen at least 150 targets in six straight seasons and has finished as a top-five receiver in five of them. Sure, the Cardinals added A.J. Green and Rondale Moore, but that's not going to stop Kyler Murray from going to his favorite target.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: DeAndre Hopkins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: In 2020, fantasy managers were fading Hopkins given that he was a veteran WR changing teams with a brand new QB without much of an offseason. At this point, we clearly know Nuk is simply too talented for any of that to matter. He returned WR5 overall value, and the last time he wasn’t a top 5 fantasy WR was in 2016. There's still room for improvement in Hopkins’ second year in the system with Kyler Murray after scoring just 6 TDs. He's as dependable as they come.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hopkins still has four more seasons left on his current deal, meaning he’s locked in as Kyler’s WR1 for quite awhile. At 28 years old, he’s still got at least two more years of elite production left in the tank at a minimum.

notes.text: There are some fascinating things Moore can do on a football field. The question is whether he'll get the opportunity to showcase his talents in Kliff Kingsbury's offense. We already know DeAndre Hopkins is getting his share, and they've been talking up A.J. Green's involvement, which means Moore would have to surpass Christian Kirk in order to see the field in 3WR sets, which seems unlikely. To be fair, they do run 4WR sets more than any other team, but Andy Isabella is still in line for some snaps as well. It's tough to see Moore as a reliable fantasy option without an injury ahead of him on the depth chart.

The Cardinals took Rondale Moore in the 2nd Round this year. Moore is electric on the field and his freshman season was legendary the way he made people miss in the open field. He’s struggled with injuries the last couple of years but in our pre-workout evaluation process, he still shined through as a potential special teams weapon with some Tyreek Hill-lite skills to his name. The Cardinals offense is a great landing spot if he is utilized on jet-sweeps and given the ball in space. In other words, instead of Tyreek, he’s going to be more Mecole Hardman: a couple of highlight-reel TDs with zero chance of predicting where and when they will come.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Rondale Moore
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Cardinals took Rondale Moore in the 2nd Round this year. Moore is electric on the field and his freshman season was legendary the way he made people miss in the open field. He’s struggled with injuries the last couple of years but in our pre-workout evaluation process, he still shined through as a potential special teams weapon with some Tyreek Hill-lite skills to his name. The Cardinals offense is a great landing spot if he is utilized on jet-sweeps and given the ball in space. In other words, instead of Tyreek, he’s going to be more Mecole Hardman: a couple of highlight-reel TDs with zero chance of predicting where and when they will come.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: A.J. Green is on a one-year deal and Christian Kirk will be a free-agent in 2022 so even if Moore doesn’t blow the doors off in Year One, be patient. He’s a Ferrari waiting to be unleashed.

notes.text: Is he done? That's the question most believe has already been answered, though the Cardinals beg to differ. Giving him $8 million is not peanuts by any means and they have talked about how big of a role he'll have with the team, including Kyler Murray who said, "A lot of people are sleeping on him." The Bengals wide receivers all underperformed expectations last year, though Green was the ringleader, finishing with 63.8 fewer fantasy points than his opportunity suggested. We saw Hopkins make a difference in year one of the Cardinals system, so it's not like they discriminate against new bodies. Green is currently free in fantasy drafts, and knowing this team targeted wide receivers 65.5 percent of the time in 2020 (sixth in NFL), it makes sense to grab him with your final pick. If he gets six-plus targets in Week 1, he's going to be a popular waiver wire addition.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: A.J. Green
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Green has always been a guy who’s put up big numbers for fantasy in his prime, but those days are over. Now, he has to compete with DeAndre Hopkins for targets and end zone looks, while Kyler Murray is going to steal a ton of production with his legs. A.J. Green may be officially donezo for fantasy purposes.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: At age 32, he’s a fine end of the bench guy in the event a change of scenery helps revitalize his career, but keep your expectations low.

notes.text: There was a stretch of games during the 2020 season where Kirk was finally living up to his potential, as he posted 9.4-plus half-PPR points in five straight games, including three games with 18-plus points. He fell off a cliff after that, leading fantasy managers to search for new options in 2021, but there might be a reason to head back to the well. With the addition of A.J. Green, it's likely we see Kirk move to the slot, which is where I believe he should've been playing all along. Despite being inefficient and limited in athleticism at his advanced age, Larry Fitzgerald saw 112, 109, and 72 targets as the primary slot receiver over the last three years under Kliff Kingsbury. If Kirk can get near the 100-target mark, he'll be a value in drafts.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Christian Kirk
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Cardinals WR depth chart got a bit more crowded this offseason making Kirk’s chances of fantasy success look less likely this year compared to last year. The team added A.J. Green via free agency then drafted Rondale Moore in the second round of the NFL Draft. Oh, and some guy named DeAndre Hopkins is there to dominate targets. This target competition plus the fact that Kyler will steal TDs via rushing makes Kirk look like a boom/bust WR4 for 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The addition of Rondale Moore could prove to put a big time damper on Christian Kirk’s long term outlook in Arizona. An impending free agent after the 2021 season, Kirk’s best chance of gaining dynasty value is likely via a change in scenery where he may see more targets.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Michael Burton, Jerick McKinnon, Darwin Thompson

notes.text: Not many realize that Edwards-Helaire was the No. 11 running back through six weeks without Le'Veon Bell on the roster. Even better, he was the No. 11 running back while scoring just once during that time. In fact, had he scored one more touchdown, he would've been the No. 6 running back through six weeks. Once they traded for Bell, though, it ruined the stable touches he was getting. With Bell gone and no one significant brought in this offseason, Edwards-Helaire should return to his 18-plus touch role in the offense. The Chiefs have rebuilt their offensive line this year, which should help make life easier on Edwards-Helaire, who did average a solid 4.44 yards per carry his rookie season. Touchdowns are what were lacking, but don't bet on that again in what's likely to be the No. 1 scoring offense in the NFL.

CEH was all the rage last year and now it feels like he’s a forgotten man. He still put up over 1,100 yards in his rookie season and [checks notes… ] is still on an offense led by Patrick Mahomes. He’s going to see 15-18 touches per game and top-5 at the position is still in his range of outcomes. If you can get him as your team’s RB2 in the 3rd round, you’re playing with house money to start your draft.

Clyde Edwards-Helaire suffered both a groin injury and a high ankle sprain in Week 15 against the Saints, which forced him to miss Weeks 16, 17 and the Divisional Round of the playoffs. He returned for the Chiefs’ Super Bowl run 5 weeks after injury but was never close to 100%. His 5 week recovery suggests this was a grade II sprain, which will heal completely this offseason. Expect no limitations from the second year RB.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Clyde Edwards-Helaire
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Based on his draft cost (RB5/1.05), it probably felt like CEH was a major bust. His four rushing TDs were extremely unfortunate for a player with that type of workload. But if we look at the total body of work, he compiled a solid rookie season. Since 1990, here are the rookie RBs with 1,100 total yards in fewer than 14 games played: Marshawn Lynch, Lev Bell, Todd Gurley, Leonard Fournette, Josh Jacobs & CEH. That's an impressive list. He's going to be a top-15 RB this year and should have more spike games with Patrick Mahomes.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: CEH’s dynasty value sunk dramatically after 2020, after not living up to the hype of a top-5 back. He’s probably being undervalued in dynasty heading into 2021 and is one of the trade targets we recommend going after. Some would say he was “drafted to be great”.

notes.text: It's kind of crazy how much Andrews gets disrespected by the fantasy community. He's tallied 2,105 yards and 20 touchdowns over his first three seasons in the league. That's the ninth-most yardage by a tight end in the post-merger era during his first three seasons. You know what other tight ends are on that list? George Kittle, Rob Gronkowski, Jimmy Graham, and Kellen Winslow. Sure, the Ravens went out and added some pass catchers, but Andrews is the go-to option for Lamar Jackson over the middle of the field and in the red zone. Health has been the biggest obstacle for Andrews, but if he's able to stay on the field, he should be the No. 4 tight end off the board.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mark Andrews
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: There is a sense of stench surrounding Andrews after his breakout 2019 campaign turned sour in 2020. He still had six performances inside the top-5 (the 3rd most at the position) and is always a threat for a multi-TD week. Andrews should bounce back in 2021 along with Lamar Jackson and the rest of the Ravens offense. However, the competition for targets has increased with rookie WRs Rashod Bateman and Tylan Wallace added to the mix.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He's still a top-5 TE for perhaps the next 3-4 years and you can view him as a differentiator.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Rhamondre Stevenson, Jakob Johnson, Sony Michel

notes.text: The Patriots want to run the ball and they chose to draft a mound of a man in the 4th Round. Sony Michel’s time is about up and Stevenson profiles as an early-down thumper who also caught some passes in college. He’s also a player you root for as the biggest dude on the field but likely will be 3rd or 4th on the depth chart in Year One.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Rhamondre Stevenson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Patriots want to run the ball and they chose to draft a mound of a man in the 4th Round. Sony Michel’s time is about up and Stevenson profiles as an early-down thumper who also caught some passes in college. He’s also a player you root for as the biggest dude on the field but likely will be 3rd or 4th on the depth chart in Year One.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If your team needs girth, we know where to find it. Sony Michel and James White are out the door in 2021 so bide your time in hopes Rha-Grande stumbles into a bigger workload next year.

notes.text: How the mighty have fallen... Just a few years removed of being the Patriots first round pick, Michel finds himself fighting for touches in this backfield. It appears Damien Harris is the starter, while James White handles passing down work, and Rhamondre Stevenson and Michel fight for the scraps. Is it possible that Michel's injury last year has us overlooking his potential? He may have only had 79 carries last year, but he did average a massive 5.7 yards per carry on them. Maybe he's just better in a timeshare? This backfield is a mess, especially if Cam Newton is under center.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Sony Michel
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The former 1st round draft pick has seen better fantasy days. He’s an early-down-only RB who has sputtered the last two seasons to show anything on the field. With Damien Harris and Rhamondre Stevenson in the mix, Michel could be the odd man out for that role.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: After declining his 5th year option, Michel will have to find a new home for 2022. He feels like he’s 30 years old (he’s only 26) but maybe that’s how his body has betrayed him.

notes.text: What's the best-case scenario for Harris? Didn't we see it last year when Sony Michel went down with an injury? Not only is Michel healthy, but the Patriots also decided to draft Rhamondre Stevenson in the fourth round of this year's draft, which just adds another body to the mix. I like Harris as a player, but as someone who topped 16 touches just twice last year with little competition and no role in the passing game, you should aim higher for your RB2/3 option.

Messing with the Patriot's backfield is often a fool's errand. That being said, Harris flashed as a runner last season and may be the best back to bet on in New England. Despite injuries, and Cam Newton, Harris put up multiple top 24 performances in 2020 and should have every chance for 15-20 carries a game for the Patriots. Could be worth a late round selection.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Damien Harris
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Harris flashed a couple of times in 2020 including five games as a top-24 RB in his ten games played. He ran at 5.0 yards per carry as a primarily early down runner with Cam Newton. The backfield continues to be a revolving door of opportunity as Harris, Sony Michel and James White are now joined by rookie Rhamondre Stevenson. Harris is a great ZeroRB candidate that could assert himself as the team’s lead runner but he’s offered zero in the passing game thus far despite shining as a receiver in college.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Any New England RB is a roll of the dice in redraft. In dynasty, you’re basically playing checkers blindfolded. Harris could be the lead back this year and maybe at the back of the line next year.

notes.text: When the Broncos signed Gordon to a two-year, $16 million contract, you had to assume they were going to use him in a big role. That's not quite what happened, as they continually wanted to involve Phillip Lindsay. After letting him walk in free agency, they snagged Mike Boone, which was a downgrade from Lindsay. Okay... but that wasn't it. They drafted Javonte Williams at the top of the second round, a running back who'll certainly compete for touches immediately. Gordon isn't going to simply go away making the money he is, but he's also not likely going to get the 16.5 touches per game he was in 2020. There's also a possible suspension coming Gordon's way for a DUI incident last year, which needs to be factored into his fantasy stock. He's not someone you should be relying on for anything more than RB3/flex production.

Entering the final year of his contract, Gordon will have plenty of opportunities in 2021.  But how consistent will he be?  And when will heralded rookie Javonte Williams begin to take over in this backfield?  The future is clearly Williams, and Gordon could see his role erode over the course of the season.  Be careful.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Melvin Gordon III
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Gordon was the fantasy RB13 last year, and Phillip Lindsay signed with the Texans. But then the Broncos traded up to draft Javonte Williams at the beginning of the 2nd round. Gordon is a plodder at this point and his fantasy days are nearing the end. He’s still a capable goal-line back and has the ability to catch passes so don’t completely write him off.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He likely can hang on as a RB2/3 in 2021 but who knows what is in store beyond? He'll be a free agent turning 29 next year at the point where his legs (skinny as they may be) might be done.

notes.text: There are many trying to appoint Williams as the top back in the Broncos offense, but don't go there just yet. Melvin Gordon has one year left on his deal, and it's the same coaching staff that brought him in on a two-year deal worth $16 million. It's likely they continue using Gordon in a timeshare with Williams in the Phillip Lindsay role, which netted 8-16 touches when Gordon was in the lineup. That does give him flex appeal, and if anything were to happen to Gordon, Williams could be a league winner. Treat him as a high-end handcuff, and anything else he gives you is a bonus.

The Broncos traded up early in the 2nd round to grab Williams, the 5’10” 220 lbs bruising back who scored 19 TDs last year at UNC. He’s known for his ridiculous contact balance and could unseat Melvin Gordon as Denver’s main RB as early as this year. Still, for redraft purposes, he’s a risky middle round pick not knowing how much work he’ll see in year one. He also didn’t catch a ton of passes in college.

Williams was a surprise pick by the Broncos, who traded up for him in the 2021 NFL Draft. With Melvin Gordon a year away from free agency, Williams fits the mold as a potential second-half superstar and one you should keep your eye on for fantasy. It may take some time, but Denver has a solid defense and the run game will be their identity.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Javonte Williams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Broncos traded up early in the 2nd round to grab Williams, the 5’10” 220 lbs bruising back who scored 19 TDs last year at UNC. He’s known for his ridiculous contact balance and could unseat Melvin Gordon as Denver’s main RB as early as this year. Still, for redraft purposes, he’s a risky middle round pick not knowing how much work he’ll see in year one. He also didn’t catch a ton of passes in college.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Side step 2021 and realize Williams is set up to be a top-10 dynasty RB as soon as 2022. He’s on a team that is just a QB away from being a true contender. Bet on his talent while ignoring the short-term roadblock with Melvin Gordon becoming a free agent next year.

notes.text: It seems like it's been forever since we've seen Sutton on a football field, right? Part of that is due to 2020 seeming like the longest year of all-time. But when he does return to the field, the Broncos offense looks quite different than the one that allowed him to rack up 1,112 yards and six touchdowns in 2019. The additions of Jerry Jeudy, KJ Hamler, Melvin Gordon, and Javonte Williams are all massive, as is the emergence of Tim Patrick. Suddenly, it's going to be tough for any receiver on this team to hit 120 targets. But what Sutton has going for him is that he's already shown that he can perform at a high level in the NFL. While I believe Jeudy can as well, we haven't seen that just yet, which gives Sutton the nod in the rankings as a WR3.

Sutton’s 2020 season barely got off the ground. He began the year by missing Week 1 thanks to an AC joint sprain in his shoulder then tore the ACL and MCL in his left knee in Week 2. As of now, Sutton appears to be on track for Week 1 and should be full go once training camp starts. Look for Sutton to be limited during the team’s offseason program this summer as he acclimates back into football shape, but given how early his injury happened, he should enter Week 1 at 100%.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Courtland Sutton
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: In his second season (2019), Sutton was a solid WR2 for fantasy. He made highlight reel catches while topping 1,100 receiving yards, with the likes of Joe Flacco, Brandon Allen and Drew Lock. However, he suffered a season-ending knee injury in Week 2 last year and his hype has taken a bit hit. All signs point to him being 100% for the start of this season. He can still be Denver's WR1 and he’s entering a contract year. The QB situation isn't ideal whether it's Drew Lock or Teddy Bridgewater.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Courtland Sutton has a chance to provide a massive bounce back appeal in dynasty. With Jerry Jeudy, Noah Fant and KJ Hamler in town Sutton seems to get lost in the shuffle when talking about alpha WRs. He presents a great ‘buy low’ opportunity for a highly productive WR who’s still only 25 years old and is set to be a free agent after 2021. There’s a great chance he gets a massive QB upgrade next season either via an upgrade from Denver or a new team in free agency.

notes.text: Don't let 2020 fool you; Jerry Jeudy is a very good wide receiver. The targets that came from Drew Lock were not worth nearly as much as they should've been, and Jeudy owners should be hoping Teddy Bridgewater wins the job. He's someone who's more timing-based than Lock, and that would benefit the route runner that Jeudy is, as you could make a highlight tape of the defenders he made look silly last year, only Lock didn't find him. The quarterback competition weighs heavily on Jeudy's fantasy potential.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jerry Jeudy
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After being selected in the 1st Round of the 2020 NFL Draft, Jerry Jeudy was thrust into an every down role last season after Courtland Sutton tore his ACL. He was targeted 110 times yet only caught 52 balls, suggesting there’s a lot of meat left on the bone entering 2021. If Drew Lock is under center, he may drag this offense down, but on paper, Jeudy looks like a good bet to take a step forward in year two.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: There may not be a more obvious buy in dynasty formats right now. Coming off an up and down rookie year thanks to questionable QB play and rookie growing pains, Jeudy profiles as someone who should take a step forward in year two. He’s still just 22 years old and has first round NFL Draft capital.

notes.text: When you throw 11 touchdowns in 14 games in today's NFL, that's a problem. Sure, Jones didn't have top-tier pass catchers last year, but Sterling Shepard, Darius Slayton, and Golden Tate were competent. The Giants seem to believe Jones was simply lacking weapons, so they went out and signed Kenny Golladay and Kyle Rudolph, and then drafted Kadarius Toney in the first round. Based on what we've seen from Jones to this point, it's tough saying he's anything more than a boom-or-bust quarterback who'll need some rushing totals in order to make him streamer-worthy.

Daniel Jones has started 25 games as an NFL quarterback and produced just six QB1 performances in that span.  Last season he only managed to give you two such games.  While Kenny Golladay is a huge upgrade for Jones, it's hard for us to envision a world where he'll make a year three leap.  Avoid him.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Daniel Jones
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Time to swing for the fences. We're in Year 3 of the Daniel Jones experiment and this is the best set of weapons he's had. We saw glimpses of him as an impact fantasy QB his rookie year and last year was a disaster with Saquon hurt and the offensive line in shambles. Remember that fantasy is different than reality and the Giants were actually knocking on the door of the playoffs last year. You can draft him very late and if it's clear he hasn't taken a step forward you can drop him to the waiver wire. Or you can just choose to avoid Daniel "Fumble" Jones and be willing to miss out if he does surprise. Unfortunately, newly signed WR Kenny Golladay is dealing with a hamstring injury, which could linger into the season.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you want to shoot your shot, Jones is a player worth trading for on the cheap heading in 2021. He’s either the Giants QB moving forward or you move on after this season.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dan Arnold
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Postman delivered as a TE1 last year in Arizona… once in Week 13. He’s averaged a robust 13.8 yards per reception in his career but he’s been more hype than reliable. Not something you want from your mail carrier. He has a new home in Carolina and an excellent narrative at play: Darnold to D. Arnold. You can see the newspaper headlines and Tweets rolling in. For fantasy, he’s the 5th target at best in this crowded Panthers passing attack.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Postman is a nice bench player to have just for the sheer enjoyment of his nickname. He’s only 26 but through four years into the league, we know what he is.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Shi Smith, David Moore, Terrace Marshall Jr.

notes.text: The exit of Curtis Samuel frees up some targets in the offense, but don't forget that Christian McCaffrey missed most of last year, which allowed more targets to go to the wide receivers. We don't know how the Panthers will deploy Marshall, though it's certainly worth noting he has experience in this offense, as he played for Joe Brady at LSU. If they align him as the big slot, he can make more of an impact with Sam Darnold, who has always favored his targets over the middle of the field. If they put him on the perimeter, it'll be a lot tougher for him to produce immediately while behind D.J. Moore, Robby Anderson, and McCaffrey in the pecking order.

Marshall fell a bit in the NFL Draft partially due to some injury concerns given his injury history. In high school, he suffered a fractured fibula with a dislocated left ankle, which forced him to miss his senior year of high school. Then, in 2019 while at LSU, Marshall suffered a stress fracture in his right foot. Despite this seeming concerning on the surface, Marshall was able to return to form and produce at a high level in 2020, suggesting there’s a chance his injury woes are behind him.

Marshall lands in Carolina to play the WR3 role behind Robby Anderson and D.J. Moore. He can be a big slot WR at the next level, so it’ll be interesting to see where the team uses him in his rookie season. Obviously, if anything happened to Anderson or Moore, he’d be an immediate add off the waiver wire but otherwise, it’s important to keep expectations in check. Remember, there’s this guy named Christian McCaffrey catching footballs out of the backfield, too, and Sam Darnold at QB.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Terrace Marshall Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Marshall lands in Carolina to play the WR3 role behind Robby Anderson and D.J. Moore. He can be a big slot WR at the next level, so it’ll be interesting to see where the team uses him in his rookie season. Obviously, if anything happened to Anderson or Moore, he’d be an immediate add off the waiver wire but otherwise, it’s important to keep expectations in check. Remember, there’s this guy named Christian McCaffrey catching footballs out of the backfield, too, and Sam Darnold at QB.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Marshall slipped a bit in the NFL Draft due to medical concerns, but his landing spot is really intriguing, and he’s still got 2nd round Draft capital to support his profile. Robby Anderson is a free agent after the 2021 season. We'll see if Sam Darnold can take a step forward in Carolina.

notes.text: There were just three receivers who finished with 93-plus yards in eight separate games last year. Calvin Ridley, Stefon Diggs, and... Moore. While the touchdowns were certainly lacking, there's something to be said about this stat and how undervalued Moore may be due to the lack of touchdowns. It was his first year in the offense, while Robby Anderson was brought in because he knew the offense. With Curtis Samuel out of town, we might see Moore in the slot far more often, which wouldn't be a bad thing. He's now finished with 1,175-plus yards in back-to-back seasons. It's only a matter of time before the touchdowns catch up. He's a solid WR2 to roster, who just might have top-12 upside if the touchdowns start to show up.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: DJ Moore
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: D.J. Moore is still very young and we've only seen consistent production that might say there's more in store. He’s gathered the 10th most receptions ever for a wide receiver before turning 24, but the TDs are the only thing lacking in his production. 41 different WRs have caught 200+ passes through the first three years of their career. D.J. Moore ranks 40th in terms of TDs with only ten. Expect the scale to start tipping in his favor soon. We’ll find out if Sam Darnold is an upgrade over Teddy Bridgewater for fantasy purposes.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Dynasty managers have been hyped about D.J. Moore for a couple of years now, and there’s reason to think we haven’t even seen Moore scratch the surface of how good he can be in this league. The talent clearly isn’t a question, and the offensive scheme is fantastic, but is Sam Darnold going to be the guy to help Moore take another step forward? That remains to be seen.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Tre'Quan Smith, Michael Thomas, Marquez Callaway

notes.text: Is Smith to blame for his lack of involvement in the offense, or were there just not enough targets to go around? He's seen 119 targets over his first three seasons combined, which have amounted to 80 receptions, 1,109 yards, and 14 touchdowns, so the efficiency has been top-notch. Did Drew Brees not have the arm to push the ball down the field anymore? If Jameis Winston is the quarterback, Smith may very well be a sleeper in fantasy drafts, though that optimism would die quickly if Taysom Hill were named the starter. It did boost Smith's stock to learn that Michael Thomas would be missing time to start the season, as that makes Smith the WR1 on the team.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tre'Quan Smith
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Entering his 4th year in the league, if ever there was a time for Tre’Quan to power up, it’s 2021. The opportunity is there opposite an injured Michael Thomas in New Orleans but he’s never quite asserted himself as a reliable fantasy option. The back of Smith’s NFT football card reads like a Wendy’s value menu: you might find a nugget or two but chances are it’s just not that good. He’s finished as a top-24 WR four times in 40 career games. Man your bow and fire that arrow as a late round dart throw into the night skies in hopes of hitting your target: a WR4.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you’re holding onto hopes that Smith becomes a thing in New Orleans in the last year of his deal, you might be delirious. If he couldn’t do it with a Hall of Fame QB, good luck with the dynamic duo of Taysom & Jameis, a reality show coming to a streaming service near you.

notes.text: It felt like too many people were dismissing Thomas this year, falling into borderline WR2 territory, but now that we know of his ankle surgery that took place in June, he's going to fall even further. It's possible he misses the first 4-6 games based on the timeline he received. It did seem like everyone forget he was the consensus No. 1 wide receiver just a year ago. The big question is: Who is his quarterback once he returns? If it's Hill, there should be a slight downgrade, but don't forget what Thomas did in the four Hill games last year: 9/104/0, 4/50/0, 9/105/0, and 8/84/0. Those are rock-solid numbers, though the touchdowns were obviously not there. Right now, I'm expecting Thomas to miss at least four games, which moves him down into WR4 territory. If you're able to stay afloat the first month of the season, snagging Thomas in the middle rounds might be a winning strategy.

News broke in late July that Michael Thomas required surgery on his ankle in June to stablize the injured ligaments. This all stems from Thomas’ left high ankle sprain from Week 1 of 2020, which forced Thomas to be shut down at the end of the season. A report originally surfaced in late January that Thomas may require surgery on his ankle, and it looks like he attempted to rehab and delay surgery as long as possible to see if he could recover without surgery. However, at this point, Thomas is going to miss regular season games and is a strong candidate to begin the year on the PUP list. The final thing to consider here is that Thomas will also require time to acclimate back into football, so it’s unlikely Thomas is 100% in his first couple of games once he does return to the field. Look for Thomas’ status to be updated in mid to late August as training camp progresses.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Michael Thomas
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Michael Thomas was considered one of the safest wide receivers in fantasy last year, coming off the board as the WR1. He was a massive bust after missing most of the season with a high ankle sprain. Now, he enters 2021 with one glaring question mark - how will he perform in his first season without Drew Brees? In four games with Taysom Hill as the starter last season, Thomas returned weekly WR16, 48, 20 and 24 finishes while averaging 85.75 yards per game. UPDATE: Thomas is now expected to miss the start of the 2021 season after undergoing surgery to repair the ligaments in his ankle in June. Reports say recommended recovery time could be as long as 4 months.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Michael Thomas was firmly entrenched as the WR1 in dynasty just a year ago, but he enters the first time in his career where there’s uncertainty surrounding his value. Drew Brees is gone, so who will be throwing the now 28 year old the football? Has he already reached his fantasy ceiling? These are the questions fantasy managers need to ask themselves with Thomas entering 2021.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Marquez Callaway
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After a modest rookie year in which he caught 21 of his 22 targets in only eight games played, Callaway suddenly finds himself with ample opportunity in 2021. With Michael Thomas presumably out the first half of the season, he could supplant Tre’Quan Smith as the top receiving weapon in New Orleans outside of Alvin Kamara and enter FLEX territory. The drumbeat news during the offseason can’t be ignored so consider Callaway a worthy late-round flier whose opportunity trumps other shaky WRs this late.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hopefully, you snagged Callway off the waiver wire earlier this offseason or had him stashed. These are the type of windows in dynasty that make the format so enticing. Callaway is only 23 so maybe there's some hidden gold for 2021 and beyond.

notes.text: Hey, remember that five-week stretch where Fulgham was the No. 1 fantasy football wide receiver? No, I'm not kidding. From Week 4 through Week 8, Fulgham scored 82.0 half PPR points while no other receiver scored more than 74.3 of them. Then, suddenly, the Eagles chose to not involve him in the offense anymore. It was odd, really. The Eagles now clearly have Devonta Smith and Jalen Reagor ahead of him on the depth chart, but if Jalen Hurts can take a step forward in his passing in 2021, we could see Fulgham have a few usable weeks in fantasy as the team's No. 3 receiver.

Is Smith to blame for his lack of involvement in the offense, or were there just not enough targets to go around? He's seen 119 targets over his first three seasons combined, which have amounted to 80 receptions, 1,109 yards, and 14 touchdowns, so the efficiency has been top-notch. Did Drew Brees not have the arm to push the ball down the field anymore? If Jameis Winston is the quarterback, Smith may very well be a sleeper in fantasy drafts, though that optimism would die quickly if Taysom Hill were named the starter. It did boost Smith's stock to learn that Michael Thomas would be missing time to start the season, as that makes Smith the WR1 on the team.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Entering his 4th year in the league, if ever there was a time for Tre’Quan to power up, it’s 2021. The opportunity is there opposite an injured Michael Thomas in New Orleans but he’s never quite asserted himself as a reliable fantasy option. The back of Smith’s NFT football card reads like a Wendy’s value menu: you might find a nugget or two but chances are it’s just not that good. He’s finished as a top-24 WR four times in 40 career games. Man your bow and fire that arrow as a late round dart throw into the night skies in hopes of hitting your target: a WR4.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you’re holding onto hopes that Smith becomes a thing in New Orleans in the last year of his deal, you might be delirious. If he couldn’t do it with a Hall of Fame QB, good luck with the dynamic duo of Taysom & Jameis, a reality show coming to a streaming service near you.

That's not quite what happened, as they continually wanted to involve Phillip Lindsay. After letting him walk in free agency, they snagged Mike Boone, which was a downgrade from Lindsay. Okay... but that wasn't it. They drafted Javonte Williams at the top of the second round, a running back who'll certainly compete for touches immediately. Gordon isn't going to simply go away making the money he is, but he's also not likely going to get the 16.5 touches per game he was in 2020. He's not someone you should be relying on for anything more than RB3/flex production.

And when will heralded rookie Javonte Williams begin to take over in this backfield?  The future is clearly Williams, and Gordon could see his role erode over the course of the season.  Be careful.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Melvin Gordon III
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Gordon was the fantasy RB13 last year, and Phillip Lindsay signed with the Texans. But then the Broncos traded up to draft Javonte Williams at the beginning of the 2nd round. Gordon is a plodder at this point and his fantasy days are nearing the end. He’s still a capable goal-line back and has the ability to catch passes so don’t completely write him off.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He likely can hang on as a RB2/3 in 2021 but who knows what is in store beyond? He'll be a free agent turning 29 next year at the point where his legs (skinny as they may be) might be done.

notes.text: When drafting a wide receiver in the first couple rounds, you can't afford to miss on them. Is there anyone more reliable than Hopkins? He's now seen at least 150 targets in six straight seasons and has finished as a top-five receiver in five of them. Sure, the Cardinals added A.J. Green and Rondale Moore, but that's not going to stop Kyler Murray from going to his favorite target.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: DeAndre Hopkins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: In 2020, fantasy managers were fading Hopkins given that he was a veteran WR changing teams with a brand new QB without much of an offseason. At this point, we clearly know Nuk is simply too talented for any of that to matter. He returned WR5 overall value, and the last time he wasn’t a top 5 fantasy WR was in 2016. There's still room for improvement in Hopkins’ second year in the system with Kyler Murray after scoring just 6 TDs. He's as dependable as they come.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hopkins still has four more seasons left on his current deal, meaning he’s locked in as Kyler’s WR1 for quite awhile. At 28 years old, he’s still got at least two more years of elite production left in the tank at a minimum.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Hunter Renfrow, Willie Snead IV, John Brown, Bryan Edwards

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Hunter Renfrow
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Let’s be honest. The Wallerus is this team’s WR1, but behind him, it’s an open competition for targets after Nelson Agholor signed with the Pats in free agency. Renfrow saw a total of 77 targets last year - if that trend continues, he’ll be mostly irrelevant for fantasy football.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Unless something changes quickly for the former Clemson WR, he could turn into a roster clogger - a guy who sits on the end of the bench but one that managers never start given the lack of upside. After WR55 and WR61 finishes in his first two years in the league, Renfrow may help the Raiders more than your fantasy team.

notes.text: While on the field, Brown has delivered for fantasy managers. The issue is that's been a struggle staying on the field. He's missed 14 full games over the last four seasons and portions of others. Still, he produced a 1,000-yard season in 2019, and finished with 70-plus yards in five of the nine games he did play in 2020. Now going to Las Vegas where there is no clear-cut No. 1 wide receiver, Brown could have a Nelson Agholor-like 2021 season where he essentially goes undrafted, but winds up being a borderline WR3 most weeks, but he needs to stay healthy in order for that to happen.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: John Brown
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Brown was quietly really good for fantasy in 2020 when on the field...but that didn’t happen very often. He missed or exited early due to injury in eight games last year. He’s on a Raiders team with a ton of question marks at the WR position, but let’s be honest Derek Carr’s first and second read is Darren Waller. Expect ‘Smoke’ Brown to have some big weeks for fantasy a la Nelson Agholor in 2020, but he’s not a reliable option at this point in his career.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: John Brown signed a one-year deal with Vegas this offseason, but he turns 32 next year when he’ll be a free agent. There isn’t likely to be a hot market for the speedy Brown, making him an obvious trade away candidate while he’s still got some (albeit small) value. Otherwise, he could provide some depth for bye weeks and injuries.

notes.text: The Raiders were high on Edwards during last year's draft process, though injuries derailed his progress.
