Once Nelson Agholor left, it felt like Edwards might be starting in 2WR sets, though they quickly replaced Agholor with the veteran John Brown. Still, Edwards is the only notable receiver on the team who's over six-feet tall and can play that go-to role they seek outside of Darren Waller. We've also heard Derek Carr say that Edwards reminded him of his former teammate in college, Davante Adams, which is never a bad thing.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Bryan Edwards
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Bryan Edwards missed most of last year with a high ankle sprain. Now, he’s looking at a WR depth chart consisting of an aging John Brown, an unproven Henry Ruggs and slot WR Hunter Renfrow. He's a dart throw at the end of your draft if you want to believe the hype.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Edwards was a dynasty darling of 2020 rookie drafts, consistently being taken in the middle of the 2nd round for perceived upside. His analytical profile from his college days (94th percentile dominator rating, 17.8 breakout age) makes him a speculative trade target on the cheap in dynasty leagues.

notes.text: You'd think that when a team spends the No. 12 overall pick on a wide receiver, they'd actually find ways to use him, right? That didn't happen with Ruggs. There wasn't a game in 2020 where he saw more than five targets or caught more than three receptions. We did see the Raiders move on from Nelson Agholor, but he was quickly replaced by John Brown. It's no secret that Brown has struggled to stay healthy, which could be the door Ruggs needs to get more targets. He shouldn't need an injury to get targets, but if this Raiders coaching staff told us anything last year, it's that they don't know how to best utilize Ruggs.

Henry Ruggs didn't exactly perform like the #12 overall pick in 2020. Injuries shelved him multiple times during the season, and he ended up with a mere 67% of snaps when he was on the field. Year two should be different, and he represents sleeper value at the position. Nelson Agholor is gone, Carr is an efficient QB, and Ruggs is bursting with talent. If he can stay healthy, he should lead their WR core and surprise.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Henry Ruggs III
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Nelson Agholor is gone, and Ruggs was drafted to be this team’s WR1. Will he be able to take a step forward after being selected 12th overall in the NFL Draft just a year ago? Good news for fantasy managers, the ADP for Ruggs is expected to stay in the double digit rounds. He’s a low risk, high reward investment but could easily end up on waiver wires after a week or two.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Ruggs was drafted by the Raiders ahead of CeeDee Lamb and Jerry Jeudy last year in the first round, yet he barely showed anything as a rookie. He can certainly be acquired for cheaper than what he was going for in rookie drafts last year.- However, as long as Darren Waller is on the roster, we know where most of the targets are going.

notes.text: It was shocking to see the Dolphins pass on running back after running back, especially considering all the picks they had in this year's draft. This is great news for Gaskin, who racked up 183 touches in just 10 games last year. Crazy, right? His 18.3 touches per game ranked ninth among running backs. Opportunity is everything, and if he gets that type of opportunity again in 2021 while playing in all the games, he's going to finish as a top-15 running back. The only difference is that the Dolphins added Malcolm Brown in free agency, which could lead to him siphoning some targets away from Gaskin, which would be less than ideal. As of now, Gaskin should probably be considered a solid RB2, though landing him as your RB3/flex would be even better based on the small sample size we have from him in a big role.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Myles Gaskin
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Gas Man was as productive as they get considering he was a former 7th round draft pick. He seized control of the Miami backfield in 2020 averaging the 7th most touches per game (18.3) among RBs, more than Alvin Kamara. He struggled to stay on the field playing in only ten games but the Dolphins surprisingly did not spend any high draft capital on an RB. Gaskin’s main competition is free-agent Malcolm Brown and Salvon Ahmed but his work as a receiver (4.1 receptions per game) is comforting. We have him ranked as a low-end RB2 who profiles as the team’s main pass-catching back but there is inherent risk involved.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Gaskin is another perfect example of a dynasty stash that turns into gold. He’s not a sure thing by any means moving forward but his status as a volume-based RB2 looks secure for now. Things could easily shift in 2022 so if you want to trade him to a team desperate for RB help that will overpay, it’s probably a wise move long-term.

notes.text: Brown's a role player, plain and simple. The Dolphins are going to give him touches; you don't sign a player for nearly $2 million to have him fourth on the running back depth chart. With that being said, he's not a sleeper candidate or anything, but rather someone who takes away some of the upside of players like Myles Gaskin.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Malcolm Brown
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After spending six years with the Rams, Brown quietly signed with the Dolphins off-season and it feels like no one remembered. He’s a capable running back and had some moments as a goal-line back in LA. Don’t discount Brown when you think about Myles Gaskin and how that Miami backfield could shake out.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Brown works as an “end-of-your-bench” flier in hopes he has a bigger role in Miami. But beyond 2021, who knows what the future holds for him at 28 years old.

notes.text: He's kind of gone under the radar this offseason, though it's odd because of how well he played when given the opportunity last year as Myles Gaskin's primary backup. He tallied 63 total touches, 291 total yards, and two touchdowns in the three games he played a big role, which is certainly enough to be started in fantasy. Worst case scenario is that he's a handcuff to Gaskin, who hasn't proven the ability to remain healthy in a workhorse role.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Salvon Ahmed
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Ahmed was a pleasant undrafted free-agent out of Washington who was solid for fantasy when he had the chance in 2020. He actually had two top-12 performances in three starts including 122 rushing yards and a score against New England in Week 15. That’s as many RB1 weeks as J.K. Dobbins had last year. Ahmed is a late round flier and could fight his way into RB2 status if Myles Gaskin goes down again.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Ahmed is a perfect example of how working the dynasty waiver wire is key. The UDFA had a couple of startable weeks and at the RB position, we’ll take anything we can get.

notes.text: Sure, Montgomery finished as the RB4 last year. There were many factors that led to that, particularly the injury to Tarik Cohen, freeing up tons of targets in the passing game. Over the course of Montgomery's short career, he's played 19 games with Cohen and 12 games without him. In the games with Cohen, he averaged 2.32 targets per game. In the 12 games without him, that number rose to 4.92 targets per game. Well, Cohen is back, and the team signed Damien Williams, who's a better receiving back than Montgomery. On top of Cohen missing, the Bears had a ridiculously easy schedule down the stretch, playing against the Packers twice, Lions, Texans, Vikings, and Jaguars to close out the season. Did you know that Montgomery was the RB20 after 10 weeks (prior to starting that schedule)? He's a fine low-end RB2, but don't go about your day thinking you're getting a steal in the fourth round or anything.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: David Montgomery
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Montgomery was one of the most valuable players in fantasy over the final two months totalling eight TDs as the RB2 from Week 12 on against weak defenses. WIth Tarik Cohen sidelined for the season, Montgomery became a full 3-down back including the 2nd most routes run among RBs and the 6th most red zone touches at the position. Expectations must be tempered in 2021 with Cohen returning and Damien Williams added into the mix. Still, David Mopportunity is being a bit disrespected in drafts where he’s currently being taken. He’s a fine RB2.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Montgomery is more solid than spectacular although that hot streak towards the end of 2020 shows you a glimpse of what he can be. If someone wants to trade for him thinking that’s who he is, it might be put him on the trading block. He’s under contract for two more years in Chicago.

notes.text: There were certainly flashes of what could be a great three-down back with Swift last year, but the Lions seem to have alternate plans. They snagged Jamaal Williams in free agency and signed him to a two-year deal. Then, they drafted Jermar Jefferson. Then, they brought in Todd Gurley on a free agent visit. While they didn't sign him, it's not promising for Swift's outlook, as they clearly want this to be somewhat of a timeshare. It's not to say timeshare backs can't get into the top-12 conversation - they can, but it requires a lot of scoring opportunities, something we're not expecting from the Lions offense. Swift is an extremely talented football player, but situation and opportunity knock him into clear-cut RB2 territory.

Swift has been missing practice time in training camp due to a mild groin injury, but according to beat writers, Swift has been consistently participating in individual drills while sitting out 7-on-7 and 11-on-11 drills. By all accounts, this seems minor, but it’s an injury to monitor over the next 1-2 weeks once Swift does return to practicing in full. As with any soft tissue injury, the concern is potential aggravation upon returning to full activity.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: D'Andre Swift
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It took a while for him to get going but once Swift was unleashed, he was everything the Lions wanted in their second-round draft pick. Since 1990, only two rookie RBs had 45+ receptions in fewer than 14 games played: Lev Bell & D’Andre Swift. That’s it. The question for 2021 is how well will this new Detroit offense function with Jared Goff at the helm. The wide receiver group in Detroit is thin with Kenny Golladay and Marvin Jones Jr. out the door and replacements being… ummm, uninspiring? There has been offseason chatter about his 3-down skillset but also some Jamaal Williams love from the coaching staff. Swift is a high variance player taken in the late 2nd round.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Swift’s team situation couldn’t be worse as Dan Campbell and his high testosterone approach might bumble a talented RB’s fantasy future. He’s still a top-15 dynasty RB given his pass-catching skills. You just hope this team gets better soon.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: La'Mical Perine
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Perine is a favorite of Mike’s and should not be completely discredited from making some noise in this Jets backfield. While Tevin Coleman was brought in due to his familiarity with this system, 4th rounder Michael Carter is no sure thing. Perine isn’t exactly fast but his frame (5’11 216) says he can handle a bigger workload. He’s a name to consider in the later rounds.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Perine is a lottery ticket and likely a discounted RB in dynasty formats. He’s worth a look in a trades for the slim chance he becomes the lead fantasy back in New York.

notes.text: If you follow college football and/or the NFL Draft, you know that Chase was a superior prospect to Tee Higgins. What we saw Higgins do as a rookie with Joe Burrow was impressive, as he was the WR11 during the eight full games they played together. Keep in mind that was with zero chemistry. Now you insert Chase into the offense, who already has chemistry with Burrow, as they set records at LSU together, and what do we get? I'll acknowledge that Higgins is going to cap Chase's ceiling and that he may not get to top-12 production, but you don't draft Chase at No. 5 overall (over an elite offensive tackle) if you're not going to highlight him in the offense immediately. Heck, even A.J. Green, who averaged 5.0 yards per target, saw 104 targets in this offense last year. Chase should be a WR2 right out of the gate.

Chase was ranked unanimously as the No. 1 WR in the NFL Draft. That hasn’t happened since Calvin Johnson was drafted. Chase is truly a 99% type of prospect. His college production profile is incredible. His athletic testing is off the charts. He’s back with his college QB. While Tee Higgins is a solid NFL WR, he’s not a true No. 1. Chase has a path to immediate fantasy relevance.

The Bengals picked Ja’Marr Chase with the 5th overall pick in this year’s draft. He’s reunited with his college QB, Joe Burrow. On the surface, it may be difficult to envision a scenario where Ja’Marr Chase, Tyler Boyd and Tee Higgins are all fantasy viable. But, AJ Green very quietly saw 101 targets last year. Assuming most of those go to Chase, he could flash massive upside if he’s as good as his college profile says he is.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Ja'Marr Chase
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Bengals picked Ja’Marr Chase with the 5th overall pick in this year’s draft. He’s reunited with his college QB, Joe Burrow. On the surface, it may be difficult to envision a scenario where Ja’Marr Chase, Tyler Boyd and Tee Higgins are all fantasy viable. But, AJ Green very quietly saw 101 targets last year. Assuming most of those go to Chase, he could flash massive upside if he’s as good as his college profile says he is.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Chase has one of the cleanest analytics profiles we’ve seen at the WR position in quite some time and now he’s reunited with Joe Burrow. His value and hype is massive for someone who hasn’t played an NFL snap yet.

notes.text: Since Zac Taylor took over as the head coach, Boyd has played a big role in the offense, though it diminished a tad last year once we saw Tee Higgins carve out a bigger role. Still, he saw 110 targets and finished as the WR35 in half PPR formats. Onto the next obstacle. Ja'Marr Chase is going to be a real thorn in Boyd's side when it comes to volume, as he'll demand more than A.J. Green received last year. All three of the Bengals receivers saw 100-plus targets last year, so it's not like Boyd is going to simply fade away, but he's lost a ton of his upside as the No. 3 option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyler Boyd
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: An underrated slot receiver in the NFL, Tyler Boyd was actually great for fantasy before Joe Burrow’s injury....then the wheels fell off on the entire offense. From Weeks 1-9, Boyd was fantasy’s WR15 and was looking like a steal in the middle to later rounds of drafts. However, now that Ja’Marr Chase is in town and Tee Higgins is likely to take a step forward in year two, there’s some uncertainty regarding Boyd’s volume and TD upside with more competition for targets.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Boyd will be playing football with Joe Burrow for quite awhile, as he’s still got three more years on his current deal. If Cincy remains a high volume passing offense and Joe Burrow is as good as he looked in year one, there’s potential for this offense to support three primary pass catchers for a long time.

notes.text: Higgins joined the starting lineup in Week 3 and played with Joe Burrow through Week 10 in seven full games. He was the WR11 during that time, so a WR1 despite A.J. Green getting tons of work and Tyler Boyd being a big presence. It was a phenomenal start to Higgins' career, and while I loved him as a low-end WR1/high-end WR2 this year, the pick of Ja'Marr Chase at No. 5 overall derailed that excitement. Chase is going to walk in and demand a large chunk of targets right away, as Burrow told the front office that he wanted Chase over Penei Sewell, the stud left tackle. This doesn't mean Higgins is going to go away - he won't. However, it does limit his target ceiling and lowers expectations. He should be valued as a low-end WR2/high-end WR3 with Chase in the picture.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tee Higgins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Tee Higgins put together a really nice rookie season in 2020 with Joe Burrow, totaling 908 receiving yards and six TDs. While Ja’Marr Chase and Tyler Boyd will certainly push for targets, it’s not out of the realm of possibility that all three WRs see a 20+ percent target share given the pass happy nature of this Bengals offense. The Bengals ranked 13th in the league in plays per game last year and that includes games after Joe Burrow tore his ACL. This offense will run a ton of plays and Higgins looks like a top-24 WR in the making even with Chase's presence.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Tee Higgins was THE talk of the town in dynasty just a few months ago, but the noise surrounding Higgins has really quieted down thanks to the team drafting Ja’Marr Chase at No. 5 overall in the NFL Draft. But, he’s still young, extremely talented and tied to Joe Burrow for the next 3+ years. Now is the time to add him to your roster.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Jalen Hurd, Mohamed Sanu, Brandon Aiyuk, Richie James Jr.

notes.text: Aiyuk is a tough one to crack, as he exploded onto the fantasy scene last year, finishing with 583 yards and four touchdowns over his final seven games, but there were factors that helped him achieve those numbers. The major ones being the injuries to George Kittle and Deebo Samuel. There were just four games where the trio were on the field together, and during that time, Aiyuk saw just 21 targets (the lowest of the three) and had 13/189/1 combined in those games. To be fair, it was from Week 4-7, so it was very early in Aiyuk's rookie season, so it's possible he just hadn't earned the trust yet. There's a wide range of outcomes in his projections, going as high as a top-15 wide receiver, but also as low as a wide receiver in the WR30-36 range. You want equity when drafting, so taking Aiyuk as anything more than a WR3 when Kittle and Samuel are healthy is risky.

The last time we saw Brandon Aiyuk on the field in Week 16, he caught one ball for 15 yards while battling through a high ankle sprain that forced him to sit in Week 17. At this point, his injury is fully healed and shouldn’t affect him moving forward.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Brandon Aiyuk
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Aiyuuuuuuuken! It was a stellar rookie season for Aiyuk, who had a 16-game pace of 1,515 receiving yards and 10.7 TDs from Weeks 7-15. However, a lot of that production came with George Kittle out and Deebo Samuel in and out of the lineup. Will Aiyuk still see the target share he saw last season? What will a Trey Lance offense mean for the wideouts? He could easily turn into an alpha in 2021 and we like his value in the early 6th round.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: After Aiyuk put up 100+ yards and/or a TD in 9 of 12 games played last year, there’s reason to be excited about the 2nd year WR in dynasty leagues. His skillset fits exactly what Kyle Shanahan looks for in a WR, but one thing to consider here is that Trey Lance could take some production from the pass catchers if he’s as good of a runner as he was in college.

notes.text: Something tells me that Samuel is going to become the Jarvis Landry of the 2020's. What do I mean by that? Well, he's probably going to finish better than where I have him ranked at the end of the season, but just because he finishes as the WR24 (hypothetically), it doesn't necessarily mean he's the 24th best receiver to roster. Through 22 career games, Samuel has never hit the "boom" mark of 25 PPR points. On top of that, there are suddenly a lot of mouths to feed in the 49ers pass attack. He's a solid player with a decent floor, but he won't be the reason you win a fantasy championship. You can take him as a stable WR3, or shoot for someone with a higher ceiling/lower floor.

Deebo Samuel was a fixture of the 2020 UDK Injury Report after suffering a Jones fracture in his foot while training in June of last year. It forced him to miss the first three games of 2020. Then in Week 7, Deebo suffered a strained hamstring and aggravated that same injury in Week 14, which ended his season. It’s possible Samuel’s hamstring issues stemmed from the fact that he wasn’t able to train optimally last summer while recovering from foot surgery. Entering 2021, he’ll be fully recovered from both his foot fracture and his hamstring issue, but it’s worth noting that he has a history of at least two separate hamstring injuries dating back to his college days. Relative to the other big name 49ers pass catchers (Aiyuk, Kittle), Deebo’s the biggest risk from a health perspective.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Deebo Samuel
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The entire 49ers offense is a bit of an enigma in 2021, primarily because there isn’t a lot of evidence with Deebo, Brandon Aiyuk and George Kittle all on the field together as all three of these players missed time in 2020 due to injury. Now, there’s a high likelihood that a rookie QB will be under center. Can Trey Lance, a rushing QB, support all three for fantasy? Nevertheless when healthy, Deebo has been a startable WR2 for fantasy the last two years.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: After the 49ers traded up to take Trey Lance at No. 3 overall in the 2021 NFL Draft, the future is bright in San Fran. Deebo’s dynasty value is a bit depressed after an injury plagued 2020, but this offense should continue to manufacture touches for him, making him an intriguing “buy low” candidate moving forward.

notes.text: There just aren't any good outcomes for Zach Ertz this year.  Unlikely to be back with the Eagles, Ertz has seen his effectiveness decrease and while he possesses a big name in the fantasy football community, it's not going to translate into a big year.  He's a full-on avoid in 2021, which makes Mike very very happy.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Zach Ertz
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Ertz’s time as an elite fantasy TE is long over. He averaged 30 receiving yards per game and finished inside the top-15 at the position once on the year. Woof. He's daily part of trade rumors and regardless if he ends up on a new team, he remains undraftable. P.S. If you send Mike a photo of Ertz, he likely will block you on Twitter for what it’s worth.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Ertz could easily be traded to another team as his favor in Philadelphia looks like it’s run out. He doesn’t have much value left in the tank as he relied solely on volume for years in the Eagles passing attack.

notes.text: Despite Zach Ertz on the roster and stealing tons of targets, Goedert has managed to rack up 1,131 yards and eight touchdowns over his last 26 games. Had Goedert played all 16 games in 2020, his pace would've been 762 yards and four touchdowns, which would've been good enough to finish as a top-10 tight end (again, with Ertz around). It seems like a foregone conclusion that Ertz will be off the team soon, which clears a path for Goedert to be among the league leaders in targets for a tight end. It's a new offense, but Nick Sirianni comes from the Frank Reich tree, which has a history of producing tight end production. Goedert may not be a can't-miss tight end, but if there's someone who has top-five upside without being drafted there, it's him.

It feels like this is the year Philly will have no choice but to unleash Goedert. Depth-chart-clogging Zach Ertz was comically inefficient last year. Jalen Reagor didn’t make the impact the team was hoping for. Goedert saw a six-game stretch before his 2nd injury where he was averaging seven targets a game. The team added DeVonta Smith in the draft, but Goedert should see an uptick in snaps and targets.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dallas Goedert
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: If you've been waiting for Zach Ertz to hang 'em up, join the club. But Goedert has functioned as this team's TE1 for most of the last year and a half. Despite missing five games in 2020, Goedert still saw 7th most deep targets and ranked 9th in yards per route run at the position. He’s a back-end TE1 with upside to go as high as Jalen Hurts will take him.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He's only 26 and entering a contract year. If he shows out in 2021 and you traded for him, expect a nice-sized extension and you were able to get ahead of the curve.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Qadree Ollison
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Ollison is a big, bruising back… the kind of runner HC Arthur Smith used in Tennessee. Ok so he’s not even a third of Derrick Henry but hey we’re grasping at straws in the Atlanta backfield.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Grab him off your dynasty waiver wire in hopes he maybe could potentially be something this year. That’s desperate.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Najee Harris, Kalen Ballage, Anthony McFarland Jr.

notes.text: Running backs are at their prime when they enter the NFL, which makes them the most valuable their rookie season, unlike quarterbacks, wide receivers, and tight ends. Because of that, Harris, who takes over as the Steelers' lead back, is someone you want to have on your roster. The Steelers are a team that hasn't been shy about giving running backs 18-plus touches per game with Mike Tomlin at the helm. You don't draft a three-down back like Harris in the first round and put him in some timeshare. I wouldn't be surprised to see him average 20-plus touches per game, which puts him smack dab in the middle of the RB1 conversation.

There’s not much more a fantasy player can hope for in the NFL Draft than a 1st round RB. Harris is the complete package and in a dream scenario. He is built to carry the ball over 300 times. He has incredible hands and an immobile QB that loves to check down. His coach has shown time after time the desire to have one main RB. Yes, it’s not the best offensive line in the league in Pittsburgh, but volume is king for fantasy.

Najee might be one of the most likable players in the league. His versatile skillset makes his landing spot almost a moot point. His pro comparison to Matt Forte is more than apt given his fluidity as a pass catcher. Harris emerged from Runningback U as the school’s all-time leading rusher and smashing the total TD record. His offensive line in Pittsburgh could be a problem but the volume could overcome that issue. Harris profiles immediately as an impact rookie and could assert himself as an RB1 for fantasy as early as 2022.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Najee Harris
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Najee might be one of the most likable players in the league. His versatile skillset makes his landing spot almost a moot point. His pro comparison to Matt Forte is more than apt given his fluidity as a pass catcher. Harris emerged from Runningback U as the school’s all-time leading rusher and smashing the total TD record. His offensive line in Pittsburgh could be a problem but the volume could overcome that issue. Harris profiles immediately as an impact rookie and could assert himself as an RB1 for fantasy as early as 2022.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Harris is the clear RB1 in his draft class with the clearest path for touches. Rookie RBs are among the most valuable commodities in dynasty and he likely will only gain value heading into 2022.

notes.text: Part of the reason we liked Gesicki last year was due to the lack of verified options in the Dolphins passing attack. That's changed as we head into 2021, as the Dolphins have added Will Fuller and Jaylen Waddle to the arsenal. Despite the lack of options last year, Gesicki saw just 85 targets. There is a new offensive coordinator, which can certainly shake things up, but the additions of Fuller and Waddle reduce the need for Gesicki's athleticism, and he's not a possession-style tight end. His upside is capped, and his floor might be in jeopardy, too.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mike Gesicki
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Gesicki is maddening for fantasy because you see weeks where he's a PPR dominator and could easily win you a week. Others, he goes 1-for-15 and you swear you'll never do that to yourself again. We know he's an athletic freak but this is now his 4th year in the league and the clock is ticking. With so much competition for targets, Gesicki is a low-end TE1 at best in 2021… which doesn’t actually help your fantasy team on a consistent basis.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He'll be a free agent and may struggle to really breakout with Tua Tagovailoa at QB. Jaylen Waddle and Hunter Long were drafted and when you add Will Fuller V to the mix, not helping his chances.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Latavius Murray, Ty Montgomery, Tony Jones Jr., Devonta Freeman

notes.text: Yes, Drew Brees is gone, which have some concerned about the handcuff value of Murray. This is where I remind you about something. Remember when Alvin Kamara missed time in 2019 and Murray was the No. 2 running back for that short stretch? Well, one of those games he played was with Teddy Bridgewater under center, where Murray rushed for 119 yards and two touchdowns against the tough Bears defense. He's getting up there in age, but should still present borderline RB1 potential behind a great offensive line should Kamara miss any time.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Latavius Murray
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Whenever Murray was given the opportunity in 2020, he showed out including two top-5 performances. Finishing at RB33 in a backfield led by Alvin Kamara is nothing to bat your eyes at. He averaged 11.5 opportunities a game and is a worthy 8th/9th round depth piece at the RB position. Don’t be surprised if Murray outperforms his ADP yet again.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Murray is one of the more valuable backup RBs in dynasty. Kamara isn’t exactly unscathed on the injury front so if something happens to last year’s RB1, you might have one sitting on your bench ready to ball out. He has two years left on his deal.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Randall Cobb, Amari Rodgers, Davante Adams, Allen Lazard, Equanimeous St. Brown

notes.text: Now that Cobb is back in Green Bay with Aaron Rodgers, he's back on the fantasy radar. Knowing Rodgers specifically requested for the Packers to get Cobb back, it tells you he's getting opportunity right out of the gate, though it's worth noting he's never played in Matt LaFleur's offense. We shouldn't go overboard, though. The last three seasons Cobb was in Green Bay, he averaged 6.4 targets, 4.4 receptions, 44.5 yards, and 0.27 touchdowns per game, which extrapolate to 70 receptions, 712 yards, and four touchdowns over a full 16-game season. My guess would be that Cobb is a solid bye-week filler who'll offer a solid floor.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Randall Cobb
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: How lucky is Randall Cobb? Rescued from the Texans and back in Green Bay, because of Aaron Rodgers. Cobb may have weeks of fantasy relevance but with a low floor and low ceiling, is likely not worth drafting.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He has little to no value left in Dynasty. This doesn't change much with the Packers trade. If you can get any value for him now off of the news, you should probably do it.

notes.text: The trade for Randall Cobb all but ruined the potential value of Rodgers, who was facing an uphill battle as-is. I say that because Aaron Rodgers isn't someone who develops chemistry with his wide receivers immediately, and not just that, but the two haven't played together at all with Aaron missing all offseason programs. Amari has actually been raised around Cobb because his dad was Cobb's receivers coach at the University of Kentucky, so there should be good tutelage during Amari's rookie season, but it's tough to see him getting meaningful touches in the offense right away, and even if he does get on the field, he has to earn Aaron's trust. If you go back through Aaron's time with the Packers, you'll see that practically every receiver took time to turn into a fantasy option, including Davante Adams.

The Packers moved up seven spots in the 3rd round to select the former Clemson Tiger. He could crack the starting lineup in near future as the depth chart in Green Bay is pretty weak behind Davante Adams. He’s a well-built (5’10, 210) slot WR with similar measurements to an early career Randall Cobb. He’s a late round dart throw with a shot at being a contributor right away. UPDATE: now the Packers have traded for THE Randall Cobb, because Aaron Rodgers made them. It may take even longer for Amari Rodgers to get an opportunity to make an impact.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Amari Rodgers
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Packers moved up seven spots in the 3rd round to select the former Clemson Tiger. He could crack the starting lineup in near future as the depth chart in Green Bay is pretty weak behind Davante Adams. He’s a well-built (5’10, 210) slot WR with similar measurements to an early career Randall Cobb. He’s a late round dart throw with a shot at being a contributor right away. UPDATE: now the Packers have traded for THE Randall Cobb, because Aaron Rodgers made them. It may take even longer for Amari Rodgers to get an opportunity to make an impact.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: A former coach’s son, Rodgers has an NFL-ready body after playing four years at Clemson. With the Packers trading up to get him, don’t feel bad reaching a big in the second round of rookie drafts as we view Rodgers as a top-20 pick. However, his long-term value is a question mark and tied to Aaron Rodgers.

notes.text: If you're planning on taking a wide receiver in the first round, you'd better make sure he's going to perform without question. Adams is that player, as he's performed as a WR1 in 22 of his last 41 games (53.7 percent), which is historically good, and it's a three-year sample size. During that time, he's scored fewer than 11.1 PPR points just four times, and once was due to leaving with an injury. As long as Aaron Rodgers is with the Packers, Adams will be a can't-miss WR1.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Davante Adams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Adams was dominant in 2020 averaging 22.1 fantasy points per game while ranking #1 in yards per route run and receiving TDs. It was a historic season for a player who only appeared in 14 games. Now with Aaron Rodgers back, Adams is the top-ranked wide receiver for the 2021 season.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Coming off a historic season, he’s only 28 years old so expect 3-4 more major years of fantasy production. Could he and Rodgers sign for the same new team in 2022?

notes.text: When the Packers drafted Amari Rodgers, who has a lot of Randall Cobb to his game, Lazard's projection became unclear. He was the Packers primary slot receiver last year, playing 53 percent of his snaps in the slot. So, it's either they move Marquez Valdes-Scantling to the bench and put Lazard in his place, or all three of them rotate on the field, which is certainly not ideal for fantasy purposes. Lazard had his shot at a breakout, but unfortunately, it didn't happen.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Allen Lazard
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It's been a while since a second wide receiver has provided consistent fantasy production in Green Bay. With Rodgers back, Lazard could be a late-round WR with flex appeal on some weeks.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Lazard's future is a wildcard. Not only because of his one-year deal with the Packers, but because of Aaron Rodgers' uncertain future with the Packers.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Devin Funchess
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After opting out of the 2020 season, Devin S. Scrumptious is likely WR4 or lower on Packers depth chart. After winning TFFB's Nickname of the Year award in 2017, things have gone downhill in terms of fantasy relevance.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Still just 27, he’s among the many WR wildcards you may have on your bench in a dynasty league.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Josh Palmer, Mike Williams, Jalen Guyton

notes.text: How often can you find a wide receiver being drafted outside the top 40 who's capable of posting WR1-type numbers? Williams fits that bill. He already has a 1,000-yard season on his resume. He also has a 10-touchdown season on it. He also happens to have one of the brightest young stars as his quarterback with little else on the depth chart outside of Keenan Allen. Health has been the biggest question mark for Williams, but once you're outside the top-40 wide receivers, there's hardly guaranteed production on the board, so take the upside.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mike Williams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Big Mike Willy has sort of always hung around as an offseason hype man entering season-long drafts, but outside of 2018 when he finished as the WR24 on the back of ten TD receptions, he’s never put a full season together. He’s a fine late round bench WR given the upside of his QB, Justin Herbert.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Williams is set to become an unrestricted free agent after the 2021 season. Ironically, playing as the ‘big outside WR’, Williams’ best spot might actually be staying in LA to play with Justin Herbert. His previous perceived WR1 upside is now clearly a thing of the past.

notes.text: Would you believe me if I told you that Keenan Allen failed to record 1,000 yards last season? It's true. Despite seeing 147 targets (5th in NFL), he finished with 992 yards (17th among wide receivers). The Chargers offense is surely going to change with Anthony Lynn out of the picture, so the hope should be that they'll utilize Allen down the field just a tad more to increase his numbers. The good news is that Justin Herbert clearly found his "go-to" receiver, targeting Allen 10-plus times on 10 separate occasions. He's an extremely safe WR2 based on volume alone, though it may be tough for him to get into the top-tier WR1 conversation seeing he's never scored more than eight touchdowns.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Keenan Allen
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Entering 2020, there were some concerns regarding the Chargers’ offense and the ability of Justin Herbert to support the pass catchers...I think we can put those concerns to bed. Herbert was electric as a rookie, and he was locked on Keenan Allen, who was the 5th most targeted WR in terms of market share in the NFL. Allen has been a top-14 fantasy WR for four straight seasons and with Herbert slinging the rock, he’s a great bet to make it five straight.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Even though Keenan Allen turns 30 next offseason, for the next two plus years, he should remain highly productive. He’s got a stable QB situation and is one of the best route runners in the NFL. His style of play combined with accurate QB play should help to keep him as a PPR stud moving forward.

notes.text: Do you know how many times a Cardinals tight end scored double-digit half-PPR points last year? One. It was when Dan Arnold caught two balls for 61 yards and two touchdowns. Heck, there was just one time in 2019 where a Cardinals tight end caught more than three balls. It's simple: Kliff Kingsbury doesn't care about tight ends producing, especially when they added a couple receivers to the mix this offseason.

It should be an interesting debate regarding Woods this year, because on the surface, it appears that he gets an upgrade to Matthew Stafford. While that's true, it can be argued that Jared Goff's skill-set was tailormade for Woods' skill-set. The 7.1 air yards per target Woods saw in 2020 was the 10th-lowest mark among wide receivers. Meanwhile, Stafford likes to push the ball down the field a bit more. Because of the questions (good or bad), Woods should ultimately be viewed as a mid-to-low-end WR2.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Robert Woods
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Has Robert Woods ever not been a value in fantasy football? At this point, we sort of know what Robert Woods is - a consistent and reliable high end WR2 in fantasy. In fact, he’s finished as a top 17 WR three years in a row, and while he’s usually not a ‘sexy’ pick, Bobby Trees has shown sneaky upside. Now he’s set to play with arguably the best QB of his career. Once again, Woods looks like a rock solid WR2 for your roster at an affordable ADP.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Woods is now 29 years old, but he just signed a big time extension last year, locking him up in Los Angeles likely for the remainder of his career through the year 2025. His fantasy value is likely to decline over time, but for the next 2-3 seasons, Woods should continue to provide WR2/3 value despite nearing the dreaded 30 year old mark. This alone makes him a great trade target for dynasty managers contending for a title.

notes.text: This time last year, I was much higher on Taylor than the consensus. I like Taylor, but did everyone forget about what happened the first 10 weeks of the season? Taylor was the RB19 and David Montgomery was the RB20. Taylor finished the year as the RB6 while Montgomery was the RB4. Many will talk about Montgomery's schedule as the reason for his production, hence why he's ranked at RB20 in ECR right now, but are they ignoring Taylor's schedule? He played against the Texans TWICE, Packers, Raiders, Jaguars, and the Steelers (who were decimated by injuries in that game). That's a large reason for his jump in production. I still like Taylor, just not nearly as much as the consensus.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jonathan Taylor
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: JTT! Yes, he was a 90’s heartthrob turned NFL RB and he certainly heated up in the second half. From Weeks 11-17, he was the RB3 winning many managers fantasy championships that believed in him despite starting slow. In the lull months of October and November, he averaged only 12 carries per game. This team looks like a playoff contender and should be in the mix with Tennessee to win the AFC South. However, Taylor was game-scripted out of far too many games in 2020 as the team seems to like Nyheim Hines a lot. Taylor averaged only 45 rush yards per game in Colts losses in 2020. He’s an RB1 albeit with an annoying set of teammates.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: JTT is a certifiable top-5 RB in dynasty. He’s going to be a stud for the next couple of years and when Marlon Mack or Nyheim Hines finally leave town, watch out.

notes.text: Was his disappointing rookie season a product of bad quarterback play? Bad offensive scheme? Or was it Reagor himself? It may have been a combination of all three things, though the other two have changed this offseason, as Nick Sirianni is now the head coach, and Jalen Hurts is now the quarterback. The downside is that the Eagles drafted Devonta Smith in the first round and he's immediately going to become the No. 1 target for Hurts, which puts Reagor into competition with Dallas Goedert as the No. 2 option in this offense. If Hurts pans out, Reagor could be a value later in drafts, though he may be a bit more boom/bust than you'd like due to his inconsistent targets.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jalen Reagor
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Reagor was dealt a bad hand last year and never really got things going thanks to multiple injuries and poor QB play, but he should be an every-down player for Philly in 2021, something he couldn’t say last year. However, Philadelphia did move up in the first round to take Heisman-winning WR DeVonta Smith. There may not be enough passing volume to support multiple productive fantasy WRs.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Reagor is being shuffled to the back of dynasty benches as we trade for him on the cheap in hopes that Jalen Hurts and the offense take a step forward and produce for fantasy. He’s the perfect player to sneak into a package deal.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Stefon Diggs, Cole Beasley, Gabriel Davis, Emmanuel Sanders

notes.text: How in the world do you go from one team to another, with no offseason to build chemistry, and then churn out 127 receptions for 1,535 yards and eight touchdowns? Diggs did that because he's uber talented, and he finally got the targets he deserves. The Vikings gave him 112 targets or less in four of the five seasons with them, hiding his true ceiling. He's now tied to Josh Allen, who's continually improved since coming into the league, on a pass-first offense where he's the featured star. There's no reason to think they don't pick up where they left off in 2020. Heck, even his three games in the playoffs against legit opponents netted 20 receptions for 311 yards and two touchdowns.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Stefon Diggs
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After being traded in the 2020 offseason, the rhetoric around the industry was “be careful what you wish for,” with most suggesting Josh Allen’s accuracy woes would negatively impact Diggs. With Josh Allen taking a massive step forward in 2020, Diggs was the primary beneficiary leading the NFL in targets, receptions and yards. He came to play when it mattered most for fantasy managers in Weeks 14-16, totalling 81.3 fantasy points, 14.9 more points than the next closest receiver, Davante Adams. The only question with Diggs is whether or not Buffalo will return to a more balanced offense in 2021 after the Bills showed a willingness to abandon the run at times. Regardless, Diggs should dominate targets once again for Buffalo.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Diggs’ long term situation is as good as any wide receiver in football. He’s under contract with Buffalo through 2023, locking him into an elite target share in one of the most pass-happy offenses in football with Josh Allen. Barring any unforeseen circumstances, Diggs will continue to return WR1 value for multiple seasons.

notes.text: Did you know Beasley's finished as the WR34 and WR26 over the last two seasons with Allen under center? Crazy, right? He's not someone who's going to win you a fantasy championship singlehandedly, but he's certainly someone who can provide WR3 value in a pinch and/or during bye weeks.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Cole Beasley
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Cole Beasley is undervalued in fantasy football every year, especially in PPR formats. The Beasles was the WR17 in PPR formats from Week 6 on last season, and he can always be drafted in the double digit rounds. If the Bills continue their pass happy ways and aside from some offseason drama, Beasley figures to be a fantastic value yet again in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Beasley is locked up in Buffalo for another two seasons. We know Diggs will dominate targets but with Josh Allen as his QB, Beasley is a sneaky trade target for contending rosters.

notes.text: Despite playing as the No. 4 wide receiver behind Stefon Diggs, John Brown, and Cole Beasley last year, Davis managed to make his presence felt, racking up 599 yards and seven touchdowns on just 62 targets. The Bills lost Brown this offseason but gained Emmanuel Sanders. They're not the same player, as Sanders isn't someone who'll stretch the field the way Brown or Davis did/can. If you're looking for a boom-or-bust player in the late rounds who just might pay off, Davis makes sense.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Gabriel Davis
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: As a rookie and the Bills’ WR4, it’s wild to see Davis was focused on as a dominator when Josh Allen and company got in close. He accumulated 12 “end-zone” targets. That’s one more than Davante Adams had and by far more than any other rookie WR. He finished at WR56 mostly on the back of his seven TDs. With John Brown gone, Davis could grow into a bigger role and is a fine late round pick as a depth piece attached to a good offense.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Davis’ dynasty stock rose this offseason once John Brown left. He could develop into a solid No. 2 wideout opposite of Stefon Diggs with the ability to win in the paint. He likely is too expensive now to trade for as Davis managers are licking their chops for finding a late round WR.

notes.text: He's now been on four different teams in the last four years, though he's still remaining relevant in the fantasy conversation. He's also going to play with one of the best young quarterbacks in football, though he's clearly behind Stefon Diggs in the pecking order. The move to sign Sanders was odd considering how well Gabriel Davis played last year, but the Bills do run the second-most 4WR sets in football, so they'll be on the field together at times. But still, Sanders is now 34 years old and is likely in Buffalo to provide a reliable receiver in a pinch rather than one who'll pop back into the WR3 conversation. He is what he is at this point, which is a low-upside bye week filler.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Emmanuel Sanders
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Set to play on his fourth team over the last three seasons at 34 years old, Emmanuel Sanders goes from New Orleans and Drew Brees to Buffalo and Josh Allen. With John Brown vacating the WR2/3 role, Sanders should be in line for an every down role, but does he still have enough left in the tank for it to matter for fantasy? We know Stefon Diggs will dominate targets, Beasley will get his and Josh Allen will steal TDs at the goal line. Expect Sanders to help the Bills more than your fantasy team.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s 34 and playing on a one year deal. Who’s to say he doesn’t hang up the cleats if Buffalo wins it all?

notes.text: Running backs are at their prime when they enter the NFL, which makes them the most valuable their rookie season, unlike quarterbacks, wide receivers, and tight ends. Because of that, Harris, who takes over as the Steelers' lead back, is someone you want to have on your roster. The Steelers are a team that hasn't been shy about giving running backs 18-plus touches per game with Mike Tomlin at the helm. You don't draft a three-down back like Harris in the first round and put him in some timeshare. I wouldn't be surprised to see him average 20-plus touches per game, which puts him smack dab in the middle of the RB1 conversation.

There’s not much more a fantasy player can hope for in the NFL Draft than a 1st round RB. Harris is the complete package and in a dream scenario. He is built to carry the ball over 300 times. He has incredible hands and an immobile QB that loves to check down. His coach has shown time after time the desire to have one main RB. Yes, it’s not the best offensive line in the league in Pittsburgh, but volume is king for fantasy.

Najee might be one of the most likable players in the league. His versatile skillset makes his landing spot almost a moot point. His pro comparison to Matt Forte is more than apt given his fluidity as a pass catcher. Harris emerged from Runningback U as the school’s all-time leading rusher and smashing the total TD record. His offensive line in Pittsburgh could be a problem but the volume could overcome that issue. Harris profiles immediately as an impact rookie and could assert himself as an RB1 for fantasy as early as 2022.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Najee Harris
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Najee might be one of the most likable players in the league. His versatile skillset makes his landing spot almost a moot point. His pro comparison to Matt Forte is more than apt given his fluidity as a pass catcher. Harris emerged from Runningback U as the school’s all-time leading rusher and smashing the total TD record. His offensive line in Pittsburgh could be a problem but the volume could overcome that issue. Harris profiles immediately as an impact rookie and could assert himself as an RB1 for fantasy as early as 2022.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Harris is the clear RB1 in his draft class with the clearest path for touches. Rookie RBs are among the most valuable commodities in dynasty and he likely will only gain value heading into 2022.

notes.text: When running through projections on the Saints, it's easy to fall in love with Trautman this year. Outside of Michael Thomas and Alvin Kamara, they don't have any reliable targets, and Trautman did well with his opportunity last year. After parting ways with both Emmanuel Sanders and Jared Cook, there's suddenly a lot of opportunity available for him. There would certainly be less appeal if Taysom Hill were the starter, but many are expecting Jameis Winston to be under center come Week 1. Whatever the case, Trautman makes for a great late-round pick where you'll find out exactly what you have in the first game of the season. There's a scenario where he finishes as a top-10 tight end, especially now that we know Michael Thomas is going to miss time at the start of the season.

Get hyped for Traut-SZN! It was made clear in the draft, when New Orleans traded four picks to move up, that Adam Trautman was the future. He may not have been unleashed as a rookie, but the path is now open with the team waiving TEs Jared Cook and Josh Hill. Trautman has the ability and opportunity to establish himself as the No.3 pass catching option behind Thomas and Kamara. He graded out as the best run blocking TE in the league last year which will keep him on the field. It's a longer shot, but Trautman is worth the gamble if you punt the TE position.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Adam Trautman
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Goodbye, Jared Cook. Hello, Mr. Trautman. We haven't seen him do much meaningful on the football field but the opportunity is there in 2021. He was uber productive in college and could be a top-10 TE if things break right. Trautman is worth the shot as a late round TE who you can cut bait with if things don’t work out early. Mike approves this message.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Trautman truthers unite! Dynasty is likely the best place to get in on the Trautman party as 2022 is probably when the rocket ship launches to the moon. In all seriousness, in many leagues, trading for Traut somehow became an impossible task this offseason.

notes.text: Based on the actual opportunity Chubb got in 2020, he should've finished as the RB24 in half PPR formats. Instead, Chubb scored 54.5 more fantasy points than the average running back would've and finished as the RB9 despite playing in just 12 games. The new offense proved to be very beneficial to the run game, though Kareem Hunt's presence does limit Chubb's true ceiling, which should be top-five, but unless he starts to get more targets, he'll remain in the mid-to-low-end RB1 range.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Nick Chubb
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It’s tough forming a compelling argument against Chubb because like Derrick Henry, he’s just an outlier. Chubb is an elite runner on a run-first team with the Browns, who had the league’s #1 rated offensive line in 2020. The main concerns are the lack of targets (fewer than two per game in 2020) and the presence of Kareem Hunt. We get it but have you ever seen this guy play football? Despite missing four games, he led NFL in Yards after Contact and had the highest Elusive Rating per PFF. He’s a locked-in end-of 1st round RB in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s just plain fun to watch play football and he’s also in a contract year although it’s expected that he’d stay with the Browns.

notes.text: If you follow college football and/or the NFL Draft, you know that Chase was a superior prospect to Tee Higgins. What we saw Higgins do as a rookie with Joe Burrow was impressive, as he was the WR11 during the eight full games they played together. Keep in mind that was with zero chemistry. Now you insert Chase into the offense, who already has chemistry with Burrow, as they set records at LSU together, and what do we get? I'll acknowledge that Higgins is going to cap Chase's ceiling and that he may not get to top-12 production, but you don't draft Chase at No. 5 overall (over an elite offensive tackle) if you're not going to highlight him in the offense immediately. Heck, even A.J. Green, who averaged 5.0 yards per target, saw 104 targets in this offense last year. Chase should be a WR2 right out of the gate.

Chase was ranked unanimously as the No. 1 WR in the NFL Draft. That hasn’t happened since Calvin Johnson was drafted. Chase is truly a 99% type of prospect. His college production profile is incredible. His athletic testing is off the charts. He’s back with his college QB. While Tee Higgins is a solid NFL WR, he’s not a true No. 1. Chase has a path to immediate fantasy relevance.

The Bengals picked Ja’Marr Chase with the 5th overall pick in this year’s draft. He’s reunited with his college QB, Joe Burrow. On the surface, it may be difficult to envision a scenario where Ja’Marr Chase, Tyler Boyd and Tee Higgins are all fantasy viable. But, AJ Green very quietly saw 101 targets last year. Assuming most of those go to Chase, he could flash massive upside if he’s as good as his college profile says he is.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Ja'Marr Chase
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Bengals picked Ja’Marr Chase with the 5th overall pick in this year’s draft. He’s reunited with his college QB, Joe Burrow. On the surface, it may be difficult to envision a scenario where Ja’Marr Chase, Tyler Boyd and Tee Higgins are all fantasy viable. But, AJ Green very quietly saw 101 targets last year. Assuming most of those go to Chase, he could flash massive upside if he’s as good as his college profile says he is.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Chase has one of the cleanest analytics profiles we’ve seen at the WR position in quite some time and now he’s reunited with Joe Burrow. His value and hype is massive for someone who hasn’t played an NFL snap yet.

notes.text: As of now, we have to assume it's Raheem Mostert as the starting running back, though Kyle Shanahan did trade up into the third round to get Sermon. This should tell you that Mostert is on a short leash, and to be fair, he hasn't been able to hold up to a workhorse workload. The 49ers have one of the softest schedules in the league among running backs, so if we start hearing whispers that Sermon will start right out of the gate, he should shoot up draft boards. For now, he should be viewed as one of the best bench stashes in fantasy football.

Any RB selected by the 49ers makes you perk up. He also is an interesting name to monitor knowing that the San Francisco backfield collective scored the 3rd most combined points in the league. He’s a solid RB3 with room to return massive value. For redraft, there’s upside if the opportunity is there or if Raheem Mostert misses time. Without the opportunity, he may be a bench clogger that you are afraid to drop.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Trey Sermon
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Any RB selected by the 49ers makes you perk up. He also is an interesting name to monitor knowing that the San Francisco backfield collective scored the 3rd most combined points in the league. He’s a solid RB3 with room to return massive value. For redraft, there’s upside if the opportunity is there or if Raheem Mostert misses time. Without the opportunity, he may be a bench clogger that you are afraid to drop.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Sermon looks like a borderline 1st round rookie pick with room to grow into an even bigger role in 2022 when Raheem Mostert becomes a free-agent. The range of outcomes is wide with San Francisco being a haven for RB fantasy points as well as a revolving door.

notes.text: Had Hubbard entered the NFL Draft a year earlier, he may have gone in the second round. But that's not what happened. He returned to school and had a weak 2020 season, leading him to fall to the end of the fourth round. He's certainly not getting much playing time with Christian McCaffrey healthy, but he should be the clear-cut handcuff, which had plenty of value last year in this offense (Mike Davis). Unfortunately, the Panthers offensive line continues to get worse, and it's tough to say Sam Darnold is an upgrade at quarterback, making Hubbard a mediocre handcuff in fantasy.

Christian McCaffrey played an average of 92% of snaps per game in 2018 and 2019. It remains to be seen if the coaching staff feels differently about CMC’s workhorse usage after his injury-riddled 2020 season. With Mike Davis leaving in free agency, Hubbard has the potential to win the backup job.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chuba Hubbard
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Christian McCaffrey played an average of 92% of snaps per game in 2018 and 2019. It remains to be seen if the coaching staff feels differently about CMC’s workhorse usage after his injury-riddled 2020 season. With Mike Davis leaving in free agency, Hubbard has the potential to win the backup job.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s obviously road blocked by CMC but is worth looking at as a cheap trade target for insurance purposes.

notes.text: There have been 109 running back performances that have netted 25-plus half-PPR points over the last two years. Despite missing essentially the whole 2020 season, McCaffrey has accounted for 9.2 percent of them. He's somehow managed to score 25-plus points in 10 of his last 19 games, and has scored fewer than 19 fantasy points in just two of them. He's basically posting quarterback numbers as a running back. He should be the No. 1 pick in 2021 drafts.

The 1.01 of fantasy drafts was a massive bust in fantasy last year, missing 13 of 16 games. He suffered a high ankle sprain in Week 2, which forced him to miss 6 weeks, then suffered an AC joint sprain in his right shoulder in Week 9, forcing him to miss the remainder of the season. It was uphill sledding with these two injuries for CMC, as they’re two injuries that are tough to battle through in the middle of the season. However, both heal reliably with enough time and rehab, and there’s no correlation between the two injuries. Managers can draft CMC with confidence this year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Christian McCaffrey
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Don’t overthink this one. A 17-game season makes him even more valuable for fantasy. CMC is a true workhorse back seeing over 90% of snaps in 2018 & 2019. We know he’s an elite pass-catcher averaging 101 receptions in three full seasons and his fantasy finishes (RB11, RB3, RB1) have shown us we know his floor is higher than anyone else. The only concerns would be recovering from his ankle, shoulder, and thigh injuries from 2020 and the Panthers installing a new QB in Sam Darnold. He’s the 1.01, basically two players in one, and feels like your opponent is cheating if you have to play against him that week.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: CMC is still in the conversation as the 1.01 in dynasty startups even at age 25 coming off an injury-plagued season. Basically, why would you want to trade away this guy?

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Kenneth Gainwell, Miles Sanders, Boston Scott

notes.text: Gainwell was one of, if not the, best pass catching running backs in the draft. It's unfortunate to see him fall until the fifth round in the NFL Draft, as that doesn't guarantee him a whole lot of opportunity out of the gate, but given Nick Sirianni's ties to Frank Reich, we could see Gainwell in the Nyheim Hines role, which we know has value. The signing of Kerryon Johnson clouded his outlook though, making him just a late-round flier.

We all need some more Kenny G in our lives. But after dropping all the way to the 5th round, we need to temper our expectations. Memphis has churned out some incredible pros (DeAngelo Williams, Tony Pollard, Darrell Henderson Jr., Antonio Gibson) at the RB position and that will definitely influence rookie drafters. Opting out of the 2020 season didn’t help overcome his small stature. Gainwell is a great pass catcher, an area where Miles struggled in 2020. He joins a backfield with Miles Sanders, Boston Scott, Kerryon Johnson, and Jordan Howard.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kenneth Gainwell
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We all need some more Kenny G in our lives. But after dropping all the way to the 5th round, we need to temper our expectations. Memphis has churned out some incredible pros (DeAngelo Williams, Tony Pollard, Darrell Henderson Jr., Antonio Gibson) at the RB position and that will definitely influence rookie drafters. Opting out of the 2020 season didn’t help overcome his small stature. Gainwell is a great pass catcher, an area where Miles struggled in 2020. He joins a backfield with Miles Sanders, Boston Scott, Kerryon Johnson, and Jordan Howard.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Gainwell went from a borderline 1st round rookie pick before the draft to falling all the way to outside the 2nd round. It’s crowded in the Eagles backfield, but Gainwell’s pass catching chops could help him make an impact as a rookie and carve out a future role.

notes.text: The start to Sanders' career hasnt been what we'd hoped for, delivering RB2 or better numbers in just 14-of-28 of games (50 percent). To be fair, he hasn't been used in a workhorse role, totaling more than 15 touches just 11 times over that span. Will the departure of Doug Pederson allow him to shine, or will Nick Sirianni implement a timeshare as well? The depth chart now consists of Sanders, Kerryon Johnson, and Kenneth Gainwell, so this could very well be a Colts-like backfield, which would make sense given that's where Sirianni comes from. Sanders should be treated as a timeshare RB2 who's more talented than most in that conversation.

Miles Sanders is an incredibly talented running back.  So why did he make this list?  The team resigned Jordan Howard, drafted Kenny Gainwell, and signed Kerryon Johnson.  Boston Scott is currently still on the roster.  The message to Miles Sanders?  The team wants more.  More from the position and likely more of a timeshare.  The world we hoped was ahead of Sanders simply may not be there, so lower your expectations a bit.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Miles Sanders
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Sanders was frustrating last year with a couple of huge runs against tough defenses and absolutely vanishing some weeks. He's always had the 3-down skillset but the ship has likely sailed of having RB1 upside. His offensive line is aged in Philadelphia and we have no idea how the offense will hold up for fantasy purposes with a whole season with Jalen Hurts at the helm.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you can trade him for a consistent WR or a 1st round rookie pick, it might be time to get ahead of the curve. Sanders’ value is like a balloon slowly letting out air.

notes.text: He went from a player who had the passing-down back role locked down at the start of the offseason, but we've watched that fade as we move throughout the offseason. The addition of Kenneth Gainwell in the draft was always going to be a problem, as Gainwell was arguably the best pass-catching back in the draft class. Not just Gainwell, though, as the team also signed Kerryon Johnson once the Lions released him. Opportunity is fading for Scott, who's nowhere near the redraft radar at this point.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Boston Scott
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The former UDFA had few explosive plays in 2020. He’s still a solid pass-catcher but with a new regime change on Philly, there’s no telling how involved he’ll be. He’s competing with Kerryon Johnson and Kenneth Gainwell for touches behind Miles Sanders.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Scott is a flier at best in a crowded Philly backfield.

notes.text: It's obviously never a good thing to see a running back cut from his rookie contract, but that's what happened with Johnson and the Lions. The Eagles were quick to snag him after that, but it's another timeshare situation where he's clearly the No. 2 back behind Miles Sanders. When you add in Kenneth Gainwell as the best receiving option, it's difficult to say where Johnson fits in. He'll need an injury to be fantasy relevant.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kerryon Johnson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Dealing with injuries and an offense that can’t run the ball consistency, Kerryon never got it going in Detroit. Now he joins a crowded Eagles backfield with Miles Sanders, Boston Scott, Jordan Howard, and rookie Kenneth Gainwell.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you’re still rostering Kerryon, all you can really do is hold on and hope he gets another shot with his new team.

notes.text: After exiting Denver's mess to join Las Vegas, most assumed Booker's career was nearing an end, but he was solid with them, averaging 4.5 yards per carry and eating into Josh Jacobs' workload a bit. While I don't expect the same thing to happen with the Giants, he's the clear No. 2 on their depth chart behind Saquon Barkley, who's had plenty of health concerns in his short career.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Devontae Booker
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Booker signed on with the Giants as Saquon Barkley’s backup. In deep leagues, he could be drafted incase Saquon isn't ready to go Week 1.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s roster worthy in deep leagues as an insurance policy to Saquon.

notes.text: After setting the fantasy world on fire his rookie season with over 2,000 yards from scrimmage and 15 touchdowns, Barkley hasn't exactly lived up to expectations producing 1,535 total yards and eight touchdowns over 15 games the last two seasons. He tore his ACL early in the season, which should give him plenty of time to bounce back, though his violent running style could take a bit longer in recovery. The Giants suddenly have more weapons than ever in the passing game, so Barkley is unlikely to come close to the 121 targets he saw in 2018, though he should have more scoring opportunities. There is some risk with Barkley at the top of drafts due to his knee, but when on the field, we know he'll produce.

Saquon Barkley tore the ACL, MCL and meniscus in his right knee in Week 2 against Chicago and underwent reconstructive surgery on October 30. By all accounts, Barkley is progressing as expected and is likely to be ready for Week 1, but the Giants will reportedly take it slow with their star RB at the start of training camp. He’ll have had 10+ months of rehab prior to the start of the season, but his year could get off to a slower start given that the meniscus repair requires a longer recovery timeline. All in all, however, research suggests that RBs coming off ACL surgery are more likely to return to form if: 1) They are age 24 or younger, 2) They have 1st or 2nd round NFL Draft capital, and 3) They’re athletic. Saquon checks all three boxes and should still return to 100% this season.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Saquon Barkley
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It’s been a while since we’ve seen Saquon on the field so maybe you forgot how much an elite talent he is. He did drop in efficiency and touches from 2018 to 2019 but still managed the type of production you want in a 1st round RB. The major concern is coming back from a torn ACL in an offense led by Daniel Jones. The Giants were dead last in yards per TD in 2020 (176.2) and going into Year 3, things need to shift. With Kenny Golladay and Kyle Rudolph added, this the best mix of weapons to compliment Saquon. The Giants have made it clear that they won't rush Saquon into game action. As of now, he's not expected to miss Week 1, but also isn't guaranteed to be ready.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Saquon’s dynasty value has held steady since entering the league as a top-2 RB which is a rare feat to accomplish over four years despite his injuries. Still only 24 years old, he’s playing for a second contract after the Giants picked up his 5th year option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Andy Dalton
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Dalton was serviceable last year in Dallas and after being announced as the team’s “QB1” earlier this offseason, it now seems clear that Justin Fields will take over at some point.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s carved out a nice little fantasy career since 2011. But he’s a backup at best now.

notes.text: The tumble to pick 11 was unforeseen by many draft pundits but the ammo that Chicago unloaded to move up nine spots shows you just how desperate this team was to jump on Fields. He’s an effortless thrower and a dynamic runner who has shown out well in big spots on the national stage. While Andy Dalton apparently is the team’s QB1, we’ve seen this same refrain when Mike Glennon (yes, the great MG) was named starter only for #2 overall pick Mitchell Trubisky to quickly supplant him. Fields is way more talented and should resurrect the marketability of this Bears franchise and give Allen Robinson II some optimism about who is throwing him the ball. Rookie QBs with the ability to run the ball can be immediately viable.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Justin Fields
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The tumble to pick 11 was unforeseen by many draft pundits but the ammo that Chicago unloaded to move up nine spots shows you just how desperate this team was to jump on Fields. He’s an effortless thrower and a dynamic runner who has shown out well in big spots on the national stage. While Andy Dalton apparently is the team’s QB1, we’ve seen this same refrain when Mike Glennon (yes, the great MG) was named starter only for #2 overall pick Mitchell Trubisky to quickly supplant him. Fields is way more talented and should resurrect the marketability of this Bears franchise and give Allen Robinson II some optimism about who is throwing him the ball. Rookie QBs with the ability to run the ball can be immediately viable.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Fields could end up being the best QB in this class. He could easily be a top-5 fantasy QB in a couple of years if the Bears surround him with the right weapons.

notes.text: If I'm being honest, I want nothing to do with the Texans this year. That's rare for me to say, as I'm a value-based fantasy manager, but I just don't see value on this team. Watson has stood by the fact that he doesn't want to play for the Texans and isn't participating in camp. On top of that, he might be facing a suspension by the NFL for his pending assault cases. We talk about how easy replacing a quarterback is in fantasy every year, so why would we risk a draft pick on Watson? Unless it's one of your final picks, I would just avoid the situation. Taylor has given us fantasy-viable performances in the past, but the last time that happened was in 2017, when he had much more mobility than he does today. Despite starting at least 14 games in three straight seasons with the Bills, Taylor never threw for more than 3,035 yards in a season. He's now 33 years old and playing for 65-year-old David Culley with one of the worst supporting casts in the league. He also has the Texans third-round pick Mills waiting in the wings. This is one of those situations where I'm okay being wrong if one of these quarterbacks pans out.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyrod Taylor
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Taylor somehow finds himself back in the fantasy conversation with the Deshaun Watson saga looming. He’s been relevant for fantasy in the past solely on the basis of his legs. He signed a one-year, $12 million deal but this has to be the worst arsenal of weapons in the league. Don’t be surprised if he becomes streamable but his ceiling is super low.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Likely resurrected off your waiver wire, he’s on his last legs in dynasty.

notes.text: The Texans want Watson to play for them. Watson doesn't want to play for them. Watson wants to be traded. No team wants the PR nightmare that would come with a trade for Watson. Also, the Texans don't want to trade him. The NFL might also step in and suspend Watson for these off-the-field incidents. It's not one obstacle, it's many of them. He shouldn't be on your redraft radar for the time being.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Deshaun Watson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Watson is the subject of many trade rumors but what isn’t in doubt is the fact that he’s a competitor despite a 2020 season flushed down the toilet for Houston, due to Bill O’Brien. After BOB’s departure following an 0-4 start, Watson was the QB1 the rest of the way averaging 25 fantasy points per contest. He led the NFL in passing yards and yards per pass attempt despite losing DeAndre Hopkins. His pending legal situation presents a giant question mark of whether he’ll be the starter for the Texans (or any team) in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: While his legal situation unfolds Deshaun Watson's value in a dynasty league is even more of a mystery than his 2021 status. His Dynasty value is all over the place depending on who you talk to.

notes.text: I know Leonard Fournette had a strong finish to the season while Jones was hurt, but we mustn't forget that Jones averaged 5.14 yards per carry and nearly hit 1,000 rushing yards despite finishing with just 192 carries. There are just eight running backs in the post-merger era who've finished with as many yards as Jones did with 192 or less carries. He's not going to be heavily utilized in the passing game, which severely caps his upside, but Jones is the Bucs best ball carrier.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Ronald Jones II
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: RoJo! He ran for almost 1,000 yards and averaged 12.3 fantasy points per game last year. Heck, for the first 12 weeks of the season, Jones was the RB10! But you, like the rest of the world, feel like that is a faded memory after the Buccaneers installed “Playoff Lenny” to a Super Bowl title. Jones still can break a long one but now he’s a roll of the dice alongside Fournette and Giovani Bernard in this backfield. You can’t FLEX him as you likely won’t know which weeks to start him.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Jones is a free agent in 2022 and without Tom Brady and this offense, his value will likely plummet. He’s still only 23 so there’s some miles still left on the tires.

notes.text: While it's typically tough for a rookie quarterback to make it into top-12 territory, Lawrence is likely the exception to the rule. He comes in as an advanced passer who has tremendous touch on his passes that not many rookies do. The Jaguars defense is in clear rebuild mode, which should allow for plenty of pass attempts, making 4,000-plus passing yards likely. On top of that, Lawrence has great mobility and is likely to rush for 400-plus yards and a handful of touchdowns on the ground. That alone should get him into the top-15, with a good chance at top-12.

We all knew this was coming. Jacksonville’s franchise gets to press reset on their recent draft failings and now envision what could be moving forward. The AFC South division is by far the worst in the league and while the Jaguars defense needs major work, the offense could make some noise in 2021. He has three legitimate WRs and RBs each able to contribute. Lawrence’s generational chorus has been sung again and again but where he excelled in 2020 at Clemson was short-area and deep passing.
