In 2020, he led college football in “screen yards” for a reason while also accumulating a 113.4 passer rating and ten TDs on 20+ yard pass attempts. He’s worth a late round stab at catching some rookie magic. It shouldn’t surprise anyone if Lawrence finishes year one inside the top-15.

Lawrence is one of the most pro-ready prospects in recent years. Urban Meyer may not succeed as an NFL head coach, but he'll put Lawrence in a position to put up fantasy points. With Chark, Shenault, Jones, and Etienne in tow, Lawrence could surprise with weekly bursts and has the potential to be a late-round steal. Consider the work Justin Herbert did last season as a template for potential success. Lawrence will scramble his way to some value as well, and be given full control of the offense. He could have some big weeks, as we've seen several rookies contribute to fantasy in recent years. Keep an eye on him.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Trevor Lawrence
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We all knew this was coming. Jacksonville’s franchise gets to press reset on their recent draft failings and now envision what could be moving forward. The AFC South division is by far the worst in the league and while the Jaguars defense needs major work, the offense could make some noise in 2021. He has three legitimate WRs and RBs each able to contribute. Lawrence’s generational chorus has been sung again and again but where he excelled in 2020 at Clemson was short-area and deep passing. In 2020, he led college football in “screen yards” for a reason while also accumulating a 113.4 passer rating and ten TDs on 20+ yard pass attempts. He’s worth a late round stab at catching some rookie magic. It shouldn’t surprise anyone if Lawrence finishes year one inside the top-15.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Lawrence should comfortably be the 1.01 in rookie Superflex drafts and should have moments as a viable streamer in 2021. He’s a likely top-10 QB for the next decade.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Chase Edmonds, Eno Benjamin, Jonathan Ward

notes.text: Have we seen Edmonds carry the workload for the Cardinals before? Well, kind of. Despite Kenyan Drake struggling through much of 2020, there were just two games where Edmonds finished with more than eight carries, which is certainly a concern. The Cardinals went out and signed James Conner in free agency, but he's proven to be incapable of staying healthy with a full workload, and it wasn't a pricey contract, so maybe we see Edmonds in a bigger role. Whatever the case, we know he has the pass-catching role locked down, which has value in itself, as he was a flex-type option most weeks (he was an RB3 or better 62.5 percent of the time). This offense is going to score points, so if Edmonds were to get a slight bump in carries, he could make his way into the RB2 conversation. Draft him as an RB3/flex and hope that's the case. Just know that he's still yet to crack 100 carries in a season.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chase Edmonds
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Only 5’9”, Edmonds is built like Dion Lewis which means he'll always be more of a threat in the passing game than a between-the-tackles runner. Last year he saw the 6th most targets and tied for 7th most routes run among RBs in 2020. With Kenyan Drake now in Las Vegas, it looks like he’ll be paired with James Conner and it’s unclear what that backfield split will be.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He can be an RB3 but if someone else envisions him as a potential RB2 with upside, look to move him. Edmonds is a free agent in 2022 so it's time to trade him now.

notes.text: Fitzpatrick broke out in his first season with Louisville, putting up 700/9. Then the numbers basically stagnated. He ended up playing all four years in school, which doesn’t generally translate to fantasy success. However, he was drafted in the early 4th Round by the Titans, whose 2nd best WR is Josh Reynolds. For redraft, he likely has little 2021 value.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dez Fitzpatrick
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Fitzpatrick broke out in his first season with Louisville, putting up 700/9. Then the numbers basically stagnated. He ended up playing all four years in school, which doesn’t generally translate to fantasy success. However, he was drafted in the early 4th Round by the Titans, whose 2nd best WR is Josh Reynolds. For redraft, he likely has little 2021 value.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s worth a flier in the later rookie picks based on opportunity, but is still a dart throw given the success rate of WRs drafted in the 4th round or later.

notes.text: The public perception on Jones is that he's towards the end of his career, but that's simply not true. In fact, he averaged a career-high 11.3 yards per target during the 2020 season and was the WR13 in half-PPR points per game while ceding plenty of work to up-and-coming superstar Calvin Ridley. It'll be a similar situation in Tennessee, as Jones will now play alongside what might be the next generation's Julio Jones, and that's A.J. Brown. Similar to Atlanta, Jones and Brown are going to cap each other's truly elite ceiling, but as Jones and Ridley proved last year, it's certainly not out of the realm of possibilities that they're both top-12 wide receivers, especially when you factor in Ryan Tannehill's efficiency. Oh, and stop calling Jones injury prone - he's played at least 14 games in seven of the last nine seasons, and has totaled at least 1,394 yards in six of the last seven seasons. You don't do that if you're injury prone.

Julio Jones battled a hamstring strain off and on all season as he was in and out of the lineup throughout the year after aggravating the same injury twice. We know the greatest risk for re-injury upon returning to the field is in the first two weeks, and that’s exactly what happened for Jones in 2020. However, with a full offseason of recovery, look for Jones to return to form in 2021. That said, Julio is now 32 years old, and research suggests that re-injury risk for hamstring, quad and calf strains increases 1.3x per year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Julio Jones
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: With the trade to Tennessee, one of the true GOATs at the WR position finds himself now as second fiddle to the new hotness known as A.J. Brown. He should still maintain a healthy target share with Corey Davis and Jonnu Smith gone via free agency. Still, with fewer targets than he was used to in Atlanta, he may not be as consistent as Julio in years past. Perhaps his TDs can go up as the Titans offense has lived off being efficient in recent seasons. As a Titan, he lands as a top-20 WR in our initial projections for 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: When the 2021 season ends, Julio Jones will have completed his 11th season in the NFL. At this point, each year that passes will lead to a reduction in Julio’s dynasty value as he likely only has a couple of seasons left as a top tier producer. Unless you’re competing for a championship, it’s time to move on from the future Hall of Famer.

notes.text: Brown is a stud, plain and simple. He's defied the rule of regression and continues to blow the roof off normal projections. Based on the targets he saw last year and where on the field he saw them, he was supposed to finish as the No. 30 wide receiver. That's the opportunity he had. Well, he finished as the No. 12 wide receiver. The year before that, he was supposed to finish as the No. 49 wide receiver but finished No. 15 instead. The addition of Julio Jones will certainly limit his target ceiling, but based on what we've seen to this point, his efficiency should carry him to new heights in 2021.

Brown suffered a bone bruise in his knee in Week 2 then missed two games before returning in Week 5. Upon returning, Brown was still playing at less than 100% as he was listed on the Titans injury report most of the season as the team attempted to limit his practice reps. Then, in January after the season was over, Brown underwent a “clean up” procedure in both knees, likely to address some mild residual damage from his bone bruise in September. Even at less than 100%, Brown posted a WR11 season and now he’s got virtually no target competition. There’s a lot to like about Brown in 2021, including the fact that he’ll be much healthier this season.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: A.J. Brown
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: A.J. Brown finished 2020 as the WR11 despite only playing in 14 games and seeing just 106 targets. The offseason dreams of A.J. Brown seeing unlimited targets in 2021 is gone after the Titans traded for Julio Jones. However, Brown should still maintain alpha status in this offense as Corey Davis and Jonnu Smith left via free agency. Even with the addition of Julio, A.J. Brown is still right on the fringe of a top-12 WR in our rankings.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: A.J. Brown ranks 2nd in NFL history at the wide receiver position in yards per target (11.19) over the first two years of an NFL career (min 135 targets). Before the Titans traded for Julio Jones, it was not hyperbole to suggest that Brown could be valued as the WR1 overall in dynasty after the 2021 season. Julio is 32 and missed seven games in 2020 with a hamstring injury. While his upside for 2020 may not be as high as it was, A.J. Brown is still the future and a supreme talent at just age 24.

notes.text: Yes, Drew Brees is gone, which have some concerned about the handcuff value of Murray. This is where I remind you about something. Remember when Alvin Kamara missed time in 2019 and Murray was the No. 2 running back for that short stretch? Well, one of those games he played was with Teddy Bridgewater under center, where Murray rushed for 119 yards and two touchdowns against the tough Bears defense. He's getting up there in age, but should still present borderline RB1 potential behind a great offensive line should Kamara miss any time.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Latavius Murray
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Whenever Murray was given the opportunity in 2020, he showed out including two top-5 performances. Finishing at RB33 in a backfield led by Alvin Kamara is nothing to bat your eyes at. He averaged 11.5 opportunities a game and is a worthy 8th/9th round depth piece at the RB position. Don’t be surprised if Murray outperforms his ADP yet again.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Murray is one of the more valuable backup RBs in dynasty. Kamara isn’t exactly unscathed on the injury front so if something happens to last year’s RB1, you might have one sitting on your bench ready to ball out. He has two years left on his deal.

notes.text: Sure, Lockett finished as the No. 9 fantasy wide receiver last year, but ask anyone who rostered him if he was a WR1. Heck, as them if he was a reliable WR2. The answer would be no, as he finished with WR2 or better numbers just 37.5 percent of the time which was behind players like Diontae Johnson, Curtis Samuel, John Brown, and Jamison Crowder. How's that possible? Because 48.7 percent of his production last year came from just three games. He's going to have massive games, but relying on him as anything more than a volatile WR3 is going to lead to disappointment.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyler Lockett
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Hot Lockett just got a big contract extension, keeping him with Seattle through 2025. Even with the breakout of DK Metcalf, Lockett had the most targets of his career (132), and his best cumulative fantasy season in 2020 despite the inconsistency. He'll likely settle in the WR18-24 range in 2021, though the inconsistency may be frustrating and even unbearable for some fantasy managers. The Seahawks could try to get back to running the ball more, which could mean less targets for both wideouts.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: As long as Tyler Lockett is tied to Russell Wilson, he’ll continue to provide fantasy value. That’s good news for Lockett, who’s signed in Seattle through 2025. However, DK Metcalf has emerged as the alpha on this team and that isn’t going to change.

notes.text: Eskridge is a 5’9 speedster with special teams chops. Seattle had a grand total of three picks and they decided to spend their first one at pick 56 on Eskridge. He profiles as a speedy slot guy who should make his way on the field on 3WR sets this year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: D'Wayne Eskridge
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Eskridge is a 5’9 speedster with special teams chops. Seattle had a grand total of three picks and they decided to spend their first one at pick 56 on Eskridge. He profiles as a speedy slot guy who should make his way on the field on 3WR sets this year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: His speed and return ability makes Eskridge any intriguing dynasty prospect albeit on a team where he’s clearly 3rd in the pecking order.

notes.text: When Metcalf came into the NFL, he was considered a "raw" prospect who had plenty of room to grow as a route runner. He's not only lived up to expectations, but has started to exceed them, finishing as a WR2 or better in 50 percent of his games in 2020, which ranked 13th among wide receivers, so the consistency was much better in year two. Then you get his "boom" performances that carry him to the next level, which is why he finished as the WR7 in half-PPR formats. Tied to Russell Wilson as his No. 1 target, Metcalf is one of the safest bets as a top-12 wide receiver.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: DK Metcalf
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: DK Metcalf took a massive step forward in his second season in the NFL, and what’s really scary about Metcalf is that there’s still room for improvement entering year three with Russell Wilson. Metcalf ran the 3rd most routes at the position and saw the 2nd most Air Yards but finished ONLY 17th in receptions.  Teammate Tyler Lockett will still soak up a number of targets, and there is some concern the team wants to run the ball more. Nevertheless, Metcalf can be a double-digit TD guy again suggesting his ceiling in 2021 is massive.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He's only 23 years old and has already proven to be more than just a ‘go deep’ WR. He’s tied to one of the best quarterbacks in football and looks like he’ll be locked into the top-10 at the position for years.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Keke Coutee, Isaiah Coulter, Nico Collins, Brandin Cooks

notes.text: I don't understand why many are talking about Collins as a "sleeper" in 2021. Do we really think this offense is going to produce two fantasy-relevant wide receivers? Somehow, Collins went from sleeper in the NFL Draft, to sleeper on a bad football team. You can like him in dynasty, that's fine, but in 2021, it's hard to see him reaching 80-plus targets if Brandin Cooks is healthy. Even outside of Cooks, the team decided to pay Andre Roberts $2.6 million, Conley $1.5 million, Chris Moore $1.3 million, and then traded for Anthony Miller. This just reeks of a situation to avoid in fantasy. Heck, even if Deshaun Watson were starting (which he's not), you'd have trouble projecting the target distribution for these receivers, though he would give Collins more of that "sleeper" appeal. I'm okay letting someone else take a shot on a non-Cooks receiver.

Collins is a big-bodied WR (6’4, 215 lbs) who comes into the league a bit older (22 years old) than you would like for a prospect. The Texans are lacking depth at the WR position and the team spent what little draft capital they had on him. He could turn into the outside starter opposite Brandin Cooks on a team destined to be a lost cause. He’s been having a good training camp and is worth a look at the end of the drafts to see what could happen.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Nico Collins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Collins is a big-bodied WR (6’4, 215 lbs) who comes into the league a bit older (22 years old) than you would like for a prospect. The Texans are lacking depth at the WR position and the team spent what little draft capital they had on him. He could turn into the outside starter opposite Brandin Cooks on a team destined to be a lost cause. He’s been having a good training camp and is worth a look at the end of the drafts to see what could happen.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: His landing spot in Houston at least gives him a chance to see some passing volume early on. He could be a potential red-zone threat and with a young QB likely to be throwing him the ball in 2022, he’s a fun stash even in a bad situation.

notes.text: Over the last six years, there have been just seven wide receivers who've finished top-24 in at least five of them. Those receivers are Mike Evans, Julio Jones, Davante Adams, DeAndre Hopkins, Amari Cooper, Jarvis Landry, and... Cooks. He's done it with four different quarterbacks, too. However, 2021 might be his toughest test yet, as it appears Tyrod Taylor will be his quarterback, and this is projected to be the lowest scoring offense in the league. Still, he's the clear-cut top option on this team and should be a lock to see 100-plus targets as long as he's healthy.

Fantasy managers probably want to write off any player with a Texans uniform in 2021. Yes, David Culley’s crew likely is headed towards the No. 1 pick but in terms of guaranteed volume, it’s hard to find a WR with Cooks’ safety. He’s a good fantasy wide receiver finishing in the top-15 in five out of the last six years! Cooks can slide in as a perfect WR3/FLEX play that you know is going to see 6-7 targets per game.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Brandin Cooks
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: No one wants Brandin Cooks in fantasy anymore after the fallout from the Texans organization over the last 18 months. Deshaun Watson may never play for Houston again and this team projects to be the NFL’s worst by a mile. That said, he should get peppered with targets and could actually be okay for fantasy based on volume alone. Consider him a worthy WR3/FLEX.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Cooks has finished as the WR15 or better in every season except one dating back to 2015 while playing for four different franchises over that time span. It’s actually pretty incredible. Still just 27 years old, Cooks might be a sneaky trade target in dynasty as his price has never been lower and the depth chart is wide open for targets.

notes.text: Being traded away from the Bears wasn't going to be the worst thing for Miller, until we found out it was to the Texans, which figures to be a fantasy wasteland without Deshaun Watson. If for some reason, Watson comes back to play for the team, Miller would have sleeper appeal, but that's not looking likely.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Anthony Miller
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Miller ran out of favor in Chicago and now is shipped to a team that treats slot WRs as collectibles. He has an opportunity in front of him to be Houston’s WR2, but it feels like we’ve been saying that for years, doesn’t it? With Brandin Cooks looking like the clear No. 1 and Tyrod Taylor being a low volume passer, Miller looks essentially useless for fantasy.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s in a new situation, in a contract year and things could get better and... oh wait. It's the Texans. At this point, it’s possible fantasy managers want Anthony Miller to be a thing more than the NFL does.

notes.text: Despite playing with a mixture of Dwayne Haskins, Alex Smith, Kyle Allen, and Taylor Heinicke the last two years, McLaurin has managed to produce 2,037 yards and 11 touchdowns. While that's not enough to get into the WR1 conversation, maybe the addition of Ryan Fitzpatrick is. We've watched Fitzpatrick support many fantasy wide receivers throughout his years, and he's been willing to target them relentlessly. It's part of the reason we loved DeVante Parker when Fitzpatrick was under center in Miami. There are suddenly a lot of mouths to feed in Washington, but McLaurin is the clear-cut No. 1 option who should be targeted 140-plus times in 2021 en route to what might be his first top-12 finish.

We get it. McLaurin broke out last year. That breakout also came with some of the worst QB play in the league. Now McLaurin gets the Bearded Wonder Ryan Fitzpatrick. Fitz loves to sling the ball down the field. He also loves to feed his No. 1 WR with an overflow of targets. Terry has legit top-10 upside this season.

Terry McLaurin quietly played through a high ankle sprain for the majority of the second half of the season. Over his final 4 games, McLaurin averaged just 39 yards per game while battling the injury, but earlier in the season, he averaged 87.5 yards per game when healthy. Look for McLaurin to return to form with a full offseason to recover.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Terry McLaurin
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It was a tale of two seasons for McLaurin last year. Through the first nine weeks, McLaurin was the WR11, but from Weeks 10-17, McLaurin fell off ranking as the WR44 over that time span. What happened? The Washington WR1 battled a high ankle sprain and was forced to catch passes from a combination of Dwayne Haskins, check-down king Alex Smith, and Kyle Allen. Yikes. McLaurin saw the 9th most targets at the WR position last year and if he sees a similar target share with Ryan Fitzpatrick at the helm, who historically elevates his WRs for fantasy, McLaurin has legitimate top-5 upside in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Scary Terry still doesn’t have a long-term QB and that’s pretty much the only knock on him at this point in his early career. Look for McLaurin to sign a long-term extension with Washington in the next 1-2 years. If the Football Team can get him a reliable passer, his dynasty value should keep him inside the top-15 at the position.

notes.text: I think most people would admit that Johnson looked much better than expected in 2020, totaling over 1,000 total yards and eight touchdowns in just 12 games. That's the good news. The bad news is that the Texans are a team that legitimately might lose every game in 2021, as they've been stripped down and look like a roster of replacements. They've also added Mark Ingram, Phillip Lindsay, and Rex Burkhead to the backfield, which presents all sorts of issues. If Deshaun Watson were going to play, we'd dig into this backfield a little deeper, but with Watson out of the picture for the foreseeable future, this is not a backfield you want to be associated with.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: David Johnson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: While we used to sing the choruses of DJ here at the Fantasy Footballers, it’s likely he’ll now be known forever as the player traded for DeAndre Hopkins. On arguably the worst team in the league, Johnson could still see 18+ touches a game which is rare to find in the 6th/7th rounds of drafts. Drafting him as your RB3 seems like a safe bet with the upside knowing he’s still one of the best pass catchers in the NFL.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Remember 2016? Good times. You might get one more year out of DJ as a top-30 RB.

notes.text: Burkhead is a talented player, particularly in the receiving game, but he's struggled to stay healthy throughout his career. He now finds himself in about as bad a situation as he could, playing for a poor Texans team with a crowded running back room, which includes David Johnson, Mark Ingram, and Phillip Lindsay. If one or more of those backs get cut, then Burkhead could have some value by default, but until or unless that happens, he can be ignored in fantasy circles.

It's a shame Lindsay went to a team that's in complete shambles at the moment because he's a fine running back. Most would be shocked to learn that since the start of the 2018 season, Lindsay ranks 10th in rushing yards among running backs. He's averaged 4.78 yards per carry during that time, so it wasn't just volume. Again, Houston is a mess right now, and have a backfield that consists of Lindsay, David Johnson, Mark Ingram, and Rex Burkhead. There are not going to be enough touches to warrant a draft pick on Lindsay.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Phillip Lindsay
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Lindsay went from being a rookie sensation and fan favorite in Denver, to now out the door and in a gross backfield in Houston. He still has the occasional juice out on the field but likely will compete for touches with Mark Ingram II behind David Johnson. This isn’t 2018 folks; those three are not going to win you a fantasy championship.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Lindsay is a backup with a full head of hair. If you, like Jason, find yourself on the short end of the follicle spectrum, Lindsay is a great boost to your morale.

notes.text: We've watched Hardman be one of the most efficient wide receivers in the league over the last two years, but it hasn't meant much to fantasy managers. For whatever reason, Andy Reid hasn't used Hardman in a full-time role, which meant he saw fewer than five targets in 11-of-16 games last year. Now that Sammy Watkins is gone, does his role grow, or does Reid continue to use him sparingly. If we hear that Hardman is being taken off special teams, it would be a massive boost to his stock. There's certainly upside with him, but we need Reid to have a change of heart for it to be recognized.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mecole Hardman
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Well, the Lizard King (Sammy Watkins) isn’t in Kansas City anymore, so the natural thought process might be to expect Mecole Hardman to see an uptick in usage. Nevertheless he's never gone over 100 receiving yards in the regular season and has only one top-12 performance in 32 career games. Hardman is not someone you can trust weekly and thus someone we don't recommend on your roster.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hardman is still just 23 years old and plays with the best QB in the NFL. As a result, he’ll have perceived dynasty value for the foreseeable future, but it’s possible the Chiefs view Mecole as Tyreek Hill’s direct backup and not the No. 2 option in the WR room, despite what dynasty managers want.

notes.text: There are some fascinating things Moore can do on a football field. The question is whether he'll get the opportunity to showcase his talents in Kliff Kingsbury's offense. We already know DeAndre Hopkins is getting his share, and they've been talking up A.J. Green's involvement, which means Moore would have to surpass Christian Kirk in order to see the field in 3WR sets, which seems unlikely. To be fair, they do run 4WR sets more than any other team, but Andy Isabella is still in line for some snaps as well. It's tough to see Moore as a reliable fantasy option without an injury ahead of him on the depth chart.

The Cardinals took Rondale Moore in the 2nd Round this year. Moore is electric on the field and his freshman season was legendary the way he made people miss in the open field. He’s struggled with injuries the last couple of years but in our pre-workout evaluation process, he still shined through as a potential special teams weapon with some Tyreek Hill-lite skills to his name. The Cardinals offense is a great landing spot if he is utilized on jet-sweeps and given the ball in space. In other words, instead of Tyreek, he’s going to be more Mecole Hardman: a couple of highlight-reel TDs with zero chance of predicting where and when they will come.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Rondale Moore
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Cardinals took Rondale Moore in the 2nd Round this year. Moore is electric on the field and his freshman season was legendary the way he made people miss in the open field. He’s struggled with injuries the last couple of years but in our pre-workout evaluation process, he still shined through as a potential special teams weapon with some Tyreek Hill-lite skills to his name. The Cardinals offense is a great landing spot if he is utilized on jet-sweeps and given the ball in space. In other words, instead of Tyreek, he’s going to be more Mecole Hardman: a couple of highlight-reel TDs with zero chance of predicting where and when they will come.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: A.J. Green is on a one-year deal and Christian Kirk will be a free-agent in 2022 so even if Moore doesn’t blow the doors off in Year One, be patient. He’s a Ferrari waiting to be unleashed.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Hunter Renfrow
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Let’s be honest. The Wallerus is this team’s WR1, but behind him, it’s an open competition for targets after Nelson Agholor signed with the Pats in free agency. Renfrow saw a total of 77 targets last year - if that trend continues, he’ll be mostly irrelevant for fantasy football.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Unless something changes quickly for the former Clemson WR, he could turn into a roster clogger - a guy who sits on the end of the bench but one that managers never start given the lack of upside. After WR55 and WR61 finishes in his first two years in the league, Renfrow may help the Raiders more than your fantasy team.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Otis Anderson Jr., Xavier Jones, Raymond Calais

notes.text: Once we heard about Cam Akers' injury, we were wondering who the Rams would sign/go after, but they've said they're staying put for now and that they're happy with last year's undrafted free agent Xavier Jones behind Darrell Henderson. We still have plenty of time for them to sign another running back, but for the time being, Jones should be viewed as the primary handcuff to Henderson.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Xavier Jones
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The former UDFA out of SMU has a chance to step into a backup role with the recent news of Cam Akers’ Achilles injury. The 5-11, 215 Jones made some noise last off-season but only saw the field as a special teamer in 2020. He’ll compete for touches with 7th rounder Jake Funk behind Darrell Henderson Jr. and makes for an interesting stash in deeper leagues.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Jones goes from unrostered to one of the most added players in dynasty following the Akers injury. He’s still an UDFA so who knows what you’ll get at the end of your bench.

notes.text: The year-ending injury to Cam Akers opens a door of opportunity for Henderson, who, just like Akers, was a Day 2 draft pick by this regime. In fact, Henderson was more efficient than Akers in nearly every category last year, though Akers had the momentum at the end of the season. Will the Rams bring in another running back to compete with Henderson for the starting job? It would seem likely, though for now, Henderson is a rock-solid RB2 with top-10 upside.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Darrell Henderson Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Suddenly the once crowned “Darnell Anderson” has become one of the most important names in fantasy. Before Cam Akers' Achilles injury, he was expected to play second-fiddle in the Rams backfield. He still can bring the thunder as evidenced by his five top-24 games in his first nine last year. Expect him to receive the lions' share of opportunity among RBs and his ADP to sky rocket over the next few weeks.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Henderson hype was insane before he played a snap in the NFL. Two years later we've come full circle as his dynasty value suddenly has a one-year window of life. If someone values him as a top-15 RB and you have depth, trading him now makes a ton of sense.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Quintez Cephus, Breshad Perriman, Sage Surratt

notes.text: Is it possible Perriman is the Lions best wide receiver in fantasy this year? While that may not mean much, it's something. The issue I have believing that is due to his strengths not aligning with Jared Goff's strengths. It's no secret that Goff has struggled to consistently throw the ball down the field, and it's part of the reason the Rams moved on from him. Perriman will be playing in another new offense with another new quarterback, something he knows all too well at this point. There will likely be a few splash weeks, but you should be happy to let someone else draft him.

Perriman plays wide receiver in the National Football League. This was enough for him to step into the gaping Kenny Golladay void in Detroit and be a potential sleeper value for fantasy leagues. Marvin Jones is also gone, and Perriman may be the de facto number one on this team. Being peppered by King Goffrey may provide some week to week value for a player that will likely be undrafted or drafted very late.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Breshad Perriman
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Perriman’s best fantasy finish since entering the league in 2015: WR48. At this point, we know who Perriman is - a guy who flashes some upside when given opportunity but he’s been a journeyman throughout his career who’s dealt with injury. But hey, someone has to catch the ball in Detroit, right?
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Perriman is an afterthought at this point in his career, as most dynasty managers are probably over the idea of Perriman after years of disappointment as a former 1st Round NFL Draft pick. Be sure to check if he’s on your waiver wire, though, as he could provide some depth for bye weeks and injuries.

notes.text: There is a path to St. Brown leading all Lions wide receivers in targets. However, the stat I keep coming back to with him is that I've tracked rookie performances for the last eight years. There have been 35 wide receivers drafted in the fourth round during that time, and none of them finished as a top-50 wide receiver in their rookie year. But now we're expecting Jared Goff to make that happen with St. Brown? There's a possibility, sure, but it's a slim one.

The “Sun God”, as his name suggests, might be the only light shining amidst the league’s gloomiest WR corp. St. Brown’s draft capital (112th overall) is nothing special but when you see the rest of the Lions WR depth chart, you can’t ignore his opportunity. Over 80 percent of the Lions’ WR targets from 2020 are gone. If you are desperate for targets, St. Brown is a shot in the dark in redraft but remember… he plays for the Lions. (Narrator: And that isn’t a good thing)

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Amon-Ra St. Brown
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The “Sun God”, as his name suggests, might be the only light shining amidst the league’s gloomiest WR corp. St. Brown’s draft capital (112th overall) is nothing special but when you see the rest of the Lions WR depth chart, you can’t ignore his opportunity. Over 80 percent of the Lions’ WR targets from 2020 are gone. If you are desperate for targets, St. Brown is a shot in the dark in redraft but remember… he plays for the Lions. (Narrator: And that isn’t a good thing)
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s a back of the 2nd round rookie pick who could jump up further if teams are desperate. While opportunity is always king in fantasy, his situation could change as soon as 2022 so don’t bank on him being a guaranteed alpha WR in Detroit.

notes.text: We have no idea who will start for the Broncos to start the season, and while it's likely going to be Lock, he needs to improve drastically, because he'll now have a much shorter leash. The Broncos have one of the most talented groups on offense and are just a quarterback away from exploding. Can Lock take the year three leap? To this point, he's averaged just 6.6 yards per attempt with 23 touchdowns and 18 interceptions through 18 games.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Drew Lock
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Mr. Irresponsible led the league in INTs and percentage of “bad throws” at 22.9 percent. He also had the highest percentage (16%) of attempts 20+ yards downfield with a league-leading seven INTs on deep throws. Give the guy some credit: he thought he could be Brett Favre. But for fantasy, he still had four weeks as a top-10 QB, as many as Philip Rivers, Drew Brees, and one fewer than Baker Mayfield. Nevertheless, Lock is more of a hindrance to the fantasy production of his WRs than a viable option. This is basically his last shot at a starting gig in the NFL for the former 2nd round draft pick.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Who knows with Lock? He could be Denver’s starting QB for two games, two more seasons, or out on the street trying to throw down a rap track in two days.

notes.text: Ridley finished as the No. 4 wide receiver with Julio Jones on the team, and that was while missing one full game. Just how much better can he be with Jones out of town? Some may worry about Ridley becoming "the guy" in the offense and seeing all the top cornerbacks, but we've already witnessed that in the games Jones missed. In the eight games Ridley has played without Jones, he's averaged 11.1 targets, 7.3 receptions, 107.0 yards, and 0.4 touchdowns, adding up to 20.1 PPR points per game. He should be a lock for 140-plus targets in 2021, making him a safe WR1.

Ridley has missed the Falcons mini camp due to lingering left foot discomfort, which required a minor “clean up procedure.” Ridley has a history of left foot and ankle injuries in the past, including a similar procedure done in his ankle in 2019 and just last year, he missed one game with a minor midfoot sprain from Week 8. These injuries can lead to lingering stiffness/discomfort in the foot, but following this procedure, which is done to remove scar tissue and/or tiny bone fragments, the outcomes are favorable with an expected recovery of 2-4 weeks. As of now, Ridley should be good to go for training camp, and assuming he’s full go early in camp, there’s no concerns about his 2021 season long outlook.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Calvin Ridley
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Calvin Ridley was labeled by many in the fantasy community as the breakout WR of 2020 and boy did he deliver. Ridley finished as fantasy’s WR4 on the back of 9 TD and 1,374 yards. Ridley led the league in air yards and number of 100-yard games, suggesting that he’s not only going to see a safe amount of volume, but he’s a high upside option as we know he’ll be targeted down the field and in the red zone. Now with Julio traded, the sky is the limit for Calvin Ridley in 2021. UPDATE: Ridley underwent a "clean up procedure" on his left foot. As of now, Ridley should be good to go for training camp, and assuming he’s full go early in camp, there’s no concerns about his 2021 season long outlook. See the full writeup in the UDK Injury Report.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Ridley took over as the Atlanta WR1 last season, thanks in part to Julio missing half the season. That said, what Ridley has done both with AND without Julio on the field in his first three seasons in the league is nothing short of fantastic. Ridley projects to lead the Falcons’ passing attack for the foreseeable future and should be in the WR1 conversation in dynasty for the next couple of years.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Rashod Bateman, Devin Duvernay, Sammy Watkins, Miles Boykin

notes.text: Bateman suffered a groin injury in camp, has undergone surgery, and should return "sometime in September." That makes him someone to largely ignore in redraft leagues. But long-term, there's plenty to like. "He's good, sure, but the offense is run-first and doesn't have a lot of volume. He's a rookie wide receiver, they take time to develop. He's not the No. 1 target on his team." We said those exact same things about Justin Jefferson last year and look what happened. From the moment I started watching Bateman's film, I was instantly reminded of Keenan Allen. A receiver who may not be an elite athlete, but one who continually got open due to intelligence and route running. When he's healthy, he should be lined up all over the formation, including the slot, becoming Lamar Jackson's favorite target as a possession-style receiver while Marquise Brown plays the field-stretching role. There's a scenario where Bateman is an every-week WR2/3 option once he returns from his injury.

The Ravens 2021 1st round pick exited practice on August 10, suffering a groin injury. After undergoing an MRI and based on head coach, John Harbaugh's description that Bateman's injury will require 'weeks not months' to recover, this is likely a grade II groin strain, which could sideline Bateman up to 6 weeks. With Week 1 four and a half weeks away, it's unlikely that we see the rookie WR in preseason action if this injury. As of mid August, being available for Week 1 isn't a guarantee.

Rashod Bateman got selected by the Ravens in the 1st round of the NFL Draft. A traditional perimeter WR with good size, Bateman has the chance to add a lot of value to the Ravens by filling a need that Marquise Brown couldn’t. That said, this is one of the run heaviest schemes in the NFL, and we know Mark Andrews will get his.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Rashod Bateman
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Rashod Bateman got selected by the Ravens in the 1st round of the NFL Draft. A traditional perimeter WR with good size, Bateman has the chance to add a lot of value to the Ravens by filling a need that Marquise Brown couldn’t. That said, this is one of the run heaviest schemes in the NFL, and we know Mark Andrews will get his. UPDATE: Bateman will undergo groin surgery and seems likely to miss Week 1.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Most are dropping Bateman in dynasty rookie draft rankings due to the landing spot in Baltimore. However, he doesn’t turn 22 until November, produced early in college, and excelled in multiple efficiency metrics while playing at Minnesota. This is a situation where talent could trump landing spot over the long term.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Sammy Watkins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: If the Lizard King can’t consistently produce on the best offense in football with Patrick Mahomes, what are his chances of producing on one of the league’s lowest volume passing offenses in Baltimore? I think we know what Sammy is at this point in his career.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: You can’t trade him. There’s no reason to acquire him. Watkins has officially entered roster clogger territory.

notes.text: There was a time where people were excited about what Boykin might bring to the table. That time has passed, as he's now entering his third season with just 32 receptions under his belt. He's actually performed solid on a per-target basis, but his opportunity is gone with the additions of Rashod Bateman, Sammy Watkins, and Tylan Wallace to the wide receiver depth chart. He wasn't fantasy relevant without them, so he sure as heck won't be with them.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Miles Boykin
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Boykin’s outlook took a massive hit after free agency and the 2021 NFL Draft. Already the most run heavy system in the NFL, the Ravens added Sammy Watkins, Rashod Bateman and Tylan Wallace. Boykin belongs on the waiver wire.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Boykin is likely going to need a change of scenery to be fantasy viable. The only issue? He’s still got two years left on his rookie deal.

notes.text: Since being drafted by the Ravens, Brown was miscast in the go-to receiver role for them, something that was righted this offseason when the team drafted Rashod Bateman, who makes a great complement to Brown. While it was a great move for the Ravens from a football perspective, it will impact Brown's target total. He likely won't see the 100 targets he saw in 2020, though his targets should be a bit more impactful. Expect him to be somewhat of a boom-or-bust receiver, making him a WR4-type option.

The ship has sailed on Hollywood.  Just four times last season did Hollywood even reach the WR2 mark.  There isn't enough volume in Baltimore, and with the addition of Rashod Bateman, Hollywood Brown is unlikely to help your fantasy team this season.

Brown suffered a hamstring injury on July 29 and has yet to return to full practices. As of August 10, Brown is still not back to practice but we do have reports from Ravens beat reporters that Brown was seen on August 7 working on individual drills on a separate field. It sounds like Brown is progressing as expected at this stage of his recovery, but we know that the greatest risk of recurring injury with hamstring strains is in the first two weeks back on the field. At this point in training camp, Brown can't suffer a setback, or it's very unlikely he's ready for Week 1. As a result, expect the Ravens to be conservative with their WR for the next couple of weeks.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Marquise Brown
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Brown was a popular breakout pick in the middle rounds of 2020 drafts, but that clearly didn’t work out. With two full seasons in the books with Lamar Jackson as the starter, we now officially know what this team wants to do - run, run, run and run some more. As a result, all pass catching options in this offense will be a bit too boom/bust to trust on a weekly basis in 2021. Plus, they just added Rashod Batemen and Tylan Wallace via the NFL Draft, and don’t forget about the Lizard King!
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Entering his third season, things don’t look promising for Brown as his value has only continued to fall. He’s in a run heavy scheme as an undersized WR who enters a season in which he’ll face the biggest competition for targets he’s seen to date. The Ravens just spent a first round pick on Rashod Bateman.

notes.text: The Patriots want to run the ball and they chose to draft a mound of a man in the 4th Round. Sony Michel’s time is about up and Stevenson profiles as an early-down thumper who also caught some passes in college. He’s also a player you root for as the biggest dude on the field but likely will be 3rd or 4th on the depth chart in Year One.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Rhamondre Stevenson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Patriots want to run the ball and they chose to draft a mound of a man in the 4th Round. Sony Michel’s time is about up and Stevenson profiles as an early-down thumper who also caught some passes in college. He’s also a player you root for as the biggest dude on the field but likely will be 3rd or 4th on the depth chart in Year One.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If your team needs girth, we know where to find it. Sony Michel and James White are out the door in 2021 so bide your time in hopes Rha-Grande stumbles into a bigger workload next year.

notes.text: It was shocking to see the Dolphins pass on running back after running back, especially considering all the picks they had in this year's draft. This is great news for Gaskin, who racked up 183 touches in just 10 games last year. Crazy, right? His 18.3 touches per game ranked ninth among running backs. Opportunity is everything, and if he gets that type of opportunity again in 2021 while playing in all the games, he's going to finish as a top-15 running back. The only difference is that the Dolphins added Malcolm Brown in free agency, which could lead to him siphoning some targets away from Gaskin, which would be less than ideal. As of now, Gaskin should probably be considered a solid RB2, though landing him as your RB3/flex would be even better based on the small sample size we have from him in a big role.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Myles Gaskin
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Gas Man was as productive as they get considering he was a former 7th round draft pick. He seized control of the Miami backfield in 2020 averaging the 7th most touches per game (18.3) among RBs, more than Alvin Kamara. He struggled to stay on the field playing in only ten games but the Dolphins surprisingly did not spend any high draft capital on an RB. Gaskin’s main competition is free-agent Malcolm Brown and Salvon Ahmed but his work as a receiver (4.1 receptions per game) is comforting. We have him ranked as a low-end RB2 who profiles as the team’s main pass-catching back but there is inherent risk involved.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Gaskin is another perfect example of a dynasty stash that turns into gold. He’s not a sure thing by any means moving forward but his status as a volume-based RB2 looks secure for now. Things could easily shift in 2022 so if you want to trade him to a team desperate for RB help that will overpay, it’s probably a wise move long-term.

notes.text: Don't sleep on Carter in redraft formats. The only player standing in his way of 15-plus touches is Tevin Coleman, who's played just 22-of-32 games the last two seasons. On top of that, he's never been efficient when asked to carry a heavy workload. Carter reminded me of Justin Forsett while scouting him. He does everything well, and though he's undersized, that shouldn't stop him from getting plenty of opportunity, especially in the passing game. The Jets are no longer an Adam Gase-led team. There's value to be had in this offense, and Carter is one of the best late-round values in fantasy football.

Carter played second-fiddle to Javonte Williams at UNC but he’s gained some steam recently given his receiving work in college. The Jets took him in the 4th round and he has a good opportunity to see 40 percent of the backfield touches in Year One. His main competition is La’Mical Perine and Tevin Coleman which is encouraging.

Talent and opportunity are lynchpins of fantasy football relevance. The Jets have improved their offensive line and Michael Carter comes into an intriguing backfield that has no true leader. Watch closely as Carter could earn the lion's share of the work right out of the gate in New York.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Michael Carter
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Carter played second-fiddle to Javonte Williams at UNC but he’s gained some steam recently given his receiving work in college. The Jets took him in the 4th round and he has a good opportunity to see 40 percent of the backfield touches in Year One. His main competition is La’Mical Perine and Tevin Coleman which is encouraging.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: When you factor in his height (5’7 7/8) and adjust for speed, he’s not an elite prospect. He’s a top-15 rookie pick in 2021 because opportunity sometimes is king. He also could be this year’s Ke’Shawn Vaughn.

notes.text: Had Hubbard entered the NFL Draft a year earlier, he may have gone in the second round. But that's not what happened. He returned to school and had a weak 2020 season, leading him to fall to the end of the fourth round. He's certainly not getting much playing time with Christian McCaffrey healthy, but he should be the clear-cut handcuff, which had plenty of value last year in this offense (Mike Davis). Unfortunately, the Panthers offensive line continues to get worse, and it's tough to say Sam Darnold is an upgrade at quarterback, making Hubbard a mediocre handcuff in fantasy.

Christian McCaffrey played an average of 92% of snaps per game in 2018 and 2019. It remains to be seen if the coaching staff feels differently about CMC’s workhorse usage after his injury-riddled 2020 season. With Mike Davis leaving in free agency, Hubbard has the potential to win the backup job.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chuba Hubbard
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Christian McCaffrey played an average of 92% of snaps per game in 2018 and 2019. It remains to be seen if the coaching staff feels differently about CMC’s workhorse usage after his injury-riddled 2020 season. With Mike Davis leaving in free agency, Hubbard has the potential to win the backup job.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s obviously road blocked by CMC but is worth looking at as a cheap trade target for insurance purposes.

notes.text: It seems like it's been forever since we've seen Sutton on a football field, right? Part of that is due to 2020 seeming like the longest year of all-time. But when he does return to the field, the Broncos offense looks quite different than the one that allowed him to rack up 1,112 yards and six touchdowns in 2019. The additions of Jerry Jeudy, KJ Hamler, Melvin Gordon, and Javonte Williams are all massive, as is the emergence of Tim Patrick. Suddenly, it's going to be tough for any receiver on this team to hit 120 targets. But what Sutton has going for him is that he's already shown that he can perform at a high level in the NFL. While I believe Jeudy can as well, we haven't seen that just yet, which gives Sutton the nod in the rankings as a WR3.

Sutton’s 2020 season barely got off the ground. He began the year by missing Week 1 thanks to an AC joint sprain in his shoulder then tore the ACL and MCL in his left knee in Week 2. As of now, Sutton appears to be on track for Week 1 and should be full go once training camp starts. Look for Sutton to be limited during the team’s offseason program this summer as he acclimates back into football shape, but given how early his injury happened, he should enter Week 1 at 100%.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Courtland Sutton
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: In his second season (2019), Sutton was a solid WR2 for fantasy. He made highlight reel catches while topping 1,100 receiving yards, with the likes of Joe Flacco, Brandon Allen and Drew Lock. However, he suffered a season-ending knee injury in Week 2 last year and his hype has taken a bit hit. All signs point to him being 100% for the start of this season. He can still be Denver's WR1 and he’s entering a contract year. The QB situation isn't ideal whether it's Drew Lock or Teddy Bridgewater.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Courtland Sutton has a chance to provide a massive bounce back appeal in dynasty. With Jerry Jeudy, Noah Fant and KJ Hamler in town Sutton seems to get lost in the shuffle when talking about alpha WRs. He presents a great ‘buy low’ opportunity for a highly productive WR who’s still only 25 years old and is set to be a free agent after 2021. There’s a great chance he gets a massive QB upgrade next season either via an upgrade from Denver or a new team in free agency.

notes.text: It was a painfully slow start to the 2020 season for Hilton, but he finished strong, tallying 27 receptions, 435 yards, and five touchdowns over the final six games of the season where he was the WR8 during that time. Did it take time to develop chemistry with Philip Rivers? If so, are we going to experience a similar slow start in 2021 with Carson Wentz? On top of the chemistry concern, he has to contend with youngsters Parris Campbell and Michael Pittman, who are both another year into their NFL career, and likely ready to take on bigger roles. Hilton's upside feels severely capped, so it's best to treat him as someone you play through bye weeks rather than someone you rely on week-in and week-out.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: T.Y. Hilton
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After battling injuries for the last two seasons, it was a quick fall from grace for Hilton who had perennially been a lock for a 1,000-yard season. Now? He’s surpassed 80 yards just four times over the last two years. Hilton is a guy who could bounce back, but everything has to go right, starting with the QB play from Carson Wentz.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Now 31 years old and battling injury for two years in a row, TY Hilton’s best fantasy days are clearly behind him and now there’s no long term financial commitment from the Colts. He’s playing on a one year deal and is set to hit free agency after 2021. Any manager with a rebuilding team should be shopping TY before it’s too late.

notes.text: Despite T.Y. Hilton aging and Parris Campbell missing the entire season, Pittman couldn't break out in his rookie season. While that might be high expectations, the opportunity was there. Philip Rivers turned out to be better than most expected, though Pittman finished with more than 66 yards just once all year, and topped 46 yards just three times. He scored just once, which surely didn't help his year-end totals, but with Campbell back in the mix, he isn't a surefire pick to gain a whole lot of targets. Hilton was re-signed, Zach Pascal out-produced him, and Carson Wentz has traditionally favored his targets over the middle of the field. Pittman should lead this team in touchdowns with his large frame, but he's likely to be a bit too touchdown-dependent to trust as anything more than a boom-or-bust WR4.

Michael Pittman dealt with compression syndrome in his leg following a Week 3 injury last year. What happens here is direct contusion or trauma to the lower leg can cause swelling, which leads to pressure on the nerves and arteries in the leg. If left untreated, this can have long term effects, but it was managed appropriately, and Pittman was able to return to the field in Week 8. This injury won’t affect Pittman moving forward.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Michael Pittman Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Pittman displayed some solid YAC moments and went 5/90 on 10 targets in the Colts playoff game. He has the draft pedigree and size to become a No. 1 wideout. The Colts are starving for playmakers and while everyone expected them to add in either free-agency or the draft, perhaps their WR1 was sitting on their roster the entire time. Carson Wentz's injury pumped the breaks on calling for a full-on Pittman breakout after an off-season of love coming from Mike.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: For WRs that didn’t quite meet the high expectations in Year One, it’s easy to discount them and move onto the next batch of shiny new toys in Dynasty. Pittman was a 2nd Round pick in the 2020 NFL Draft, and a player worth trading for in hopes that he breaks out with Carson Wentz.

notes.text: Whenever a receiver gets hurt early in the year, it's easy for drafters to forget about them. Campbell had nine targets, six receptions, and 71 yards in the one game he played last year. Do you know how many times Michael Pittman (who's being drafted as a top-50 wide receiver) can say he hit those numbers? Once. Both former second rounders have a ceiling depending on who Carson Wentz favors, but it's not built into Campbell's price. If Wentz keeps doing what he did in Philadelphia, that's targeting tight ends/slot receivers over the middle of the field, which is primarily where Campbell lines up.

Parris Campbell missed virtually all of his rookie season in 2019 with three separate surgeries - a broken hand, a broken foot and a sports hernia repair. Then, in Week 2 of last season, Campbell suffered a sprained MCL and PCL in his left knee. Yet another season-ending surgery for Campbell ended his 2020 campaign early. Recent reports indicate Campbell has been cleared for full participation in the team’s offseason program, which makes sense given that the typical recovery timeline for this injury is 6-9 months. The injury history looks scary on paper, but there is nothing in his profile that suggests these injuries are correlated in any way.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Parris Campbell
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Campbell missed most of 2020 with a knee injury, and he’s only played nine career games in two seasons, so we still have no clue what he can be in fantasy. That said, the depth chart in Indy is wide open and Parris could be a near every down slot WR for this offense.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Campbell still has two years left on his rookie deal. If you believe Carson Wentz can turn it around and you’re a Parris truther, his asking price in dynasty can’t be much.

notes.text: Have we seen Edmonds carry the workload for the Cardinals before? Well, kind of. Despite Kenyan Drake struggling through much of 2020, there were just two games where Edmonds finished with more than eight carries, which is certainly a concern. The Cardinals went out and signed James Conner in free agency, but he's proven to be incapable of staying healthy with a full workload, and it wasn't a pricey contract, so maybe we see Edmonds in a bigger role. Whatever the case, we know he has the pass-catching role locked down, which has value in itself, as he was a flex-type option most weeks (he was an RB3 or better 62.5 percent of the time). This offense is going to score points, so if Edmonds were to get a slight bump in carries, he could make his way into the RB2 conversation. Draft him as an RB3/flex and hope that's the case. Just know that he's still yet to crack 100 carries in a season.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chase Edmonds
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Only 5’9”, Edmonds is built like Dion Lewis which means he'll always be more of a threat in the passing game than a between-the-tackles runner. Last year he saw the 6th most targets and tied for 7th most routes run among RBs in 2020. With Kenyan Drake now in Las Vegas, it looks like he’ll be paired with James Conner and it’s unclear what that backfield split will be.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He can be an RB3 but if someone else envisions him as a potential RB2 with upside, look to move him. Edmonds is a free agent in 2022 so it's time to trade him now.

notes.text: Bateman suffered a groin injury in camp, has undergone surgery, and should return "sometime in September." That makes him someone to largely ignore in redraft leagues. But long-term, there's plenty to like. "He's good, sure, but the offense is run-first and doesn't have a lot of volume. He's a rookie wide receiver, they take time to develop. He's not the No. 1 target on his team." We said those exact same things about Justin Jefferson last year and look what happened. From the moment I started watching Bateman's film, I was instantly reminded of Keenan Allen. A receiver who may not be an elite athlete, but one who continually got open due to intelligence and route running. When he's healthy, he should be lined up all over the formation, including the slot, becoming Lamar Jackson's favorite target as a possession-style receiver while Marquise Brown plays the field-stretching role. There's a scenario where Bateman is an every-week WR2/3 option once he returns from his injury.

The Ravens 2021 1st round pick exited practice on August 10, suffering a groin injury. After undergoing an MRI and based on head coach, John Harbaugh's description that Bateman's injury will require 'weeks not months' to recover, this is likely a grade II groin strain, which could sideline Bateman up to 6 weeks. With Week 1 four and a half weeks away, it's unlikely that we see the rookie WR in preseason action if this injury. As of mid August, being available for Week 1 isn't a guarantee.

Rashod Bateman got selected by the Ravens in the 1st round of the NFL Draft. A traditional perimeter WR with good size, Bateman has the chance to add a lot of value to the Ravens by filling a need that Marquise Brown couldn’t. That said, this is one of the run heaviest schemes in the NFL, and we know Mark Andrews will get his.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Rashod Bateman
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Rashod Bateman got selected by the Ravens in the 1st round of the NFL Draft. A traditional perimeter WR with good size, Bateman has the chance to add a lot of value to the Ravens by filling a need that Marquise Brown couldn’t. That said, this is one of the run heaviest schemes in the NFL, and we know Mark Andrews will get his. UPDATE: Bateman will undergo groin surgery and seems likely to miss Week 1.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Most are dropping Bateman in dynasty rookie draft rankings due to the landing spot in Baltimore. However, he doesn’t turn 22 until November, produced early in college, and excelled in multiple efficiency metrics while playing at Minnesota. This is a situation where talent could trump landing spot over the long term.

notes.text: Despite missing one full game and a large portion of another, Johnson finished with 144 targets in 2020, which ranked sixth among wide receivers. Unfortunately, he was not particularly efficient with them, averaging just 6.4 yards per target. Part of his issues were drops, but Ben Roethlisberger's drop-down mentality certainly didn't help, either. Still, chasing targets at wide receiver is never a bad thing. If Johnson would've averaged just 7.4 yards per target (easily attainable), he would've finished as the WR14. He should be a safe high-floor WR2 with upside for top-12 numbers.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Diontae Johnson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Find someone who loves you the way Ben Roethlisberger loves targeting Diontae Johnson. In Johnson’s 2020 breakout campaign, he dominated targets for Pittsburgh. In games where Johnson played and didn’t leave early due to injury, he saw 10+ targets in 10 of 13 games excelling as a PPR monster. With the team seemingly wanting to establish the run more in 2021, Johnson will likely need to improve upon his efficiency and find the end zone more often if he’s looking to take a step forward in his third year in the NFL.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Johnson has now proven that he can produce with subpar QB play, as he was Pittsburgh’s most productive WR two years ago with Mason Rudolph under center (yikes!) and has put up big numbers with a declining Big Ben. Still less than 25 years old, Johnson’s ceiling is massive if he finds himself with a more established QB over the next one to two years.

notes.text: Claypool may have finished as the WR19 on the season, but his year was littered with lackluster performances. He posted WR3 or better type numbers in just 50 percent of the games last year, which was tied with Jamison Crowder and DeVante Parker for 34th among wide receivers. His four-touchdown game in Week 5 really catapulted his numbers at season's end, as he failed to top 59 yards in 11-of-16 games, making him a touchdown-or-bust option most weeks. With Ben Roethlisberger's arm strength seemingly deteriorating by the day, it's tough to see Claypool having a true breakout season in 2021, as he relies on those high value targets more than JuJu Smith-Schuster and Diontae Johnson do. Claypool is an upside pick for sure, but not one I'd bet heavily on.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chase Claypool
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Here’s the list of rookie WRs over the last decade with 11 total TDs in year one: Mike Evans, Odell Beckham Jr., Tyreek Hill & Chase Claypool. That’s it. It’s an elite list, but is Claypool due for statistical regression? 22% of Claypool’s fantasy points came in Week 5 against Philadelphia when he scored four total TDs. With Diontae Johnson likely to dominate the target share again and Pittsburgh wanting to get back to running the ball, Claypool will have to rely on efficiency to reach his ceiling this year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Well, we thought JuJu Smith-Schuster would be gone from Pittsburgh this year, but he’s back on a one year deal, which could limit Claypool’s volume for one more year. With Big Ben in decline and Pittsburgh without a long-term starter at QB, it’s possible to get max value for Claypool after a massive rookie season. Hang on if you think the talent can eventually win out, even with bad QB play.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: James Washington
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Washington is the clear No. 4 option on the Steelers depth chart, but Big Ben likes him. If we see Diontae struggle with drops or lackluster play from one of JuJu or Chase Claypool, Washington could be an add off the waiver wire but for now, pass on him in drafts.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Washington is still just 25 years old and has flashed when given the opportunity. He’s in a contract year and could see more opportunity after the 2021 season with Pittsburgh or he lands in a new situation with a clearer path to targets. He’s a cheap trade target in dynasty.

notes.text: Through two full seasons, Harry has not lived up to expectations. He's only seen 81 targets over those first two years, but that's due to his lack of efficiency. Since coming into the league, his 5.11 yards per target ranks as the second-worst in the NFL during that time. After the Patriots spend a boatload of money in free agency, we can't even say that Harry is a top-three receiver on the depth chart.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: N'Keal Harry
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After being drafted with the final pick of the 1st Round in the 2019 NFL Draft, N’Keal Harry hasn’t been able to make any sort of impact. Bill Belichick identified the Patriots’ weaknesses and addressed the WR aggressively via free agency. It’s pretty bad when Nelson Agholor and Kendrick Bourne are considered upgrades at the position. Leave Harry on the waiver wire.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: A former 1st round NFL Draft pick, N’Keal Harry may flame out in the NFL. If you’ve got him, he’s a hold, and we certainly haven’t seen anything from him to suggest he’s a trade target.

notes.text: Reunited and it feels so good? Maybe. Waddle will be playing with his college quarterback, Tua Tagovailoa. That certainly helps project him for a quick start to his career, as does the absence of Will Fuller in Week 1 as he serves the remainder of his suspension. Tagovailoa talked about his pass catchers not gaining separation last year, but that shouldn't be an issue with Waddle. Even when Fuller joins the lineup, it might not be a bad thing for Waddle, as he should slide into the slot where he'll be matched up with nickel cornerbacks and safeties. Waddle might be someone who produces quicker than most rookies due to his familiarity with his quarterback.

Waddle suffered an ankle fracture-dislocation during his final season at Alabama in October of 2020. This injury forced him to miss the rest of the regular season, the SEC championship and the first game of the College Football Playoff. Remarkably, Waddle was able to suit up for the National Championship game but was nowhere close to 100%. Now 7+ months out from surgery, look for Waddle to regain full explosiveness and ability to cut as the summer progresses with him entering Week 1 at or close to full strength.

Waddle was the 6th overall pick in the NFL Draft. He reunites with his college QB, but DeVante Parker, Mike Gesicki, and now Will Fuller are on this roster, and it’s very likely Waddle is 4th in the pecking order in his rookie season in terms of target share. He’ll have some splash plays, but it doesn’t look like he’s a guy you can trust in his rookie season despite his insane athleticism and speed.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jaylen Waddle
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Waddle was the 6th overall pick in the NFL Draft. He reunites with his college QB, but DeVante Parker, Mike Gesicki, and now Will Fuller are on this roster, and it’s very likely Waddle is 4th in the pecking order in his rookie season in terms of target share. He’ll have some splash plays, but it doesn’t look like he’s a guy you can trust in his rookie season despite his insane athleticism and speed.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Waddle projects as a high upside dynasty option given his NFL Draft capital, but he dealt with a significant injury in college, and we never got to see just how good he can be. Assuming Will Fuller is gone next year, Waddle could see an uptick in dynasty value while playing with his college QB.

notes.text: Despite losing Dak Prescott early in the year, Gallup managed to finish with 843 yards and five touchdowns despite being behind both Amari Cooper and CeeDee Lamb on the depth chart. That was good enough for a WR38 finish, though he's lasting much later than that in drafts. Now in a contract year, Gallup is likely showcasing himself for his future team.

There are a ton of mouths to feed in Dallas, and Michael Gallup seems to eat last.  With the return of Blake Jarwin and the ascension of Ceedee Lamb, Gallup's involvement will be hard to predict and even harder to rely on in fantasy football.  He'll have his games, but volume will go elsewhere in Dallas.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Michael Gallup
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Gallup was a hot name in the middle rounds of 2020 drafts, primarily because most in the industry were excited about the Cowboys passing attack. Through four weeks, the Dallas offense was cookin’, but without Dak on the field, the offensive production came to a screeching halt. Dak is back, but CeeDee Lamb will look to take a step forward in year two and Amari Cooper is still this team’s WR1. We only have a five-game sample of Cooper, Lamb and Gallup all on the field with Dak but in those games, Gallup saw just 5.6 targets per game. Expect spiked weeks from Gallup, but the consistency could be an issue.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Barring any major changes, Gallup figures to be the odd man out in the Dallas passing game after the 2021 season when he becomes an unrestricted free agent. CeeDee Lamb is still on his rookie deal, and Amari Cooper is under contract through 2024. With the team likely needing to upgrade their offensive line and their defense soon, it’s possible the Cowboys use their money to spend up elsewhere. That said, a change of scenery with more targets could be good for Gallup.

notes.text: Despite missing four games over the last two years, Cook has still managed to rack up 3,572 total yards and 30 touchdowns. He's still yet to play 16 games in his four-year career, but when he's on the field, he's a surefire RB1. In each of the final 12 games he played in 2020, he touched the ball a minimum of 17 times, including 24-plus touches in nine of them. The craziest part about his numbers, though, is the fact that he has 97 receptions for 880 yards over the last two years, but just one receiving touchdown, so there's room for even more of a ceiling.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dalvin Cook
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The only knock on Cook is his injury concerns but every single RB gets injured at some point. Of the top-20 RBs, only two(!) played all 16 games in 2020. Cook is a true dominator who gets the type of money touches that produces for fantasy. He had a league-leading 66 red-zone touches and the most goal-line carries in football. That’ll work! He also is an elite talent with the 2nd most evaded tackles and has been a top-5 RB in back-to-back seasons despite only playing 14 games. The change in offensive coordinator shouldn’t scare anyone as it’s all in the family with Klint Kubiak replacing Gary Kubiak. If you wanted to take him at 1.01, we wouldn’t file a complaint to the powers that be.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Cook is a top-3 dynasty RB and after signing a massive extension last year, he’s still under contract with the Vikings for four more years.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Alex Collins, Chris Carson, Rashaad Penny

notes.text: Throughout Carson's career, he's produced RB2 or better numbers in 60 percent of his games. That's just a smidge behind Marshawn Lynch's number of 61.7 percent, which goes to show just how undervalued Carson has been to this point. Injuries have been a question, which should lower his ADP a bit, but when on the field, Carson is a borderline RB1 who the Seahawks signed to a fresh new deal this offseason.

Carson has dealt with injury in nearly every professional season of his career, but his injury history doesn’t seem to have any correlation. Rather, he seems to be the product of the fact that RBs sustain injuries at a higher rate than any other position in the NFL. Carson missed 4 weeks last year with a foot sprain but returned to full strength later in the year. Based on his track record, it may be unrealistic to expect Carson to play all 17 games, but he’s healthy entering the offseason program and training camp.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chris Carson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Over the last three years, Carson has averaged 19 opportunities per game and Seattle believed in him enough to extend him at least for the next two years. He's an RB2 with a floor that's hard to find in this age of committee backfields.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Carson’s two year deal gives managers some breathing room. There is no-one else that should eat into his workload and you probably are better off keeping him than trading him at this point.

notes.text: It's not the start to his career that he hoped for, as Penny has totaled just 161 carries over his first three seasons in the league. While on the field, he was productive with his touches, but he failed to bounce back from his ACL injury in 2020, an injury that not many have had problems coming back from. It seemed he may finally get his opportunity to claim this backfield in 2021, but the Seahawks decided to re-sign Chris Carson to a pricey contract, locking Penny into the backup role. He's a solid handcuff, but one who hasn't been able to stay healthy himself.

Pete Carroll told reporters on Wednesday, June 16 that Rashaad Penny underwent a cleanup procedure on the same knee that he injured in 2019. Penny barely contributed to the Seahawks in 2020 as he was still limited early in the year given the lengthy recovery from his December 2019 ACL injury. Remember, Penny’s ACL injury was more complex, which likely involved a meniscus injury. This, combined with the news of a subsequent surgery does not bode well for Penny’s 2021 outlook and beyond, as each surgical intervention that’s required will accelerate the rate of developing arthritis in the knee joint. At this point, the cards are stacked against the former 1st round NFL Draft pick.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Rashaad Penny
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The former 1st round draft pick has gone from hyped to hurt to does this guy still play in the NFL? He’s scored six total TDs in three years and with Chris Carson re-signed, he’s a backup soon to be out the door. For redraft, he should not be rostered.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Seahawks rightly declined his 5th year option. He’s one of the many examples of why NFL teams spending 1st round draft capital on a RB is a losing proposition.

notes.text: Once Chris Carson re-signed with the Seahawks, almost all hope for Dallas went out the window. Carson is clearly the lead back, while Rashaad Penny is fully rehabbed from his ACL injury, making Dallas the No. 3 option at best, and he'd still likely have to fight with Alex Collins and/or Travis Homer for that job.

Since Kittle came into the NFL, he's produced TE1-type numbers in 58.5 percent of his games, which ranks third among all tight ends since 2000, ahead of guys like Tony Gonzalez and Jimmy Graham. He's in the prime of his career and now gets an upgrade at quarterback? He hasn't scored many touchdowns (never more than five), which has kept him out of the Travis Kelce territory. If he gets a bump in touchdowns with Trey Lance, we could see a Kelce-like finish in 2021 for Kittle. Health has proven to be an obstacle, but you shouldn't bet against Kittle finishing as a top-two tight end.

George Kittle’s 2020 season got off to a rough start when he hyperextended his knee in Week 1. He was able to escape the hyperextension injury without structural damage and returned a few weeks later. Then, Kittle sat out Weeks 9-15 with a fractured cuboid in his foot. This bone, located at the lateral side of the arch, is rarely fractured in NFL players, but the recovery is relatively straightforward and rarely requires surgery thanks to its excellent blood supply. To this point in his career, Kittle has dealt with injury in every professional season but his injuries have primarily come as a blocker or defenseless receiver, suggesting he’s been more unlucky than “injury prone.”

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: George Kittle
