ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Kittle’s zest for life and football is contagious but he’s also missed ten games the last two seasons due to freak injuries. Move past the concern and realize he is the most athletic TE at the position with YAC-ability to take five-yard outs to the house. He’s averaged 81 yards per game over the last three seasons. Trey Lance’s ability to get outside the pocket could vault Kittle into TE1 status as soon as this year. He’s a worthy late 2nd round pick.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s 27 and under contract until 2025. His cap hit is 17th at the TE position this year. Kittle can jump Kelce as the TE1 in dynasty this year especially if Lance progresses.

notes.text: It's easy to recall the good times Fournette had in the playoffs and use that as a reason to move him up draft boards, but don't let a couple games spoil what was a very mediocre season. He finished with more than 52 rushing yards just once all year, and that came in Week 2 against the Panthers. Fournette's primary source of fantasy points in 2020 was via the passing game, as he saw 47 targets in 13 games. Unfortunately, the Bucs added Gio Bernard, who's a much better receiver out of the backfield. Knowing that Bernard is the more reliable third-down option and that Ronald Jones is probably the better two-down option, that leaves Fournette in no man's land. He's not someone you're going to want to start every week.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Leonard Fournette
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Fat Len turned into Playoff Lenny and earned himself a new contract in 2021. What a wild ride for a player taken 4th overall, cut by his former team, signed with the Bucs right before the season, and played his way to the Super Bowl. Now he's back with the Bucs, splitting carries with Ronald Jones and Giovani Bernard. Fournette and Jones are back-to-back in our rankings and neither seem like dependable options in fantasy.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you somehow held onto Fournette through all of the turmoil, you were rewarded with at least another year attached to Tom Brady. But the clock is ticking so be willing to trade him if he gets hot early.

notes.text: Bass had a fine rookie season, seeing plenty of volume in an explosive Bills offense. He ranked second in the league in extra-point attempts and conversions, and made 28 of his field-goal tries. He could use to improve his accuracy (82.4%), but it's hard to fault him too much for it given that he kicks in a notoriously difficult home venue. All in all, Bass should again be drafted as a starting-caliber kicker in fantasy leagues.

How often can you find a wide receiver being drafted outside the top 40 who's capable of posting WR1-type numbers? Williams fits that bill. He already has a 1,000-yard season on his resume. He also has a 10-touchdown season on it. He also happens to have one of the brightest young stars as his quarterback with little else on the depth chart outside of Keenan Allen. Health has been the biggest question mark for Williams, but once you're outside the top-40 wide receivers, there's hardly guaranteed production on the board, so take the upside.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mike Williams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Big Mike Willy has sort of always hung around as an offseason hype man entering season-long drafts, but outside of 2018 when he finished as the WR24 on the back of ten TD receptions, he’s never put a full season together. He’s a fine late round bench WR given the upside of his QB, Justin Herbert.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Williams is set to become an unrestricted free agent after the 2021 season. Ironically, playing as the ‘big outside WR’, Williams’ best spot might actually be staying in LA to play with Justin Herbert. His previous perceived WR1 upside is now clearly a thing of the past.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dalton Schultz
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The party planned for Blake Jarwin in 2020 was commandeered by Schultz after Week 1. From that moment on, Schultz was the TE10 for the rest of the season propped up by volume averaging a respectable 5.7 targets per game. He was out on the field a ton running the 3rd most routes at the TE position but his snaps should drastically decrease with Jarwin back in the fold. He’s not draft worthy.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The former 4th round pick turns 25 years old and is an unrestricted free agent in 2022, much to the delight of Mike Wright.

notes.text: Do you know how many times Jackson has finished with fewer than 16.5 fantasy points since taking the starting job in 2019? Four. He's posted 21.3 or more fantasy points in 22-of-30 games during that stretch, which is flat-out ridiculous. Since becoming the starter two years ago, he's posted QB1-type numbers in 76.7 percent of his games. The only other quarterback who's posted higher than 64.8 percent in their career is Patrick Mahomes, who's sitting at 69.6 percent. On top of that, Jackson now got better weapons to throw to, yet some are ranking him as the fourth-best quarterback in fantasy? Not me. Jackson should be in the conversation to be the first quarterback off the board.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Lamar Jackson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: His TD rate was bound to drop but it felt like the passing pie in Baltimore was a baby-sized portion some weeks as he had 12(!) games under 200 passing yards and only three games of 3+ passing TDs. On the ground, Lamar averaged only 13 fewer yards per game, had the same amount of rushing TDs (7), and less than half a yard per carry difference from his historic 2019 MVP season. He’s still a game-breaker as he now owns two of the top-3 QB rushing seasons of all-time. He’s an high-risk, high-reward player as you need him to boom in order to return his 4th/5th round draft cost.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: With the Ravens exercising their 5th year option on Lamar, we know a massive long-term extension is coming soon. His playing style and low passing volume makes him a bit more volatile than other dynasty QBs but he’s still the most exciting player in the league.

notes.text: We got somewhat of a breakout season from Davis last year, as he finished with 65 receptions for 984 yards and five touchdowns despite missing two games and playing second fiddle to A.J. Brown. He signed with the Jets in free agency and figures to be their go-to receiver, though there are suddenly tons of mouths to feed in New York. The Jets also added Keelan Cole in free agency, drafted Elijah Moore in the second round, and managed to restructure Jamison Crowder's contract to keep him in town. On top of all that, they have a rookie quarterback under center, which presents another obstacle. Davis is likely to be the leader in targets, but he may not have enough consistency to be a weekly WR3. Ideally, you draft him as a WR4 to play in spots.

The Jets new WR suffered a shoulder injury during OTAs in late May, but by all accounts, the injury is minor. It sounds like Davis landed on the top of his shoulder, which is typically consistent with one of two injuries: a sprained AC joint and/or a bruised rotator cuff. Regardless, these injuries won’t affect Davis moving forward. He’ll be ready for Week 1.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Corey Davis
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After being left for dead by fantasy managers, Corey Davis put together a really nice 2020 season playing alongside A.J. Brown in Tennessee. Now, he lands in New York with the Jets. While he could see an uptick in target volume, he’ll be relying on a rookie QB Zach Wilson. It's rare to find a team's WR1 sitting in the double-digit rounds so take the value in hopes he can be a top-36 guy in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Davis signed a 3-year deal with the Jets, but his 2023 contract carries zero guaranteed money. In other words, if things don’t work out over the next two seasons, Davis could be on the move once again.

notes.text: Ok, we're out of excuses for Darnold. It's now or never and he's getting his shot in Joe Brady's pass-friendly offense with some tremendous weapons. The one issue that remains, however, is that his offensive line is brutal. Despite that, Teddy Bridgewater was able to post 19-plus fantasy points in seven games last year, and that was while throwing just 15 touchdowns. The Panthers traded him for essentially nothing, and then passed on Justin Fields and Mac Jones in the draft, so they clearly believe Darnold can be their long-term answer. I don't want to hold it against Darnold that he had to play for Adam Gase in two of his first three seasons, but at the same time, he's thrown more than two touchdowns in just three of his 38 career games to this point and offers minimal fantasy upside on the ground. Because of that, it's hard to see him as a true breakout performer this year, but he should be a great target in Superflex/2QB leagues because he's not going to lose the job anytime soon, so you have an every-week starter.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Sam Darnold
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It's put up or shut up time for Sammy D. Now in Carolina, he has the weapons in place at WR (Moore, Anderson, Marshall) and fantasy’s most valuable player (CMC). The Adam Gase excuses used like crop dusting farts should no longer linger. His metrics across the board are porous through three years especially how he responds under pressure. If there is room for optimism, OC Joe Brady is creative enough to make this work. For fantasy, he’s a wait-and-see.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Panthers picked up his 5th year option so it looks like Darnold is their starter through 2022. Hopefully he will respond and continue to bolster an exciting young offense.

notes.text: As of now, the Saints are undecided on who the starting quarterback will be heading into the 2021 season. If it's Hill, he's going to jump all the way up into the top-15 quarterback conversation. If I knew he'd start all 17 games, he'd be ranked top-10 for his rushing upside, but it seems like Jameis Winston has the slight edge heading into camp. Do you think that sounds crazy? It's not. Hill was the QB6 during the month he started while Drew Brees was out. This is a battle we'll be watching closely as the season nears.

Hill might sound like a gamble at this point of the offseason but regardless of what you think about the New Orleans QB situation, his fantasy production was just too good last year to get buried in bias. In his four starts, Hill averaged 21.6 fantasy points (QB6) on the back of 53 rushing yards per game.  Andy & Jason, in particular, are bullish on Hill for 2021. If he is named the starter, you can bank on that safe rushing floor but also dream of a scenario where he improves even slightly as a passer. If that clicks, you are getting a steal for a player basically going undrafted. If he’s not named the starter, just cut bait and find another starter.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Taysom Hill
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Saints could certainly take a step back this year with Drew Brees gone. Teams now have more film to prepare for Hill's style of play so don't expect the same league-leading adjusted completion percentage in 2021. His production on the ground alone makes him a late-round QB worth “shooting your shot” with his early-season schedule. The Saints have said that Taysom Hill and Jameis Winston will compete for the starting role. *If you think Jameis Winston will be the starter, he will likely be drafted as a top 15 fantasy QB.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: We have no idea exactly how things are going to shake out in New Orleans. But there is a possibility by this time next year Hill is cut and signing on as a gadget player somewhere else.

notes.text: Lutz had core muscle surgery in August and is likely to miss several weeks of the season. Although he may regain his job upon his return, he had his worst season as a professional last year, setting career-lows in field goal percentage (82.1%), attempts (28), and conversions (23). The New Orleans offense was simply far less explosive with a declining (and injured) Drew Brees, and Lutz couldn't make up for his lack of efficiency with increased volume. Given Lutz's injury and the now less-desirable New Orleans offense, there's no reason to consider him in fantasy leagues.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Drew Sample
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: If you’ve ever been asked for a stool sample, you understand it’s not a glorious process. Ergo Drew Sample’s 2020 season. After C.J. Uzomah went down and Sample saw nine targets in relief of that Week 2 game, he never got off the toilet the rest of the season. He averaged 3.5 fantasy points per game from Week 3 on and never cracked the top-15. With crowded competition for targets, it’s best to cleanse your system now of any fantasy dreams for Sample.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Once curiously taken as a 2nd round draft pick, Sample is a rosterable player in dynasty. He has to prove he belongs in a starting lineup though.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Kadarius Toney, Darius Slayton, Kenny Golladay

notes.text: His NFL career has gotten off to a rough start so far. First, it was contract issues. Next, it was an injury that kept him sidelined through rookie mini-camp. Lastly, it was being placed on the COVID reserve list. With all the setbacks, my guess is that the Giants open the season with Kenny Golladay, Sterling Shepard, and Darius Slayton in 3WR sets while Toney has to earn a place in the offense. There's no guarantee that happens early in the season, making Toney a very shaky pick in redraft formats.

The Giants surprised everyone by trading back in the NFL Draft then selecting a WR, despite signing Kenny Golladay in free agency and already having a pretty loaded pass catching group. Toney’s skillset is raw, and he’ll need time to develop as an NFL WR, suggesting he may help the Giants more than your fantasy team in 2021.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kadarius Toney
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Giants surprised everyone by trading back in the NFL Draft then selecting a WR, despite signing Kenny Golladay in free agency and already having a pretty loaded pass catching group. Toney’s skillset is raw, and he’ll need time to develop as an NFL WR, suggesting he may help the Giants more than your fantasy team in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Toney’s profile has many holes - a late breakout age, minimal production at Florida and he’s a bit undersized. However, Toney’s athleticism and skillset is intriguing, assuming Jason Garrett can be creative enough to get him the ball in space. We know he’ll be competing with Kenny G for targets for the next four years. Daniel Jones’ NFL future is still a big question mark going forward.

notes.text: While 2019 seemed like Slayton might have a bright future in the NFL, 2020 wasn't as kind to him. He did lead all Giants wide receivers in targets (97) but it didn't lead to much in the production department, as he tallied just 50 receptions for 751 yards and three touchdowns. The Giants appeared to lose confidence in him, too, as they signed Kenny Golladay in free agency, and then drafted Kadarius Toney. Suddenly, Slayton may not be a starter on this offense, as Sterling Shepard and Golladay are the locked-in starters, while Toney figures to start in the slot. At this point, Slayton shouldn't even be drafted.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Darius Slayton
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Slayton’s fantasy outlook got crushed when the team signed Kenny Golladay to a 4-year, $72 million deal. There’s a lot that needs to go right for Slayton to be fantasy viable but he could be a spot start type of guy in the right matchup.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Slayton made some noise in dynasty after posting 740 yards and eight TDs as a rookie. However, we saw him fall off significantly last year, thanks in part due to poor QB play from Danny Dimes and the Giants offense looking inept at times. Is Jones good enough to support multiple fantasy viable WRs? Slayton is signed with the Giants for two more years.

notes.text: Going to a new team is never easy, especially for someone who's coming from a team that was lacking any depth of pass catchers. It was easy for him to get eight-plus targets per game, especially when Marvin Jones was hurt. Now going to the Giants, who have a bevy of options, including Sterling Shepard, Kadarius Toney, Darius Slayton, Evan Engram, Kyle Rudolph, and Saquon Barkley is going to be tough. To be fair, you don't go out in free agency and sign someone like Golladay to give him five targets per game, but he's not going to get the consistent targets he got in Detroit, and the targets he does get aren't going to be as efficient coming from Daniel Jones.

Fantasy managers won't forget Kenny Golladay missed Weeks 9-17 last year with an undisclosed hip injury. By now, this is completely healed and should be a non-issue moving forward. However, Golladay also missed Weeks 1-2 due to a hamstring issue he picked up during training camp last season and during his rookie season in 2017, Golladay missed 5 games thanks to a strained hamstring. I bring this up because on August 3, Golladay left Giants practice early, grabbing the back of his left thigh, which is usually the tell-tale sign of a hamstring strain. As of this writing, we don't have any more information, but it's reasonable to expect Golladay to miss practice time early in August. His status will be updated once we get more information on his most recent injury.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kenny Golladay
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We all needed some more smooth routes in our life in 2020. Kenny G's move to New York was one of the bigger free agent signings, but for fantasy, may struggle to break into the top-12 WRs. He made his money in Detroit on a plethora of end-zone targets and deep passes on low target numbers. Will Kenny G finally see the targets he deserves? Daniel Jones has been more than capable down the field but whether this team will have the scoring opportunities fantasy managers want is another question mark. When you add upa rough training camp with HC Joe Judge's tough guy antics, infighting among the team, and Golladay's hamstring woes, his fantasy stock is pointing down heading into drafts.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Golladay signed a massive 4-year, $52 million deal to be the Giants’ WR1 for the next handful of seasons, but if Daniel Jones can’t get it going, will Golladay waste his prime years playing for the G-men? His QB situation will likely determine his upside for the next 3-4 years.

notes.text: Jordan fell all the way to the 5th round but he finds himself in a situation in Houston with a team desperate for playmakers. However, he’s a rookie TE… playing for the Texans. Even the best TE prospects in good situations usually take time to develop.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Brevin Jordan
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Jordan fell all the way to the 5th round but he finds himself in a situation in Houston with a team desperate for playmakers. However, he’s a rookie TE… playing for the Texans. Even the best TE prospects in good situations usually take time to develop.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s not much of a blocker but with his after-the-catch ability reminiscent of Jonnu Smith, he could make a difference at the TE position if things break right in a couple of years.

notes.text: Naturally, we should've expected some rust on Gronkowski after taking a year off football. He was a bit slot out of the gate, but was ultimately able to finish as the No. 8 tight end in 2020. That's not a huge accomplishment or anything, as he still failed to record more than 48 yards in 11-of-16 games, and that's despite Chris Godwin missing time to injury, and Antonio Brown not joining the team until midseason. We also can't forget about O.J. Howard, who had more production and targets than Gronkowski when he tore his Achilles. Gronkowski will certainly offer some streamable weeks, but relying on him as your every-week tight end would be a mistake with all the mouths they have to feed in Tampa Bay.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Rob Gronkowski
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Gronk Smash! It took a minute as Gronk had 20 total fantasy points through the first five weeks of the season. Yet, he got back in playing shape and was the TE4 from Week 6 on. He was used in classic Bruce Arians fashion downfield with the most TE targets, receptions and yards on 20+ yard attempts. With Tom Brady being projected as a high-end QB1, Andy is in on Gronk being more than just a streamable player in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you held onto the slim hopes of Gronk remaining on the end of your dynasty roster, you were rewarded in 2020. As long as he’s connected with Brady, he has life.

notes.text: We barely got to see Tom Brady toss the ball to Howard in 2020, but what we did see was Howard out-producing Rob Gronkowski. It's easy to forget that Howard was supposed to be the next big thing at tight end, similar to how people feel about Kyle Pitts today. Early reports out of Bucs camp suggest Howard is being flexed as a receiver and that Brady sees him as a legit threat in the passing game. With Gronkowski getting up there in age/bumps/bruises, we could see Howard finally take the step many thought he would years ago. Best of all, you'll find out for free.

OJ Howard tore his Achilles in Week 5 last year and shortly after, underwent Achilles tendon repair surgery. The data suggests that skill position players in the NFL see about a 20% reduction in on field performance for the first year after surgery. While Howard is expected to be ready for Week 1, fantasy managers should manage expectations in the first several weeks of the season as it will likely take Howard time to acclimate back into the NFL.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: O.J. Howard
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The artist formerly known as O'Terrius Jabari Howard is almost erased from our memories considering he was part of the Super Bowl-winning Buccaneers. Howard actually had two top-8 fantasy performances before an Achilles injury abruptly ended his season in Week 4. He returns with Rob Gronkowski in tow and a bag of disappointment he’s carrying around his shoulders four years after being a 1st round pick. He’s not on the redraft radar.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Howard had been the subject of trade rumors but it seems he’ll ride out his rookie contract in Tampa Bay. He’s only 26 and possesses some of the tools that could make him a second contract value somewhere else in the NFL.

notes.text: Hopkins had a typical season with less than stellar accuracy but enough volume to make him a borderline starter most weeks. He doesn't have the biggest leg and hits at only about a 50% clip from 50 yards or beyond. The Washington offense should be better this year with Ryan Fitzpatrick under center, so Hopkins could see more than the 34 attempts he did last year. But, ultimately, he's in that large conglomerate of streamable kickers, but one who doesn't separate himself from the pack.

We watched Mayfield take major strides in Kevin Stefanski's offense as the year went on in 2020, but it's important to remember that he didn't throw the ball more than 33 times in 12-of-16 games. They want to play good defense and run the ball as much as possible, which makes Mayfield much more efficient. While he's a great target in 2QB leagues, there's rarely a week-to-week ceiling to his projection.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Baker Mayfield
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Browns took a major step forward in 2020 but for most of the year, he didn’t help you out for fantasy. From Weeks 1-11, he was the QB31 in fantasy points per game, the same as Drew Lock. Woof. However, from Weeks 12-15, he was the QB3 eventually beating the Steelers in the WildCard round of the playoffs. The Browns should be a top tier AFC team once again but Baker is best left on the waiver wire for much of the year as the ground-and-pound approach with the Cleveland running game is preferred by HC Kevin Stefanski.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: With his 5th year option exercised, look for the Browns to work an extension with Baker this next offseason. He’s settled in as a QB2 for fantasy, which sadly is much lower than the hype surrounding the Heisman-winning, 1st overall pick.

notes.text: The man just keeps getting better... Every year he's been in the league, we've watched his rushing yardage go up by at least 250 yards. I'm sure he peaked last year with 2,027 yards on the ground, but now going to a 17-game season, maybe I'm wrong. Henry should be in scoring position quite a bit this year knowing the Titans went out and acquired Julio Jones this offseason. There's no scenario where your offense gets worse in that equation. However, we don't know how the offense is going to look in 2021, as Arthur Smith (offensive coordinator the last two years) is gone. Still, with Jones and A.J. Brown on the perimeter, it's going to be tough for opponents to stack the box the way they have against Henry the last few years, so his efficiency may actually go up. There are certainly some variables to his projections, but Henry has proven that despite his lack of usage in the passing game, he's going to make up for it on the ground.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Derrick Henry
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Whoaaaa buddy. Henry is one of the true outliers at the RB position that doesn’t need major passing work to be effective for fantasy. Over the last two seasons, he’s averaged 340 rushes for 1783 yards and 16 rush TDs. His 378 rush attempts last year were the most since Demarco Murray’s 394 in 2014 for the Cowboys. Although he feasted on bad defenses (+5.69 fantasy points vs bottom-16 defenses) and weirdly was better on the road (+8.3 fantasy points), it’s hard to doubt him.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: In dynasty, Henry is a different story. He will turn 29 in early January 2022 and over the last eight years, there's been only one player inside the top-10 of Dynasty RB ADP over the age of 27 that maintained top-10 status the next year: Adrian Peterson. If you’re in win-now mode, you gotta ride with him. If not, trading now for a haul makes a ton of sense.

notes.text: I think most people were shocked when the Titans selected Evans in the third round of the 2020 NFL Draft, though I figured it meant they were going to start to lighten the burden on Derrick Henry, as Evans profiled as a timeshare back. Instead, it was all Henry, all the time. Will that change with Arthur Smith out of town? It's possible. I'm expecting a bigger role on obvious passing downs, while carrying some solid handcuff value in a high-scoring offense.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Darrynton Evans
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Evans entered the 2020 season looking to be the backup to Derrick Henry. However, heonly played in 5 games last year, missing the rest due to injury. He does have some receiving chops so perhaps Year Two will treat him better. He’s like getting an insurance policy on your 1989 Honda Civic: you probably won’t need it even if things go awry.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Evans is worth a roster spot as an emergency insurance policy for Derrick Henry managers. He was drafted in the 3rd round last year and has 4.41 speed so he’s no slouch.

notes.text: Koo scored the most fantasy points per game of any kicker, and would have been the tops overall at the position had he not missed a game because of a COVID-19 situation. Koo missed just two field goals all year, and was a perfect 8-for-8 from 50 yards or more. He'll again play in a dome in Atlanta, but with new head coach Arthur Smith and an offense that will be slower and less explosive without Julio Jones, it's far from a sure thing that he'll see 39 field-goal attempts again. Nevertheless, the indoor environment and Koo's success from long range makes him a top-five option at the kicker position.

Tucker remains the best kicker in the game from a real-life standpoint, hitting nearly 90% of his field-goal attempts and all but one of his extra-point attempts last year. The issue from a fantasy standpoint is that the Ravens' efficiency in the red zone with Lamar Jackson under center has led to fewer field goal attempts. After averaging 39 field-goal attempts per season from 2015-2018, Tucker has attempted just 29 field goals in each of the past two seasons. His increase in extra-point attempts (he's averaged 56 extra-point attempts the last two seasons after averaging just 33 the four prior seasons) just isn't enough to make up the difference. Still, even if Tucker is down from his peak, he remains a locked-in top-10 kicker and the safest option on the board. He should be one of the first few taken at the position, even if his upside isn't quite as high anymore.

Memories of Zuerlein's outstanding 2017 season with the Rams keep him on the forefront of fantasy managers' minds, but the fact is that he hasn't been nearly the same kicker since. He missed seven field-goal attempts and three extra-point attempts last year, but was a solid fantasy starter simply because of his volume. He led the league in field-goal attempts with 41, and was accurate within 50 yards, missing just a single kick. But he simply couldn't hit from long range, going just 3-for-9 from 50-plus yards. With Dak Prescott back, the Dallas offense should put up plenty of points, which should again provide Zuerlein with a ton of opportunities. If he can rediscover his accuracy from long distance, he'll likely be a stud option, but even if not, he's a fantasy starter.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jameis Winston
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Saints have said that Taysom Hill and Jameis Winston will compete for the starting role. With Michael Thomas likely sidelined early in the 2021 season, this certainly hurts Jameis' upside IF he is declared the starter. Head coach, Sean Payton might not allow Famous Jameis to get away with the same INT shenanigans that he pulled in Tampa Bay. This team will likely win with defense and success on the ground. Temper your expectations but know there will be some shootouts in store especially against his NFC South opponents.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: It’s kinda one of those things where you’re flying by the seat of your pants. ‘Is he the starter? Woohoo! I believed the whole time!... Oh, he’s not? Well, maybe that saved me from a disaster.’ His trade value is low, but will obviously go up big time if he's named the starter.

notes.text: It's really unfair to judge Tagovailoa after a pretty weak rookie season, as he dealt with an injury throughout the offseason, had no preseason, and plenty of injuries to his pass catchers. On top of that, he had Ryan Fitzpatrick breathing down his neck. Fast forward to 2021 where Fitzpatrick is gone, and the Dolphins have added Will Fuller and Jaylen Waddle to his stable of pass catchers. If his injuries really limited him in 2020, we could see an explosion in 2021 with the firepower they have at wide receiver, but don't automatically assume that.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tua Tagovailoa
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Dolphins went 6-3 in Tua’s starts but you’d think he went 3-6 with the way fantasy managers wanted Ryan Fitzpatrick back at the helm. Some of his upside was on display against Kansas City in Week 14 as he threw for 316 yards, two passing TDs, and added another score on the ground en route to being the QB4 on the week. But most of his targets throughout the season were of the low aDOT variety. Since 2000, his 9.75 yards per completion ranks 49th of 51 rookie QBs 8+ starts in a given season. The excuses need to subside though as DeVante Parker, Will Fuller V, and now Jaylen Waddle give him three legitimate weapons. He could surprise or submarine the entire offense’s upside.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Tua’s value is all over the place and it depends on if you think he’s a true franchise QB in the NFL. Right now he’s a hold knowing 2021 will determine much of his future. Does he go the route of Josh Allen and steadily improve or Sam Darnold and shipwrecks a franchise?

notes.text: When Burrow went down with a torn ACL last year, he was sitting as the QB16 in the fantasy rankings, just behind Jared Goff and Teddy Bridgewater. That's not exactly living up to expectations. He is apparently on track to be back in the lineup for Week 1, but his mobility might be limited, especially to start the year, which will put a damper on his fantasy upside. The good news is that the Bengals improved the offensive line this offseason, as well as drafting Ja'Marr Chase at No. 5 overall based on Burrow's recommendation. He now has one of the best trio of wide receivers in the game, paired with a rebuilding defense, which should be the recipe for plenty of pass attempts. But again, dial back expectations because of his mobility. Burrow is best-served as a high-end QB2 in fantasy this year.

No QB in the NFL dropped back to pass more than Joe Burrow before he went down in Week 11 with a left knee injury. Burrow suffered a torn ACL and MCL with “additional damage” in the knee joint, which likely suggests either a cartilage or meniscus injury. His surgery took place on December 2, giving Burrow approximately 9 months to be ready for Week 1. Right now, all reports regarding his recovery are positive, and he should start in Week 1. However, he’s not yet at 100% and is unlikely to be when the season starts. Expect Burrow to be more of a traditional pocket QB in the first month of the season with limited rushing upside to start the year. He’ll get even stronger and perform at a higher level as the season progresses.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Joe Burrow
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Burrow’s rookie year was promising in many ways before going down with a serious leg injury. He made his fantasy dough on volume averaging the most pass attempts per game (40.4) by a rookie in NFL history. However, he also played a little reckless taking 32 sacks (tie-2nd most) & 42 QB hits (tied-5th most) over the first 11 weeks of the season. He also sported the 3rd lowest adjusted completion rate on deep passes in the NFL. Ask A.J. Green. Right now, all reports regarding his recovery point to him being able to start in Week 1.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: With his LSU running mate Ja’Marr Chase now in tow, Burrow is outfitted with a ridiculous trio of pass-catching weapons for the next few years. He’s a top-10 dynasty QB.

notes.text: In his career as a starting QB, Jimmy Garoppolo has never made it out of September without an injury. Last year, it was a high ankle sprain in Week 2 that kept him out three weeks. But, he returned too quickly and aggravated that same injury in Week 5 and again in Week 8. We didn’t see Jimmy G under center for the rest of the season. To this point, his injury history includes a high ankle sprain, a torn ACL and a sprained AC joint, which don’t seem to have any correlation. As far as injury risk, Garoppolo should be completely healthy this summer heading into training camp.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jimmy Garoppolo
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Handsome Jimmy went from nearly leading this team to a Super Bowl two years ago to now clearly out the door. He might begin the season as starter but it’s clear Trey Lance will jump in the driver’s seat for this franchise. He’s a fine NFL QB but between injuries and some physical limitations outside the pocket, it’s probably best the 49ers moved on.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: It’s a miracle the team didn’t cut him this off-season as a cap casualty. If your league gives points for good looks, hold onto him.

notes.text: Now that Cobb is back in Green Bay with Aaron Rodgers, he's back on the fantasy radar. Knowing Rodgers specifically requested for the Packers to get Cobb back, it tells you he's getting opportunity right out of the gate, though it's worth noting he's never played in Matt LaFleur's offense. We shouldn't go overboard, though. The last three seasons Cobb was in Green Bay, he averaged 6.4 targets, 4.4 receptions, 44.5 yards, and 0.27 touchdowns per game, which extrapolate to 70 receptions, 712 yards, and four touchdowns over a full 16-game season. My guess would be that Cobb is a solid bye-week filler who'll offer a solid floor.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Randall Cobb
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: How lucky is Randall Cobb? Rescued from the Texans and back in Green Bay, because of Aaron Rodgers. Cobb may have weeks of fantasy relevance but with a low floor and low ceiling, is likely not worth drafting.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He has little to no value left in Dynasty. This doesn't change much with the Packers trade. If you can get any value for him now off of the news, you should probably do it.

notes.text: We're getting close to the age where tight ends typically fall off with Kelce (32 in October) but he's shown no signs of slowing down, as he just broke the all-time record for yards in a season by a tight end. The Chiefs didn't really add anyone to the offense who should jeapordize his targets, and in fact, losing Sammy Watkins may only add to his appeal. Not only did he finish as the No. 1 tight end and give you a massive weekly advantage at an unpredictable position, but he would've finished as the No. 4 wide receiver. So, if drafting a tight end early scares you, just think of him like a wide receiver who you can play in your tight end slot. He's worth a late first-round pick.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Travis Kelce
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Five years in a row, the message has been clear: Kelce is the undisputed TE1. 2020 he had the 2nd best season by a fantasy TE ever behind Gronk’s 2011 campaign. Kelce essentially was the WR3 in fantasy points and an unfair positional advantage if you were fortunate enough to roster him last year. He’s worth a late first round pick and doesn’t seem to be slowing down at all.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s under contract for another five years which is a rarity not only at the position but at his age of 31 years old. He’s a unicorn and could go down as the greatest ever. Why trade him?

notes.text: Remember when Cooper was labeled as a "boom or bust" receiver during his Oakland days? While with the Cowboys, that hasn't been the case at all. He's now been a WR2 or better in 20-of-41 games with the Cowboys, which amounts to 48.8 percent. That number is the exact same as Stefon Diggs' career number. It's higher than Terry McLaurin's 48.3 percent. The emergence of CeeDee Lamb may take some of the upside potential away from Cooper, but he's still a great high-end WR2 to have on your fantasy team.

Cooper’s stock somehow has dropped this year where Ceedee Lamb is consistently being drafted at or above his ADP. We still believe Cooper is the clear No. 1 in this offense and he has a ridiculous rapport with Dak Prescott. In 29 career full games with Dak, he’s averaged 8.5 targets & 80 receiving yards per game. Right now Cooper is being drafted in WR2 territory while we know fully he’s capable of finishing inside the top-10 of the position. Snagging him with your 4th round pick feels like cheating especially on an offense that could blow the doors off in 2021.

Cooper picked up a mild right high ankle sprain against the Giants in Week 17 then underwent a procedure on his right ankle on January 7th. As of now, there aren’t details available regarding the procedure done in early January, but it sounds like Cooper is still dealing with some lingering irritation in his right ankle, which has forced him to miss Cowboys mini camp. Coming off a surgery, athletes can develop irritation in the ankle joint or tendinitis of the muscles around the ankle. Assuming it’s the latter of these two scenarios, his injury should respond well to rest and rehab. As of now, it’s wait and see mode for Cooper as how he progresses over the next month will determine his early season 2021 outlook. Look for Cooper’s write up to be updated over the next few weeks.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Amari Cooper
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Fantasy managers may forget just how good Amari Cooper was before Dak Prescott’s injury in Week 5. From Weeks 1-6, Cooper was fantasy’s WR7. When Andy Dalton and Ben DiNucci were forced under center, the Dallas offense got stuck in the mud, and Cooper finished as the WR30 from Week 7 on. In 29 full games with Dak, Cooper has averaged 8.5 targets and 80 receiving yards per game. Assuming Dak is back to full health, Mr. Cooper has top-12 WR upside in 2021. UPDATE: Cooper missed Cowboys mini-camp as he is still dealing with some lingering irritation in his right ankle post surgery. Check out his full Injury Report write-up as we monitor his situation.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Since Dallas acquired him from the Raiders in 2018, Cooper's production speaks for itself. However, he enters a point in his contract where the Cowboys can move on from him for just $6 million in dead cap after the 2021 season. If he sticks around beyond 2021, however, expect Cooper to continue to produce at a high level with Prescott now locked up long-term.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kyle Rudolph
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Red-zone Reindeer now finds himself in a new habitat albeit with a QB not nearly as jolly or generous for fantasy options as his previous home. Rudolph is going to siphon away end-zone looks from Kenny Golladay and Evan Engram and literally ruin everything for fantasy. He’s the kid at the lunch table bent on smashing your food that no-one likes… but he keeps sitting with you.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Rudolph is a roster clogger who apart from an Evan Engram injury, has no real dynasty value.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Andy Dalton
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Dalton was serviceable last year in Dallas and after being announced as the team’s “QB1” earlier this offseason, it now seems clear that Justin Fields will take over at some point.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s carved out a nice little fantasy career since 2011. But he’s a backup at best now.

notes.text: This is funny because I was always the guy saying that Parker was undervalued, and he was, but we've reached the point where I'm abandoning that ship. Last year, he played in eight games with Tua Tagovailoa, and in those games, he averaged 7.1 targets, 3.6 receptions, 43.1 yards, and 0.25 touchdowns. That's... not great. And now you add Will Fuller and Jaylen Waddle to the offense? Parker is the "big body" wide receiver of the bunch, but he's never been a touchdown scorer, finishing with more than four touchdowns just once in his six-year career. His ADP is way too high.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: DeVante Parker
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Parker didn’t have much competition for targets last year in Miami, especially after Preston Williams went down with injury but now the Dolphins have 1st round talent, Jaylen Waddle, and the prolific Will Fuller on the roster. Parker’s fantasy success will rely heavily on whether or not Tua can take a step forward in his second season, as this offense doesn’t look like it’ll be the one that can support three fantasy viable wide receivers. Remember, Parker’s breakout 2019 season and best fantasy games last year came with Fitzmagic under center.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The WR depth chart looks crowded right now given that Will Fuller is in town, but the Flying V is only on a one-year deal, and if he moves on, Parker and Waddle could be this team’s WR core for the next couple of seasons. He’s 28 and under contract with Miami until 2023. If Tua turns out to be the real deal, Parker could provide sneaky WR3/Flex value for 2+ seasons.

notes.text: McCorkle! Michael McCorkle Jones went right about where we thought he would go before all of the 49er whispers in the bushes. Jones’ production in 2020 was historic at Alabama and his fast processing skills and accuracy are what made him a first-round pick despite the “dad-bod”. He should mix in well with OC Josh McDaniels in Foxboro. Jones will likely work behind Cam Newton in 2021 as he adjusts. But if things go south for Cam, he could be thrust into a starting role on a team that can win now with their defense.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mac Jones
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: McCorkle! Michael McCorkle Jones went right about where we thought he would go before all of the 49er whispers in the bushes. Jones’ production in 2020 was historic at Alabama and his fast processing skills and accuracy are what made him a first-round pick despite the “dad-bod”. He should mix in well with OC Josh McDaniels in Foxboro. Jones will likely work behind Cam Newton in 2021 as he adjusts. But if things go south for Cam, he could be thrust into a starting role on a team that can win now with their defense.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Every year “2nd-tier” rookie QBs slide in rookie drafts. Getting Jones in the late 2nd round is a solid strategy for someone you know will get playing time soon.

notes.text: It seems that Washington is going to utilize Antonio Gibson in the passing game much more often in 2021, which will come at the expense of McKissic. It's not just Gibson, either. The Football Team also signed Curtis Samuel in free agency, a player that's used in a hybrid role who gets plenty of intermittent targets, as well as a handful of carries per game. While McKissic was a hidden gem in PPR formats last year, it appears his role is shrinking in this offense. As someone who relies on volume to produce, McKissic is more of a passing-down handcuff to Gibson.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: J.D. McKissic
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Just give me a kiss! Our guy Smooches benefitted from having checkdown Charlie himself (Alex Smith) hitting him left and right last year out of the backfield. McKissic had the most routes run in the league en route to being the RB24 in Half PPR scoring. Over the last 20 years, he totalled the 2nd fewest rushing yards for a RB with 80+ receptions in a season. With Antonio Gibson likely taking a bigger weight coupled with Ryan Fitpatrick’s propensity to hyper target his receivers, McKissic is a low-end FLEX play at best in PPR leagues this year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: McKissic has bounced around the league and will be a free agent in 2022. You likely saw the best season of his career so if someone is willing to trade you for 2020’s stats, moving him now makes a ton of sense.

notes.text: It was a painfully slow start to the 2020 season for Hilton, but he finished strong, tallying 27 receptions, 435 yards, and five touchdowns over the final six games of the season where he was the WR8 during that time. Did it take time to develop chemistry with Philip Rivers? If so, are we going to experience a similar slow start in 2021 with Carson Wentz? On top of the chemistry concern, he has to contend with youngsters Parris Campbell and Michael Pittman, who are both another year into their NFL career, and likely ready to take on bigger roles. Hilton's upside feels severely capped, so it's best to treat him as someone you play through bye weeks rather than someone you rely on week-in and week-out.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: T.Y. Hilton
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After battling injuries for the last two seasons, it was a quick fall from grace for Hilton who had perennially been a lock for a 1,000-yard season. Now? He’s surpassed 80 yards just four times over the last two years. Hilton is a guy who could bounce back, but everything has to go right, starting with the QB play from Carson Wentz.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Now 31 years old and battling injury for two years in a row, TY Hilton’s best fantasy days are clearly behind him and now there’s no long term financial commitment from the Colts. He’s playing on a one year deal and is set to hit free agency after 2021. Any manager with a rebuilding team should be shopping TY before it’s too late.

notes.text: How in the world do you go from one team to another, with no offseason to build chemistry, and then churn out 127 receptions for 1,535 yards and eight touchdowns? Diggs did that because he's uber talented, and he finally got the targets he deserves. The Vikings gave him 112 targets or less in four of the five seasons with them, hiding his true ceiling. He's now tied to Josh Allen, who's continually improved since coming into the league, on a pass-first offense where he's the featured star. There's no reason to think they don't pick up where they left off in 2020. Heck, even his three games in the playoffs against legit opponents netted 20 receptions for 311 yards and two touchdowns.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Stefon Diggs
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After being traded in the 2020 offseason, the rhetoric around the industry was “be careful what you wish for,” with most suggesting Josh Allen’s accuracy woes would negatively impact Diggs. With Josh Allen taking a massive step forward in 2020, Diggs was the primary beneficiary leading the NFL in targets, receptions and yards. He came to play when it mattered most for fantasy managers in Weeks 14-16, totalling 81.3 fantasy points, 14.9 more points than the next closest receiver, Davante Adams. The only question with Diggs is whether or not Buffalo will return to a more balanced offense in 2021 after the Bills showed a willingness to abandon the run at times. Regardless, Diggs should dominate targets once again for Buffalo.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Diggs’ long term situation is as good as any wide receiver in football. He’s under contract with Buffalo through 2023, locking him into an elite target share in one of the most pass-happy offenses in football with Josh Allen. Barring any unforeseen circumstances, Diggs will continue to return WR1 value for multiple seasons.

notes.text: Hill was more of a streaky wide receiver early in his career who relied on big plays to get him into WR1 territory, though that seemingly ended in 2020 where he saw 10-plus targets in seven different games. Those numbers combined with his efficiency equals big things, and there's no reason to think they go away; Travis Kelce is going to be 32 years old, Sammy Watkins is gone, and they brought in no big-name wide receivers who are guaranteed much of anything. He's worthy of a first-round pick in fantasy drafts.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyreek Hill
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Most people think of Tyreek Hill as this splashy up and down player and while he does have immense upside weekly, Hill was actually one of the most consistent wide receivers in the league in 2020. Hill finished outside of the top 36 receivers just three times all season. Since 2017, Tyreek Hill is tied with Davante Adams for the most multi-TD games at the WR position. With Patrick Mahomes throwing him passes, Hill has one of the safest floor/ceiling combos in all of fantasy football.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: As long as Tyreek Hill is playing with Patrick Mahomes as his QB and Andy Reid as his head coach, he’ll be a top five dynasty wide receiver. He’s only under contract with Kansas City through the 2022 season, but look for Cheetah to sign a long term deal soon.

notes.text: There just aren't any good outcomes for Zach Ertz this year.  Unlikely to be back with the Eagles, Ertz has seen his effectiveness decrease and while he possesses a big name in the fantasy football community, it's not going to translate into a big year.  He's a full-on avoid in 2021, which makes Mike very very happy.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Zach Ertz
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Ertz’s time as an elite fantasy TE is long over. He averaged 30 receiving yards per game and finished inside the top-15 at the position once on the year. Woof. He's daily part of trade rumors and regardless if he ends up on a new team, he remains undraftable. P.S. If you send Mike a photo of Ertz, he likely will block you on Twitter for what it’s worth.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Ertz could easily be traded to another team as his favor in Philadelphia looks like it’s run out. He doesn’t have much value left in the tank as he relied solely on volume for years in the Eagles passing attack.

notes.text: He should be a very good player for a very long time, but we've seen highly-athletic tight ends have trouble out of the gate before. In fact, rookie tight ends in general have trouble producing. I want to ask you a question: Since 1998, how many tight ends do you think have topped 627 yards in their rookie season? Two of them. Both of those tight ends saw 115-plus targets, a number Pitts isn't likely to see with Arthur Smith as the new head coach. It helps that Julio Jones has left town, but don't forget that ultra-athletic Jonnu Smith saw just 65 targets in Smith's offense just last year, and he wasn't a rookie.

Kyle Pitts is the highest-drafted TE in NFL history. He joins a Falcons roster that has historically targeted the tight end position, and Pitts has the skill and ability to dominate right out of the gate as a pass-catcher. We must remind you that rookie tight ends rarely put up huge numbers, but Pitts may be the outlier especially with Julio Jones now in Tennessee. A true athletic marvel, Pitts will not be blocking much especially Hayden Hurst in the fold, and may provide a rare weekly ceiling at TE for fantasy teams.

Pitts has done nothing but shatter any ceiling the fantasy community has placed on him. At his pro-day, Pitts’ wingspan (83″ 3/8) was the longest ever recorded for a TE prospect and his unofficial 4.44 40-time is stunning for a player his size. Being drafted 4th overall to Atlanta as the highest TE ever selected is a lot to live up to. Now with Julio traded to the Titans, the Pitts hype train is moving at full speed and his average draft position is on the rise. He has the talent, but depending on draft cost in your league, he may have to defy the odds for rookie TEs, to pay off for fantasy.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kyle Pitts
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Pitts has done nothing but shatter any ceiling the fantasy community has placed on him. At his pro-day, Pitts’ wingspan (83″ 3/8) was the longest ever recorded for a TE prospect and his unofficial 4.44 40-time is stunning for a player his size. Being drafted 4th overall to Atlanta as the highest TE ever selected is a lot to live up to. Now with Julio traded to the Titans, the Pitts hype train is moving at full speed and his average draft position is on the rise. He has the talent, but depending on draft cost in your league, he may have to defy the odds for rookie TEs, to pay off for fantasy.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: It’s really hard to rise any higher when you’re at the top. When the hype, the tape, and measurables all collide you are looking at a player who dynasty managers don’t want to overthink. Pitts is a top-4 rookie pick and we wouldn’t tell you you’re crazy if you took him at the 1.02.

notes.text: The Penn State product was drafted in the second round and looks like a future starter for the Steelers. He has been compared to Rob Gronkowski in terms of being a complete player at the position although he will be behind Eric Ebron in the pecking order in 2022. He’s not on the radar this year but remember the name for the future.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Pat Freiermuth
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Penn State product was drafted in the second round and looks like a future starter for the Steelers. He has been compared to Rob Gronkowski in terms of being a complete player at the position although he will be behind Eric Ebron in the pecking order in 2022. He’s not on the radar this year but remember the name for the future.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Freiermuth likely would’ve been a 1st round pick in this year’s NFL Draft if not for off-season surgery. Eric Ebron is under contract for one more year so if you’re willing to be patient, Freiermuth can turn into a solid top-10 TE in the near future.

notes.text: Gainwell was one of, if not the, best pass catching running backs in the draft. It's unfortunate to see him fall until the fifth round in the NFL Draft, as that doesn't guarantee him a whole lot of opportunity out of the gate, but given Nick Sirianni's ties to Frank Reich, we could see Gainwell in the Nyheim Hines role, which we know has value. The signing of Kerryon Johnson clouded his outlook though, making him just a late-round flier.

We all need some more Kenny G in our lives. But after dropping all the way to the 5th round, we need to temper our expectations. Memphis has churned out some incredible pros (DeAngelo Williams, Tony Pollard, Darrell Henderson Jr., Antonio Gibson) at the RB position and that will definitely influence rookie drafters. Opting out of the 2020 season didn’t help overcome his small stature. Gainwell is a great pass catcher, an area where Miles struggled in 2020. He joins a backfield with Miles Sanders, Boston Scott, Kerryon Johnson, and Jordan Howard.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kenneth Gainwell
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We all need some more Kenny G in our lives. But after dropping all the way to the 5th round, we need to temper our expectations. Memphis has churned out some incredible pros (DeAngelo Williams, Tony Pollard, Darrell Henderson Jr., Antonio Gibson) at the RB position and that will definitely influence rookie drafters. Opting out of the 2020 season didn’t help overcome his small stature. Gainwell is a great pass catcher, an area where Miles struggled in 2020. He joins a backfield with Miles Sanders, Boston Scott, Kerryon Johnson, and Jordan Howard.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Gainwell went from a borderline 1st round rookie pick before the draft to falling all the way to outside the 2nd round. It’s crowded in the Eagles backfield, but Gainwell’s pass catching chops could help him make an impact as a rookie and carve out a future role.

notes.text: Did you know Beasley's finished as the WR34 and WR26 over the last two seasons with Allen under center? Crazy, right? He's not someone who's going to win you a fantasy championship singlehandedly, but he's certainly someone who can provide WR3 value in a pinch and/or during bye weeks.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Cole Beasley
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Cole Beasley is undervalued in fantasy football every year, especially in PPR formats. The Beasles was the WR17 in PPR formats from Week 6 on last season, and he can always be drafted in the double digit rounds. If the Bills continue their pass happy ways and aside from some offseason drama, Beasley figures to be a fantastic value yet again in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Beasley is locked up in Buffalo for another two seasons. We know Diggs will dominate targets but with Josh Allen as his QB, Beasley is a sneaky trade target for contending rosters.

notes.text: If I'm being honest, I want nothing to do with the Texans this year. That's rare for me to say, as I'm a value-based fantasy manager, but I just don't see value on this team. Watson has stood by the fact that he doesn't want to play for the Texans and isn't participating in camp. On top of that, he might be facing a suspension by the NFL for his pending assault cases. We talk about how easy replacing a quarterback is in fantasy every year, so why would we risk a draft pick on Watson? Unless it's one of your final picks, I would just avoid the situation. Taylor has given us fantasy-viable performances in the past, but the last time that happened was in 2017, when he had much more mobility than he does today. Despite starting at least 14 games in three straight seasons with the Bills, Taylor never threw for more than 3,035 yards in a season. He's now 33 years old and playing for 65-year-old David Culley with one of the worst supporting casts in the league. He also has the Texans third-round pick Mills waiting in the wings. This is one of those situations where I'm okay being wrong if one of these quarterbacks pans out.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyrod Taylor
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Taylor somehow finds himself back in the fantasy conversation with the Deshaun Watson saga looming. He’s been relevant for fantasy in the past solely on the basis of his legs. He signed a one-year, $12 million deal but this has to be the worst arsenal of weapons in the league. Don’t be surprised if he becomes streamable but his ceiling is super low.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Likely resurrected off your waiver wire, he’s on his last legs in dynasty.

notes.text: Jordan fell all the way to the 5th round but he finds himself in a situation in Houston with a team desperate for playmakers. However, he’s a rookie TE… playing for the Texans. Even the best TE prospects in good situations usually take time to develop.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Brevin Jordan
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Jordan fell all the way to the 5th round but he finds himself in a situation in Houston with a team desperate for playmakers. However, he’s a rookie TE… playing for the Texans. Even the best TE prospects in good situations usually take time to develop.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s not much of a blocker but with his after-the-catch ability reminiscent of Jonnu Smith, he could make a difference at the TE position if things break right in a couple of years.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Jaelon Darden, Chris Godwin, Mike Evans, Tyler Johnson

notes.text: If there's one thing we can say about Godwin with Tom Brady under center, it's that he's a near lock for six-plus targets per game. He saw at least six targets in 10-of-12 games despite all the other talent on the roster, which is never a bad thing. The downside is that Godwin never really got into any sort of WR1 groove. He didn't hit the 100-yard mark until Week 17, when Mike Evans was essentially out of the lineup. To be fair, Godwin was playing through a few injuries last year, which may have hindered his upside, but we did watch Mike Evans' relationship with Brady grow as the year went on. On top of that, Antonio Brown and Rob Gronkowski returned to game shape, which will certainly cap everyone's upside. Godwin should be a solid WR2 on a weekly basis, but it's tough seeing him approach top-12 territory without an injury to one of Evans or Brown.

Godwin’s 2020 season was really disappointing from a fantasy perspective, primarily because he only played in 12 games last year, missing time with a concussion, a hamstring strain and a fractured index finger, which required surgery. Godwin returned to form late in the season and throughout the Bucs’ Super Bowl run, so he’s clearly recovered from all three of these injuries.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chris Godwin
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It was a down year for Chris Godwin in 2020, especially after finishing as the WR2 in 2019. Godwin dealt with a myriad of injuries, including a hamstring issue as well as a surgery on his index finger, keeping him out of the lineup for four games. After a WR32 finish in 2020, Godwin will look to be a more consistent producer in year two with TB12 under center, but it’s unlikely we see Godwin reach the ceiling he saw with Jameis Winston in 2019.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Still just 25 years old, Chris Godwin is only now getting ready to enter his prime years in the NFL. He’s playing on the franchise tag in 2021 and will likely secure a long-term deal with a new team next offseason, so his situation is a bit up in the air. Regardless, Godwin’s got the talent and should have the financial commitment from his team entering 2022 to be considered a rock solid WR2 with WR1 upside for multiple seasons.

notes.text: There may be no fantasy wide receiver who's continually undervalued more than Mike Evans. He's now turned in at least 1,000 yards in seven straight seasons with a handful of different quarterbacks, and has scored at least eight touchdowns in five of them. The reason he can't be considered in the elite tier is due to the number of mouths to feed in the Bucs offense. Think about it this way: Despite Chris Godwin being hurt for a while and Antonio Brown not joining the team until mid-season, Evans finished with just 109 targets. He's one of the better WR2's to have in fantasy, but he doesn't come with top-five upside unless there are injuries to those around him.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mike Evans
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Mike Evans’ consistency is just ridiculous. All the man has done since entering the NFL seven years ago is surpass 1,000 yards every year and threaten for 10+ TD every year. In his seven professional seasons, Evans has finished as a top-12 fantasy WR five times yet he's almost always drafted outside of that range. Look for Tom Brady to once again target Evans close to the end zone, making Evans one of the most likely WRs in the game to score double digit TDs in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The only concern with Evans in dynasty is that Tom Brady can’t play forever making his QB situation for the next few years a bit uncertain. Regardless, Evans’ consistency and production to this point in his career makes him a top-tier option moving forward.

notes.text: Brown was expected to be back with the Bucs all along. From the time he joined them in Week 9, Brown finished as the No. 38 wide receiver in fantasy. And to be fair, he got better as the year went on, as he had to get back into football shape. Over the final three games he saw 27 targets and turned them into 19 receptions for 266 yards and four touchdowns. Look, he's not going to surpass Mike Evans and Chris Godwin, but he'll be closer than some think.

Antonio Brown still has juice.  From weeks 9-17 last season, he was on a 17-game pace of 95/1056/8 for the Super Bowl champions.  Those numbers are impressive for just acclimating to the offense, and his draft cost is significantly lower than Mike Evans and Chris Godwin.  You can draft him late and play him weekly for a shot at success.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Antonio Brown
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: AB stayed on the straight & narrow path after signing with Tampa Bay midway through the season. While winning a Super Bowl was the highlight, AB quietly led the team in targets in his eight games and was on a 17-game pace of 130. He’s a fine FLEX option for Tom Brady with upside despite entering his age-33 season.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you’re a contender, Brown can still be a flex option for your squad. When all is said and done, someone is going to make a full length documentary on this guy… and we’re just talking about his dynasty value. From 6th round NFL draft pick to the 1.01 in dynasty to “will he ever play again?”... It’s been a wild ride.

notes.text: We can talk about all the good things that Hockenson did last year, but it wouldn't matter. His world has been flipped upside down in 2021, as he has a new coaching staff, and more importantly, a new quarterback. The team isn't going to be in scoring position nearly as much, but the good news for Hockenson is that he's now the clear-cut No. 1 target on the team after we watched Kenny Golladay and Marvin Jones leave in free agency. Jared Goff has limitations as a quarterback, but his skill-set should actually align with Hockenson's role quite well. It may not be exciting to start Hockenson week-to-week for upside purposes, but he should deliver a rock-solid floor that allows you to start him every week.

As Jason would say, Hockenson was ‘drafted to be great’. We all got a little taste of it last year as Hock finished as the TE4, but a pretty inconsistent TE4. The Lions are in a rebuild mode and it’s possible that Hockenson is the best pass catching option on the team. The team projects to be a higher passing volume team as they try to catch up. Hock could find himself knocking on the elite tier of TEs by the end of the season.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: T.J. Hockenson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Depending on which week it was, you either got Hockules or the Hockstrap or even T.J. Dropenson in 2020. Hockenson saw the 5th most targets and 3rd most receiving yards at the TE position but he was also credited with 11 drops, most among TEs. With 60 percent of the targets in Detroit gone through free agency, Hockenson might be peppered with 120+ targets this year which is rare to find. All three Ballers are bullish on his 2021 outlook as an every week startable TE.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hockenson was drafted in the top-10 just two years ago but his dynasty value increased this offseason by simply everyone else leaving town. He’ll turn 24 years old and will be a steady TE regardless of who his QB is the next few years.

notes.text: I'll be the first to admit it's possible we're all underestimating Jones this year. Sure, he's now 31 years old, but he's also coming off 1,757 yards and 18 touchdowns over the last two seasons, and that was while missing three full games. The Jaguars and their new coaching staff sought him out in free agency and paid him $7 million per year, so he's not likely going to be "just a mentor" to the young receivers. It is tough to see him being a consistent producer, however, as D.J. Chark, Laviska Shenault, and Travis Etienne are all going to be heavily targeted as well.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Marvin Jones Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Marvin Jones has out-performed his ADP three of the last four seasons, but there’s some uncertainty in Jacksonville this year. He goes from reliable gunslinger Matthew Stafford to unproven rookie Trevor Lawrence with a crowded WR room including D.J. Chark, Laviska Shenault and now possibly Travis Etienne. One thing working in Marv’s favor, however, is his connection with offensive coordinator, Darrell Bevell, who comes over from Detroit.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Now 31 and changing teams, Jones doesn’t hold much value in dynasty. If you’re rebuilding, look to move on from Marv after a splash week by trading him to a contender.

notes.text: The Jets liked Wilson enough to draft him over Trey Lance and Justin Fields, which tells you just how high they were on him. Judging by ADP on the entire Jets roster, many are still approaching the team as if they're run by Adam Gase. Insider info: They're not. Wilson is locked in as the starter all year long in Mike LaFleur's offense, and fantasy managers need to know about Wilson's upside as a rusher. Even Daniel Jones, who threw for 11 touchdowns in 14 games last year and missed two games, finished as a top-24 quarterback due to his 423 yards and one touchdown on the ground. Wilson is going to finish as a top-20 fantasy quarterback in year one.

The baby-faced BYU signal-caller made his mark on an “out-of-nowhere” junior season where he put up 41 combined touchdowns albeit against weak competition. Wilson won over scouts and Jets management with his “off-platform” throws and improvisation skills that many likened to Aaron Rodgers or dare we say Patrick Mahomes. While those are a bit grandiose, Wilson does have the mobility to make things happen on the ground and the Jets seem to be surrounding him with the type of weapons and offensive line protection that Sam Darnold never had. It looks like Wilson will start Day 1. For redraft, he’s not draftable yet until we see him on an NFL field.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Zach Wilson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The baby-faced BYU signal-caller made his mark on an “out-of-nowhere” junior season where he put up 41 combined touchdowns albeit against weak competition. Wilson won over scouts and Jets management with his “off-platform” throws and improvisation skills that many likened to Aaron Rodgers or dare we say Patrick Mahomes. While those are a bit grandiose, Wilson does have the mobility to make things happen on the ground and the Jets seem to be surrounding him with the type of weapons and offensive line protection that Sam Darnold never had. It looks like Wilson will start Day 1. For redraft, he’s not draftable yet until we see him on an NFL field.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s firmly the 4th QB off the board in terms of rookie picks behind Lawrence, Lance, and Fields. Wilson is intriguing in SuperFlex leagues with upside to be a top-10 QB in near future.

notes.text: Slye isn't an elite kicker. He's converted just 79.4% of his field-goal attempts and 90.1% of his extra-point attempts in his career. That's not often good enough to hold down a job for long, and especially when you're 1-for-6 from 50 yards or more, as Slye was last year. He'll likely begin the year as the Panthers' closer, but he could certainly lose the job if he can't straighten out his accuracy.

The trade for Randall Cobb all but ruined the potential value of Rodgers, who was facing an uphill battle as-is. I say that because Aaron Rodgers isn't someone who develops chemistry with his wide receivers immediately, and not just that, but the two haven't played together at all with Aaron missing all offseason programs. Amari has actually been raised around Cobb because his dad was Cobb's receivers coach at the University of Kentucky, so there should be good tutelage during Amari's rookie season, but it's tough to see him getting meaningful touches in the offense right away, and even if he does get on the field, he has to earn Aaron's trust. If you go back through Aaron's time with the Packers, you'll see that practically every receiver took time to turn into a fantasy option, including Davante Adams.

The Packers moved up seven spots in the 3rd round to select the former Clemson Tiger. He could crack the starting lineup in near future as the depth chart in Green Bay is pretty weak behind Davante Adams. He’s a well-built (5’10, 210) slot WR with similar measurements to an early career Randall Cobb. He’s a late round dart throw with a shot at being a contributor right away. UPDATE: now the Packers have traded for THE Randall Cobb, because Aaron Rodgers made them. It may take even longer for Amari Rodgers to get an opportunity to make an impact.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Amari Rodgers
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Packers moved up seven spots in the 3rd round to select the former Clemson Tiger. He could crack the starting lineup in near future as the depth chart in Green Bay is pretty weak behind Davante Adams. He’s a well-built (5’10, 210) slot WR with similar measurements to an early career Randall Cobb. He’s a late round dart throw with a shot at being a contributor right away. UPDATE: now the Packers have traded for THE Randall Cobb, because Aaron Rodgers made them. It may take even longer for Amari Rodgers to get an opportunity to make an impact.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: A former coach’s son, Rodgers has an NFL-ready body after playing four years at Clemson. With the Packers trading up to get him, don’t feel bad reaching a big in the second round of rookie drafts as we view Rodgers as a top-20 pick. However, his long-term value is a question mark and tied to Aaron Rodgers.

notes.text: I don't understand why many are talking about Collins as a "sleeper" in 2021. Do we really think this offense is going to produce two fantasy-relevant wide receivers? Somehow, Collins went from sleeper in the NFL Draft, to sleeper on a bad football team. You can like him in dynasty, that's fine, but in 2021, it's hard to see him reaching 80-plus targets if Brandin Cooks is healthy. Even outside of Cooks, the team decided to pay Andre Roberts $2.6 million, Conley $1.5 million, Chris Moore $1.3 million, and then traded for Anthony Miller. This just reeks of a situation to avoid in fantasy. Heck, even if Deshaun Watson were starting (which he's not), you'd have trouble projecting the target distribution for these receivers, though he would give Collins more of that "sleeper" appeal. I'm okay letting someone else take a shot on a non-Cooks receiver.

Collins is a big-bodied WR (6’4, 215 lbs) who comes into the league a bit older (22 years old) than you would like for a prospect. The Texans are lacking depth at the WR position and the team spent what little draft capital they had on him. He could turn into the outside starter opposite Brandin Cooks on a team destined to be a lost cause. He’s been having a good training camp and is worth a look at the end of the drafts to see what could happen.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Nico Collins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Collins is a big-bodied WR (6’4, 215 lbs) who comes into the league a bit older (22 years old) than you would like for a prospect. The Texans are lacking depth at the WR position and the team spent what little draft capital they had on him. He could turn into the outside starter opposite Brandin Cooks on a team destined to be a lost cause. He’s been having a good training camp and is worth a look at the end of the drafts to see what could happen.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: His landing spot in Houston at least gives him a chance to see some passing volume early on. He could be a potential red-zone threat and with a young QB likely to be throwing him the ball in 2022, he’s a fun stash even in a bad situation.

notes.text: I really liked Moss coming out of college, but being injury prone was a label he needed to shake. Unfortunately, he suffered an injury early in the season and was never able to wrestle the starting gig away from Devin Singletary. He did finish with at least 12 carries in three of the last four games, which leaves room for hope, but he also saw just three targets in those four games combined, which makes him extremely touchdown-dependent. When Josh Allen is the primary goal-line back, that presents an issue. Without an injury to Singletary, it's tough to see Moss being anything more than a touchdown-dependent RB3/4 option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Zack Moss
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Moss suffered a toe injury and missed Weeks 3-5. It was hard to trust him in fantasy given the fact Josh Allen functions as this team's goal-line back. Devin Singletary and Moss basically cannibalized each other's fantasy production on the year. Apart from pass protection (which doesn't equate to fantasy points), he has no discernable, difference-making skill to make him an asset.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Before the NFL draft, Moss could be seen as the 1A in the timeshare in Buffalo and trading him away now is advisable. He is destined to be a backup and likely scouring dynasty waiver wires a couple of years from now.

draftingDetails.handcuffs: Pooka Williams Jr., Joe Mixon, Trayveon Williams

notes.text: Over the final nine games of 2019, Zac Taylor gave Mixon 214 touches (23.8 per game), which made us believe they'd finally realized he should be used in a workhorse fashion. The start of 2020 wasn't as generous, but he did average 19.7 touches per game over the first three weeks. Then we saw Giovani Bernard get knocked out of the lineup for a few weeks, and it led to Mixon totaling 27.0 touches per game over the next three weeks before getting hurt.
