Now that Bernard is gone, are we finally going to get a full season's worth of 20-plus touch games for Mixon? If so, top-five is in the realm of possibilities, especially knowing he'll be more involved in the passing game. Don't sleep on Mixon; he's still a top-10 running back talent-wise.

No matter your past fantasy outlooks for Mixon, it’s hard to bet against his situation this year. With Giovani Bernard being waived, Samaje Perine is now the No. 2 RB for Cincinnati and Mixon’s biggest competition for snaps. The Bengals have the weapons to be a high-flying offense and Mixon has the opportunity to be a true 3-down running back.

Joe Mixon suffered a foot sprain in Week 6 that forced him to miss the rest of the season. Initial reports suggested Mixon could return within a few weeks, but these injuries tend to be unpredictable in season, and it’s not uncommon for an athlete to battle pain and swelling for several weeks as we saw with Mixon. Fortunately, his injury didn’t require surgery, suggesting the injury was stable. This bodes well for Mixon given that about 80% of players coming off a stable mid-foot sprain play more games in the following season.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Joe Mixon
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: When Mixon is on the field, he gets work. He averaged 24 opportunities per game but the bad news is, he played in only six games. Yikes. In fact, fantasy managers were left holding the bag waiting for his return which never materialized. With Giovani Bernard out the door, he should be able to continue seeing the type of touches that return RB1 status. It remains to be seen if the offensive line is improved but Andy and Jason would give you a wholehearted thumbs up on Mixon’s 2021 outlook.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Still only 24 years old, Mixon is set up to remain a top-10 dynasty RB if he can shake the injury bug. The offense has the pieces in place and he can handle a giant workload.

notes.text: We can talk about all the good things that Hockenson did last year, but it wouldn't matter. His world has been flipped upside down in 2021, as he has a new coaching staff, and more importantly, a new quarterback. The team isn't going to be in scoring position nearly as much, but the good news for Hockenson is that he's now the clear-cut No. 1 target on the team after we watched Kenny Golladay and Marvin Jones leave in free agency. Jared Goff has limitations as a quarterback, but his skill-set should actually align with Hockenson's role quite well. It may not be exciting to start Hockenson week-to-week for upside purposes, but he should deliver a rock-solid floor that allows you to start him every week.

As Jason would say, Hockenson was ‘drafted to be great’. We all got a little taste of it last year as Hock finished as the TE4, but a pretty inconsistent TE4. The Lions are in a rebuild mode and it’s possible that Hockenson is the best pass catching option on the team. The team projects to be a higher passing volume team as they try to catch up. Hock could find himself knocking on the elite tier of TEs by the end of the season.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: T.J. Hockenson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Depending on which week it was, you either got Hockules or the Hockstrap or even T.J. Dropenson in 2020. Hockenson saw the 5th most targets and 3rd most receiving yards at the TE position but he was also credited with 11 drops, most among TEs. With 60 percent of the targets in Detroit gone through free agency, Hockenson might be peppered with 120+ targets this year which is rare to find. All three Ballers are bullish on his 2021 outlook as an every week startable TE.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hockenson was drafted in the top-10 just two years ago but his dynasty value increased this offseason by simply everyone else leaving town. He’ll turn 24 years old and will be a steady TE regardless of who his QB is the next few years.

notes.text: Mills was labeled as “pro-ready” by many and has a strong enough arm and size (6’4, 217) to make it in this league. Tyrod Taylor is the starter and Mills has a chance to battle Ryan Finley (yes that guy) as the Texans backup. Geez, this team is bad.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Davis Mills
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Mills was labeled as “pro-ready” by many and has a strong enough arm and size (6’4, 217) to make it in this league. Tyrod Taylor is the starter and Mills has a chance to battle Ryan Finley (yes that guy) as the Texans backup. Geez, this team is bad.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you want to roll the dice on Mills in hopes he’s the future Texans QB, go for it. There’s a good chance this team ends up with the No. 1 pick in next year’s draft and selects a new franchise QB.

notes.text: It's pretty remarkable what a change of scenery can do to a player, and no one better represents that than Agholor, who was left for dead after his stint in Philadelphia. He bounced back in a big way with the Raiders, averaging 10.9 yards per target, which ranked fifth among wide receivers who saw 60-plus targets. Unfortunately, he'll have to prove it again with another franchise. If Cam Newton is under center, we saw what that does to wide receivers in 2020, but knowing it's possible that Mac Jones starts gives us hope for Agholor with the Patriots. But as of now, it seems Newton will get the gig to start the season, meaning Agholor may not pay dividends right out of the gate.

Often maligned as an Eagle, Nelson Agholor got the last laugh last season in Las Vegas. The Raiders got a great season from Agholor, who put up four top 10 performances over the final 11 weeks. He parlayed the breakout performance into a new contract in New England, a team desperate for WR help. Agholor's upside only exists if Mac Jones and the passing game evolve and the volume increases. He'll be significantly down in drafts, so could be worth the late round flyer as New England's de facto #1.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Nelson Agholor
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Raiders were mocked by fantasy managers when they signed Nelson Agholor, but it’s time to give credit where credit is due - Nelson Agholor put together a solid 2020 season, finishing as a top-30 WR. Now, he lands in New England where the offense projects to run a ton of 2TE sets and utilize the run game to control the clock. More likely than not, Agholor won’t repeat his 2020 season given the constraints of the offense. However, he could be worth the late round flyer as New England's de facto #1.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Agholor’s career was revitalized in Las Vegas last year, helping him land a 2-year deal with New England. However, with Cam Newton likely to play the majority of the 2021 season in a run heavy scheme and Mac Jones unproven as a rookie, it’s still possible Agholor’s 2020 season is the best of his NFL career. It may be worth it to trade Agholor after he set career highs in receiving yards and TD last year.

notes.text: We saw a glimpse of what Hurts can bring to the table last year, though it was just a four-game sample size. He started four games for the Eagles, and each of those games netted at least 16.3 fantasy points, highlighting a floor that's hard to find. He also flashed upside with a 37.8-point outburst in Week 15 against the Cardinals. The downside is that it was a small sample size, and Hurts appeared to get worse every time out. Even then, it's still a small sample size. There's a new coaching staff, along with a new No. 1 receiver, but if what we saw from Hurts in 2020 was his floor, we're in for a treat in 2021. If he can hone in and improve his accuracy numbers from 2020, there's legitimate top-six quarterback upside.

Hurts has a very fertile fantasy situation cultivating around him. He brings the needed toolset with his rushing ability. The team traded up to grab a true number one wide receiver DeVonta Smith. It wasn’t the prettiest nor largest of sample sizes in his few starts last year, but we at least saw proof of concept. It’s hard to know if the team really has complete faith in him or not, but at the very least they chose Jalen over Carson Wentz. If the ADP doesn’t get out of control, Hurts becomes very interesting this year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jalen Hurts
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: With Carson Wentz shipped out of town, Hurts looks like the main guy in Philadelphia. In four starts during Weeks 14-17, Hurts was a better fantasy star than real-life QB. He averaged 68 rushing yards per game, the most ever for a rookie QB with at least four starts. On the other hand, he had the lowest adjusted completion percentage in the league during that span. His upside is immense because of how electric he is on the ground. He’ll be a popular QB who fits the mold of a Year 2 breakout in the league but he’s not really a secret as his hype is driving him up the draft boards this summer.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hurts was the steal of rookie drafts last year if you were able to win that lottery. However, we do not know Philadelphia’s long-term outlook or confidence in Hurts. For 2021, he’s a top-10 guy if he starts the whole season. If he falters, you might be left holding the bag.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jimmy Graham
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Despite finishing as the TE11 last year, it’s still a mystery how Jimmy Graham-pa and his body are still somehow allowed in the NFL. Out of everything we survived in 2020, did you have Jimmy Graham catching as many TDs (8) as Michael Thomas, Julio Jones, Odell Beckham Jr. and Kenny Golladay combined on your Bingo Card? With Cole Kmet asserting himself as the lead TE by the end of the year, the “less visually appealing Jimmy G” is now relegated to annoying red zone work. You won’t be able to start him for fantasy in 2021, which will likely be his final year in the league at age 78… sorry I meant 35.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He has one year left on his deal in Chicago and then it might be time for him to hang up his cleats.

notes.text: Despite T.Y. Hilton aging and Parris Campbell missing the entire season, Pittman couldn't break out in his rookie season. While that might be high expectations, the opportunity was there. Philip Rivers turned out to be better than most expected, though Pittman finished with more than 66 yards just once all year, and topped 46 yards just three times. He scored just once, which surely didn't help his year-end totals, but with Campbell back in the mix, he isn't a surefire pick to gain a whole lot of targets. Hilton was re-signed, Zach Pascal out-produced him, and Carson Wentz has traditionally favored his targets over the middle of the field. Pittman should lead this team in touchdowns with his large frame, but he's likely to be a bit too touchdown-dependent to trust as anything more than a boom-or-bust WR4.

Michael Pittman dealt with compression syndrome in his leg following a Week 3 injury last year. What happens here is direct contusion or trauma to the lower leg can cause swelling, which leads to pressure on the nerves and arteries in the leg. If left untreated, this can have long term effects, but it was managed appropriately, and Pittman was able to return to the field in Week 8. This injury won’t affect Pittman moving forward.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Michael Pittman Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Pittman displayed some solid YAC moments and went 5/90 on 10 targets in the Colts playoff game. He has the draft pedigree and size to become a No. 1 wideout. The Colts are starving for playmakers and while everyone expected them to add in either free-agency or the draft, perhaps their WR1 was sitting on their roster the entire time. Carson Wentz's injury pumped the breaks on calling for a full-on Pittman breakout after an off-season of love coming from Mike.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: For WRs that didn’t quite meet the high expectations in Year One, it’s easy to discount them and move onto the next batch of shiny new toys in Dynasty. Pittman was a 2nd Round pick in the 2020 NFL Draft, and a player worth trading for in hopes that he breaks out with Carson Wentz.

notes.text: Despite playing as the No. 4 wide receiver behind Stefon Diggs, John Brown, and Cole Beasley last year, Davis managed to make his presence felt, racking up 599 yards and seven touchdowns on just 62 targets. The Bills lost Brown this offseason but gained Emmanuel Sanders. They're not the same player, as Sanders isn't someone who'll stretch the field the way Brown or Davis did/can. If you're looking for a boom-or-bust player in the late rounds who just might pay off, Davis makes sense.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Gabriel Davis
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: As a rookie and the Bills’ WR4, it’s wild to see Davis was focused on as a dominator when Josh Allen and company got in close. He accumulated 12 “end-zone” targets. That’s one more than Davante Adams had and by far more than any other rookie WR. He finished at WR56 mostly on the back of his seven TDs. With John Brown gone, Davis could grow into a bigger role and is a fine late round pick as a depth piece attached to a good offense.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Davis’ dynasty stock rose this offseason once John Brown left. He could develop into a solid No. 2 wideout opposite of Stefon Diggs with the ability to win in the paint. He likely is too expensive now to trade for as Davis managers are licking their chops for finding a late round WR.

notes.text: Sure, Lockett finished as the No. 9 fantasy wide receiver last year, but ask anyone who rostered him if he was a WR1. Heck, as them if he was a reliable WR2. The answer would be no, as he finished with WR2 or better numbers just 37.5 percent of the time which was behind players like Diontae Johnson, Curtis Samuel, John Brown, and Jamison Crowder. How's that possible? Because 48.7 percent of his production last year came from just three games. He's going to have massive games, but relying on him as anything more than a volatile WR3 is going to lead to disappointment.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyler Lockett
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Hot Lockett just got a big contract extension, keeping him with Seattle through 2025. Even with the breakout of DK Metcalf, Lockett had the most targets of his career (132), and his best cumulative fantasy season in 2020 despite the inconsistency. He'll likely settle in the WR18-24 range in 2021, though the inconsistency may be frustrating and even unbearable for some fantasy managers. The Seahawks could try to get back to running the ball more, which could mean less targets for both wideouts.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: As long as Tyler Lockett is tied to Russell Wilson, he’ll continue to provide fantasy value. That’s good news for Lockett, who’s signed in Seattle through 2025. However, DK Metcalf has emerged as the alpha on this team and that isn’t going to change.

notes.text: It's a shame the Jets re-worked Crowder's contract to keep him with the team because I'm not really sure where he fits in. The Jets are head over heels in love with Elijah Moore, who projects as someone who'll play quite a few slot snaps. They also went out and snagged Corey Davis in free agency, so he'll be their top receiver. You mustn't forget that Adam Gase is no longer the head coach, and Sam Darnold is no longer the quarterback. Removing those two is bad for Crowder's production, as both loved the slot very much. The Jets suddenly have a crowded depth chart at wide receiver, meaning Crowder might not even play a full-time role.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jamison Crowder
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Always underrated for fantasy, Jamison Crowder was a great value in the 11th-13th rounds of fantasy drafts last year. But, he’s one player who could actually be worse without Adam Gase, who’s always targeted his slot WR. There was concern with new regime in place and Elijah Moore on the roster, the Jets could actually cut Crowder before the start of the season. However, his contract has been renegotiated and he'll remain with the Jets in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: We don’t know if Crowder will get the volume in New York with a new scheme. Look for Crowder to be playing football in a new uniform next season as he’s an unrestricted free agent after 2021. At 28 years old, he could still have an impact on the right team and useable in certain weeks for fantasy.

notes.text: He's now been on four different teams in the last four years, though he's still remaining relevant in the fantasy conversation. He's also going to play with one of the best young quarterbacks in football, though he's clearly behind Stefon Diggs in the pecking order. The move to sign Sanders was odd considering how well Gabriel Davis played last year, but the Bills do run the second-most 4WR sets in football, so they'll be on the field together at times. But still, Sanders is now 34 years old and is likely in Buffalo to provide a reliable receiver in a pinch rather than one who'll pop back into the WR3 conversation. He is what he is at this point, which is a low-upside bye week filler.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Emmanuel Sanders
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Set to play on his fourth team over the last three seasons at 34 years old, Emmanuel Sanders goes from New Orleans and Drew Brees to Buffalo and Josh Allen. With John Brown vacating the WR2/3 role, Sanders should be in line for an every down role, but does he still have enough left in the tank for it to matter for fantasy? We know Stefon Diggs will dominate targets, Beasley will get his and Josh Allen will steal TDs at the goal line. Expect Sanders to help the Bills more than your fantasy team.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s 34 and playing on a one year deal. Who’s to say he doesn’t hang up the cleats if Buffalo wins it all?

notes.text: Is it possible Perriman is the Lions best wide receiver in fantasy this year? While that may not mean much, it's something. The issue I have believing that is due to his strengths not aligning with Jared Goff's strengths. It's no secret that Goff has struggled to consistently throw the ball down the field, and it's part of the reason the Rams moved on from him. Perriman will be playing in another new offense with another new quarterback, something he knows all too well at this point. There will likely be a few splash weeks, but you should be happy to let someone else draft him.

Perriman plays wide receiver in the National Football League. This was enough for him to step into the gaping Kenny Golladay void in Detroit and be a potential sleeper value for fantasy leagues. Marvin Jones is also gone, and Perriman may be the de facto number one on this team. Being peppered by King Goffrey may provide some week to week value for a player that will likely be undrafted or drafted very late.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Breshad Perriman
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Perriman’s best fantasy finish since entering the league in 2015: WR48. At this point, we know who Perriman is - a guy who flashes some upside when given opportunity but he’s been a journeyman throughout his career who’s dealt with injury. But hey, someone has to catch the ball in Detroit, right?
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Perriman is an afterthought at this point in his career, as most dynasty managers are probably over the idea of Perriman after years of disappointment as a former 1st Round NFL Draft pick. Be sure to check if he’s on your waiver wire, though, as he could provide some depth for bye weeks and injuries.

notes.text: While scouting Moore this offseason, I came away saying, "that guy is a natural football player." The game seemed to come easy to him, which is the same thing I said about Tee Higgins. They're different players, but some are just born to play this game. So, to hear about Moore tearing up the offseason workouts, it didn't surprise me. What did surprise me was them re-working Jamison Crowder's contract to keep him with the team. His presence is going to be an issue for Moore's ceiling in his rookie year. The hope for Moore is that they'll use him in a Curtis Samuel-type role where they manufacture touches for him to give fantasy managers weekly usability. He's certainly someone to keep an eye on.

Elijah Moore somehow slipped to the 2nd round to the Jets and finds his way in a situation ripe with opportunity. His 40-yard time (4.33) was the main headline but his broad jump (121 in) and short-area burst was also on display at his pro day. He profiles as a slot WR (5'9, 184 lbs) but also didn't shy away from contested-catch situations at Ole Miss. His route running has been praised to the point where it shouldn't be shocking if he leads the team in receptions in Year One. The big question mark is rookie QB Zach Wilson.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Elijah Moore
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Elijah Moore somehow slipped to the 2nd round to the Jets and finds his way in a situation ripe with opportunity. His 40-yard time (4.33) was the main headline but his broad jump (121 in) and short-area burst was also on display at his pro day. He profiles as a slot WR (5'9, 184 lbs) but also didn't shy away from contested-catch situations at Ole Miss. His route running has been praised to the point where it shouldn't be shocking if he leads the team in receptions in Year One. The big question mark is rookie QB Zach Wilson.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Largely selected in the early 2nd round of dynasty rookie drafts, look for Moore to hold his value for at least one season regardless of his on-field performance. Moore fits exactly what the new Jets’ staff wants from their receivers - run after the catch ability.

notes.text: Brown was a vertical threat at UNC going over 1,000 receiving yards along with 20 receiving TDs the last two years. With Terry McLaurin and Curtis Samuel locked in as the team’s top two WRs, he’ll be fighting for playing time alongside Adam Humphries, Cam Sims, and Antonio Gandy-Golden. Luckily, Ryan Fitzpatrick knows how to pepper his WRs with targets. Brown isn’t on the redraft radar for 2021.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dyami Brown
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Brown was a vertical threat at UNC going over 1,000 receiving yards along with 20 receiving TDs the last two years. With Terry McLaurin and Curtis Samuel locked in as the team’s top two WRs, he’ll be fighting for playing time alongside Adam Humphries, Cam Sims, and Antonio Gandy-Golden. Luckily, Ryan Fitzpatrick knows how to pepper his WRs with targets. Brown isn’t on the redraft radar for 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Brown should be drafted in the late 2nd round of rookie drafts but his ceiling looks capped on a team with two other dynamic playmakers at wide receivers.

notes.text: Fitzpatrick broke out in his first season with Louisville, putting up 700/9. Then the numbers basically stagnated. He ended up playing all four years in school, which doesn’t generally translate to fantasy success. However, he was drafted in the early 4th Round by the Titans, whose 2nd best WR is Josh Reynolds. For redraft, he likely has little 2021 value.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dez Fitzpatrick
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Fitzpatrick broke out in his first season with Louisville, putting up 700/9. Then the numbers basically stagnated. He ended up playing all four years in school, which doesn’t generally translate to fantasy success. However, he was drafted in the early 4th Round by the Titans, whose 2nd best WR is Josh Reynolds. For redraft, he likely has little 2021 value.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s worth a flier in the later rookie picks based on opportunity, but is still a dart throw given the success rate of WRs drafted in the 4th round or later.

notes.text: Dobbins is extremely talented, there's no doubting that. However, if you think he's a breakout candidate to finish as a top-five running back, you're betting against the odds. Among the running backs who finished top-10 last year, just two of them finished there while seeing fewer than 39 targets. Those two running backs were Derrick Henry and Nick Chubb, who averaged 5.4 and 5.6 yards per carry, numbers no one can actually project to hit. They also scored 17 and 12 touchdowns on the ground, propping their numbers up. Dobbins saw just 24 targets last year, a number that's unlikely to move much considering he's in the same offense with the same quarterback, only with more weapons around him. If Dobbins can rush for over 5.0 yards per carry (he did last year) and score double-digit rushing touchdowns (again, hard to project), he's going to finish as a top-10 running back, but not top-five due to the lack of work in the passing game. He's best-suited as your RB2 who has RB1 in his range of outcomes.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: J.K. Dobbins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Dobbins was a fantasy force in the second half last year if you had the patience to wade through Mark Ingram szn. From Weeks 11 to 17, Dobbins was the RB8 averaging 16.7 fantasy points per game. His nine TDs are the most ever by a rookie RB with fewer than 140 carries. That is a ridiculously high TD rate and causes you to question: did he show double-digit TD ability or is there regression coming? From the eye test, the dude looks like belongs on the field finishing top-10 in PFF’s Elusive Rating. However, the backfield split may continue to be a thorn in the side of those rostering Dobbins.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Nine percent of Dobbins’ rush attempts were 15+ Yards, the highest in the NFL. The TD rate might come down but the explosive runs were always part of his profile coming into the league. Think of Dobbins like rookie Nick Chubb, a ridiculously efficient runner on a team committed to running the ball. That could be a top-10 dynasty RB for the next couple of years.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kendrick Bourne
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Patriots added WRs Nelson Agholor and Kendrick Bourne early in the free agency process. It may be another difficult year for all New England receivers.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Outside of a few weeks, Bourne hasn't been startable for fantasy in his first four seasons. However, Bourne was paid nicely on a 3-year deal and there is opportunity at WR in New England. Perhaps Mac Jones can eventually provide a much needed boost to the Patriots passing game.

notes.text: Naturally, we should've expected some rust on Gronkowski after taking a year off football. He was a bit slot out of the gate, but was ultimately able to finish as the No. 8 tight end in 2020. That's not a huge accomplishment or anything, as he still failed to record more than 48 yards in 11-of-16 games, and that's despite Chris Godwin missing time to injury, and Antonio Brown not joining the team until midseason. We also can't forget about O.J. Howard, who had more production and targets than Gronkowski when he tore his Achilles. Gronkowski will certainly offer some streamable weeks, but relying on him as your every-week tight end would be a mistake with all the mouths they have to feed in Tampa Bay.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Rob Gronkowski
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Gronk Smash! It took a minute as Gronk had 20 total fantasy points through the first five weeks of the season. Yet, he got back in playing shape and was the TE4 from Week 6 on. He was used in classic Bruce Arians fashion downfield with the most TE targets, receptions and yards on 20+ yard attempts. With Tom Brady being projected as a high-end QB1, Andy is in on Gronk being more than just a streamable player in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you held onto the slim hopes of Gronk remaining on the end of your dynasty roster, you were rewarded in 2020. As long as he’s connected with Brady, he has life.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Van Jefferson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After using a 2nd round pick on Van Jefferson in 2020, the Rams selected WR Tutu Atwell in the 2nd Round of this year’s draft. Of course Robert Woods and Cooper Kupp will dominate the targets, but the Rams also signed speedy veteran wideout DeSean Jackson. Jefferson will really have to step up to have any sort of fantasy impact.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Rams unexpectedly drafted a WR in Round 2 of this year’s draft (Tutu Atwell), although he may be used as more of a gadget player. Even though Josh Reynolds is gone, it’s still crowded in LA, and Jefferson will have to prove he belongs on dynasty rosters.

notes.text: His NFL career has gotten off to a rough start so far. First, it was contract issues. Next, it was an injury that kept him sidelined through rookie mini-camp. Lastly, it was being placed on the COVID reserve list. With all the setbacks, my guess is that the Giants open the season with Kenny Golladay, Sterling Shepard, and Darius Slayton in 3WR sets while Toney has to earn a place in the offense. There's no guarantee that happens early in the season, making Toney a very shaky pick in redraft formats.

The Giants surprised everyone by trading back in the NFL Draft then selecting a WR, despite signing Kenny Golladay in free agency and already having a pretty loaded pass catching group. Toney’s skillset is raw, and he’ll need time to develop as an NFL WR, suggesting he may help the Giants more than your fantasy team in 2021.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kadarius Toney
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Giants surprised everyone by trading back in the NFL Draft then selecting a WR, despite signing Kenny Golladay in free agency and already having a pretty loaded pass catching group. Toney’s skillset is raw, and he’ll need time to develop as an NFL WR, suggesting he may help the Giants more than your fantasy team in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Toney’s profile has many holes - a late breakout age, minimal production at Florida and he’s a bit undersized. However, Toney’s athleticism and skillset is intriguing, assuming Jason Garrett can be creative enough to get him the ball in space. We know he’ll be competing with Kenny G for targets for the next four years. Daniel Jones’ NFL future is still a big question mark going forward.

notes.text: I think most people would admit that Johnson looked much better than expected in 2020, totaling over 1,000 total yards and eight touchdowns in just 12 games. That's the good news. The bad news is that the Texans are a team that legitimately might lose every game in 2021, as they've been stripped down and look like a roster of replacements. They've also added Mark Ingram, Phillip Lindsay, and Rex Burkhead to the backfield, which presents all sorts of issues. If Deshaun Watson were going to play, we'd dig into this backfield a little deeper, but with Watson out of the picture for the foreseeable future, this is not a backfield you want to be associated with.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: David Johnson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: While we used to sing the choruses of DJ here at the Fantasy Footballers, it’s likely he’ll now be known forever as the player traded for DeAndre Hopkins. On arguably the worst team in the league, Johnson could still see 18+ touches a game which is rare to find in the 6th/7th rounds of drafts. Drafting him as your RB3 seems like a safe bet with the upside knowing he’s still one of the best pass catchers in the NFL.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Remember 2016? Good times. You might get one more year out of DJ as a top-30 RB.

notes.text: My guess is that analysts are worried about the Falcons adding a free agent running back because even my RB24 ranking feels a bit low for a back who should have no issue getting 15-plus touches per game. That would amount to 240-plus touches on the season. There have been 144 running backs who've hit that mark over the last 10 years and none have finished worse than RB28 (his current ECR). In fact, just 10 of those running backs (6.9 percent) have finished worse than RB20. If the Falcons don't add anyone of significance, I'll be moving him up even more.

The thighs might drive up his ADP even further but we still consider Davis a value heading into the summer. While he did not maintain high level production the entire time in relief of CMC last year, Davis was the RB6 from Week 3-14! He looks like the lead back in Atlanta and if new HC Arthur Smith’s zone running scheme takes off like it did in Tennessee, Davis could be in store for a solid season. His pass-catching ability also gives you some hope even if Atlanta remains inefficient on the ground.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mike Davis
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: CMC’s replacement held his own for a couple of weeks before hitting the wall. He signed with the Falcons, and looks to be the starter as of now, as the team failed to address the position in the draft. Consider Davis a volume-based RB2/3 that could have sneaky upside if the Falcons offense takes off under new HC Arthur Smith.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you held onto Davis, it looks like his improbable window of opportunity has opened again. Trading him now to a manager desperate for RB help might be wise because this joy ride could be over sooner than later.

notes.text: Some are expecting Bernard to come in and play a big role on passing downs for the Bucs, though it's tough to see where that's coming from after the team re-signed Leonard Fournette. While Ronald Jones was the best early-down back for that team last year, Fournette was the primary passing-down back. Sure, Bernard is better in that role, but then why re-sign Fournette? Whatever the case, Bernard is going to be nothing more than a third-down back who might help during bye weeks in PPR formats.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Giovani Bernard
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Gio is still kicking after all these years and now he’s hitched to Tom Brady in Tampa Bay. It’s a crowded backfield so unless there are injuries, it’s hard envisioning Bernard seeing more than six or seven touches a game.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Tom Brady breathes some life into Gio’s dynasty outlook. The pass-catching RB alongside TB12 has always had a place in fantasy.

notes.text: His weight (155 lbs) is frightening to imagine someone running around on an NFL football field. Terrifying, actually. Sean McVay did spend the team’s first draft pick (2nd round, 57th overall) on Atwell and compared him to DeSean Jackson, who already is on this team. He consistently weighs in at one tutu if your league rewards points for that kinda thing.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tutu Atwell
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: His weight (155 lbs) is frightening to imagine someone running around on an NFL football field. Terrifying, actually. Sean McVay did spend the team’s first draft pick (2nd round, 57th overall) on Atwell and compared him to DeSean Jackson, who already is on this team. He consistently weighs in at one tutu if your league rewards points for that kinda thing.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Woods and Kupp clearly lead the way at WR. They also drafted Van Jefferson in the 2nd Round of the 2020 NFL Draft, and signed DeSean Jackson this offseason. While his production and speed is elite, he likely ends up as a gadget player.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Will Dissly
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Big Montana shook off the injury label, bear-wrestled it to the ground, and ended up having the worst fantasy season of his career despite playing all 16 games. He never scored double-digit fantasy points in any game and now that Gerald Everett is in town, his value went poof.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: It was a fun trip to Disslyland while it lasted. We’ll always remember you Big Montana with that tattoo we all got marked across our chests.

notes.text: The start to Sanders' career hasnt been what we'd hoped for, delivering RB2 or better numbers in just 14-of-28 of games (50 percent). To be fair, he hasn't been used in a workhorse role, totaling more than 15 touches just 11 times over that span. Will the departure of Doug Pederson allow him to shine, or will Nick Sirianni implement a timeshare as well? The depth chart now consists of Sanders, Kerryon Johnson, and Kenneth Gainwell, so this could very well be a Colts-like backfield, which would make sense given that's where Sirianni comes from. Sanders should be treated as a timeshare RB2 who's more talented than most in that conversation.

Miles Sanders is an incredibly talented running back.  So why did he make this list?  The team resigned Jordan Howard, drafted Kenny Gainwell, and signed Kerryon Johnson.  Boston Scott is currently still on the roster.  The message to Miles Sanders?  The team wants more.  More from the position and likely more of a timeshare.  The world we hoped was ahead of Sanders simply may not be there, so lower your expectations a bit.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Miles Sanders
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Sanders was frustrating last year with a couple of huge runs against tough defenses and absolutely vanishing some weeks. He's always had the 3-down skillset but the ship has likely sailed of having RB1 upside. His offensive line is aged in Philadelphia and we have no idea how the offense will hold up for fantasy purposes with a whole season with Jalen Hurts at the helm.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you can trade him for a consistent WR or a 1st round rookie pick, it might be time to get ahead of the curve. Sanders’ value is like a balloon slowly letting out air.

notes.text: Aiyuk is a tough one to crack, as he exploded onto the fantasy scene last year, finishing with 583 yards and four touchdowns over his final seven games, but there were factors that helped him achieve those numbers. The major ones being the injuries to George Kittle and Deebo Samuel. There were just four games where the trio were on the field together, and during that time, Aiyuk saw just 21 targets (the lowest of the three) and had 13/189/1 combined in those games. To be fair, it was from Week 4-7, so it was very early in Aiyuk's rookie season, so it's possible he just hadn't earned the trust yet. There's a wide range of outcomes in his projections, going as high as a top-15 wide receiver, but also as low as a wide receiver in the WR30-36 range. You want equity when drafting, so taking Aiyuk as anything more than a WR3 when Kittle and Samuel are healthy is risky.

The last time we saw Brandon Aiyuk on the field in Week 16, he caught one ball for 15 yards while battling through a high ankle sprain that forced him to sit in Week 17. At this point, his injury is fully healed and shouldn’t affect him moving forward.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Brandon Aiyuk
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Aiyuuuuuuuken! It was a stellar rookie season for Aiyuk, who had a 16-game pace of 1,515 receiving yards and 10.7 TDs from Weeks 7-15. However, a lot of that production came with George Kittle out and Deebo Samuel in and out of the lineup. Will Aiyuk still see the target share he saw last season? What will a Trey Lance offense mean for the wideouts? He could easily turn into an alpha in 2021 and we like his value in the early 6th round.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: After Aiyuk put up 100+ yards and/or a TD in 9 of 12 games played last year, there’s reason to be excited about the 2nd year WR in dynasty leagues. His skillset fits exactly what Kyle Shanahan looks for in a WR, but one thing to consider here is that Trey Lance could take some production from the pass catchers if he’s as good of a runner as he was in college.

notes.text: Once we heard about Cam Akers' injury, we were wondering who the Rams would sign/go after, but they've said they're staying put for now and that they're happy with last year's undrafted free agent Xavier Jones behind Darrell Henderson. We still have plenty of time for them to sign another running back, but for the time being, Jones should be viewed as the primary handcuff to Henderson.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Xavier Jones
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The former UDFA out of SMU has a chance to step into a backup role with the recent news of Cam Akers’ Achilles injury. The 5-11, 215 Jones made some noise last off-season but only saw the field as a special teamer in 2020. He’ll compete for touches with 7th rounder Jake Funk behind Darrell Henderson Jr. and makes for an interesting stash in deeper leagues.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Jones goes from unrostered to one of the most added players in dynasty following the Akers injury. He’s still an UDFA so who knows what you’ll get at the end of your bench.

notes.text: Eskridge is a 5’9 speedster with special teams chops. Seattle had a grand total of three picks and they decided to spend their first one at pick 56 on Eskridge. He profiles as a speedy slot guy who should make his way on the field on 3WR sets this year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: D'Wayne Eskridge
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Eskridge is a 5’9 speedster with special teams chops. Seattle had a grand total of three picks and they decided to spend their first one at pick 56 on Eskridge. He profiles as a speedy slot guy who should make his way on the field on 3WR sets this year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: His speed and return ability makes Eskridge any intriguing dynasty prospect albeit on a team where he’s clearly 3rd in the pecking order.

notes.text: To this point in his career, do you know who Singletary's fantasy comparison is? Duke Johnson. Yeah, we all know how that story ended. Singletary has produced RB2 or better numbers just 35.7 percent of the time, which is extremely poor for a running back who's averaged 14.2 opportunities per game. The Bills don't run the ball a whole lot, and it's extremeley likely that Zack Moss is the better early-down back who will get more goal-line carries. Singletary is a very low upside pick late in drafts who's best served as a bye week flex-type player.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Devin Singletary
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Singletary is a between the 20s runner who does have some wiggle to his game. But for fantasy, he’s like buying a steak to-go from Applebees. It’s a bad idea and will ruin your appetite everytime you make the decision to go for it. Singletary is stuck in a timeshare with Zack Moss and the Bills’ goal-line is none other than QB Josh Allen. You're better off shooting your shot with another RB with higher upside than trying to ride with “Mr. Singlecarry”.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Heading into Year 3, Singletary just turned 23 so he still has a ton of tread left on his tires. Honestly, his dynasty outlook would look so much better if he was on another team.

notes.text: To think that Brady would join a new team at 43 years old, have zero offseason, then proceed to throw for 4,633 yards and 40 touchdowns is mindblowing. He's going to be 44 years old when the season starts, which brings us back to the conversation, "When does he fall off?" I'm done trying to predict that, but it must be factored into his price in fantasy drafts. Was last year a best-case scenario? He finished as the QB8 even with those numbers, as mobility is almost neccesary to finish higher in today's game. Because of that, Brady shouldn't be drafted as anything more than a low-end QB1 with a limited ceiling.

The dude threw 40 TD passes. He won a Super Bowl. For fantasy, Brady was the QB8 with only two bust games the entire year. He’s one of our favorite values this year at QB because Tampa Bay returns all of their starters and the downfield passing that Bruce Arians preaches is going to continue to be a thing. With a healthy Chris Godwin mixing in with Mike Evans, Brady could go for 45+ TDs this year in a 17-game season. We can argue every year that the wheels might fall off but he’s done nothing but prove he’s superhuman.

Reports in mid-July surfaced that Brady played with a torn MCL in his knee in 2020 that required surgery in February to repair the torn ligament. Fortunately, this recovery timeline won’t affect his Week 1 availability. There’s optimism Brady could play even better in 2021 following this surgery given that he likely played through pain last year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tom Brady
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It’s almost unfair at this point that the Plant Man continues to steamroll to another Super Bowl. It took him a second to adjust but Bruce Arians’ relentless desire to push the ball downfield paid off: Brady led the league in Air Yards and 20+ yard completions. His 6.6 percent TD rate was his highest in more than a decade as he was equipped with better weapons than much of his time in New England. He’ll look to run it back in the NFC South where the Buccaneers might assert themselves as alpha if New Orleans takes a step back. As a fantasy QB, Brady belongs in the conversation as a top-5 fantasy QB although his stats suggested he feasted on bottom-tier defenses in 2020.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Brady claims he could play until he’s 50! While imagining him not playing in the NFL is difficult, he’s still producing for fantasy. In startup drafts, he’s criminally undervalued despite his age. Don’t be afraid to trade for the Plant Man in dynasty.

notes.text: Brown's a role player, plain and simple. The Dolphins are going to give him touches; you don't sign a player for nearly $2 million to have him fourth on the running back depth chart. With that being said, he's not a sleeper candidate or anything, but rather someone who takes away some of the upside of players like Myles Gaskin.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Malcolm Brown
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After spending six years with the Rams, Brown quietly signed with the Dolphins off-season and it feels like no one remembered. He’s a capable running back and had some moments as a goal-line back in LA. Don’t discount Brown when you think about Myles Gaskin and how that Miami backfield could shake out.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Brown works as an “end-of-your-bench” flier in hopes he has a bigger role in Miami. But beyond 2021, who knows what the future holds for him at 28 years old.

notes.text: Burkhead is a talented player, particularly in the receiving game, but he's struggled to stay healthy throughout his career. He now finds himself in about as bad a situation as he could, playing for a poor Texans team with a crowded running back room, which includes David Johnson, Mark Ingram, and Phillip Lindsay. If one or more of those backs get cut, then Burkhead could have some value by default, but until or unless that happens, he can be ignored in fantasy circles.

Why is Wilson continually hated by the fantasy community? His late-season struggles last year have many avoiding him in 2021, though you shouldn't be one of those people. Over the course of his career (now 144 games), he's posted top-12 type numbers in 50.7 percent of his games, which ranks sixth among quarterbacks who've started 50-plus games since 2000. That's a better career mark than Drew Brees, who was continually drafted as a top-three quarterback during his prime. Wilson has never finished worse than QB11 and has finished as a top-three quarterback in four of the last seven seasons. He's as stable as they come.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Russell Wilson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: For the second year in a row, it was a tale of two seasons as Week 10 was a cliff for Wilson fantasy managers. He was the QB2 in points per game from Weeks 1-9 but QB16 from Week 10 on. One of the keys to Wilson’s early success was play-action. He had the highest completion percentage (74.3) on those plays in the league. But teams figured out DK Metcalf and Tyler Lockett’s deep ball game and after being ousted in the playoffs, there has been some off-season chatter about Wilson wanting to move on from Seattle. He’s a QB1 no matter what but how your fantasy team traverses the ups-and-downs of Mr. Unlimited is a bit frustrating.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: It’s hard to imagine Wilson not in Seattle. He’s a hold for now and still provides rock solid fantasy production although we might not see him fully set free for fantasy as a Seahawk.

notes.text: Throughout Carson's career, he's produced RB2 or better numbers in 60 percent of his games. That's just a smidge behind Marshawn Lynch's number of 61.7 percent, which goes to show just how undervalued Carson has been to this point. Injuries have been a question, which should lower his ADP a bit, but when on the field, Carson is a borderline RB1 who the Seahawks signed to a fresh new deal this offseason.

Carson has dealt with injury in nearly every professional season of his career, but his injury history doesn’t seem to have any correlation. Rather, he seems to be the product of the fact that RBs sustain injuries at a higher rate than any other position in the NFL. Carson missed 4 weeks last year with a foot sprain but returned to full strength later in the year. Based on his track record, it may be unrealistic to expect Carson to play all 17 games, but he’s healthy entering the offseason program and training camp.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chris Carson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Over the last three years, Carson has averaged 19 opportunities per game and Seattle believed in him enough to extend him at least for the next two years. He's an RB2 with a floor that's hard to find in this age of committee backfields.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Carson’s two year deal gives managers some breathing room. There is no-one else that should eat into his workload and you probably are better off keeping him than trading him at this point.

notes.text: In case you may have missed it, Dirk Koetter is no longer calling plays for the Falcons. The Falcons ran 3WR sets 61 percent of the time last year, which allowed Gage to get on the field more often. Arthur Smith's offense in Tennessee last year ran 3WR sets just 38 percent of the time, the second-lowest mark in football. That obviously presents a problem for Gage, as does the arrival of Kyle Pitts, who'll be utilized as a receiver at times. Some may wonder if the loss of Julio Jones opens things up for him. Yes, it will likely net him more targets, but targets on the perimeter haven't been the same for Gage, as he works best from the slot. The Falcons could very well start Tajae Sharpe over him in 2WR sets.

Russell Gage isn't flashy.  He certainly isn't Julio Jones.  What Russell Gage manages to be, however, is productive.  From the bye week on last season, he was on pace for a 140 target season, with 90 receptions and 7 touchdowns.  Now that Julio has flown the coop, Gage represents potential sleeper value on a team that loves to (and will have to) throw the football.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Russell Gage
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Russell Gage finished the 2020 season as the WR37, but it didn’t feel like it as he went radio silent from Weeks 3-9. He caught fire towards the end of the season, however, rattling off three top-16 finishes over the final month of the season. Now that Julio has been traded to the Titans, Gage could be a late round sleeper pick as the Falcons WR2.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Gage is in a contract year, making his dynasty value uncertain at this point. With Julio in Tennessee, Gage should have opportunity in 2021 as the likely WR2 for the Falcons behind Calvin Ridley.

notes.text: Is he done? That's the question most believe has already been answered, though the Cardinals beg to differ. Giving him $8 million is not peanuts by any means and they have talked about how big of a role he'll have with the team, including Kyler Murray who said, "A lot of people are sleeping on him." The Bengals wide receivers all underperformed expectations last year, though Green was the ringleader, finishing with 63.8 fewer fantasy points than his opportunity suggested. We saw Hopkins make a difference in year one of the Cardinals system, so it's not like they discriminate against new bodies. Green is currently free in fantasy drafts, and knowing this team targeted wide receivers 65.5 percent of the time in 2020 (sixth in NFL), it makes sense to grab him with your final pick. If he gets six-plus targets in Week 1, he's going to be a popular waiver wire addition.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: A.J. Green
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Green has always been a guy who’s put up big numbers for fantasy in his prime, but those days are over. Now, he has to compete with DeAndre Hopkins for targets and end zone looks, while Kyler Murray is going to steal a ton of production with his legs. A.J. Green may be officially donezo for fantasy purposes.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: At age 32, he’s a fine end of the bench guy in the event a change of scenery helps revitalize his career, but keep your expectations low.

notes.text: Some will suggest that Jarwin can't break out as a top-10 tight end in 2021 due to the presence of Amari Cooper, CeeDee Lamb, and Michael Gallup, but that's not really the case. If you need any proof of that, just look at Dalton Schultz last year. He was Jarwin's backup, took over in Week 2, and played with a backup quarterback for almost a full season. Still, he finished as the TE14 in fantasy football while having the 13th-most expected fantasy points. With Prescott back under center and Jarwin back to full health, there is breakout potential here. At the very worst, Jarwin will be a streaming-worthy tight end on multiple occasions.

Sorry, Mike. Blake Jarwin caught some steam in redraft leagues thanks to the Hitman’s strong endorsement. However, Jarwin tore the ACL in his right knee in Week 1 and underwent surgery shortly after. By all accounts, Jarwin’s injury was a straightforward ACL tear, so there’s little doubt he’ll be full go for training camp.

While Andy is not bullish on Blake Jarwin, Mike and Jason both believe he could be a sleeper tight end in 2021. With Dak returning, Jarwin will hope to establish himself this season, after showing so much promise last year only to lose the season to injury. The Cowboys may pass the ball more than any team in football, as they were on a 17 game pace of nearly 700 attempts last season. Dak's return could mean great things for Jarwin, who could be a spot start and maybe more.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Blake Jarwin
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The tears have finally stopped flowing from Mike’s eyes after Jarwin tragically went down Week 1 with a torn ACL. Despite Dalton Schultz stepping in and running the 3rd most routes among TEs, we see Jarwin stepping back into his lead role in 2021. The Cowboys offense should return to top-5 status with Dak Prescott back and although there are a lot of mouths to feed, Jarwin could gather a few more red-zone TDs than you might think.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: After signing a 4-year $22 million deal in 2020, Jarwin could be a potential cut candidate after this year. However, if you fought through a heart-wrenching shower cry after his early injury, hold strong my friends and give yourself a locker room speech for the ages believing this is the year Jarwin truthers feast! Let’s ride!

notes.text: Since Zac Taylor took over as the head coach, Boyd has played a big role in the offense, though it diminished a tad last year once we saw Tee Higgins carve out a bigger role. Still, he saw 110 targets and finished as the WR35 in half PPR formats. Onto the next obstacle. Ja'Marr Chase is going to be a real thorn in Boyd's side when it comes to volume, as he'll demand more than A.J. Green received last year. All three of the Bengals receivers saw 100-plus targets last year, so it's not like Boyd is going to simply fade away, but he's lost a ton of his upside as the No. 3 option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyler Boyd
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: An underrated slot receiver in the NFL, Tyler Boyd was actually great for fantasy before Joe Burrow’s injury....then the wheels fell off on the entire offense. From Weeks 1-9, Boyd was fantasy’s WR15 and was looking like a steal in the middle to later rounds of drafts. However, now that Ja’Marr Chase is in town and Tee Higgins is likely to take a step forward in year two, there’s some uncertainty regarding Boyd’s volume and TD upside with more competition for targets.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Boyd will be playing football with Joe Burrow for quite awhile, as he’s still got three more years on his current deal. If Cincy remains a high volume passing offense and Joe Burrow is as good as he looked in year one, there’s potential for this offense to support three primary pass catchers for a long time.

notes.text: There's no denying it... when Mostert is healthy and on the field, he's a beast. He's turned 282 career carries into 1,590 yards and 11 touchdowns. But that's the issue, he's never healthy. There's a reason he's 29 years old and has just 282 carries on his frame. Have the 49ers lost patience? They traded up to draft Trey Sermon in the third round, which could indicate they're ready to move on from Mostert, or it could be them ensuring they have a high-quality backup for if/when he gets injured. Mostert tallied at least 14 carries in 5-of-8 starts last year, which is more than enough to get into RB2 territory with his efficiency, but you can't draft him as such when injuries/Sermon are factored in. He's not someone you can confidently draft as a starter for your fantasy team because there's so much unknown. However, if he gets the job back, this is a pick that can make a difference in fantasy leagues. The 49ers have one of the easiest schedules in the league, so if they let Mostert get rolling, he's unlikely to slow down.

Raheem Mostert’s injury history is piling up quickly. He missed 2 weeks last year with a sprained MCL in his knee then suffered a high ankle sprain in Week 6. Upon returning later in the year, Mostert then re-aggravated his high ankle sprain in Week 15, and he missed the final 2 games. Mostert’s injury profile is concerning - he’s 29 years old and has missed 5+ games in every professional season except for one. The primary culprit? Recurring ankle and foot injuries. Research shows that 20-47% of ankle sprains are recurrent, indicating Mostert carries a higher injury risk entering 2021.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Raheem Mostert
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Mostert is an efficiency king with some of the best long speed of any RB in the game averaging over five yards per carry in his career. Unfortunately, he hasn’t exactly been the pinnacle of health. He also has only one 100-yard rushing game in the regular season over the last three seasons. Mostert and rookie Trey Sermon will be an ongoing conversation piece but consider Mostert the lead going into training camp. He’s risk/reward RB2.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s shockingly 29 years old so this joy ride for the former UDFA could be over soon. With one year left on his deal in San Francisco,

notes.text: Would Ingram have signed with the Texans had he known all the moves that have taken place? I'm guessing not. He's now stuck on a depth chart that has David Johnson, Phillip Lindsay, and Rex Burkhead on it, while Tyrod Taylor is under center on what's expected to be a low-scoring Texans offense. You should avoid the Texans if you can help it, especially Ingram.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mark Ingram II
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Despite what he meant to the Ravens, the team cut him in early January after he dressed for only nine games on the season. He now joins David Johnson and Phillip Lindsay in the Texans backfield and has little fantasy value.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Ingram had a good run in New Orleans but now at 31, he’s basically a hype man who happens to play RB in the NFL.

notes.text: I remember getting Waller in the fifth or sixth round last year, and though it never felt amazing while doing it, the end result worked out. Why didn't it feel amazing? He's part of the Raiders offense, that lacks potency. The targets were what we were chasing, and the targets are what we got. But when you're paying TE2 prices in the second round, you not only need the targets, you need touchdowns. While Waller scored nine of them last year, he scored just three of them in 2019 in the same offense. There's a reason people pay up for Travis Kelce, and while I like Waller, I just don't have that guaranteed Kelce-like production.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Darren Waller
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: I am the Wallerus! Goo goo g'joob! We’re big fans of Waller and he’s shown on the football field the last two seasons that he belongs in the elite tier of big-3 TEs. He led all TEs in Red Zone targets (24), team's target share (27.7%), and reception share (29.0%) while being the main option for Derek Carr last year and finished at the top-5 at the position eight times. None of that should change in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Waller is one of the best dynasty stories ever. From 6th round draft pick and substance abuse issues to become waiver wire gold and cementing himself as an elite at the position, he is 29 but under contract in Las Vegas for another three years. Sit on the volume for at least another year.

notes.text: It seems we won't know who the Patriots starting quarterback will be until weeks before the start of the season, but the expectation should be that Newton starts Week 1. He wasn't good in 2020 - there's no denying that, though it certainly didn't help that his top receiver was out for most of the season, and they were weak behind him on the depth chart. The Patriots beefed up their wide receiver/tight end depth chart by signing quite a few players, including Jonnu Smith, Nelson Agholor, and Hunter Henry. Knowing that Newton still flashed 500-plus yard rushing upside, he can be considered a solid streamer as long as he has the job, but if he plays like he did last year, his starting job will be short lived.

During OTAs this spring, Newton suffered a bone bruise in his right hand after he hit a helmet while throwing. He won’t participate in the team’s mini camp, but with appropriate rest, this should be a non-issue moving into training camp.

The Patriots offense was aesthetically displeasing last year. However, Cam was able to use his rushing ability to be a very relevant fantasy QB. His lows were very low, but he knocked out a top-12 performance in 8 of his 15 games. The Patriots have reloaded the pass catchers. Cam has been talking about his throwing shoulder finally feeling healed after years of chronic pain. The ability to run is still there and the offense could be at the least a bit more consistent in 2021. It’s a long shot, but Cam has a shot.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Cam Newton
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Cam lives to booty scoot one more year! Last year, he was basically a RB scoring 12 rushing TDs but averaging a meager 177 passing yards including six games with fewer than 120. The passing offense was historically bad and the Patriots drafted Mac Jones at 15th overall. Newton is likely a veteran bridge and it’s hard to consider him the year long starter especially at his salary of only $3.5 million guaranteed. He still could be stream-worthy to start the year against the Dolphins and the Jets, two divisional teams he averaged 26.5 fantasy points against in four starts last year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: This is likely the last hoorah. If you can get one more year from the dynamic Newton, hats off to you.

notes.text: The highly sought after handcuff flashed his potential in 2020, racking up 18 touches in Ezekiel Elliott's absence, finishing with 132 total yards and two touchdowns against a tough 49ers defense. Granted, the defense may not have given him the same respect they gave Elliott, but the offensive line was also not in great shape at that point, and Dak Prescott was not under center. If Elliott were to miss time, Pollard would be an insta-start RB1. Heck, he even flashed some flex viability last year when Elliott was on the field, which could help you get through bye weeks.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tony Pollard
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Pollard finally received a chance to showcase his talents and went to town in Week 14 scoring 28 fantasy points when Zeke went out. He saw 40 targets last season and that role likely will continue in 2021. He’s a worthy 10th round selection as a fantasy lottery ticket.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Pollard is 24 with two years left on his contract in Dallas. He’s a must have for Zeke managers and someone who could eventually score a second contract and given a bigger opportunity by some team.

notes.text: The public perception on Jones is that he's towards the end of his career, but that's simply not true. In fact, he averaged a career-high 11.3 yards per target during the 2020 season and was the WR13 in half-PPR points per game while ceding plenty of work to up-and-coming superstar Calvin Ridley. It'll be a similar situation in Tennessee, as Jones will now play alongside what might be the next generation's Julio Jones, and that's A.J. Brown. Similar to Atlanta, Jones and Brown are going to cap each other's truly elite ceiling, but as Jones and Ridley proved last year, it's certainly not out of the realm of possibilities that they're both top-12 wide receivers, especially when you factor in Ryan Tannehill's efficiency. Oh, and stop calling Jones injury prone - he's played at least 14 games in seven of the last nine seasons, and has totaled at least 1,394 yards in six of the last seven seasons. You don't do that if you're injury prone.

Julio Jones battled a hamstring strain off and on all season as he was in and out of the lineup throughout the year after aggravating the same injury twice. We know the greatest risk for re-injury upon returning to the field is in the first two weeks, and that’s exactly what happened for Jones in 2020. However, with a full offseason of recovery, look for Jones to return to form in 2021. That said, Julio is now 32 years old, and research suggests that re-injury risk for hamstring, quad and calf strains increases 1.3x per year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Julio Jones
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: With the trade to Tennessee, one of the true GOATs at the WR position finds himself now as second fiddle to the new hotness known as A.J. Brown. He should still maintain a healthy target share with Corey Davis and Jonnu Smith gone via free agency. Still, with fewer targets than he was used to in Atlanta, he may not be as consistent as Julio in years past. Perhaps his TDs can go up as the Titans offense has lived off being efficient in recent seasons. As a Titan, he lands as a top-20 WR in our initial projections for 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: When the 2021 season ends, Julio Jones will have completed his 11th season in the NFL. At this point, each year that passes will lead to a reduction in Julio’s dynasty value as he likely only has a couple of seasons left as a top tier producer. Unless you’re competing for a championship, it’s time to move on from the future Hall of Famer.

notes.text: While 2019 seemed like Slayton might have a bright future in the NFL, 2020 wasn't as kind to him. He did lead all Giants wide receivers in targets (97) but it didn't lead to much in the production department, as he tallied just 50 receptions for 751 yards and three touchdowns. The Giants appeared to lose confidence in him, too, as they signed Kenny Golladay in free agency, and then drafted Kadarius Toney. Suddenly, Slayton may not be a starter on this offense, as Sterling Shepard and Golladay are the locked-in starters, while Toney figures to start in the slot. At this point, Slayton shouldn't even be drafted.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Darius Slayton
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Slayton’s fantasy outlook got crushed when the team signed Kenny Golladay to a 4-year, $72 million deal. There’s a lot that needs to go right for Slayton to be fantasy viable but he could be a spot start type of guy in the right matchup.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Slayton made some noise in dynasty after posting 740 yards and eight TDs as a rookie. However, we saw him fall off significantly last year, thanks in part due to poor QB play from Danny Dimes and the Giants offense looking inept at times. Is Jones good enough to support multiple fantasy viable WRs? Slayton is signed with the Giants for two more years.

notes.text: After exiting Denver's mess to join Las Vegas, most assumed Booker's career was nearing an end, but he was solid with them, averaging 4.5 yards per carry and eating into Josh Jacobs' workload a bit. While I don't expect the same thing to happen with the Giants, he's the clear No. 2 on their depth chart behind Saquon Barkley, who's had plenty of health concerns in his short career.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Devontae Booker
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Booker signed on with the Giants as Saquon Barkley’s backup. In deep leagues, he could be drafted incase Saquon isn't ready to go Week 1.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s roster worthy in deep leagues as an insurance policy to Saquon.

notes.text: He went from a player who had the passing-down back role locked down at the start of the offseason, but we've watched that fade as we move throughout the offseason. The addition of Kenneth Gainwell in the draft was always going to be a problem, as Gainwell was arguably the best pass-catching back in the draft class. Not just Gainwell, though, as the team also signed Kerryon Johnson once the Lions released him. Opportunity is fading for Scott, who's nowhere near the redraft radar at this point.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Boston Scott
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The former UDFA had few explosive plays in 2020. He’s still a solid pass-catcher but with a new regime change on Philly, there’s no telling how involved he’ll be. He’s competing with Kerryon Johnson and Kenneth Gainwell for touches behind Miles Sanders.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Scott is a flier at best in a crowded Philly backfield.

notes.text: If there's one thing we can say about Godwin with Tom Brady under center, it's that he's a near lock for six-plus targets per game. He saw at least six targets in 10-of-12 games despite all the other talent on the roster, which is never a bad thing. The downside is that Godwin never really got into any sort of WR1 groove. He didn't hit the 100-yard mark until Week 17, when Mike Evans was essentially out of the lineup. To be fair, Godwin was playing through a few injuries last year, which may have hindered his upside, but we did watch Mike Evans' relationship with Brady grow as the year went on. On top of that, Antonio Brown and Rob Gronkowski returned to game shape, which will certainly cap everyone's upside. Godwin should be a solid WR2 on a weekly basis, but it's tough seeing him approach top-12 territory without an injury to one of Evans or Brown.

Godwin’s 2020 season was really disappointing from a fantasy perspective, primarily because he only played in 12 games last year, missing time with a concussion, a hamstring strain and a fractured index finger, which required surgery. Godwin returned to form late in the season and throughout the Bucs’ Super Bowl run, so he’s clearly recovered from all three of these injuries.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chris Godwin
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It was a down year for Chris Godwin in 2020, especially after finishing as the WR2 in 2019. Godwin dealt with a myriad of injuries, including a hamstring issue as well as a surgery on his index finger, keeping him out of the lineup for four games. After a WR32 finish in 2020, Godwin will look to be a more consistent producer in year two with TB12 under center, but it’s unlikely we see Godwin reach the ceiling he saw with Jameis Winston in 2019.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Still just 25 years old, Chris Godwin is only now getting ready to enter his prime years in the NFL. He’s playing on the franchise tag in 2021 and will likely secure a long-term deal with a new team next offseason, so his situation is a bit up in the air. Regardless, Godwin’s got the talent and should have the financial commitment from his team entering 2022 to be considered a rock solid WR2 with WR1 upside for multiple seasons.

notes.text: We've legitimately seen Wentz perform as a top-five fantasy quarterback in Frank Reich's offense, so this one speaks for itself. The Colts offensive line might be better than the one the Eagles had in those days, though they'll need Eric Fisher healthy as soon as possible. Despite his bad 2020 season, Wentz has posted QB1-type numbers in 44.1 percent of the games in his career, which ranks as the 16th best quarterback over the last 15 years. *Update* Wentz has a foot issue that could require surgery, and the Colts are bracing for him to miss time at the start of the year. Stay tuned in for more updates.

Wentz injured his foot on July 26 and is set to miss up to 12 weeks following surgery to remove a piece of fractured bone from his foot. Given that this decision wasn't made until early August, it's very possible Wentz misses multiple regular season games. At this point, however, it's too early to determine how many exactly he'll miss. Because the surgery is to remove a piece of bone rather than repair an injured tissue, the progression of his rehab will primarily depend on rate of recovery and soreness levels. Look for Wentz's status to be updated as the regular season nears, but he is certainly a candidate to start the year on the PUP list. The latest report is that he is 'trending' towards playing in Week 1. We'll be monitoring this situation and updating as needed.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Carson Wentz
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: For all of the turmoil Wentz faced this season, he was the QB7 for the first seven weeks of the season and a viable every week start. But you know the rest of the story, as he crashed and burned into losing his job to Jalen Hurts before being traded to Indianapolis, and reunited with Frank Reich. The QB Guru will have to correct some of Wentz’s mistake-prone ways as he holds onto the ball for way too long, hence the reason he led the NFL in sacks despite not playing the final month of the season. The change of scenery should do wonders but he’s a bit of a mystery for 2021. UPDATE: Carson Wentz will undergo surgery to remove a piece of fractured bone from his foot. The latest report is that he's trending towards starting in Week 1. This is a situation we'll be monitoring.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Wentz’s dynasty value has cratered over the last two years. He’s still only 28 years old and playing indoors with a solid team can resurrect his stock. He’s a better QB2 in SuperFlex leagues than someone we’d trust going into 2021.

notes.text: Pascal has kind of just "hung around" in the fantasy conversatoin over the last two years due to injuries to T.Y. Hilton, Michael Pittman, and Parris Campbell. He's made the most of his opportunity, totaling at least 600 yards and five touchdowns in each of the last two seasons despite not eclipsing 72 targets. However, going into 2021 with a healthy group of pass catchers, Pascal will only be on the field in 4WR sets, which doesn't work for fantasy.

It felt like too many people were dismissing Thomas this year, falling into borderline WR2 territory, but now that we know of his ankle surgery that took place in June, he's going to fall even further. It's possible he misses the first 4-6 games based on the timeline he received. It did seem like everyone forget he was the consensus No. 1 wide receiver just a year ago. The big question is: Who is his quarterback once he returns? If it's Hill, there should be a slight downgrade, but don't forget what Thomas did in the four Hill games last year: 9/104/0, 4/50/0, 9/105/0, and 8/84/0. Those are rock-solid numbers, though the touchdowns were obviously not there. Right now, I'm expecting Thomas to miss at least four games, which moves him down into WR4 territory. If you're able to stay afloat the first month of the season, snagging Thomas in the middle rounds might be a winning strategy.

News broke in late July that Michael Thomas required surgery on his ankle in June to stablize the injured ligaments. This all stems from Thomas’ left high ankle sprain from Week 1 of 2020, which forced Thomas to be shut down at the end of the season. A report originally surfaced in late January that Thomas may require surgery on his ankle, and it looks like he attempted to rehab and delay surgery as long as possible to see if he could recover without surgery. However, at this point, Thomas is going to miss regular season games and is a strong candidate to begin the year on the PUP list. The final thing to consider here is that Thomas will also require time to acclimate back into football, so it’s unlikely Thomas is 100% in his first couple of games once he does return to the field. Look for Thomas’ status to be updated in mid to late August as training camp progresses.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Michael Thomas
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Michael Thomas was considered one of the safest wide receivers in fantasy last year, coming off the board as the WR1. He was a massive bust after missing most of the season with a high ankle sprain. Now, he enters 2021 with one glaring question mark - how will he perform in his first season without Drew Brees? In four games with Taysom Hill as the starter last season, Thomas returned weekly WR16, 48, 20 and 24 finishes while averaging 85.75 yards per game. UPDATE: Thomas is now expected to miss the start of the 2021 season after undergoing surgery to repair the ligaments in his ankle in June. Reports say recommended recovery time could be as long as 4 months.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Michael Thomas was firmly entrenched as the WR1 in dynasty just a year ago, but he enters the first time in his career where there’s uncertainty surrounding his value. Drew Brees is gone, so who will be throwing the now 28 year old the football? Has he already reached his fantasy ceiling? These are the questions fantasy managers need to ask themselves with Thomas entering 2021.

notes.text: Ebron saw more targets than most expected last year, finishing with 91 of them, which ranked eighth among tight ends. Unfortunately, he wasn't particularly efficient with them, finishing 15th in fantasy scoring. The reason was because he lacked upside and never scored more than 13.7 half PPR points all season. That's going to happen when you're the No. 4 option behind the three wide receivers. Now we add Najee Harris to this offense, and suddenly, Ebron may not even get the volume he did last year, and we haven't even talked about the addition of Pat Friermuth in the second round of the draft. Ebron should be labeled as a streamer, and not an every-week option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Eric Ebron
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: As the poster child for Jason’s “drafted to be great” argument, Ebron finished as the TE15 despite seeing the 8th most TE targets, running the 7th most routes and seeing the 4th most looks inside the red zone among TEs.
