He honestly squandered his opportunity last year and now with 2nd rounder Pat Freiermuth in the mix, his time as a streamworthy player is coming to an end.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Ebron has played seven years in the league and still is only 28 years old. We’re going to be talking about how young this guy is well into his 80s. With one year left on his deal and Pat Freiermuth waiting in the wings, he’s got a one way ticket to the waiver wire in his near future.

notes.text: Tannehill has been disrespected by the fantasy community long before Julio Jones was traded there. Tannehill became the starter of the Titans in Week 7 of 2019. Since that time, he's tallied 575.3 fantasy points, which ranks third among quarterbacks, behind only Josh Allen and Lamar Jackson. That's right... despite ranking 16th in pass attempts during that time (26-game sample size), he's finished with more fantasy points than Patrick Mahomes, Russell Wilson, Kyler Murray, and Deshaun Watson.

Ryan Tannehill is a slightly more popular pick now that Julio Jones is in town, but we don’t think most people realize how good Tannehill can be in fantasy. After the Titans Week 4 Bye last season (also known as the time they didn’t have AJ Brown) Ryan Tannhehill was the #2 QB in fantasy. Add Julio Jones to that mix and Ryan Tannehill is the late round QB who could turn into an unexpected league winner.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Ryan Tannehill
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After receiving a massive contract extension in the offseason as the Titans’ franchise QB, Tannehill responded with an AFC South title. He was clutch, leading the NFL in 4th quarter comebacks (5) and game-winning drives (6). As a fantasy QB, Tannehill was almost 10 fantasy points per game better at home and his final season ranking of QB7 was bolstered by five rushing TDs in his final three games. He’s a solid low-end QB1 who relies more on efficiency than volume. Now having Julio Jones paired with A.J. Brown, Tannehill's chances to repeat as a top 10 fantasy QB have gone way up.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The last two years have been magical for Tannehill as his fantasy football resurrection has been on the back of some insane efficiency. Know who can help maintain such insane efficiency? How bout future Hall of Famer, Julio Jones. If Julio (and A.J. Brown) are healthy, another top 10 season is in the cards for Ryan Tannehill.

notes.text: Gould isn't quite as automatic as he once was, but even at 38 years of age, he can still be a fantasy starter. The fantasy points weren't there for him last year, as San Francisco often converted touchdowns rather than settling for field goals once they got into the red zone. In fact, Gould's 23 field-goal attempts were his lowest ever in a full season (Gould missed one game lat year, but still). But he converted at an 82.6% rate, and hit 11 of his 14 attempts from 40 yards or more. With natural regression, Gould should see his field-goal attempts jump by about 25%, and he should be a top-12 kicker by season's end if he can maintain his level of performance for another season.

Yes, I'm fully aware that Cousins has continually finished as a top-12 quarterback, but my rankings are based on how I'd draft quarterbacks and not where I project them to finish. Why? Well, Cousins has stayed healthy and played all 16 games, allowing him to finish higher than those right around him who missed a game or two. But on a week-to-week basis, you're never going to say Cousins is a top-12 quarterback. He's a rock-solid QB2 in Superflex formats, but he's just a streamer in 1QB leagues. I'd rather draft someone like Trevor Lawrence for upside.

All Cousins did last year was throw for a career-high 35 passing TDs (6th most in the NFL) but it seems no one noticed. While the Vikings stumbled to a 7-9 record, with some improvement on the defensive side of the ball, they look like they’re in contention for a playoff spot in 2021. He’s a solid late-round QB to roll with out of the gate with plus matchups against Cincinnati, Arizona and Seattle.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kirk Cousins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: You might’ve deleted Cousins from your 2020 memory but Captain Kirk set career-highs in passing TDs (35) and TD rate (6.9) but was only  QB11 on the season. It felt like a fantasy season out of place as that passing TD total would’ve ranked second in the NFL in 2019. In fact, Cousins’ fantasy finish is the lowest ever for a QB with 35+ passing TDs. Nevertheless, he is hitched to two top-notch WRs that should continue to buoy his fantasy value as a streamer.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Captain Kirk has two years left on his fully guaranteed contract. Kellen Mond is lurking in the depths but for now, Cousins is a fine QB2 on a dynasty roster who will have blow up moments.

notes.text: The Lions signing Williams seems to have gone under the radar, but should it? He was likely brought in due to his experience in Anthony Lynn's offense, which gives him a leg up on the competition, as that's the play-caller he had his breakout 1,059-yard, seven-touchdown season under. Unfortunately, Jared Goff hasn't been a great deep passer in the NFL, which is where Williams has made most of his noise, averaging at least 15.3 yards per reception in each of his five NFL seasons played. Still, there should be at least some value in a wide receiver who's likely to lead the Lions wide receivers in targets.

Williams missed all of 2020 after undergoing surgery to address a torn labrum in his shoulder last September. The recovery for this injury is typically 6-9 months, so it’s not surprising he missed the entire year. He’ll be full go in training camp and won’t be limited by the shoulder.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyrell Williams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Tyrell the Gazelle didn’t play at all in 2020 and after the Raiders released him, he found a giant void in Detroit and signed on for $6 million. He’s always been a big-play guy averaging 16.1 yards per reception for his career. Taking a shot on him becoming the main target in Detroit isn’t insane especially at the end of your draft.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Gazelle was likely wounded, wasting away on the dynasty waiver wire during 2020. This is one last desperate chance to get some production before he is set out to pasture.

notes.text: If there's one player who saw his stock significantly rise when Aaron Rodgers announced his return, it's Tonyan. He wouldn't have been in my top-15 tight ends had Rodgers not played, but instead, he's now inside my top-eight tight ends. While doing research for my "Which tight ends were better/worse than expected" article, I found out that based on the opportunity he received, and more importantly where he received it, Tonyan was supposed to finish as the No. 18 tight end. He scored 61.2 more fantasy points than the average tight end would've, pushing him all the way up to the No. 3 tight end on the season. That's a 15-spot leap over opportunity. No other tight end jumped more than six spots than their opportunity. To be fair, that screams regression, and that will happen on a per-target basis, but we can't forget it was Tonyan's first season in a full-time role, so there's some natural career progression. The chemistry between him and Rodgers can't be denied, either, as he caught 88.1 percent of his targets, a new record for tight ends. Tonyan isn't going to see 100-plus targets like the top-tier tight ends, but he's one of the best bets for a touchdown each and every week, which is all you can ask for when taking a tight end in the later rounds.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Robert Tonyan
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Tonyan finished as the fantasy TE3 in 2020! He found the endzone 11 times, despite a measly 52 receptions on 59 targets. We often say that touchdowns are NOT a sticky stat. Still, because Rodgers is back, no one will be surprised if Tonyan has close to double-digit TDs again.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: With Rodgers back in Green Bay for at least the 2021 season, Tonyan's chance at a bright future is much better. He's hoping to have another big year to influence a future contract, as he's a free agent in 2022.

notes.text: While on the field, Brown has delivered for fantasy managers. The issue is that's been a struggle staying on the field. He's missed 14 full games over the last four seasons and portions of others. Still, he produced a 1,000-yard season in 2019, and finished with 70-plus yards in five of the nine games he did play in 2020. Now going to Las Vegas where there is no clear-cut No. 1 wide receiver, Brown could have a Nelson Agholor-like 2021 season where he essentially goes undrafted, but winds up being a borderline WR3 most weeks, but he needs to stay healthy in order for that to happen.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: John Brown
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Brown was quietly really good for fantasy in 2020 when on the field...but that didn’t happen very often. He missed or exited early due to injury in eight games last year. He’s on a Raiders team with a ton of question marks at the WR position, but let’s be honest Derek Carr’s first and second read is Darren Waller. Expect ‘Smoke’ Brown to have some big weeks for fantasy a la Nelson Agholor in 2020, but he’s not a reliable option at this point in his career.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: John Brown signed a one-year deal with Vegas this offseason, but he turns 32 next year when he’ll be a free agent. There isn’t likely to be a hot market for the speedy Brown, making him an obvious trade away candidate while he’s still got some (albeit small) value. Otherwise, he could provide some depth for bye weeks and injuries.

notes.text: This might seem weird to some, but Fitzpatrick has produced QB1-type numbers in 18-of-37 games over the last four years (includes seven games where he threw 18 or less passes). Do you know how many quarterbacks posted QB1-type numbers in better than 50 percent of their games in 2020? 10 of them. That's it. Under Scott Turner, the Panthers threw the ball 633 times with Cam Newton, Kyle Allen, and Will Grier in 2019. Then, in 2020, Washington threw the ball 599 times with Dwayne Haskins, Alex Smith, and Kyle Allen.

Ryan Fitzpatrick steps into a great situation in Washington. The Football Team was a playoff contender, and Fitzmagic knows how to sling the rock. Gone are the Alex Smith dump-offs, as Fitzpatrick will have Terry McLaurin and Curtis Samuel to throw the ball to. One thing we like about Fitzpatrick is the fact he can throw the ball downfield on a consistent basis. He may take chances, but that's translated to fantasy success for him in recent years. He makes the team better, and you may get more starts than you'd expect out of him in fantasy this year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Ryan Fitzpatrick
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Let’s ride! Fitzpatrick is not merely an NFL legend but a Fantasy Footballers favorite as one of the most unique individuals to grace the field. He historically peppers his WRs with targets and as recent as 2019 was a league winner for fantasy. Excitement aside, he does crash-and-burn quite often for fantasy so be willing to cut bait if things don’t work out as well as we want to.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you hung onto Fitzmagic on the end of your dynasty squad, you’ll likely get one more year of a rollercoaster ride.

notes.text: There may be no fantasy wide receiver who's continually undervalued more than Mike Evans. He's now turned in at least 1,000 yards in seven straight seasons with a handful of different quarterbacks, and has scored at least eight touchdowns in five of them. The reason he can't be considered in the elite tier is due to the number of mouths to feed in the Bucs offense. Think about it this way: Despite Chris Godwin being hurt for a while and Antonio Brown not joining the team until mid-season, Evans finished with just 109 targets. He's one of the better WR2's to have in fantasy, but he doesn't come with top-five upside unless there are injuries to those around him.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mike Evans
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Mike Evans’ consistency is just ridiculous. All the man has done since entering the NFL seven years ago is surpass 1,000 yards every year and threaten for 10+ TD every year. In his seven professional seasons, Evans has finished as a top-12 fantasy WR five times yet he's almost always drafted outside of that range. Look for Tom Brady to once again target Evans close to the end zone, making Evans one of the most likely WRs in the game to score double digit TDs in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The only concern with Evans in dynasty is that Tom Brady can’t play forever making his QB situation for the next few years a bit uncertain. Regardless, Evans’ consistency and production to this point in his career makes him a top-tier option moving forward.

notes.text: Not only will Fuller finish up his suspension and miss Week 1 this year, but he'll also be returning to the field with a new quarterback, and let's just say that life without Deshaun Watson hasn't been kind to him. In 20 games with non-Watson quarterbacks, Fuller has averaged 6.0 targets, 3.1 receptions, 38.7 yards, and 0.10 touchdowns, which is a far cry from his 6.5 targets, 4.5 receptions, 70.6 yards, and 0.67 touchdowns per game with Watson under center. Can Tua Tagovailoa take a step forward in his career in 2021? Sure, but he's not going to be Watson, and there are suddenly tons of options for him to throw to, which means Fuller is going to have to fight for his target share. There's more risk than you'd like with Fuller, who's also had his fair share of injuries throughout his career. Getting him as a WR4 would be ideal, as you aren't relying on him for production week-in and week-out.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: William Fuller V
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Flying V's landing spot in Miami has Fuller enthusiasts up in arms after he pieced together a great first half of the 2020 season. Normally missing time due to injury, it was a PED suspension that caused him to miss the final five games of 2020 and the first game of the 2021 season coming up. Nevertheless, he’s always worth rostering despite the risk. The fact is when he’s on the field, he’s a difference maker for fantasy as he led the league in yards per target in 2020.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Will Fuller is playing on a one-year deal in Miami in 2021 but he’ll look to prove the doubters wrong and stay healthy for a full season...without PEDs. Given that he’s in a contract year, the long term outlook for Fuller is uncertain, but if he puts together a strong 2021, he’ll get paid in the offseason to likely serve as a team’s WR2.

notes.text: The exit of Curtis Samuel frees up some targets in the offense, but don't forget that Christian McCaffrey missed most of last year, which allowed more targets to go to the wide receivers. We don't know how the Panthers will deploy Marshall, though it's certainly worth noting he has experience in this offense, as he played for Joe Brady at LSU. If they align him as the big slot, he can make more of an impact with Sam Darnold, who has always favored his targets over the middle of the field. If they put him on the perimeter, it'll be a lot tougher for him to produce immediately while behind D.J. Moore, Robby Anderson, and McCaffrey in the pecking order.

Marshall fell a bit in the NFL Draft partially due to some injury concerns given his injury history. In high school, he suffered a fractured fibula with a dislocated left ankle, which forced him to miss his senior year of high school. Then, in 2019 while at LSU, Marshall suffered a stress fracture in his right foot. Despite this seeming concerning on the surface, Marshall was able to return to form and produce at a high level in 2020, suggesting there’s a chance his injury woes are behind him.

Marshall lands in Carolina to play the WR3 role behind Robby Anderson and D.J. Moore. He can be a big slot WR at the next level, so it’ll be interesting to see where the team uses him in his rookie season. Obviously, if anything happened to Anderson or Moore, he’d be an immediate add off the waiver wire but otherwise, it’s important to keep expectations in check. Remember, there’s this guy named Christian McCaffrey catching footballs out of the backfield, too, and Sam Darnold at QB.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Terrace Marshall Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Marshall lands in Carolina to play the WR3 role behind Robby Anderson and D.J. Moore. He can be a big slot WR at the next level, so it’ll be interesting to see where the team uses him in his rookie season. Obviously, if anything happened to Anderson or Moore, he’d be an immediate add off the waiver wire but otherwise, it’s important to keep expectations in check. Remember, there’s this guy named Christian McCaffrey catching footballs out of the backfield, too, and Sam Darnold at QB.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Marshall slipped a bit in the NFL Draft due to medical concerns, but his landing spot is really intriguing, and he’s still got 2nd round Draft capital to support his profile. Robby Anderson is a free agent after the 2021 season. We'll see if Sam Darnold can take a step forward in Carolina.

notes.text: There've been six times over the course of Higbee's career where he's tallied more than 67 yards. Five of those games came at the end of the 2019 season when Gerald Everett was either out of the lineup or very limited. Well, Everett has been signed by the Seahawks, and the next man up on the Rams depth chart to fill his spot is Bryce Hopkins, who's seen as many targets as I have in an NFL uniform (none). Eliminating Everett's targets and upgrading Higbee's quarterback is the recipe for success, and it shouldn't shock anyone to see Higbee finish as a top-10 tight end in 2021.

Hig-beast was one of the hot topics (no, not the clothing store) of the fantasy off-season last year after he ended 2019 on an absolute tear. His production leveled off and now it seems like he’s been thrown away by the wayside for 2021. With Gerald Everett on to Seattle, there is plenty of opportunity for Higbee, who seems like he'll be an every-down player. Going outside of the top-12 of TEs, Higbee is one of the few TEs we’ve seen with a ceiling to boast about this late in a draft. Take your shot on Higbee and a newfound connection with Matthew Stafford.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tyler Higbee
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Higbeast is another player who was hyped coming into the 2020 season and the air got let out early. Apart from a 3-TD game in Week 2, he was a tease to fantasy managers. He now finds himself alone in Los Angeles with Everett out the door and an upgrade at QB with Matthew Stafford. He’s shown a ceiling before with five stellar games in a row to end the 2019 season. He’s one of the better late round TEs to target in 2021 with hopes he breaks through again.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: In a PPR or TE premium league, Higbee can take a step this year and if the dynasty manager has a bad taste in their mouth, why not put an offer for a player we've seen have a monster season?

notes.text: Butker had the worst fantasy season of his career, though it was hardly his fault. He set a career-high by hitting 92.6% of his field-goal attempts, including all four of his ones from 50 or more yards. The problem was largely the lack of volume, as he attempted just 27 field goals on the season after 38 the year before. Even with his "down" year, Butker remains one of the most accurate kickers in the game playing on an elite offense. He should be drafted as one of the first few kickers off the board, and managers should just hope the Kansas City offense stalls just a bit more before reaching the end zone.

If you were thinking the hate went too far with Goff and that he might be a decent streamer/platoon option, think again. His start to the season is a nightmare and it really doesn't get any better as it goes on. The first seven weeks include the 49ers, Packers, Ravens, Bears, Vikings, and Rams. If you want to find a great matchup, you have to wait all the way until Week 16. The Lions offense isn't one you should aggressively attack in fantasy drafts.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jared Goff
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: You kind of feel sorry for Goff, the native California boy who was shipped out of town to Detroit aka football Siberia. Unfortunately, the Rams saw the writing on the wall for a QB who turned into more of a hindrance than a difference-maker on the football field. Goff turned in the lowest yards per attempt of his career and boosted his stats against bottom-16 defenses averaging 11.26 more fantasy points against them, the highest discrepancy among all QBs. He’s still young but this Lions team is lacking pass-catching talent and looks destined to be a bottom feeder in 2021. He’s off the redraft radar but could have some streamable moments at home in the right matchup.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Goff’s contract becomes expendable in 2023 so he’ll likely be the Lions signal caller for the next two years perhaps as a bridge to someone else. His best days are behind him but you can’t feel too bad for a guy who has made $80+ million already in his career.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Sammy Watkins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: If the Lizard King can’t consistently produce on the best offense in football with Patrick Mahomes, what are his chances of producing on one of the league’s lowest volume passing offenses in Baltimore? I think we know what Sammy is at this point in his career.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: You can’t trade him. There’s no reason to acquire him. Watkins has officially entered roster clogger territory.

notes.text: Crosby had just 16 field-goal attempts, easily the least among any kicker that played a full season. But he also had 63 extra-point attempts, the most among kickers. In essence, Crosby was a victim of Aaron Rodgers' dominance once the Packers got near the end zone. There should be at least some natural regression to the mean this year (he had averaged 31 field-goal attempts in his 13 other seasons), and given that Crosby converted all of his field-goal tries, there's no reason to expect a decline. He's a borderline started in 12-team leagues, but ignore the low volume from last year.

If you're planning on taking a wide receiver in the first round, you'd better make sure he's going to perform without question. Adams is that player, as he's performed as a WR1 in 22 of his last 41 games (53.7 percent), which is historically good, and it's a three-year sample size. During that time, he's scored fewer than 11.1 PPR points just four times, and once was due to leaving with an injury. As long as Aaron Rodgers is with the Packers, Adams will be a can't-miss WR1.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Davante Adams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Adams was dominant in 2020 averaging 22.1 fantasy points per game while ranking #1 in yards per route run and receiving TDs. It was a historic season for a player who only appeared in 14 games. Now with Aaron Rodgers back, Adams is the top-ranked wide receiver for the 2021 season.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Coming off a historic season, he’s only 28 years old so expect 3-4 more major years of fantasy production. Could he and Rodgers sign for the same new team in 2022?

notes.text: Over the last six years, there have been just seven wide receivers who've finished top-24 in at least five of them. Those receivers are Mike Evans, Julio Jones, Davante Adams, DeAndre Hopkins, Amari Cooper, Jarvis Landry, and... Cooks. He's done it with four different quarterbacks, too. However, 2021 might be his toughest test yet, as it appears Tyrod Taylor will be his quarterback, and this is projected to be the lowest scoring offense in the league. Still, he's the clear-cut top option on this team and should be a lock to see 100-plus targets as long as he's healthy.

Fantasy managers probably want to write off any player with a Texans uniform in 2021. Yes, David Culley’s crew likely is headed towards the No. 1 pick but in terms of guaranteed volume, it’s hard to find a WR with Cooks’ safety. He’s a good fantasy wide receiver finishing in the top-15 in five out of the last six years! Cooks can slide in as a perfect WR3/FLEX play that you know is going to see 6-7 targets per game.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Brandin Cooks
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: No one wants Brandin Cooks in fantasy anymore after the fallout from the Texans organization over the last 18 months. Deshaun Watson may never play for Houston again and this team projects to be the NFL’s worst by a mile. That said, he should get peppered with targets and could actually be okay for fantasy based on volume alone. Consider him a worthy WR3/FLEX.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Cooks has finished as the WR15 or better in every season except one dating back to 2015 while playing for four different franchises over that time span. It’s actually pretty incredible. Still just 27 years old, Cooks might be a sneaky trade target in dynasty as his price has never been lower and the depth chart is wide open for targets.

notes.text: Succop had a fine season in his first year with Tamp Bay, converting 90.3% of his field-goal attempts and 52 extra-point attempts. He doesn't have a huge leg (his career long field goal is just 54 yards), but he's consistent and playing in a dynamic offense. He should be a fine option in most standard-sized leagues, but if your league awards bonus points for long kicks, you'll need to take into consideration that Succop won't help you much there.

Let's do an exercise... How many targets per game do you anticipate Beckham getting this year? I'm going with an extremely low number and say he averages 6.5 targets per game. That sounds more than reasonable, right? Beckham had 7.0 targets per game during the 2020 season before getting hurt and that includes a three-target game against the Steelers. The Browns were also throwing the ball a lot less early in the year as Baker Mayfield was still getting grasp on Kevin Stefanski's playbook. If Beckham gets 6.5 targets per game, that'd put him on pace for 104 targets, which again, is what I'd consider low. There were just 32 receivers in the NFL who hit that number last year, with 24 of them (75 percent) finishing as top-24 receivers and just two finishing worse than WR38. You mean to tell me with Beckham's talent, he can't produce top-24 numbers? There's health risks for sure, but there's also top-five wide receiver upside.

Odell Beckham Jr. has had some horrible injury luck since he entered the NFL. Dating back to 2014, his injury history includes a fractured fibula, a hamstring strain, a quad strain, sports hernia repair surgery and most recently a torn ACL. He’ll be 29 in November, which is important given that there is a statistically significant difference in the rate of soft tissue injuries in players that are age 26 and younger and we know from research studies that younger NFL players tend to have better performance outcomes following ACL surgery. Beckham will be ready for Week 1, but is he the same WR we saw five years ago? The injury history suggests possibly not.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Odell Beckham Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: OBJ’s 2020 season was cut short thanks to a torn ACL in his left knee, which happened in Week 7. Beckham’s injury history is piling up, and let’s be honest: Beckham hasn’t been good for fantasy while playing in Cleveland. He’s cleared 100 receiving yards just three total times since joining Cleveland in 2019. Beckham is still an extremely talented WR, but is he relying solely on name value at this point in his career?
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Beckham has really struggled to stay on the field throughout his NFL career, and now he’s coming off a torn ACL. To make matters worse, Beckham turns 29 in November and his current contract carries zero dead cap money after the 2021 season. Unless Beckham turns it around quickly, he could be a declining asset sitting on the end of dynasty rosters who never really lived up to the hype from earlier in his career.

notes.text: Opportunity is everything, right? It's why despite Robinson's lackluster quarterback play, he's been able to finish as a top-12 receiver in back-to-back seasons. The upgrade to Andy Dalton was solid, but if the Bears play Justin Fields, it could be even better. Based on opportunity alone, Robinson should have finished as the WR4 in each of the last two seasons (that's based on how many targets he saw and where he saw them), so there's certainly room for improvement in his finish. Robinson has proven to be a WR1 with bad quarterback play in this same offense, making him one of the safer options as a low-end WR1/high-end WR2.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Allen Robinson II
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Allen Robinson has dominated in Chicago for multiple years now. Coming off 150+ target seasons in back-to-back years, there’s virtually no competition on the Bears roster to suggest that ARob can’t push for a 25+% target share yet again in 2021. Robinson has returned top-12 WR value in back-to-back seasons thanks to volume, but it is worth noting that his average depth of target has dropped every season since 2015. If the Bears’ QBs can push the ball down the field, A-Rob’s ceiling is massive with the target share he’ll see. Even if Andy Dalton starts the season over Justin Fields, he’s likely the best QB Robinson has played with.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: With ARob playing on the franchise tag in 2021, his long term outlook is difficult to project. However, at this point in his career, Robinson has proven to be QB-proof and excels when given the opportunity. If Justin Fields is the future in Chicago, you’d have to think the Bears attempt to bring Robinson back on a long term deal to secure a bonafide WR1 to support their young QB.

notes.text: The marriage between the Raiders and Drake is an odd one, as Drake was somewhat of a Josh Jacobs doppleganger last year. They both finished between 3.9 and 4.0 yards per carry, both scored double-digit rushing touchdowns, and both were extremely limited in the passing game. The Raiders have continually given guys like DeAndre Washington, Jalen Richard, and Devontae Booker work alongside Jacobs over the last two years, so Drake is going to get mixed in quite heavily, and my guess would be that the passing game is where he gets most of it. You may not remember, but Drake was considered a solid third-down back early in his career with the Dolphins, and has two seasons with 50-plus catches on his NFL resume. It's tough to see him eating into Jacobs' carry totals a whole lot, especially after the way he looked with the Cardinals in 2020, but he should offer low-upside flex value due to his work in the passing game.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kenyan Drake
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Ouch. Josh Jacobs managers went on tilt after Kenyan Drake joined the Raiders on a two-year deal. Additionally, the Raiders have lost key pieces on the offensive line and could be in for a rough season. Drake is a worthy later round/Zero RB target if the team utilizes him in the passing game like they have spoken about this offseason.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Drake is on his last dynasty leg. Despite being only 27, he’s likely to bottom out in the next two years. If you can squeeze another year or two as a depth piece, you’re fortunate.

notes.text: The man just keeps getting better... Every year he's been in the league, we've watched his rushing yardage go up by at least 250 yards. I'm sure he peaked last year with 2,027 yards on the ground, but now going to a 17-game season, maybe I'm wrong. Henry should be in scoring position quite a bit this year knowing the Titans went out and acquired Julio Jones this offseason. There's no scenario where your offense gets worse in that equation. However, we don't know how the offense is going to look in 2021, as Arthur Smith (offensive coordinator the last two years) is gone. Still, with Jones and A.J. Brown on the perimeter, it's going to be tough for opponents to stack the box the way they have against Henry the last few years, so his efficiency may actually go up. There are certainly some variables to his projections, but Henry has proven that despite his lack of usage in the passing game, he's going to make up for it on the ground.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Derrick Henry
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Whoaaaa buddy. Henry is one of the true outliers at the RB position that doesn’t need major passing work to be effective for fantasy. Over the last two seasons, he’s averaged 340 rushes for 1783 yards and 16 rush TDs. His 378 rush attempts last year were the most since Demarco Murray’s 394 in 2014 for the Cowboys. Although he feasted on bad defenses (+5.69 fantasy points vs bottom-16 defenses) and weirdly was better on the road (+8.3 fantasy points), it’s hard to doubt him.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: In dynasty, Henry is a different story. He will turn 29 in early January 2022 and over the last eight years, there's been only one player inside the top-10 of Dynasty RB ADP over the age of 27 that maintained top-10 status the next year: Adrian Peterson. If you’re in win-now mode, you gotta ride with him. If not, trading now for a haul makes a ton of sense.

notes.text: Here's a fun fact: Landry is one of just seven wide receivers who've finished as a top-24 fantasy wide receiver in five of the last six years. The others are Julio Jones, Mike Evans, DeAndre Hopkins, Davante Adams, Brandin Cooks, and Amari Cooper. However, the issue is that Landry isn't the "sexy" pick that everyone wants because he's never going to be the reason you win a championship. With Odell Beckham due back to the lineup, it's only going to cap his upside even more, and therefore supress his ADP. You need balance on your fantasy roster and Landry can provide stability that not many have. Just keep your weekly expectations in check.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jarvis Landry
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Jarvis Landry has always been a reliable fantasy WR, but in Kevin Stefanski’s run heavy scheme last year, Jarvis saw the lowest target count of his career and produced his worst fantasy finish since 2015. Odell Beckham is back, and this offense will look to remain run heavy, limiting Jarvis’ upside in 2021. He’ll likely settle into the top-40 range come season’s end.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Jarvis Landry has been extremely reliable throughout his entire career, but he’s a WR who’s thrived thanks to volume and targets. If the Browns remain run heavy for the foreseeable future, it’s possible Landry has already reached his ceiling in terms of fantasy performance. Cleveland can move on from him easily after the 2021 season.

notes.text: Fairbairn had a fine season, converting 87.1% of his field-goal attempts and 37 extra-point attempts. But regardless of his accuracy, it's going to be a struggle fantasy-wise for him this season playing in what is surely going to be a subpar offense. With a team that should struggle to move the ball and is likely to be playing from behind most weeks, there's just little reason to consider Fairbairn in fantasy this year.

Prater had a poor fantasy season for several reasons. He attempted only 28 field goals and hardly made the most of them, converting only 21. That 75% field goal percentage was his worst since 2008, and his accuracy from long-range, usually his calling card, waned significantly, as he went just 10-for-17 from 40 yards or more (though he did set the NFL record for most career field goals of 50-yards or more). He signed a two-year deal with the Cardinals in the offseason and Arizona's fast-paced offense should allow for extra opportunities for Prater. He's not the kicker he once was, but he should see enough volume and have enough juice left in his leg to be a startable option.

We are finally going to see what Ryan looks like without Julio Jones. That doesn't sound appealing, does it? There's actually been 42 games in Ryan's career he's played without Jones. In those games, he's averaged 43.5 fewer yards, 0.13 fewer touchdowns, and 0.07 more interceptions, which may not sound like a lot, but it all adds up to 2.9 fewer fantasy points per game, and it's not as if Ryan was an elite fantasy starter with Jones. On top of that, Ryan has a new head coach, and one whose offenses have ranked 30th and 31st in pass attempts over the last two years. Ryan is going to be a streamer in 2021, so don't draft him as your every-week option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Matt Ryan
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We know what Ryan is at this point: a yardage monster who is a gamble in the TD department. He led the league in completions for the second year in a row but also in “interceptable” passes with 38, although his end of season line looks more acceptable with just 11 INTs.  He also paced the league in pass attempts with 626 but managed only 26 passing TDs, which has been his bugaboo in his career. The early offseason sentiment is that the Falcons were ready to move on but their moves recently have dictated they're ready to roll with him for at least another two years. He can easily finish inside the top-8 with new head coach Arthur Smith but you won’t have to draft him there. Expect more play-action passes and perhaps we'll see a flood of TDs. While Calvin Ridley has reached star status, Matt Ryan has struggled in the past without Julio on the field.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Falcons and owner Arthur Blank showed continued confidence in Ryan keeping him on the team while passing on young QBs in the draft. It seems like he has at least two more years in Atlanta in what should be a high-octane offense. Even without Julio, Ridley is clearly ready to step up and be the WR1 for this team.

notes.text: It seems the torch has been passed from Thielen to Justin Jefferson, though it's not as if Thielen will just fade into oblivion. It goes back to the Stefon Diggs days where he had to share that production. While Thielen did finish as the No. 8 wide receiver last year, it was thanks to his 14 touchdowns on just 74 receptions and 925 yards. No other receiver finished higher than No. 18 with fewer yards than Thielen. He's also going to be 31 years old at the start of the season and has a history of back issues, presenting a bit of risk, though he does have a ton of proven production with Kirk Cousins, which can't be ignored.

Adam Thielen was one of the best red-zone receivers in football last year, and all he gets for it is a place on this list.  We want to warn players about the otherworldly efficiency that Thielen had last season.  On just 13 red-zone targets, he ended up with 10 touchdowns.  These numbers are unlikely to repeat, and his volume has gone down in recent years.  He could surprise again, but banking on that level of touchdown efficiency is normally a bad bet.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Adam Thielen
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: “Ahhhhhhh--ahhhh--Hooked on a Thielen!” Or maybe not according to ADP... Adam Thielen looks like he’ll be a massive value in drafts with Justin Jefferson as the new hotness as fantasy managers look more excited to draft the younger Vikings WR. But let’s not forget - Thielen has finished as a top 10 WR three of the last four seasons, and he’s coming off a 14 TD season in 2020. The TD total should regress a bit, but he’s still locked in as Kirk Cousins’ favorite target in the red zone and should return WR2 value at a significant discount relative to 2020 ADP.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Adam Thielen has been a big fantasy contributor over the past few seasons, but his best football is probably behind him at this point. He’ll be 31 years old before the season starts, making him a player who should be rostered only by dynasty managers contending for a championship.

notes.text: Here's a fun fact: Prescott's 27.0 fantasy points per game in 2020 was the second-most all-time. What makes that stat even crazier is that his 4.05 percent touchdown rate was below the league average of 4.80 percent, so there was room for more. Of the top eight single-game performances by quarterbacks in 2020, there was only one quarterback on that list twice: Prescott, and he only played four full games. With the receiving weapons he has available, the sky is the limit, though his ankle injury could hamper his rushing upside in 2021. He's certainly someone who's going to throw for a lot of yards and touchdowns, but you need the rushing upside to get into the top-three conversation, so his risk bumps him out of that conversation.

Dak Prescott was on fire to start the 2020 season before it all came to a screeching halt. In Week 5, Dak suffered a fracture with dislocation of his right ankle. The Cowboys QB picked up a low-grade muscle strain in his right shoulder in late July during the first week of training camp. This injury was confirmed via MRI as a grade I strain of the latissimus dorsi, a muscle that is part of the shoulder complex and partially responsible for generating power in the throwing motion. This will be an injury to monitor but as of now, there isn’t concern regarding Dak’s regular-season availability. Expect him to miss the first 2-3 preseason games, however.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dak Prescott
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Through the first month of the season, Dak was on pace for 6,728 passing yards! His injury was devastating and completely sunk the rest of the Cowboys’ season. He got the bag this offseason and is set up as Dallas’ franchise guy after years of speculation. Dak is a legitimate MVP candidate and with a healthy offensive line, it’s not hard seeing him settle back in as a top-5 fantasy QB in 2021. UPDATE: Dak suffered a low-grade muscle strain in his right shoulder in late July during the first week of training camp. While he's likely to miss preseason games, he's expected to be ready for Week 1.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s a top-5 dynasty QB. Dak is the heart and soul of the Cowboys and he’s done nothing but produce as a fantasy starter.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Damien Williams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After nearly winning a Super Bowl MVP in 2019 and opting out of the 2020 season, Damien Williams found himself on the outside looking in at the Kansas City backfield. Now he joins the Bears with David Montgomery and Tarik Cohen. He’s not draftable.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Remember when Damien Williams hype was through the roof? He’s always been a replacement level player outside of Kansas City.

notes.text: When you put Stafford's fantasy career alongside his peers, he's essentially the same quarterback as Matt Ryan. The difference? Stafford hasn't had a play-caller to bring out the best in him for quite some time and it's crushed his fantasy upside. Welcome to L.A. where you'll be working with Sean McVay, whose offense has been handicapped with Jared Goff under center. Could this be the change Stafford needed to reach the next level? The only concern would be that the Rams defense is so good, we won't get the volume needed for a pocket passer like Stafford. He has upside to finish as a top-10 option, but knowing his limitations as a rusher (with back problems), he likely won't reach much higher than the QB8-QB10 range.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Matthew Stafford
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Matty snapback has long been a Footballers favorite and he moved on after 12 years in Detroit to Sean McVayville in Los Angeles. Stafford’s strengths of pinpoint accuracy and downfield passing should bolster a passing attack that totaled a paltry 20 passing TDs in 2020. Stafford had five games of three or more passing TDs last year, as many as Kyler Murray, but he can also disappear at times. With a plentiful array of WRs, Stafford and the Rams are set up for success. But for fantasy, Stafford might not touch the same passing volume he had in Detroit.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: It’s possible the Rams are a Super Bowl contender but Stafford is just mediocre for fantasy purposes. He has a two year window in Los Angeles before their cap situation falls apart.

notes.text: Lance currently isn’t the starting QB for his team. However, the actions of the team trading up and selecting him with the 3rd overall pick would indicate he will be starting sooner than later. If/When he takes that job, it will be a race to the waiver wire. His raw ability of arm talent and rushing ability should take him to a must-start fantasy QB immediately. He’s also surrounded by elite weapons. As of now Lance is worth the last pick in your draft and seeing if he can seize that starting gig.

The most talked-about pick of the draft finally ended with NDSU’s Trey Lance being unveiled as the 49ers “Man of Mystery”. Lance has a rocket arm and unbelievable rushing upside that makes him enticing running San Francisco’s West Coast offense. While the team has said Jimmy Garoppolo is the starter, it remains to be seen when the transition will take place to the talented Lance.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Trey Lance
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The most talked-about pick of the draft finally ended with NDSU’s Trey Lance being unveiled as the 49ers “Man of Mystery”. Lance has a rocket arm and unbelievable rushing upside that makes him enticing running San Francisco’s West Coast offense. While the team has said Jimmy Garoppolo is the starter, it remains to be seen when the transition will take place to the talented Lance.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Lance’s ceiling is someone who could break fantasy football scoring in a couple of years. He also comes with massive risks playing at the Division-II level and a lack of overall experience. Still, he’s young and at this point, it’s hard arguing with the success Kyle Shanahan has had molding QBs. In SuperFlex leagues, Lance is in consideration for the 2nd QB off the board with Justin Fields.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Carlos Hyde
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: There’s debate over how much of a role he will have sitting behind James Robinson and rookie Travis Etienne. He’s an Urban Meyer guy from Ohio State who actually looked fine last year in Seattle.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hyde’s spot at the end of your dynasty bench is nice and warm.

notes.text: It seems that Washington is going to utilize Antonio Gibson in the passing game much more often in 2021, which will come at the expense of McKissic. It's not just Gibson, either. The Football Team also signed Curtis Samuel in free agency, a player that's used in a hybrid role who gets plenty of intermittent targets, as well as a handful of carries per game. While McKissic was a hidden gem in PPR formats last year, it appears his role is shrinking in this offense. As someone who relies on volume to produce, McKissic is more of a passing-down handcuff to Gibson.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: J.D. McKissic
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Just give me a kiss! Our guy Smooches benefitted from having checkdown Charlie himself (Alex Smith) hitting him left and right last year out of the backfield. McKissic had the most routes run in the league en route to being the RB24 in Half PPR scoring. Over the last 20 years, he totalled the 2nd fewest rushing yards for a RB with 80+ receptions in a season. With Antonio Gibson likely taking a bigger weight coupled with Ryan Fitpatrick’s propensity to hyper target his receivers, McKissic is a low-end FLEX play at best in PPR leagues this year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: McKissic has bounced around the league and will be a free agent in 2022. You likely saw the best season of his career so if someone is willing to trade you for 2020’s stats, moving him now makes a ton of sense.

notes.text: Is it possible that Edwards is another version of Raheem Mostert? Someone who's never heavily used, but one who kills it with every opportunity he gets. He's averaged at least 5.0 yards per carry in each of his three seasons with the Ravens. Now that Mark Ingram is gone, it's possible we see Edwards top his 144-carry career mark from 2020, but the real issue is that he's obsolete in the passing game, totaling just 23 targets over 43 games. He's never caught more than two passes in a game. If J.K. Dobbins were to miss time, Edwards would be a solid RB2 in fantasy, though he'd be a bit more touchdown-dependent than most in that range.

The Gus Bus is a ticket you need to book for 2021 and not just as an insurance policy. Edwards will have standalone value this year because Baltimore doesn’t like to overload their backs. He’s averaged 5.2 yards per carry over three seasons running for 700+ yards in each. Even while J.K. Dobbins was on fire towards the end of the year, Edwards was by no means “phased-out” of the Baltimore attack as the RB16 from Weeks 12 to 16. Grab him as a valuable depth piece that you can FLEX in a pinch.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Gus Edwards
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Gus Bus is averaging over five yards per carry in his career and put up a respectable 726 rushing yards and six scores in 2020. The Ravens offered assigned second round tender so he’s coming back to Baltimore. Expect him to lose more touches to J.K. Dobbins as Edwards takes the lower side of a 60-40 split. He’s a solid depth piece for fantasy with the potential for a bigger impact if Dobbins went down.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The former UDFA is 26 years old and there’s no telling where he’ll be in 2022. He’s an early down specialist on a team bent on running the ball. If he signs somewhere else next year, consider his fantasy stock non-existent.

notes.text: I like Gibson, it's not that I don't. The issue is that he's not heavily involved in the passing game, and he topped 94 yards on the ground just twice all of last season, with both of those games coming against the Cowboys. In fact, 28.7 percent of his fantasy points in 2020 were against the Cowboys. I can certainly see Gibson finishing higher than my ranking, but those above him have either (a) a more consistent track record, or (b) less question marks. He scored a touchdown once every 15.5 carries last year, a number that's surely to go up.

News broke recently that Gibson’s turf toe injury from Week 13 last year has “lingered into the offseason” but at the same time, he’s “rehabbed well enough to make cuts.” While this may seem concerning on the surface, there’s reason to remain optimistic at this point in the offseason. Gibson was able to avoid surgery and return to play just last year just three weeks after injury (albeit at less than 100%). Typical return to play for a grade III (complete tear of the ligaments) injury ranges from 8-12 weeks if treated nonoperatively, and we already know Gibson was able to avoid surgery, suggesting this is not as significant as an injury as the one sustained by Patrick Mahomes. Unless Gibson suffered a setback in rehab (which has not yet been reported), I remain optimistic about Gibson’s health entering 2021, especially given that he is participating in OTA’s in June, sprinting and cutting. For now, it’s a situation to monitor, but if I’m drafting today, I’m not moving Gibson down my board.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Antonio Gibson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Gibson is the only rookie RB EVER with double-digit rushing TDs & 35+ receptions in fewer than 15 games played. Gibson was a top-12 fantasy back this past year and while he scored TDs at a ridiculously high rate, it's also possible we've seen the floor in terms of his workload. There's no chance J.D. McKissic will see the same sort of cheap checkdowns with Ryan Fitzpatrick now at the helm. Gibson's talent should shine through the situation in Washington and he certainly can hit top-5 at the position if things break right in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Oh baby! Gibson has exceeding even the loudest of hype trains and now looks like a top-15 dynasty player heading into 2021. With his passing volume likely going up even further, the window to trade for Gibson was probably a year ago.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Marquez Callaway
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After a modest rookie year in which he caught 21 of his 22 targets in only eight games played, Callaway suddenly finds himself with ample opportunity in 2021. With Michael Thomas presumably out the first half of the season, he could supplant Tre’Quan Smith as the top receiving weapon in New Orleans outside of Alvin Kamara and enter FLEX territory. The drumbeat news during the offseason can’t be ignored so consider Callaway a worthy late-round flier whose opportunity trumps other shaky WRs this late.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hopefully, you snagged Callway off the waiver wire earlier this offseason or had him stashed. These are the type of windows in dynasty that make the format so enticing. Callaway is only 23 so maybe there's some hidden gold for 2021 and beyond.

notes.text: In eight full games with Justin Herbert under center last year, Ekeler saw 63 targets. Over a full 16-game season, that amounts to 126 targets. While I don't expect him to get there, he's one of just two running backs (Christian McCaffrey is the other) who I'm projecting for 100-plus targets in 2021. Targets are worth twice as much as carries, so even if Ekeler winds up getting just 12 carries per game, it's not the end of the world. In fact, he can still finish as a borderline RB1 if he were to hit just 200 carries on the season. The new coaching staff obviously brings on some potential volatility, but there's not much other talent on the roster at running back, so his role should be very safe.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Austin Ekeler
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Good friend of the show, Awesome Excellence was all set to dominate the fantasy rankings last year as the team’s clear-cut lead back with Melvin Gordon III finally gone. Instead, an early hamstring injury decimated any hopes for the pass-catching specialist to build off of his 2019 RB6 breakout. The Chargers improved their offense line and didn’t add any real competition in the backfield.The only thing holding Ekeler back is his lack of usage in the Red Zone as he had only two carries inside the 5-yard line. Ekeler is an awesome fantasy asset that has weekly top-10 upside, especially in PPR leagues.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Ekeler is under contract for three more years under a team-friendly deal. Still only 26, the only thing holding him back from being a top-10 back the next few years might be the lack of goal-line work. But the receptions are PPR gold...

notes.text: While Robinson was on the field last year, the Jaguars running backs combined for 332 touches. Robinson accounted for 289 of them, or 87.0 percent, a number that doesn't really exist in today's NFL. He averaged 4.46 yards per carry, 5.73 yards per target, and scored 10 total touchdowns, which is solid, though nothing special. Enter Urban Meyer, who said they wanted to add depth/competition at the running back position. After adding Carlos Hyde, you knew Robinson would lose some touches, but it wasn't that much of a concern. After drafting Travis Etienne in the first round, it's definitely a concern. Robinson would be lucky to earn a 50/40/10 split with Etienne and Hyde, with Robinson being the 40 of the group. If we knock Robinson's touches into the 10-12 per game territory, you're not going to be trusting him as anything more than a shaky flex option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: James Robinson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We just witnessed the greatest season ever for an undrafted rookie. Robinson was a usage monster with the most touches (289) ever by an undrafted rookie RB. Carlos Hyde will chip away at his early-down touches and Travis Etienne was a 1st Round pick this year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The window of trading Robinson promptly shut after the NFL Draft.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jalen Richard
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Jon Gruden has a weird obsession with Richard. The team had the chance to cut him for next to nothing this off-season and promptly decided to sign a Richard clone in Theo Riddick. He has no value even in PPR leagues.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He should be chilling on your waiver wire like Jason on a block of ice during a hot Arizona summer day.

notes.text: Going to a new team is never easy, especially for someone who's coming from a team that was lacking any depth of pass catchers. It was easy for him to get eight-plus targets per game, especially when Marvin Jones was hurt. Now going to the Giants, who have a bevy of options, including Sterling Shepard, Kadarius Toney, Darius Slayton, Evan Engram, Kyle Rudolph, and Saquon Barkley is going to be tough. To be fair, you don't go out in free agency and sign someone like Golladay to give him five targets per game, but he's not going to get the consistent targets he got in Detroit, and the targets he does get aren't going to be as efficient coming from Daniel Jones.

Fantasy managers won't forget Kenny Golladay missed Weeks 9-17 last year with an undisclosed hip injury. By now, this is completely healed and should be a non-issue moving forward. However, Golladay also missed Weeks 1-2 due to a hamstring issue he picked up during training camp last season and during his rookie season in 2017, Golladay missed 5 games thanks to a strained hamstring. I bring this up because on August 3, Golladay left Giants practice early, grabbing the back of his left thigh, which is usually the tell-tale sign of a hamstring strain. As of this writing, we don't have any more information, but it's reasonable to expect Golladay to miss practice time early in August. His status will be updated once we get more information on his most recent injury.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kenny Golladay
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We all needed some more smooth routes in our life in 2020. Kenny G's move to New York was one of the bigger free agent signings, but for fantasy, may struggle to break into the top-12 WRs. He made his money in Detroit on a plethora of end-zone targets and deep passes on low target numbers. Will Kenny G finally see the targets he deserves? Daniel Jones has been more than capable down the field but whether this team will have the scoring opportunities fantasy managers want is another question mark. When you add upa rough training camp with HC Joe Judge's tough guy antics, infighting among the team, and Golladay's hamstring woes, his fantasy stock is pointing down heading into drafts.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Golladay signed a massive 4-year, $52 million deal to be the Giants’ WR1 for the next handful of seasons, but if Daniel Jones can’t get it going, will Golladay waste his prime years playing for the G-men? His QB situation will likely determine his upside for the next 3-4 years.

notes.text: Badgley may have had the most points in his young career, but it was hardly a banner season for him. He missed nine of his 33 field-goal attempts as well as three extra-point attempts. A 72.7% accuracy rate on field goals isn't going to cut it in the NFL, so expect the Chargers to allow for some competition at their kicker position this year. If Badgley wins the job, and recaptures his 2018-2019 form, then he should be a borderline starter in fantasy leagues this season.

Carlson had an outstanding 2020 season, converting 94.3% of his field-goal attempts and missing just two of his 47 extra-point attempts. Kickers are notoriously fickle, and Carlson is evidence of that, as he's converted 94.1%, 73.1%, and 94.3% of his field-goal attempts since joining the Raiders. In other words, it's worth drafting Carlson in a standard-sized league, but he's far from a guarantee in terms of his success.

The article I write every year titled, "Boom, Bust, and Everything In Between," highlights the both the consistency a player offers, as well as his upside. Carr has no upside. Over the last two years under Jon Gruden, Carr has played 32 games. In those games, he's delivered QB1-type performances just 14 times (43.8 percent), and a "boom" performance just one time (3.1 percent). I'd rather take shots on the rookie quarterbacks who might not start out of the gate, as Carr certainly wouldn't be your QB1.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Derek Carr
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Through the first six games, his TD:INT ratio was 13:2 with a 72% completion rate. The Raiders were actually in the playoff hunt for much of the year after starting 6-3 including a win in Arrowhead against the Chiefs. Carr set career highs in passing yards, yards per completion & QB Rating and yet you wouldn’t know it based on Jon Gruden’s resting angry face. He’s a fine real life NFL QB who typically is streamable in plus matchups throughout the year. We don’t advise drafting him in redraft with few proven weapons outside of Darren Waller.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Carr could certainly be looking for new employment after 2021. He’s an expiring asset that you kind of just have to hold onto at this point.

notes.text: Is it possible that Cohen is this generations Darren Sproles? Looking at their Boom, Bust, and Everything In Between numbers, they're nearly identical, as both posted RB2 or better numbers 39 percent of the time, though Cohen has delivered RB3 or better numbers 61 percent of the time to Sproles' 56 percent. Cohen is still in the same offense that gave him those numbers and with what should be a much better quarterback (regardless of Dalton or Fields) under center, leading a higher scoring offense. He's never going to be someone who wins you a fantasy league single-handedly, but he's someone who can certainly contribute in your flex spot, and he costs next to nothing.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tarik Cohen
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The “Dinosaur Hunter” was sidelined after a devastating, season-ending injury in Week 3. In the past, Cohen made his mark in fantasy in the passing game while Chicago flipped through early-down runners. With David Montgomery established, Cohen is left getting the slim pickings of 3-4 targets a game and the occasional rushing attempt. He’s a gadget player at this point and ranks outside of drafting territory.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Cohen will turn 26 and while he has three years left on his deal, he’s an obvious cut candidate in 2022. Hang onto him in PPR leagues but know we’ve likely seen the best fantasy days of the diminutive “Dinosaur Hunter”.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Justin Jackson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Jackson’s opportunity to step up into a bigger role after Austin Ekeler was injured was unfortunately cut short due to his own injuries. He’s never been able to stay on the field and it looks like he’ll face more competition this year with rookie Larry Rountree III in the mix as well.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Jackson’s time to shine seems to be coming to a close. He’ll be an unrestricted free agent in 2022 and will be lucky to find a role as a 3rd stringer.

notes.text: We were hoping to see a second-year jump from Knox, but what we got was essentially the same thing we saw his rookie season. This has led to us hearing about the Bills exploring a trade for Evan Engram, as well as Zach Ertz. They signed Jacob Hollister, who's expected to compete for the starting job, though with all the receiving options they have, it's not likely either provides much fantasy value. There were just three occasions where a Bills tight end saw more than four targets last year, which means you'll use them in streaming situations. It's tough envisioning any sort of breakout season from Knox.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Dawson Knox
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It’s wild that the Bills would rank 3rd in points per game (29.9) and 2nd in yards per game (396.4) with such little production from the TE position. The Buffalo TE group as a whole sadly put up the 6th fewest points in the league. While Knox missed four games, he averaged a paltry 4.6 fantasy points per game when he did play. He’s a fun real-life NFL player with little fantasy value despite being connected with Josh Allen.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Knox’s slim dynasty hopes were dashed last year so while he’s still a starting TE in the NFL, he’s moved from potentially a thing to “sure, have him on your roster”.

notes.text: I was all aboard the value train with Rodgers last year, but now that he's coming off his 2020 MVP campaign, he's going to be drafted higher than I'm willing to go. Why? His touchdown rate was 9.1 percent in 2020. Every quarterback who's ever finished with a touchdown rate of 8.5 percent or more has regressed the following season. If we dial that number back to Rodgers' career mark of 6.3 percent, which is still elite, he would've finished as the QB10 instead of the QB2 that he did. He doesn't offer mobility anymore and his offense isn't what we'd describe as "pass heavy." Don't forget that many left him for dead after the 2019 season when he posted QB1-type numbers just 31.3 percent of the time. There's probably an in-between here, but that's the issue: I'm unwilling to pay for last year's performance. In reality, he's a safe QB1 who requires an ultra-high touchdown-rate to finish top-five. The same can be said about Tom Brady, who is likely to come a few rounds later in drafts.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Aaron Rodgers
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Hope you enjoyed your Green Bay Packers offseason circus. Rodgers proved all of his naysayers wrong as he went out and put up an MVP season at the age of 37. On top of 48 passing TDs, he was especially lethal inside the red-zone leading the league with a 73 percent completion rate and 35 passing TDs. With Davante Adams as his partner in crime in 2021, Rodgers is a threat for 40+ TDs again.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: It appears the 2020 MVP is back with the Packers for at least the 2021 season. He'll be 38 at the end of the year, and who knows what next offseason holds. If you have good QB depth, it may be worth exploring deals to move Rodgers for solid value while you can.

notes.text: We certainly watched Thomas break out last season, particularly from Week 6 forward. Head coach Ron Rivera said a lightbulb went off for him, and it led to him finishing as the No. 3 tight end through his final 11 games, behind only Travis Kelce and Darren Waller. The issue with expecting that continue into 2021? Well, there are many variables. The Football Team went out and acquired Ryan Fitzpatrick - who's never targeted tight ends heavily - as well as Curtis Samuel in free agency, Dyami Brown in the draft, and they've vowed to give Antonio Gibson more work this year. Volume is everything for tight ends, and if we can't guarantee it for Thomas, he's not worthy of an early-round pick. There's still certainly an avenue for 100 targets; it's just not guaranteed. Thomas should be considered a mid-to-low-end TE1.

Logan Thomas outperformed even the most generous expectations of him last year.  This season, he'll remain involved in the offense but may see his total volume decline significantly.  The addition of Curtis Samuel and the change from check-down-happy Alex Smith to Ryan Fitzpatrick might make his week-in-and-week-out performances far more choppy.  Be careful with what you expect from Logan Thomas.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Logan Thomas
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Thomas was an incredible story last year as the former QB broke through as Washington's reliable short-area pass-catcher alongside J.D. McKissic. But that likely was the best season we'll ever see from him as circumstances and the lack of other weapons in Washington force-fed him with some cheap targets including a 16(!) target game against Seattle. He’s a fine late round TE who likely will end up more as a streamer than an every week starter.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He'll turn 30 years old and is a free agent in 2022. Trading him now to a TE-needy makes sense if you can receive future picks or another depth piece.

notes.text: When the Packers drafted Amari Rodgers, who has a lot of Randall Cobb to his game, Lazard's projection became unclear. He was the Packers primary slot receiver last year, playing 53 percent of his snaps in the slot. So, it's either they move Marquez Valdes-Scantling to the bench and put Lazard in his place, or all three of them rotate on the field, which is certainly not ideal for fantasy purposes. Lazard had his shot at a breakout, but unfortunately, it didn't happen.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Allen Lazard
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It's been a while since a second wide receiver has provided consistent fantasy production in Green Bay. With Rodgers back, Lazard could be a late-round WR with flex appeal on some weeks.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Lazard's future is a wildcard. Not only because of his one-year deal with the Packers, but because of Aaron Rodgers' uncertain future with the Packers.

notes.text: Everett signed a one-year $6 million deal to fly north to division rival Seattle. He's always had raw talent since the Rams took him in the 2nd round (44th overall) four years ago. He's easily the most talented TE to work with Russell Wilson since Jimmy Graham and could be in a position to steal some red-zone looks from D.K. Metcalf. He's always had encouraging metrics (yards per route run, SPARQ score) that suggest there's more meat on the bone for fantasy. He can easily outperform his current ADP and could end up being more than just a streamer in 2021.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Gerald Everett
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: His move to Seattle might seem ancillary but Everett has always been talented since the Rams took him in the 2nd round. The Seahawks were familiar with him as he's had a couple of monster games against them. If you still believe in Will Dissly, we understand based on “Big Montana” lore alone. Everett is another one of those TE dart throws who could work out on your roster... or the waiver wire.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Everett is a fine TE2 with the athletic profile to potentially have fantasy value in 2021. He’s someone worth asking for as a trade throw-in.

notes.text: It's not the start to his career that he hoped for, as Penny has totaled just 161 carries over his first three seasons in the league. While on the field, he was productive with his touches, but he failed to bounce back from his ACL injury in 2020, an injury that not many have had problems coming back from. It seemed he may finally get his opportunity to claim this backfield in 2021, but the Seahawks decided to re-sign Chris Carson to a pricey contract, locking Penny into the backup role. He's a solid handcuff, but one who hasn't been able to stay healthy himself.

Pete Carroll told reporters on Wednesday, June 16 that Rashaad Penny underwent a cleanup procedure on the same knee that he injured in 2019. Penny barely contributed to the Seahawks in 2020 as he was still limited early in the year given the lengthy recovery from his December 2019 ACL injury. Remember, Penny’s ACL injury was more complex, which likely involved a meniscus injury. This, combined with the news of a subsequent surgery does not bode well for Penny’s 2021 outlook and beyond, as each surgical intervention that’s required will accelerate the rate of developing arthritis in the knee joint. At this point, the cards are stacked against the former 1st round NFL Draft pick.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Rashaad Penny
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The former 1st round draft pick has gone from hyped to hurt to does this guy still play in the NFL? He’s scored six total TDs in three years and with Chris Carson re-signed, he’s a backup soon to be out the door. For redraft, he should not be rostered.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Seahawks rightly declined his 5th year option. He’s one of the many examples of why NFL teams spending 1st round draft capital on a RB is a losing proposition.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Mo Alie-Cox
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Gigantor! Mo-Alie Cox is the largest human in existence. Ok maybe not but he looks that way out on the football field and could have a chance to break through as more than just a fun story in 2021. Trey Burton is gone and Jack Doyle’s baby hands are nothing compared to Alie-Cox’s mitts. He actually started out last year hot with three TE1 performances as the TE13 through the first month of the season. He’s never going to see much volume so he’s more of a hope & a prayer that he boxes out defenders in the end-zone and comes down with a score.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you believed when no one else did, now is the time to see Gigantor potentially start a game or two on your dynasty roster. Oh, did you know he played basketball?

notes.text: How the mighty have fallen... Just a few years removed of being the Patriots first round pick, Michel finds himself fighting for touches in this backfield. It appears Damien Harris is the starter, while James White handles passing down work, and Rhamondre Stevenson and Michel fight for the scraps. Is it possible that Michel's injury last year has us overlooking his potential? He may have only had 79 carries last year, but he did average a massive 5.7 yards per carry on them. Maybe he's just better in a timeshare? This backfield is a mess, especially if Cam Newton is under center.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Sony Michel
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The former 1st round draft pick has seen better fantasy days. He’s an early-down-only RB who has sputtered the last two seasons to show anything on the field. With Damien Harris and Rhamondre Stevenson in the mix, Michel could be the odd man out for that role.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: After declining his 5th year option, Michel will have to find a new home for 2022. He feels like he’s 30 years old (he’s only 26) but maybe that’s how his body has betrayed him.

notes.text: The Raiders were high on Edwards during last year's draft process, though injuries derailed his progress. Once Nelson Agholor left, it felt like Edwards might be starting in 2WR sets, though they quickly replaced Agholor with the veteran John Brown. Still, Edwards is the only notable receiver on the team who's over six-feet tall and can play that go-to role they seek outside of Darren Waller. We've also heard Derek Carr say that Edwards reminded him of his former teammate in college, Davante Adams, which is never a bad thing.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Bryan Edwards
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Bryan Edwards missed most of last year with a high ankle sprain. Now, he’s looking at a WR depth chart consisting of an aging John Brown, an unproven Henry Ruggs and slot WR Hunter Renfrow. He's a dart throw at the end of your draft if you want to believe the hype.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Edwards was a dynasty darling of 2020 rookie drafts, consistently being taken in the middle of the 2nd round for perceived upside. His analytical profile from his college days (94th percentile dominator rating, 17.8 breakout age) makes him a speculative trade target on the cheap in dynasty leagues.

notes.text: What Herbert did in 2020 was miraculous. There's no two ways about it. To be handed the starting job just one hour before the game in Week 2, then go on to break the rookie record for passing touchdowns (31) is ridiculous. Now, with that being said, he still finished as the QB9 last year while throwing 595 pass attempts, the fourth most in the legaue. Now that he's got a defensive-minded head coach and a healthy defense, we could see the pass attempts dip a bit in 2021, which would certainly hurt his appeal. The Chargers did increase the talent on the offensive line, but also replaced Hunter Henry with Jared Cook, which is a certainly a downgrade. Herbert should still be a solid low-end QB1, but it's tough to see him finishing as a top-five option in 2021.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Justin Herbert
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We just witnessed the greatest rookie QB passing season of all-time as Herbert was unbelievable from the get-go. His 31 passing TDs gets the press but he also set the rookie record for completion percentage (66.5) for any QB with 500+ pass attempts. Herbert led all QBs with completions under pressure and 3rd down passing TDs. With a healthy Keenan Allen and Austin Ekeler, Herbert looks to have a high-floor but will be in the conversation of top-8 QBs selected come draft time.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Herbert looks like a steady dynasty asset for years to come. He’s just outside of that elite tier as he doesn’t have quite the rushing upside of others. Nevertheless, after the Chargers addressed their offensive line issues this offseason, his floor remains high like a young Matt Ryan but we also could envision a ceiling to go nuclear like post-Favre Aaron Rodgers.

notes.text: There was a time where people were excited about what Boykin might bring to the table. That time has passed, as he's now entering his third season with just 32 receptions under his belt. He's actually performed solid on a per-target basis, but his opportunity is gone with the additions of Rashod Bateman, Sammy Watkins, and Tylan Wallace to the wide receiver depth chart. He wasn't fantasy relevant without them, so he sure as heck won't be with them.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Miles Boykin
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Boykin’s outlook took a massive hit after free agency and the 2021 NFL Draft. Already the most run heavy system in the NFL, the Ravens added Sammy Watkins, Rashod Bateman and Tylan Wallace. Boykin belongs on the waiver wire.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Boykin is likely going to need a change of scenery to be fantasy viable. The only issue? He’s still got two years left on his rookie deal.

notes.text: Smith's talent was not put on display nearly enough with the Titans, as he never saw more than 65 targets in a single season. Despite that, he finished as a top-12 tight end in 2020. The Patriots were aggressive with him, signing him the first day of free agency to a four-year, $50 million deal, which tells us all we need to know: They aren't going to hide him. The signing of Hunter Henry hurt his projection a bit, but the drafting of Mac Jones improved it a bit because once he takes over as the starter, this team will throw a lot more. Once you get outside the top five tight ends, you're chasing upside, and Smith has plenty of it.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jonnu Smith
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Jonnu scored a huge free agent contract but the fantasy community could not be more sad. The bruising after-the-catch specialist now must split targets with Hunter Henry and likely will see more snaps run-blocking than you’d prefer. He’s still intriguing given his athletic profile but he’s out of redraft territory on a low volume pass offense for 2021.
