ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s only 26 and still has a ton of good football in front of him. Jonnu is probably a better real-life NFL player than what actually translates for fantasy. He’s a hold for now as trading him away for pennies on the dollar is not worth it.

notes.text: Follow the production in the first round. There's just one player who's finished as a top-12 running back five times since 2015. That player is Elliott, and as crazy as it sounds, he wasn't even in the league in 2015. "But Mike, Elliott tanked last year to RB11." The entire team sank without Dak Prescott, but in the five games with him, Elliott was the No. 3 running back in fantasy. If he keeps falling until the end of the first round, there will be a lot of championship rosters from that area of drafts.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Ezekiel Elliott
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Zeke is going to be a name to watch in drafts because there’s a narrative going around that he’s somehow “old busted”. Losing Dak Prescott early and having an offensive line decimated with injuries did not help his cause at all. He still finished as an RB1, something he’s done every year of his career. If he slips towards the back of the 1st round, we’re bullish on his opportunity in 2022.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Zeke feels like he’s been around forever but he’s still only 25 years old. If you can trade him for a haul and someone else views him as a top-5 back, it’s probably forward-thinking. But don’t rush to trade him just for the sake of it.

notes.text: It's been odd to watch Isabella not gain a bigger role in the offense over the last two years while Larry Fitzgerald faded into oblivion. He's only received 48 targets over his first two years in the league, though they've netted 413 yards and three touchdowns, so it's not like he wasn't productive with them. The issue is that we now have DeAndre Hopkins, A.J. Green, and then a trio of second-round picks fighting behind them. Moore, who was drafted at 49 overall this year, Kirk who was drafted at 47 overall three years ago, and Isabella, who was drafted at 62 overall. If they didn't give Isabella the nod over Fitzgerald last year, I can't see it happening, especially when they chose to draft another second-round receiver.

Despite Odell Beckham missing most of the 2020 season, Hooper wound up with just 70 targets on his new team. Sure, Hooper himself missed three games, but we also watched rookie Harrison Bryant making a name for himself, and will likely get more targets in 2021. With tight ends, you need someone who'll consistently get 5-6 targets per game, or you're streaming the position. With Beckham back and Bryant ascending in his career, you're not going to get a consistent 5-6 targets per game out of Hooper, making him a streamer.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Austin Hooper
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: After signing a massive deal last off-season, the big question was whether his numbers in Atlanta were inflated and how that would translate to Cleveland. Unfortunately, injuries somewhat slowed him down, missing three games and not coming on strong until the final three weeks of the season. The passing volume is fairly low and the Browns’ identity is running the ball on the ground. The upside just isn’t there to see anything more than a low-end TE1 on the horizon for Hoops.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The big contract was an illusion to thinking Hooper was going to remain an elite fantasy TE. He has a bloated deal with the Browns unable to get out of this deal until 2023 at the earliest. Still, he’s only 26 and this team should be in playoff contention.

notes.text: We've been saying, "just wait until the Vikings get rid of Kyle Rudolph." That was when we were supposed to see Smith's breakout. Well, unfortunately for him, Justin Jefferson came around. Despite the Vikings inflating their pass attempts last year, the combination of Rudolph and Smith netted just 80 targets. Even if Smith received all of Rudolph's departed targets, that's no guarantee to net top-12 production. Their defense should get back on track this year, and it's not like Jefferson will become less involved. You shouldn't be paying for top-12 production, but rather hoping for it.

Over the final four games of the season, Irv Smith established more playing time and knocked out multiple top-3 finishes at the position. He’s not likely to become a volume play, but a dart throw TE for a QB that just threw 35 TDs is a decent dart to throw.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Irv Smith Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: BIG IRV! Smith is a borderline TE1 who came on strong towards the end of last year when Kyle Rudolph was out. He’s always been talented since the Vikings took him 50th overall in 2019. His opportunity is there although it remains to be seen if there is enough volume outside of Justin Jefferson and Adam Thielen to feed him regularly for fantasy. He’s a great high upside option for 2021 but don’t be surprised if fellow TE Tyler Conklin is annoyingly on the field more than you think.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: With Rudolph now out the door, Smith managers have the scenario they envisioned of seeing him assert himself as a breakout TE. He isn’t yet 23 and the arrow is pointing up for Big Irv.

notes.text: If there's one thing Cook has going for him with the Chargers, it's that he knows the offense that's being installed by Joe Lombardi. Unfortunately, that's the only thing. He's now 34 years old, starting over with a new quarterback who certainly played favorites last year, and Hunter Henry wasn't even one of them. Prior to playing with Drew Brees, Cook had never topped six touchdowns in a season, so dialing back expectations would be wise. He could be a solid streamer in projected shootouts, but relying on him every week wouldn't be wise.

It seems like every single year our guy Cook is disrespected because it feels like he’s been around forever. Yep, he came into the league in 2009, when Justin Herbert was a middle schooler and new coach Brandon Staley was the defensive line coach at the University of St. Thomas. Since we’re strolling down memory lane, for the first 133 games of his career (2009-2017) Cook looked like a bust with only 19 total receiving TDs. Over his last 36 games (2018-2020), he also has 19 TDs. He’s become a legitimate red-zone weapon and right now you can get him with the last pick in your draft

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jared Cook
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Jared Cyook! Over the last couple of years, Cook has affectionately become an annual steal in drafts as a back-end TE1 who can have stretches of elite production. In 2020, he finished with seven games of double-digit fantasy points, as many as Mark Andrews. In Los Angeles, he’s paired up with Justin Herbert and an offense that should be top-10 in the league in points per game. If you want to roll with him out of the gate as your TE in Week 1, go for it.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Cook came into the league during the first year of the Obama administration. He's 34 and running on the last tank of gas. But he’s still a viable top-15 TE for at least one more season with LAC.

notes.text: It seemed like the Rams wanted to stretch the middle of the field with Kupp at times over the last couple years, though Jared Goff's inability to accurately throw the ball downfield hindered Kupp's upside. Of the eight deep targets he saw in 2020, just one was catchable. Kupp's not a burner by any means, but if he doesn't have splash plays, he's not going to be anything more than a boring PPR asset. There's more to his game than what we've seen, and it's possible that Matthew Stafford unlocks it. He should be treated as a safe, high-floor WR2.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Cooper Kupp
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It was an up and down year for Cooper Kupp and the entire Rams passing attack last season, thanks largely in part to the Rams being one of the NFL’s run heaviest teams from inside the red zone. As a result, Kupp saw a significant hit in the TD department, hitting pay dirt just three times all season. He had ten receiving TDs the year before, and six TDs in just eight games played in 2018. With Jared Goff out and Matthew Stafford now under center, Kupp gets a QB upgrade with a good chance of having a bounce back year, scoring more TDs.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The Rams continue to add to their WR depth chart with mid round picks, but Cooper Kupp is locked up for multiple seasons after signing an extension last offseason and now he’s got the chance to play with the best QB of his career. He looks like a rock solid WR2/3 for the next couple of seasons.

notes.text: Despite seeing a solid 14.2 percent target share last year, White was a non-factor in fantasy. Cam Newton wasn't throwing touchdowns, and he was stealing all the touchdowns near the goal line. Not that White gets many opportunities around the goal line, as he only totaled 35 carries last year, but the lack of touchdowns destroyed his usability. If Newton is still under center in 2021, White's going to have similar problems. If Mac Jones were to take over as the starter, it might inject some life back into White, as the offense would certainly be passing the ball more.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: James White
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It feels like he’s been in New England forever but perhaps you’re merging together Shane Vereen, Danny Woodhead, and anyone else who has played that pass-catching role in New England. His skill set is still valuable and he’ll continue to be a valuable 3rd down back for the Patriots. Nevertheless, the passing volume is much lower these days in New England making White a fringe draft pick in redraft leagues.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The trading window for White was three or four years ago.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jordan Howard
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Last year Howard was crowned as one of the “fantasy winners” after the NFL draft with Miami’s backfield having little competition. While he actually led the team in rushing TDs with four, Howard played a total of 50(!) snaps before bouncing back to the Eagles. He’s a plodder and a zero in the passing game. With Miles Sanders, Boston Scott, Kenneth Gainwell, and Kerryon Johnson also on the roster, there is no guarantee he makes this team.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Howard was once a top-10 dynasty RB after his rookie year. He’s now barely top-10 on the Eagles roster. Don’t waste your time rostering him.

notes.text: I do an article every year highlighting which players performed better than expected based on where their touches took place, as well as how many carries/targets they receive. Aaron Jones has finished No. 7, No. 4, No. 4, and No. 16 over the last four years on that list, which highlights just how good he is. During that time, he's scored 143.4 more fantasy points than the average running back would've. Him and Alvin Kamara are much more similar than most realize. You take proven production at the top of drafts, and Jones has proven it time-and-time again. If Aaron Rodgers doesn't ever show up to the Packers, he does lose a bit of his touchdown upside, though.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Aaron Jones
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Jones is an efficiency monster who has the type of explosion performances that can win you a week. Last year, he saw the ninth most targets among RBs and the 4th highest yards per touch at RB. With back-to-back top-5 fantasy finishes, the only other person in the backfield that could challenge Jones is behemoth A.J. Dillon. The Packers offense could be due for some TD regression. The Packers are still the class of the NFC North and should be in contention for the Super Bowl meaning Jones is a locked-in RB1 for 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Jones’ outlook moving forward needs some more context as his “four-year” contract extension has a clear out for the Packers in two years. He’ll turn 27 years old this year and if we’ve seen any sort of historical indicator as of late, it’s that free agent RBs don’t end up finishing out their contract extensions. You can likely bank on at least two more years of top-end production barring an injury and A.J. Dillon’s thighs taking over. But if your league mates value Jones as a top-5 RB right now given the explosion of fantasy points we’ve seen from him over the last two years, be willing to trade for a haul.

notes.text: Despite being an freakish athlete, Fant was an incredibly boring fantasy asset to roster in 2020, finishing with 35-57 yards in 9-of-15 games, while failing to top 81 yards in any one game. The issue stems from his quarterback, as the targets are simply not that valuable, because 93 of them (what Fant saw) is more than enough to be a reliable fantasy asset. Unfortunately, we don't know if Drew Lock will still be the quarterback, and the Broncos have Courtland Sutton returning to the lineup, which will surely cut into Fant's target share. On top of that, the team seemed to like using both Fant and Albert Okwuegbunam prior to Okwuegbunam's injury last year, which is another ding on Fant's fantasy stock. He's fine, but unless there's a change at quarterback, he's nothing you can't live without.

Fant enters his 3rd year in the league after being selected in the 1st round by Denver yet it feels like he’s been a disappointment to fantasy managers. He’s still gifted athletically, averaging over 12 yards per reception in his first two years. If this Denver passing offense somehow is redirected through Drew Lock or Teddy Bridgewater, Fant could be a major beneficiary and a weekly startable TE, which doesn’t grow on trees folks! He’s one of the few later TEs that could move into the top-5 this season.

Fant picked up a high ankle sprain in Week 4 last year then sat out the Broncos Week 5 bye and their Week 6 game. Upon returning to the lineup in Week 7, Fant was clearly playing at less than 100%, which isn’t surprising considering he returned just three weeks out from injury. The Denver TE showed some toughness playing through injury for multiple weeks, but he should be able to be even better in 2021 given that he’ll be fully healthy entering the team’s offseason program.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Noah Fant
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: We’ve yet to truly see Noah Fantastic sustain fantasy production for long periods of time. While he technically finished as the TE12 on the back of the sixth most targets and receiving yards at the position, he scored double-digit fantasy points a grand total of three times on the year. The pass-catching weapons in Denver are plentiful so it will be hard for him to match even the 18.3 target share he saw. Fant is still tantalizing knowing his 1st round pedigree and after-the-catch-ability. He’s in that middle tier of TEs and could be an every week start if Drew Lock or Teddy Bridgewater stabilize this offense.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Coming into his 3rd year in the league, this is the time when young TEs breakout. Hold onto Fant in hopes of that tier jump and the slim chance he’s paired with Aaron Rodgers. If that happens, WE GO TO THE MOON!

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Marquez Valdes-Scantling
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Once again he'll be among the WR corps behind Davante Adams, with a few splash weeks. He could be a desperate boom/bust flex play for your fantasy roster but will be disappointing most weeks.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: MVS will remain a desperation flex play, likely on someone's bench in dynasty leagues.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Tim Patrick
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Poor Tim. His name isn’t exactly intimidating and although he was arguably the team’s most consistent WR in 2020, he’s getting buried behind Courtland Sutton and Jerry Jeudy in 2021 ADP. He averaged almost 13 fantasy points per game from mid-September to early December (if you throw out the immortal Kendall Hinton game) and the Broncos placed a second round tender on him. Unfortunately, he won’t see enough volume to be fantasy relevant in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: At 27 years old, Patrick’s 2020 campaign was likely a blip on the radar. He has one year left in Denver and then who knows.

notes.text: It was good to see Samuel finally have his breakout season in year four, though it's worth noting that his numbers have improved every year. The issue, however, is that he's being reunited with offensive coordinator Scott Turner, who couldn't get the most out of Samuel during the 2019 season. While Samuel saw a career-high 106 targets that year, he averaged a minuscule 5.9 yards per target while used in an incorrect role. Will that change? It's tough to say, but Terry McLaurin, J.D. McKissic, Antonio Gibson, and Logan Thomas are all competition for targets with his new team. Samuel should have plenty of manufactured touches, but don't automatically assume he's as valuable as he was in 2020.

Samuel missed all of Washington’s June mini-camp with a groin issue, and it appears he is still battling the same injury now in training camp after landing on the PUP list. Reports out of Washington indicate that the team is not concerned about their WR’s injury, but it is worth noting that this injury has been an issue dating back to OTAs in late May. Assuming this is a groin strain, his recovery timeline suggests this is a moderate strain. These injuries can be tricky, as they’re stressed with dynamic lateral movements, which are crucial for wide receivers coming in and out of their breaks. Washington may be conservative with Samuel in the preseason as an aggravation of this injury over the next few weeks could possibly lead to concerns regarding his Week 1 availability. This is an injury to monitor leading up to fantasy drafts.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Curtis Samuel
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Reunited with OC Scott Turner and head coach Ron Rivera, Samuel is very familiar with this system. Two years ago when he last played in Turner’s system in Carolina, Samuel ranked 9th in air yards and now he gets to play with a QB in Fitzmagic who loves to push the ball downfield. Despite starting training camp on the PUP list, Samuel has sneaky upside in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Samuel signed a 3-year deal this offseason to land in Washington, and now he’s got a coaching staff who knows how to use him. McLaurin and Samuel can form an exciting 1-2 punch for multiple seasons. Most managers view Samuel as a WR3/4 in dynasty, but we still haven’t seen his ceiling. Now is the time to buy before it’s too late.

notes.text: Williams has shown his talent when he has been on the field, but health - or a lack thereof - has limited him to just 16 games in his two-year career. He underwent surgery on his foot in November and even if he returns to full health, he's likely going to be in merely a depth role with Will Fuller, Jaylen Waddle, and DeVante Parker in front of him. There's little reason to consider him in pretty much any fantasy format this year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Preston Williams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Preston Williams missed the second half the 2020 season. Now he's low on the depth chart with DeVante Parker, Jaylen Waddle, and Will Fuller in Miami.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: It's hard to see a path to fantasy relevance for Williams in Miami. He's a restricted free agent in 2022.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Josh Reynolds
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Reynolds was an interesting late-round gamble this year as the Titans took a one-year flier on him in free agency. He's a big target (6'3) that could haul in some looks as the WR3 this year with Jonnu Smith and Corey Davis gone. With Julio Jones now in the mix, any talk of him being a sleeper probably is put to rest.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s a one-year flier in hopes of opportunity in Tennessee. But his window for opportunity shut once the team traded for Julio Jones.

notes.text: Despite missing one full game and a large portion of another, Johnson finished with 144 targets in 2020, which ranked sixth among wide receivers. Unfortunately, he was not particularly efficient with them, averaging just 6.4 yards per target. Part of his issues were drops, but Ben Roethlisberger's drop-down mentality certainly didn't help, either. Still, chasing targets at wide receiver is never a bad thing. If Johnson would've averaged just 7.4 yards per target (easily attainable), he would've finished as the WR14. He should be a safe high-floor WR2 with upside for top-12 numbers.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Diontae Johnson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Find someone who loves you the way Ben Roethlisberger loves targeting Diontae Johnson. In Johnson’s 2020 breakout campaign, he dominated targets for Pittsburgh. In games where Johnson played and didn’t leave early due to injury, he saw 10+ targets in 10 of 13 games excelling as a PPR monster. With the team seemingly wanting to establish the run more in 2021, Johnson will likely need to improve upon his efficiency and find the end zone more often if he’s looking to take a step forward in his third year in the NFL.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Johnson has now proven that he can produce with subpar QB play, as he was Pittsburgh’s most productive WR two years ago with Mason Rudolph under center (yikes!) and has put up big numbers with a declining Big Ben. Still less than 25 years old, Johnson’s ceiling is massive if he finds himself with a more established QB over the next one to two years.

notes.text: When drafting a player like Mattison, it's not going to make you feel all warm and fuzzy inside. He's a handcuff, plain and simple. As long as Dalvin Cook is on the field, Mattison isn't going to get more than 10 touches in a game. However, if Cook were to miss time, Mattison is a potential league winner. If you have the space on your bench for someone like Mattison, he's much better than a bye-week-filler-type player.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Alexander Mattison
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Man… if Alexander Mattison ever got the opportunity, he’d… Ok we say this almost every year and when Dalvin Cook went out, he flopped against Atlanta but showed out in Week 17. He’s a volume-based backup that can be 70 percent of Cook when given the chance. However, he’s lucky to see five or six touches when Cook is in.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Mattison turns 23 and still has two years left on his deal in Minnesota. He’s a must for Dalvin Cook managers although he might never materialize for fantasy.

notes.text: Sanders was the top kicker in fantasy both because he was in an offense that was able to move the ball consistently but not score touchdowns and because he was just flat-out accurate. He was perfect from within 40 yards and on extra-point attempts, went 12-of-14 from 40-49 yards, and 8-of-9 from 50 yards or more. Sanders had never shown that level of accuracy from long range before, so fantasy managers would be wise to view it with a bit of skepticism. Still, with his 2020 performance, it would be difficult to consider drafting him as anything but a top-10 kicker in fantasy.

Mack is going to be a tough one to project in 2021, as he's returning from an Achilles injury, which used to be a career killer. It still might be, and it's not like Mack was lighting the world on fire before he suffered that injury. Jonathan Taylor is the lead back and Nyheim Hines will cap upside as the receiving back, so Mack is arguably just a second-tier handcuff who also has question marks about his health.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Marlon Mack
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Colts shockingly re-signed Mack to a modest one-year deal after he tore his Achilles in Week 1. He was productive the previous two seasons totaling more than 2,000 rushing yards. He’s more of an annoyance to Jonathan Taylor’s fantasy value than anything and not someone draftable in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Still just 25, he’s playing for his next contract this year.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Teddy Bridgewater
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: He might have a chance to start in Denver but Teddy B did not take advantage of his shot at commanding an NFL offense in Carolina. He’s a low-floor, low-ceiling passer: not exactly inhabitable for fantasy production. Great guy. You’d want him to be a groomsman in your wedding. But not for fantasy.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If your dynasty team needs a “glue guy” to hold things down on your bench, Teddy B is your guy. If your league awards points for that kinda thing...

notes.text: It's rare to see a quarterback who has three wide receivers being drafted inside the top-30 and a running back being drafted as a borderline top-12 option, yet he's not being drafted as a fantasy starter. That's the case with Roethlisberger. He's not going to finish as a top-five quarterback or anything, but Roethlisberger has thrown at least 28 touchdowns in each of the last six seasons he's played more than 12 games. He's a perfectly fine QB2 in Superflex/2QB formats.

The end is near for ol' Big Ben Roethlisberger.  Despite gobs of talent at the wide receiver position,  Ben showed a significant decline last season and the team drafted Najee Harris to re-establish the run.  Roethlisberger was simply far too up and down last season to be relied on in fantasy football.  This will likely be his final season in Pittsburgh.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Ben Roethlisberger
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb:
The Steelers season was a mirage as early success eventually nosedived into a first round exit in the playoffs. Big Ben was pressured on the lowest percentage of his dropbacks in the NFL, but had a league-leading 459 dropbacks of less than 2.5 seconds, which masked an inefficient offensive line. 
 The 17-year veteran is going to give it one last go-around in 2021 but the line still looks like a problem. He can put up monster games so be ready to use him in plus home matchups.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: This looks like the end of Big Ben. If you can squeeze one more season out of him as your team’s QB2, congrats.

notes.text: Claypool may have finished as the WR19 on the season, but his year was littered with lackluster performances. He posted WR3 or better type numbers in just 50 percent of the games last year, which was tied with Jamison Crowder and DeVante Parker for 34th among wide receivers. His four-touchdown game in Week 5 really catapulted his numbers at season's end, as he failed to top 59 yards in 11-of-16 games, making him a touchdown-or-bust option most weeks. With Ben Roethlisberger's arm strength seemingly deteriorating by the day, it's tough to see Claypool having a true breakout season in 2021, as he relies on those high value targets more than JuJu Smith-Schuster and Diontae Johnson do. Claypool is an upside pick for sure, but not one I'd bet heavily on.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chase Claypool
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Here’s the list of rookie WRs over the last decade with 11 total TDs in year one: Mike Evans, Odell Beckham Jr., Tyreek Hill & Chase Claypool. That’s it. It’s an elite list, but is Claypool due for statistical regression? 22% of Claypool’s fantasy points came in Week 5 against Philadelphia when he scored four total TDs. With Diontae Johnson likely to dominate the target share again and Pittsburgh wanting to get back to running the ball, Claypool will have to rely on efficiency to reach his ceiling this year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Well, we thought JuJu Smith-Schuster would be gone from Pittsburgh this year, but he’s back on a one year deal, which could limit Claypool’s volume for one more year. With Big Ben in decline and Pittsburgh without a long-term starter at QB, it’s possible to get max value for Claypool after a massive rookie season. Hang on if you think the talent can eventually win out, even with bad QB play.

notes.text: It's never a good thing for a running back to go from a workhorse role into a timeshare, but in Conner's case, it might be for the best. While operating as Le'Veon Bell's backup, Conner had pep in his step and performed like an RB1 when given the opportunity. But once he took over as the team's No. 1 running back, injuries continually piled up, letting his body know he wasn't capable of being that guy. Many are assuming that Chase Edmonds is the No. 1 running back in this offense, and while I believe that's the case, there's a non-zero percent chance that Conner takes over the Kenyan Drake role from last season that netted 239 carries and 31 targets. There's a reason the Cardinals signed him in free agency, so he will have a role, but the question is "how big?" He might be worth a late-round pick just in case he does get the Drake role (or even 80 percent of it).

Maybe you’ve already placed him on your “do-not-draft” list for 2021. Hold up! As the presumed goal-line back, his cakewalk opening schedule could produce some early TDs for fantasy. The Cardinals face Tennessee, Minnesota and Jacksonville to start the year and all three were in the bottom-10 of rushing yards allowed last year. He’s in RB3 territory on an offense that should give him the opportunity to bang in a few short ones on the ground.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: James Conner
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Conner went from a capable back in the first half of the season to averaging less than 38 rushing yards per game over the final two months. It was a nice ride for Le’Veon Bell‘s replacement but his moment in the light of fantasy glory is over. He’ll battle with Chase Edmonds in a timeshare in Arizona. As the presumed goal-line back, his cakewalk opening schedule could produce some early TDs for fantasy.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: His value evaporated within a year as the wheels fell off. Conner is a one-year desperate play at the RB position and perhaps someone you could trade for if you need depth.

notes.text: After an impressive rookie campaign where he tallied 502 yards and four touchdowns on just 56 targets, Herndon's last two seasons have been... non-existent. Adam Gase didn't make Herndon a priority in the offense, but he's gone, which can give us room for optimism. This is a brand-new offense and one that should reset your thinking on what Herndon is/isn't.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Chris Herndon
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Bahahaha… that laughter you hear is more of an indictment on the way the Jets have utilized the TE position for a better part of the last decade. He had the opportunity with a porous group of Jets pass catchers and yet he never took advantage of it. With Corey Davis and Elijah Moore now in the mix, you might get an occasional TD. But more than likely, you will be gifted with the Chris Herndon special: a big fat goose egg in your starting lineup.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: If you had the stones to hold onto Herndon over the last couple of years, congrats. He might be physically on your roster but figuratively speaking, he’s non-existent. We can all laugh about this together in a couple of years. Right?

notes.text: The exit of Darren Fells should've made Akins a potential breakout tight end, and while I suppose he still is, it's a lot tougher when you have a quarterback who's never thrown for more than 20 touchdowns in a season. You need the targets for Akins to be considered an option, because on top of Tyrod Taylor's struggles, Akins himself has scored just three touchdowns on 129 career targets, which is well below the league average for tight ends. There were four games last year where Akins saw six-plus targets in Tim Kelly's offense, but that didn't amount to much, as he never topped 10.9 half-PPR points in a game, and that was with Deshaun Watson under center.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jordan Akins
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The third-round pick from 2018 is now the seasoned veteran in the Texans tight end room.  A physically gifted pass catcher, Akins could make an occasional impact in an offense desperate for pass-catching talent.  The quarterback room doesn’t give you a lot to be excited about, but Akins will lead the tight ends in receiving was on pace for 50-500 last season in Houston.  Heading into his fourth season, he’s a desperate streaming play if times get tough.

notes.text: Based on the targets Engram received and where they took place on the field, he scored 41.4 fewer fantasy points than he was expected to, which ranked as the second-worst mark among tight ends. In fact, he was supposed to finish as the TE5 based on his opportunity. It's no surprise the Giants felt the need to go out and add playmakers this offseason. On top of adding Kenny Golladay, Kyle Rudolph, and Kadarius Toney, they'll also get Saquon Barkley back, which will surely cut into Engram's target share. He's no longer an every-week starter in fantasy.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Evan Engram
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: He finished as the TE16 but it might as well have felt like TE96. Engram never surpassed 14 fantasy points in any game and his allure as a PPR threat seems to be over. Kenny Golladay and Kyle Rudolph will likely take away some red zone looks and he no longer can live off of any promises of volume in this offense. Engram is probably going to finish near TE15 but that won’t help you win a championship.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: The dropoff has been steep since 2017 when he submitted the best rookie TE season in PPR scoring in almost 30 years. The dream of a young, athletic PPR machine is dead but he can still hop on with a new team as he’ll be playing for his next contract entering 2021 as a 26-year-old.

notes.text: Henry has never been an elite tight end in my eyes. He's always been someone who benefitted from a lot of volume in an offense with not a whole lot of options to throw to. Based on the opportunity he had last year and where it took place on the field, Henry scored 18.7 fewer fantasy points than he was expected to, which ranked as the fourth-worst number in football. He's now the No. 2 tight end on a Patriots team that figures to have Cam Newton under center for at least the first few games. Henry is nothing more than a streamer in 2021, and to be honest, I don't anticipate there being many weeks to use him without an injury ahead of him on the depth chart.

As if trusting a tight end wasn't difficult enough, try trusting two of them.  Henry arrives in New England to share snaps with Jonnu Smith, as the Patriots try to re-establish their offense in 2021.  While he'll always provide touchdown upside, it's hard to see Henry approaching the 93 targets he had last season on the way to a TE #13 season.  Stay away and resist any hype regarding Henry in New England.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Hunter Henry
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It's hard trying to spin a narrative where Henry is a difference-making TE in 2021 and beyond in New England. Drafting feels like you're admitting defeat but the reality is he's going to end up in the TE10-15 range which doesn't help your fantasy team.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Managers were probably waiting for this off-season for Henry to cash in free agency and elevate his dynasty stock. Instead, his presence alongside Jonnu Smith in New England is basically the worst-case scenario. You can’t really trade him for good value and starting him is a gamble. We send condolences to you and your dynasty squad.

notes.text: It's odd to say, but Anderson was somewhat of a Jarvis Landry-type fantasy asset last year. He finished with more than 15.5 half PPR points just twice, but he also scored fewer than 8.0 half PPR points just four times, offering a level of consistency we hadn't seen out of him. It's because they used him in the possession-style role with a shorter average depth of target than he was getting with the Jets. The Panthers lost Curtis Samuel in free agency, but gained Terrace Marshall in the draft, and will get Christian McCaffrey back from injury, so the loss of Samuel doesn't do a whole lot for projections. D.J. Moore started coming on more as the year went on, though the switch to Sam Darnold could prove to be a good thing for Anderson, who was Darnold's teammate with the Jets. It's still the same offense, and Anderson proved he's able to contribute in a big way, making him somewhat of a safe WR3/4 option with WR2 upside should Darnold favor him as the top option.

Robby A is reunited with Sam Darnold so perhaps everyone in your league is down on his 2021 prospects. Anderson saw a ton of volume last year with 136 targets, the 10th most in the NFL. However, he drastically underperformed based on expectation metrics leaving a lot of fantasy “meat on the bone”. Buy the dip! Ok but for real he’s a value right now on an offense that will be bent on throwing the ball. He’s a top-36 receiver in our book.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Robby Anderson
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: As D.J. Moore garnered most of the fantasy hype entering 2020, Robby Anderson ended up being a massive value late in drafts...at least to start the year. Anderson had 99+ yards in 4 of the first 5 weeks then saw his fantasy production fall off a cliff. In fact, Anderson’s tied Mike Evans' 2015 for 4th worst fantasy season with 1,100 receiving yards since 2000. He reunites with Sam Darnold, but will that make him a more consistent fantasy producer in his 2nd season in Carolina? While WR Curtis Samuel is off to Washington, CMC will be back and obviously commands targets.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Anderson finds himself in a contract year, as he’ll be a 29 year old unrestricted free agent after the 2021 season. He’ll likely push for one more multi-year contract and will rely on rekindling an old relationship with Sam Darnold to make it happen.

notes.text: We're now 46 games into Mahomes' career as a starter, and in those games he's totaled QB1-type numbers in 69.6 percent of them. There are just two other quarterbacks who've posted those over 59.5 percent of their career since 2000, and one was Justin Herbert who has just a 15-game sample size. When Mahomes is on the field, he's producing. The question is this: By drafting him in the early rounds, which running back or wide receiver are you passing on to get him, and is the dropoff more from the quarterback you'd get in the later rounds? If you wanted to draft Mahomes in the third round, you can, but know you're going to need to hit on a player or two later in your draft to make up the ground.

Mahomes suffered a significant turf toe injury in the NFL Playoffs and limped his way into the Super Bowl before having surgery to repair the torn ligaments at the base of his left big toe. In high level athletes that undergo this surgery, the average return to play timeline ranges between 14.5 to 24 weeks. Given that Mahomes had surgery on February 10, fantasy managers can expect Mahomes to be 100% in Week 1.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Patrick Mahomes
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: It felt like Mahomes almost fell under the radar this year in fantasy but he was still off the charts. He tied Aaron Rodgers for lowest INT rate (1.0 %) and led the league with 316 passing yards per game. Since 2018, Mahomes has been a top-12 fantasy QB in 34 out of 45 starts, an insane 75 percent! His Super Bowl defeat might stain the minds of many but for fantasy, he’s still a clear QB1. 40+ passing TDs seems almost like a safe line at this point.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Mahomes is the universal QB1 in dynasty drafts. If you’re lucky enough to have him on your roster, he’s rock solid for the next decade. Doesn't appear to carry the same injury risk as the more run heavy QBs.

notes.text: Once the Giants decided to move on from Golden Tate, it got me excited for Shepard, who was slated to move into the slot, an area he had a lot of success in earlier in his career. When the Giants signed Kenny Golladay in free agency, it surely lowered the target ceiling for Shepard, but again, he was going to be the starting slot receiver. After that, they went and drafted Kadarius Toney in the first round, a receiver who's essentially slot-only. Will he start over Shepard right away? Will they move Shepard opposite Golladay and send Darius Slayton to the bench? We don't know those answers right now, but there's certainly less appeal with Shepard now that all these new faces are around.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Sterling Shepard
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: With Kenny Golladay now leading this team’s WR room, Sterling Shepard can now move back into the slot, which is where he plays his best football. Shepard may be a solid bench WR for your fantasy team, especially in PPR who you can plug and play during bye weeks, but we haven’t seen Daniel Jones support multiple high end fantasy WRs in his career (or anything close to it).
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Shockingly, Shepard is already 28 years old and while he’s technically on the roster through 2023, there’s an out in his contract after the 2021 season. Did the team draft Kadarius Toney to be his replacement?

notes.text: Boswell missed a few games in 2020, but convered 19 of his 20 field-goal attempts on the year, adding to his reputation as one of the more accurate kickers in the game. The issue for Boswell from a fantasy perspective, however, is that playing his home games on Heinz Field's difficult turf, as well as just his natural skill set, generally limits his attempts from 50 yards or beyond. Indeed, he's attempted just four field goals from that range in the last three seasons. Boswell is your classic high-floor, low-ceiling play, who is better utilized as a weekly streamer when you're favored to win.

If you watched Mooney last year, you would've seen him routinely get open, only to be underthrown and overthrown by his quarterbacks. No matter who is under center for the Bears (it'll be Justin Fields before long), they'll be an upgrade for Mooney, who finished with 98 targets his rookie season, meaning he took over Taylor Gabriel's role and then some. With Anthony Miller now gone, it's likely we see Mooney with a similar, if not bigger role in 2021. He's not likely to see a consistently high target share with Allen Robinson on the field, but with his field-stretching ability, he doesn't need double-digit targets to make a splash in fantasy. He'll be worth even more when Fields takes the starting job.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Darnell Mooney
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The Moon Man! As a rookie, Mooney was an Air-Yards fiend totalling 23 deep targets (11th most in NFL) as well as elusive tying for the 4th-most missed tackles (17) among WRs. He’s an intriguing 2nd year player who saw 98 targets last year with the speed skillset to get some big plays over-the-top. Between Andy Dalton and Justin Fields, his QB situation is a bit up in the air but it’s not crazy to envision him ending up as a weekly FLEX in 2021 if things break right.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: With the addition of Justin Fields and that gorgeous deep ball at his command, Mooney’s dynasty prospects are rising. He’s only 23 years old and under contract for three more years. If he enters the conversation as a WR3 by the end of this year, you’re likely dancing for joy as a dynasty manager.

notes.text: Murray was extremely good to fantasy managers last year, delivering QB1-type performances 68.8 percent of the time, which was the third-best mark in the league. He wasn't just barely hitting those numbers, either, as he tallied 26-plus fantasy points on eight separate occasions, tied for the most in the league. The Cardinals added A.J. Green and Rondale Moore, while losing Kenyan Drake. This suggests there's going to be more dropbacks, which in turn means more fantasy points. Murray is an every-week starter and worthy of a top-five quarterback selection in the 4th/5th round.

Kyler Murray was fantasy’s QB1 through the first 10 weeks of the season, averaging 67.1 rushing yards per game in that time frame. Then, he sprained his AC joint in Week 11, and from Weeks 11-15, he averaged just 27.4 rush yards per game, significantly limiting his fantasy ceiling. It makes perfect sense, as an AC joint injury will be directly affected by direct contact to the top of the shoulder. However, moderate AC joint sprains heal well with enough time, and they do not affect an athlete the following season. Draft Kyler with confidence.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kyler Murray
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Kyler was hyped by many in the fantasy community to take the next step as a dual-threat fantasy monster and he delivered. Before Josh Allen wrestled away the title at the end, Murray held the QB1 spot from Weeks 1 to 16. He formed a dynamite combo with DeAndre Hopkins bucking the negative trend of WRs changing teams in the offseason. He’s now the only QB in league history to throw for 3,500 passing yards and run for 800+ yards in the same season. His floor is high and if Kliff Kingsbury figures out how to be a bit more creative and push the ball downfield, Murray has a chance to reclaim the QB1 throne in 2021.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Murray trails only Cam Newton for the 2nd most total offensive yards (passing + rushing) ever through a QB’s first two seasons. He has among the highest floors in dynasty.

notes.text: I was really hoping Gallman would get an opportunity somewhere after flashing his ability in 2020 where he talled double-digit PPR points in seven straight games after taking over for Saquon Barkley and Devonta Freeman. Unfortunately, he landed on a depth chart that's now crowded with Raheem Mostert, Trey Sermon, Jeff Wilson, and Elijah Mitchell. The injury to Wilson that'll keep him out at the start of the season likely holds a roster spot for Gallman, but he still likely needs another injury to be relevant.

You won't find a bigger Kamara fan than me, and that's going back to his college days. However, with the way Sean Payton rotates his running backs, it's going to be mighty hard for Kamara to live up to his draft cost now that Drew Brees is gone. Brees targeted his running backs at least 28 percent of the time in each of the last four years. Meanwhile, Jameis Winston hasn't targeted running backs more than 18 percent of the time in each of his last four seasons as a starter. The offense is also not nearly as likely to be scoring as many points without Brees. Upon finding out that Michael Thomas will miss time to start the season, it only makes Kamara more valuable, as he could be in line for eight-plus targets per game during that time.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Alvin Kamara
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Fantasy’s RB1 in 2020 was an unstoppable force and single-handedly won people fantasy championships with a Week 16 to remember: 54.7 fantasy pts on the back of SIX rushing TDs. Super Kamario is an elite pass-catcher, playmaker, and the model of consistency with his season reception totals: 81, 81, 81, 83. Treat him like the fantasy difference-maker that he is. The big concern in 2021 is the Saints offense without Drew Brees and with Taysom Hill / Jameis Winston. It’s likely they find a way to get Kamara the touches he deserves.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Kamara will turn 26 before the season but we still have him ranked as a top-5 dynasty RB. He’s insanely efficient: since 1970, he’s averaging the most yards per touch (6.18) of any RB through their 1st four years in the NFL. You still probably have 2-3 more years of production.

notes.text: Over the final nine games of 2019, Zac Taylor gave Mixon 214 touches (23.8 per game), which made us believe they'd finally realized he should be used in a workhorse fashion. The start of 2020 wasn't as generous, but he did average 19.7 touches per game over the first three weeks. Then we saw Giovani Bernard get knocked out of the lineup for a few weeks, and it led to Mixon totaling 27.0 touches per game over the next three weeks before getting hurt. Now that Bernard is gone, are we finally going to get a full season's worth of 20-plus touch games for Mixon? If so, top-five is in the realm of possibilities, especially knowing he'll be more involved in the passing game. Don't sleep on Mixon; he's still a top-10 running back talent-wise.

No matter your past fantasy outlooks for Mixon, it’s hard to bet against his situation this year. With Giovani Bernard being waived, Samaje Perine is now the No. 2 RB for Cincinnati and Mixon’s biggest competition for snaps. The Bengals have the weapons to be a high-flying offense and Mixon has the opportunity to be a true 3-down running back.

Joe Mixon suffered a foot sprain in Week 6 that forced him to miss the rest of the season. Initial reports suggested Mixon could return within a few weeks, but these injuries tend to be unpredictable in season, and it’s not uncommon for an athlete to battle pain and swelling for several weeks as we saw with Mixon. Fortunately, his injury didn’t require surgery, suggesting the injury was stable. This bodes well for Mixon given that about 80% of players coming off a stable mid-foot sprain play more games in the following season.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Joe Mixon
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: When Mixon is on the field, he gets work. He averaged 24 opportunities per game but the bad news is, he played in only six games. Yikes. In fact, fantasy managers were left holding the bag waiting for his return which never materialized. With Giovani Bernard out the door, he should be able to continue seeing the type of touches that return RB1 status. It remains to be seen if the offensive line is improved but Andy and Jason would give you a wholehearted thumbs up on Mixon’s 2021 outlook.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Still only 24 years old, Mixon is set up to remain a top-10 dynasty RB if he can shake the injury bug. The offense has the pieces in place and he can handle a giant workload.

notes.text: McManus' overall numbers last year were pretty much in line with his career marks. He converted 82.4% of his field-goal attempts (81.6% career) and 24 of his 27 extra-point attempts. But the Broncos were willing to trust him from long range, which included 15 field-goal attempts from at least 50 yards, of which he converted 10. Playing in Denver's thin air, McManus is always a threat to convert from long range, so he should be considered a borderline startable option in standard-sized leagues.

It was pretty much an abysmal season for Elliott in every way possible last year. He attempted just 19 field goals and had the lowest conversion rate for field-goal and extra-point attempts in his four-year career. The Eagles' offense was terrible last year, so you should expect Elliott's volume to regress to his career levels as the team plays better in 2021, which should mean about 33% more field-goal and extra-point attempts. But given his accuracy issues last year, there's no reason to draft him right now in fantasy.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Benny Snell Jr.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Snell started the year out with 113 rushing yards against the Giants on Monday night football and that basically was his lone highlight of the season. James Conner returned from injury and Snell was relegated to seeing seven or fewer touches over the next three months. With Najee Harris now on the scene, Snell is a forgotten man for fantasy.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Bye bye Benny. You are best left on the banks of the shore as this dynasty ship must sail on.

notes.text: Despite Nick Chubb getting hurt and missing 4.5 games, Hunt failed to meet expectations in 2020. Sure, he finished as a top-10 running back at season's end, but if you were to ask his managers, they'd tell you he was a flex-type option. He finished as an RB2 or better in just 56.3 percent of games in PPR formats, which was slightly behind Miles Sanders and slightly ahead of Ronald Jones. His value was arguably better with Chubb on the field last year, so maybe it's a matter of keeping him fresh? Whatever the case, Hunt should be a strong RB3/flex option who has 20-touch upside should Chubb miss time.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Kareem Hunt
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Hunt was somewhat frustrating last year despite finishing as the RB10. In the four games, Nick Chubb was out, Hunt never really seized the opportunity averaging only 12 more total yards per game. We also saw his receiving work dip to just 37 receptions. Nevertheless, his consistency and skillset on a run-first team is still valuable for fantasy. He’s a borderline RB2 this year.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Hunt turns 26 before the season but doesn’t have nearly the same wear and tear of a player his age. He’s worth putting a trade offer or two out there considering Nick Chubb will be an unrestricted free agent in 2022. (Kareem Hunt will be a free agent as well).

notes.text: I'm not sure I'm seeing the allure that some do to Williams as a handcuff in Detroit. Williams isn't a bad running back by any means, but it's more about the offense and their want to use a timeshare at running back. It's the same reason D'Andre Swift is falling into middling RB2 range of drafts - it's not because of his talent. Even if Swift were to miss time, the Lions would likely bring in another running back to share the workload. They already brought Todd Gurley in for a visit, so they clearly haven't taken their minds off adding another running back. Not just that, but it's also likely to be a low-scoring offense, which just doesn't give you a lot of upside/potential.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Jamaal Williams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Drafted before Aaron Jones in the 2017 draft, Williams is a solid if unspectacular backup who will not be needed in Green Bay especially with the emergence of A.J. Dillon. He's a capable pass blocker so expect him to be annoying for D'Andre Swift managers.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He’s a depth piece albeit on a terrible real life NFL team.

notes.text: There was some real excitement surrounding Firkser a few months ago, but then Julio Jones was acquired, bringing that enthusiasm down a level. Still, there's no competition for targets among the tight ends, and with Arthur Smith out of town, it's very likely the Titans throw the ball more in 2021. The issue with thinking Firkser could be a breakout tight end is due to the fact that he's just 6-foot-2 and 246 pounds, which is not very big for a tight end, and it's shown in the red zone, as he's scored just three career touchdowns on 97 targets. There's going to be streaming opportunities when the Titans are playing in a projected shootout, but he's not someone you want to rely on week-in and week-out.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Anthony Firkser
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Did you know he went to Harvard? We jokingly referred to Firkser as the Titans' TE1 last year as he saw more targets, receptions, and receiving yards after Week 5 than former teammate Jonnu Smith. Firkser currently has the position all to himself with a ton of vacated targets in the offense. He’s another of the late-round TEs that you can spin a narrative where he ends up being fantasy-relevant although with Julio Jones being added to the mix, he doesn't really have a ceiling.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: He's not a special talent and could be a product of being in the right place at the right time. But nine times of ten those situations don't turn into the next Gary Barnidge. Trading him based on opportunity makes sense if he’s a luxury sitting on your bench.

notes.text: From a real-life perspective, Myers had a fantastic season. He was perfect on his field-goal attempts, and converted the longest attempt in the NFL at 61 yards. The problem for fantasy purposes is that the Seahawks again ranked near the bottom of field-goal attempts at 24, meaning Myers' excellence was somewhat wasted. Even so, he still finished as th No. 10 quarterback in fantasy, and he should continue to be a reliable option. If Seattle can manage to attempt more field-goal attempts than the 26 they have averaged over the last two seasons, Myers could be an elite option.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Samaje Perine
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: The “Painbot” is a no-nonsense between the tackles runner who exploded in championship week with 27.6 fantasy points taking advantage of Joe Mixon being on the sidelines. He re-signed with Cincinnati in the offseason and with Giovani Bernard gone, he’s the clear backup.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Perine was once a first round dynasty pick in Washington. He’s bounced around the league but with Mixon’s injury history, it’s not a bad idea to keep him as insurance.

notes.text: It's kind of crazy how fall Williams falls in drafts considering the offense he plays in. Should anything happen to Clyde Edwards-Helaire, Williams would step into a 15-touch role and be an every-week starter. He has very little until that happens, but that can be said about many handcuffs available. If you play in a league that has eight bench spots, Williams should have a spot at the end of it.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: Darrel Williams
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: Darrel won out in the battle of Williamses as he was given a 2nd rounder tender and Damien is now in Chicago. He’s been a trustworthy backup for Andy Reid although it needs to be noted he only saw 39 carries last year. Clyde Edwards-Helaire is going to be the main guy here.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Williams is 26 years old and under contract for one more year in Kansas City. As long as Patrick Mahomes is attached to your name, you definitely can have fantasy value.

notes.text: Though it was better than his 2019 season, there were plenty of ups and downs from Smith-Schuster in 2020. Part of the reason for inconsistency is due to Ben Roethlisberger's volatile performance, but even if he rights the ship in 2021, the bigger part of the problem for Smith-Schuster is the competition he has for targets. Chase Claypool will be entering his sophomore season, Diontae Johnson seemed to figure out his drops as the year went on, and they added Najee Harris and Pat Freiermuth in the first two rounds of the draft. Suddenly, Smith-Schuster might be third in line for targets in this offense. He'll probably finish as a WR3, but I just don't see the upside to drafting him as anything more than a low-end WR3.

ffBallersPlayerProjection.name: JuJu Smith-Schuster
ffBallersPlayerProjection.blurb: JuJu Smith-Schuster’s WR18 season in 2020 felt...well, dirty. Why? Despite catching nine TD passes last year, JuJu went over the 100-yard mark exactly the same number of times as you, the reader. Aka, zero. He was the ultimate volume monster averaging a measly 8.6 yards per reception, good for 126th (Yikes!) in the NFL. If Ben doesn’t start pushing the ball down the field, JuJu’s upside is severely limited.
ffBallersPlayerProjection.dynastyBlurb: Remarkably, JuJu Smith-Schuster is still just 24 years old, but he’s an enigma in dynasty. Through four seasons, he’s tied with Randy Moss for the 4th most receptions by a WR before turning 25, yet his future has never been more uncertain as he’s playing on a one-year deal with Pittsburgh.
